item.title: Polar Prince to work on UK wind farms
item.description: Aberdeen-based offshore installation group Subocean confirmed a hire deal for the Polar Prince construction ship which is to work on the new Greater Gabbard wind farm being developed off the UK's east coast Subocean says it is spending £30 m. to hire the construction ship for a two-year charter with options for a further three years, starting in July this year. Once on hire, the vessel will allow Subocean to work on the 140 wind turbine Greater Gabbard project, off the UK coast in Suffolk where it will operate complete with survey and ROV equipment spreads.

item.title: Dong proceeds with Walney II
item.description: Denmark's DONG Energy said it is going to go ahead and build another UK offshore wind farm after learning of further financial support offered to the renewable energy industry in the government's Budget announcement.

item.title: Winds of change blow for offshore power operators
item.description:
It's official: it's getting windier down south. This unexpected quirk of climate change has given a much needed boost to offshore wind-farm developers.
For those struggling to make the economics of hugely expensive wind farms work, more wind equals more money.
Experts said that the waters off the coast of East Anglia and Essex could host many more wind farms as a result

item.title: E.ON increases earnings in difficult environment
item.description: E.ON posts significantly higher earnings, demonstrating strength in the current economic crisis. In a very difficult environment, E.ON increased its 2008 adjusted EBIT by 7,3 percent to ?9.9 billion. This result is in line with the forecast E.ON issued in the spring of 2007 before the economic crisis began. Sales were up 26 percent to ?86.8 billion. Adjusted net income, the earnings figure E.ON uses to determine its dividend, rose by 9 percent to ?5.6 billion. Management will propose raising the dividend to ?1.50 per registered share, resulting in a payout ratio of just over 50 percent.

item.title: London Array consortium welcomes Government move to increase support for offshore wind
item.description: The companies behind London Array, the world?s largest offshore wind farm, have welcomed the UK Government?s proposal to increase its incentives to build offshore wind farms

item.title: Darling powers up clean energy
item.description:
Extra subsidies will secure the future of key projects such as offshore wind farms.
The firms behind the world?s largest wind farm, the London Array, are poised to approve the long-delayed project after Alistair Darling announced an aid package for the industry.

item.title: Vattenfall To Acquire Utility Company Nuon
item.description: Energy company Vattenfall (VATN.UL), in a move to become the Europe's numero uno offshore wind power entity, stated that it will acquire utility company Nuon for 10.3 billion euros or $13.3 billion. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the second quarter of 2009, subject to the approval of at least 80% of Nuon's shareholders.

item.title: npower To Start Turbine Construction At Rhyl Flats Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: npower renewables (npower) said that offshore installation works are to resume at the site of Rhyl Flats Offshore Wind Farm next week. Construction of the first of 25 wind turbines will begin on April 1, 2009 when the jack-up barge Lisa-A2 will be loaded with components at the Port of Mostyn, from where it will sail to the wind farm site. It is anticipated that the erection of the first turbine will be completed about a week later.

item.title: Siemens Energy Wins Contract From EnBW For Supply Of 21 Wind Turbines For Baltic 1 Wind Farm
item.description: Siemens Energy has received an order from EnBW Energie Baden-Wurttemberg AG (EnBW) for the supply of 21 SWT 2.3-93 wind turbines for the Baltic 1 offshore wind farm. Baltic 1 will be located about 16 kilometers north of the Darss/Zingst peninsula and will cover an area of about seven square kilometers. Maritime civil engineering work will commence in early 2010. The wind farm with a total capacity of 48.3 megawatts (MW) is scheduled to come on line in the last quarter of 2010.

item.title: China Updates On Offshore Wind Farm Construction At Shanghai East China Sea Bridge
item.description: China's offshore wind farm is ongoing construction near the Shanghai East China Sea Bridge, the China Business News reported. The new wind farm is comprised of 34 wind-driven generators, each with a capability of 3,000 kilowatt (kW). The constriction cost of the wind farm is CNY2.4 billion ($351 million) and has an installed capacity of 100,000 kW. The wind farm will provide sufficient electricity to power 200,000 homes.

item.title: RWE Innogy to resume work at Rhyl Flats offshore wind farm
item.description: RWE Innogy has announced that it will resume the offshore installation works at its Rhyl Flats offshore wind farm.

item.title: Siemens to supply wind turbines to Sheringham Shoal offshore wind farm
item.description: German engineering firm Siemens Energy has received an order from StatoilHydro and Statkraft to provide 88 wind turbines to the Sheringham Shoal offshore wind farm off the east coast of the UK

item.title: Areva to supply 80 wind turbines to Wetfeet Offshore
item.description: French power engineering major Areva, through its subsidiary Multibrid, has executed a binding memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Wetfeet Offshore Windenergy, to supply 80 M5000 turbines for the offshore 400MW Global Tech-1 wind farm

item.title: Delsea Energy files request to build wind farm offshore New Jersey
item.description: Delsea Energy has filed initial permit applications with the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and the US Army Corps of Engineers to build a utility scale wind farm project offshore New Jersey

item.title: REpower Systems AG: 6M is the world's most powerful wind energy turbine
item.description: In addition to the REpower 5M currently in series production, the third-largest German wind turbine manufacturer now has the most powerful wind turbine in the world in its portfolio with the further development of the model series to the REpower 6M: At the Hanover Trade Fair, REpower Systems AG (WKN 617 703) is demonstrating its offshore turbine REpower 6M with a new guaranteed rated electrical power of 6,150 kilowatts (kW). In the framework of the leading international trade fair "Wind", the company shows its technology at the world's most important industry exhibition.

item.title: REpower and RWE Innogy agree major framework agreement for the offshore wind industry
item.description: REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703) and RWE Innogy GmbH today signed a framework agreement on the supply of 250 REpower 5M/6M offshore wind energy units. With a potential volume of approx. EUR 2 billion, this framework agreement represents one of the largest contracts in the history of wind industry and is at the same time the largest agreement ever in the area of offshore wind energy use.

item.title: REpower Systems AG announces financial figures for first nine months of fiscal year 2008/09 (01.04.2008 ? 31.12.2008)
item.description: In the first nine months of fiscal year 2008/09 REpower Systems AG (WKN 617 703) realised a total performance figure of EUR 842.9 million compared to EUR 552.7 million in the same period of the previous year. Sales increased year-on-year from EUR 582.5 million to EUR 850.5 million. Earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) for the period from April to December 2008 stood at EUR 38.1 million compared to EUR 27.9 million in the previous year. Net profit increased from EUR 21.1 million as per end of December 2007 to now EUR 26.1 million.

item.title: Fluor and Airtricity form new consortium for Round 3 of UK Wind farm programme
item.description: Fluor Limited, the UK operating arm of Fluor Corporation has formed Seagreen Wind Energy Limited with Airtricity, the renewable energy division of Scottish and Southern Energy. Seagreen Wind Energy has bid for the exclusive rights to develop wind farms under The Crown Estate?s Round 3 Offshore Wind Farm Development Programme (Round 3).

item.title: Wind of change set for Lowestoft
item.description:
A WIND of change is all set to blow through the port of Lowestoft.
For the port will become the operations centre for the Greater Gabbard Offshore Windfarm which, when completed, will be the world's largest offshore wind farm.
The turbines will be located 15 miles off the Suffolk coast, and Lowestoft's Outer Harbour is being used to house the necessary operational support facilities.

item.title: Europe's green energy vision puts UK in dark
item.description: It is a dazzling vision of a clean energy future. An entire continent powered by solar panels, wind and wave turbines, geothermal and hydroelectric power stations ? and all stitched together by a European ?supergrid? stretching from the sunbaked deserts of the south to the windswept North Sea, from the volcanoes of Iceland to the lakes of Finland.

item.title: Horns Rev 2 offshore wind farm ready to start delivering power
item.description: The transmission station which connects Denmark's new offshore wind farm Horns Rev 2 with the terrestrial grid, is now ready to start supplying clean, green electricity from the North sea

item.title: Carbon Trust in £20 Million hunt for offshore turbine foundations
item.description:
Competition seeks sturdier foundations for wind turbines to withstand the harsh conditions in the deep ocean that hold vast potential for producing electricity.
The UK's Carbon Trust announced a £20 million prize to encourage engineers across the globe to help commercialize sturdier and cheaper foundations for offshore wind farms.
In addition to the Carbon Trust, the competition is also being funded by five wind energy developers: Denmark's Dong Energy, Ireland-based Airtricity, Germany's RWE nPower, Scotland's ScottishPower Renewables, and StatoilHydro in Norway.

item.title: Help for wind farms and strict carbon targets
item.description:
Faltering plans for Britain to become a leader in green energy received a boost with measures to aid investment in renewables and a binding target to reduce carbon emissions by more than a third over the coming decade.
Claiming that an economic recovery must be ?sustainable and protect the environment?, Alistair Darling announced that up to £4.5 billion of extra funding ? the bulk of it from the European Investment Bank ? would be made available to help to build offshore wind parks. Many of these schemes have stalled because of their cost, the credit crunch and the weakening of sterling.

item.title: Government knocks the wind out of renewables
item.description: Two breaking stories neatly illustrate the flawed logic which still lurks at the heart of UK energy policy. First up is that German energy utility RWE's bid to build a new nuclear plant near Kirksanton in Cumbria will mean dismantling an existing wind farm on the site. While at the other end of the country, 600 workers at the Vestas Blades wind turbine factory on the Isle of Wight could be facing redundancy.

item.title: Siemens to expand position as green infrastructure giant
item.description:
Siemens intends to rigorously expand its world-leading position as a supplier of ecofriendly products and solutions.
The move to a green economy is a huge opportunity for us,? said Siemens President and CEO Peter Löscher at the company?s Semiannual Press Conference in Berlin. In his speech, Löscher referred to the statements of German President Horst Köhler who, in his fourth Berlin address, called for an ?environmental, industrial revolution. Technological revolutions have always been our specialty. That's why no one is better equipped to lead the green revolution than Siemens. As a green infrastructure giant, the company is a reliable, long-term partner worldwide due to its experience, technological expertise and solid financial position, added Löscher. The technologies in Siemens? Environmental Portfolio already generate sales of roughly 19 billion, accounting for about one-quarter of the company's total revenue.

item.title: Layoffs Blow Through The Largest Wind Maker, Vestas
item.description: When the CEO of the world?s No. 1 turbine maker, Vestas, said earlier this year that the global downturn was slashing demand for its products, it seemed like only a matter of time before the company would respond with cuts. The rest of the wind industry hasn?t been shy about layoffs. Well, here it is: Vestas is cutting 1,900 jobs ? 9 percent of its work force ? largely in the UK (closing a turbine plant on the Isle of Wight) and Denmark.

item.title: Share capital increase of DKK 18,500,000 new shares will be completed
item.description: Vestas Wind Systems A/S (?the Company?) is pleased to announce that the share capital increase with nominal value DKK 18,500,000 representing 18,500,000 shares, which was announced earlier today has been fully subscribed for and finalised in connection with a private placement carried out through an accelerated book building process. Please refer to company announcement No. 10/2009 of 28 April 2009.

item.title: Interim financial report, first quarter 2009
item.description: Vestas generated first-quarter revenue of EUR 1,105m, an increase of 58 per cent, achieving an EBIT improvement of 124 per cent to EUR 76m and lifting the EBIT margin from 4.9 per cent to 6.9 per cent. Net working capital stood at 8 per cent of expected annual revenue, against 2 per cent in Q1 2008. The increase was significantly attributable to larger inventories. The order backlog of firm and unconditional orders amounted to EUR 4.9bn at 31 March 2009. Full-year expectations for 2009 are still for an EBIT margin of 11-13 per cent on revenue of EUR 7.2bn. At the end of the first quarter of 2009, Vestas? total undrawn financial facilities amounted to EUR 850m. Vestas continues to expand its operations in the USA and China owing to the positive market prospects. Capacity will be reduced in Northern Europe, as demand in this area at the moment does not meet expectations. Consequently, Vestas expects to lay off approx 1,900 employees in the production units in Northern Europe, primarily in Denmark and England. As a result of these measures, expected investments in property, plant and equipment and intangible assets are reduced by EUR 200m to EUR 1.0bn. The British Government?s commitment of 21 April 2009 regarding massive investments in wind power and higher tariffs, will have a positive influence on Vestas? possibilities of producing blades in Great Britain.

item.title: Green Growth:Korea's New Strategy - Wind energy offers a new growth engine
item.description: The following is the 37th in a series of articles focusing on the Korean government's "green growth" strategy. The series will also introduce the increasing efforts of major advanced countries of the world to promote a green economy.

item.title: Britain's only wind turbine plant to close
item.description: Vestas is to shut down its Isle of Wight factory in the face of collapsing demand from a wind-farming industry hobbled by the recession and red tape

item.title: Winds of change blow for offshore power operators
item.description: Based on information taken from Nasa satellite images, the research found that average annual wind speed in the southern part of the North Sea had increased from about 7.5 metres per second in 1990 to 8.5 metres in 2008. In contrast, wind speeds in the northern part of the North Sea, off the coast of Scotland, have remained constant during this period.

item.title: Germany Nets $8.5 Billion In Revenues From Wind Energy Plants In 2008: BWE Reports
item.description: According German Wind Energy Association (BWE), revenues from wind energy plants and their components built in Germany increased in 2008 by around 12% relative to 2007, from 7.6 billion to 8.5 billion. The export business alone brought in 82% of those proceeds. Global energy demand will continue to increase and thus also demand for efficient and environmentally sound energy technologies. Globally, wind energy plants with a capacity of over 27,000 megawatts were newly installed in 2008

item.title: Green energy gaining favor with investors
item.description: Many ways to invest in rapidly growing industry Revenue from solar, wind power, ethanol and biodiesel fuel grew 50 percent to about $116 billion last year, according to Clean Edge Inc., a research and publishing firm. The spike in green revenue, and the backing of the federal government to explore these energy sources, has excited investors.

item.title: Nordex Opens U.S. Headquarters In Chicago
item.description: Germany-based Nordex USA Inc., a manufacturer of wind turbines, has opened its new North American headquarters in Chicago

item.title: Work Under Way on Gunfleet Sands Wind Farm
item.description: The first turbines were installed last month at DONG Energy?s Gunfleet Sands Offshore Wind Farm project in the Thames Estuary off the East coast of England.

item.title: Investments in knowledge economy show steep decline
item.description:
INVESTMENTS AND other equity transactions in the knowledge economy collapsed in the first quarter of this year, according to new research.
The Who42 Equity Funding Quarterly shows the value of all transactions in Ireland?s know-ledge economy during the first three months was ?51.1 million, down over ?140 million on the last quarter of 2008.

item.title: Renewable energy firm wants Scottish base
item.description: Swedish state-owned utility Vattenfall Wind Power is hoping to set up UK headquarters in Edinburgh and increase workforce

item.title: Renewables chief Ormiston joins Vattenfall
item.description:
GREEN energy trade body Scottish Renewables is searching for a chief executive after current boss Jason Ormiston was poached to join Swedish energy firm Vattenfall.
Ormiston, chief executive since October 2007, will leave at the end of June to take up his new post as communications manager of Vattenfall's wind business in the UK.

item.title: Norfolk Green Party Fight For Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: Norfolk County Council green party members were not happy this week when Norfolk?s planning and highways committee registered an objection to the 620MW Race Bank wind farm off the North Norfolk coast, 27 km from Blakeney Point, England.

item.title: Scottish Power Challenges EON's Fixed Tariff Dominance
item.description: Scottish Power has released a new capped tariff which is set to rival EON's competitive Fixed Online energy tariff

item.title: UK to tender offshore wind farm grid connections in June
item.description: UK energy regulator Ofgem is to launch the process for the first of two tender rounds for electricity transmission links from offshore wind farms to shore in June

item.title: Wind farm rejected by councillors
item.description: Councillors have rejected plans to build a wind farm in Oxfordshire after residents voiced fears about how it would spoil the view.

item.title: Business Study - US Wind Power
item.description: The U.S. has reclaimed its position atop the global wind power market. It installed 8,558 MW in 2008, which enabled the U.S. to pass Germany as the leader in installed wind power capacity. This achievement follows several years of unprecedented growth that has yielded a total capacity of over 25 GW in the U.S.

item.title: Energy Commissioner Andris Piebalgs welcomes the agreement of the three Baltic States on the route of the electricity interconnection project between them and Sweden
item.description: Energy Commissioner, Andris Piebalgs, welcomed the agreement signed today between the Prime Ministers of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to start without delay, the implementation of a Baltic-Swedish electricity link.

item.title: 'Smart Turbine Blades' To Improve Wind Power
item.description: Researchers have developed a technique that uses sensors and computational software to constantly monitor forces exerted on wind turbine blades, a step toward improving efficiency by adjusting for rapidly changing wind conditions.

item.title: Controllable Rubber Trailing Edge Flap To Reduce Loads On Wind Turbine Blades
item.description: The trailing edge of wind turbine blades can be manufactured in an elastic material that makes it possible to control the shape of the trailing edge. This will reduce the considerably dynamic loads that large wind turbine blades are exposed to during operation.

item.title: Robot Inspects Wind Energy Converters
item.description: The material of wind energy converters must withstand intense forces. Are rotor blades damaged? A new robot inspects wind energy converters more precisely than a human ever could. It detects the minutest damage ? even below the surface.

item.title: Denmark?s largest offshore wind farm ready for tender
item.description: The Danish Energy Agency is now publishing the tender for the Anholt Offshore Wind Farm in Kattegat west of the island of Anholt. All interested companies are invited to bid on the 400 MW offshore wind farm, which will be the biggest offshore wind farm in Denmark. The offshore wind farm shall be connected to the Danish electrical grid by 2012.

item.title: Getting wind of the future's energy needs
item.description:
China has set a target for renewable energy consumption of 40 percent of the market by the year 2050.
The news comes as it emerges that China will have 100 GW of wind power capacity by 2020, more than three times the 30 GW the government set as a target 18 months ago.
It's also been revealed that China will become the biggest growth market for wind power generating capacity this year, ahead of the United States, which has been worse-hit by the economic downturn, according to the Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC).

item.title: U.S. to clear way for offshore wind farms
item.description: The Interior Department has finalized sweeping rules that clear the way for the first offshore wind turbines to be erected along the Atlantic Coast, the most aggressive move yet from an administration that hopes to shift the nation's offshore

item.title: Massachusets energy board votes to approve Cape Wind - composite certificate
item.description: In a unanimous vote, the Massachusetts Energy Facilities Siting Board (Siting Board), the agency created by the Legislature to ensure the siting of needed and least environmental impact energy facilities, voted yesterday to grant Cape Wind a Certificate of Environmental Impact and Public Interest (Certificate) that effectively rolls up all nine state and local permits related to the electric cables into one - composite certificate -.

item.title: Environmental group stands behind Cape Wind
item.description: Cape Cod's preeminent environmental group has come out in favor of the proposed Nantucket Sound wind farm.

item.title: Constant in turbulent times: wpd gets an A-rating again
item.description: Euler Hermes Rating GmbH (a member of Allianz Group) again rates wpd AGs reliability and sustainability with the rating notation -A- in 2008. The company is thus rated as strongly above average in comparison to the total economy. We are pleased with the renewed strong rating on the part of the rating company. Especially in view of the current turbulences in the financial markets, this is a confirmation of the work of all the wpd team, Dr. Gernot Blanke, member of the Board of Directors, comments.

item.title: BIW explores future in wind power
item.description: Building ships will remain its core business, but the company sees opportunity in ocean energy projects.

item.title: Finding Space for All in Our Crowded Seas
item.description: The ocean is getting crowded: Fishermen are competing with offshore wind projects, oil rigs along with sand miners, recreational boaters, liquefied gas tankers and fish farmers. So a growing number of groups -- including policymakers, academics, activists and industry officials -- now say it's time to divvy up space in the sea.

item.title: Lake Erie turbines costly but feasible
item.description:
Energy researchers say the winds blowing across Lake Erie can power wind turbines, but the project won't be cheap.A study released Friday showed it will cost $77 million to $92 million to build several turbines and a nearby wind research center to be run by Case Western Reserve University. Earlier estimates had put the price tag at about $60 million.
The world's first freshwater turbines would stand some 260 feet above the water level and produce up to five megawatts of power each - enough to power up to 5,000 homes. Visible from downtown Cleveland, they would be built 3 to 5 miles offshore.

item.title: Biden coming to UD campus on Monday
item.description:
Vice President Joe Biden will visit his alma mater Monday afternoon to discuss offshore windpower.
He will be joined at the University of Delaware's Newark campus by U.S. Energy Secretary Ken Salazar, who has been championing offshore projects that include the Bluewater Wind proposal for the Delaware coast.

item.title: Statkraft and StatoilHydro to develop major offshore wind farm
item.description: StatoilHydro and Norwegian power utility Statkraft join forces to develop the 315 MW Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm off the coast of Norfolk in the UK.

item.title: Eon calls for global CO2 auctioning
item.description: German utility Eon hopes the climate talks in Copenhagen in December will bring the world closer to establishing a global carbon trading system featuring the gradual introduction of auctioning, it said on Monday.

item.title: RWE Innogy taking a share in Belgian offshore wind farm
item.description: RWE Innogy acquires 20.22 percent of the shares of the Belgian developer and operator of offshore wind farms, C-Power NV, Zwijndrecht. The shares are sold by the Belgian investment companies Ecotech and Socofe, both located in Liège. RWE Innogy also acquires 6.5 percent of C-Power from other shareholders (EDF Energies Nouvelles, Nutsbedrijven Houdstermaatschappij and DEME)

item.title: Massachusetts legislators urge Cape Wind approval
item.description: A majority of the members of the Massachusetts Legislature, 107 in total, representing Democrats and Republicans in the House and Senate, including 28 Committee Chairmen, have signed onto a letter to Interior Secretary Ken Salazar urging him to approve the Cape Wind offshore wind farm project - as soon as possible.

item.title: Study suggests offshore winds are getting stronger
item.description: The UK's offshore wind industry has received a further boost with the release of new data suggesting that wind speeds in the southern part of the North Sea are increasing.

item.title: US: Investors see bright future in wind energy
item.description: DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) - When President Barack Obama stood in front of wind turbine towers in a Newton, Iowa, factory last week he was not only pushing his green energy policies but promoting an industry that has been growing rapidly and gaining favor with investors.

item.title: GE Energy?s 1.5-Megawatt Wind Turbine Maintains Top Spot in U.S. Wind Industry
item.description: GE Energy?s 1.5-megawatt (MW) wind turbine, which continues to hold its position as the best selling wind turbine in the United States, is being showcased at Windpower 2009. According to a recent report from the American Wind Energy Association, GE 1.5-MW wind turbines accounted for 43% of all new wind power capacity in the United States in 2008, the sixth straight year that GE technology has led the industry in annual installed capacity.

item.title: Lectra Showcases Latest Innovations for Industrial Fabrics at the WINDPOWER 2009 Show The Company Presents Its Complete, Integrated Offering Dedicated to the Processing of Industrial Fabrics for the Manufacturing of Wind Turbine Blades
item.description: Lectra, the world leader in integrated technology solutions dedicated to industries using soft materials -- textiles, leather, industrial fabrics, and composite materials -- showcases its complete and integrated suite of solutions dedicated to the manufacturing of industrial fabrics for the wind energy industry at the WINDPOWER 2009 Show.

item.title: Production Plant in China
item.description: The local wind turbine manufacturer Fuhrländer proves even more international commitment by having its own production line and sales office in China and by offering training and licences there.

item.title: Siemens to build wind turbine production facility in the U.S.
item.description: Siemens intends to build a new production facility for wind turbines in the state of Kansas. Initially, 400 new jobs are expected to be created in the new wind turbine production facility in Hutchinson, Kansas. When production begins at this facility, Siemens will be able to even more effectively meet the strong demand for wind turbine equipment in North and South America in the future.

item.title: Vestas Makes Colorado a Clean-Energy Hub
item.description: Vestas, the Denmark-based wind turbine manufacturer, is helping Colorado Governor Bill Ritter get a little closer to realizing his vision of establishing the state as a hub of the -New Energy Economy -.

item.title: Statoil's world first floating wind turbine nears testing
item.description: StatoilHydros world first Hywind technology project - that aims to make high wind offshore projects more cost effective and competitive in relation to coastal wind farms - is fast nearing testing mode, StatoilHydro spokesman Øistein Johannessen told Offshore.no in an interview.

item.title: GE Energy Joins Forces with WSI, a Member of the Weather Channel Companies, to Launch Forecasting Technology for Wind Farms
item.description: GE Energy and WSI Corporation, the global leader in weather information and a member of The Weather Channel Companies, are joining forces to launch more accurate forecasting tools for wind farm owner/operators and transmission/distribution providers

item.title: China drafting support plan for renewable energy industry
item.description: The Chinese government is working on a support plan for the renewable energy industry aimed at raising the country's wind power capacity to 100-150 million KWh by 2020, sources close to the plan making said on Tuesday

item.title: Siemens In US Wind Turbine Production Plan
item.description: Siemens intends to build a new production facility for wind turbines in the state of Kansas.

item.title: E.ON, EDF Said to Consider Swap of Power-Generating Capacity
item.description: E.ON AG, Germanys largest utility, is in talks to swap power generating capacity with Electricite de France SA as part of a deal in which it would gain full control of its French unit, three people familiar with the matter said.

item.title: Offshore Solutions wins prestigious OTC Woelfel Award
item.description: Offshore Solutions B.V., the joint venture between AMEC and GTI N.V. is celebrating after winning the Offshore Technology Conference 2009 Woelfel Best Mechanical Engineering Achievement Award (BMEA) for the design and operation of its Offshore Access System (OAS).

item.title: Salazar: US should lead in offshore wind power
item.description: U.S. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar says the United States can lead the world in offshore wind energy production and should have significant offshore development within four years

item.title: RWE to Acquire 27% in Belgian Wind Farm Developer
item.description: RWE Innogy acquires 20.22 percent of the shares of the Belgian developer and operator of offshore wind farms, C-Power NV, Zwijndrecht. The shares are sold by the Belgian investment companies Ecotech and Socofe, both located in Liège. RWE Innogy also acquires 6.5 percent of C-Power from other shareholders

item.title: Firm with Dundee link pays off 150
item.description: About 150 employees of Aberdeen-based Oceanteam Power & Umbilical were made redundant yesterday after the firms Norwegian holding company parent, Oceanteam, withdrew financial support.

item.title: Wind Energy Leaders Pore Over Challenges, Opportunities
item.description: Wind energy leaders revealed how much the industry will rely on government incentives and standards to maintain its breakneck growth, during a May 6 press conference at Wind Power 2009

item.title: E.ON replaces SOURCE fund with Sustainable Energy Fund
item.description: Energy company E.ON has replaced its SOURCE fund with the Sustainable Energy Fund, which is open for applications from community groups across the UK which are seeking funding for sustainable improvement energy projects.

item.title: New wind turbine blade technology created
item.description:
Purdue University and Sandia National Laboratory scientists say they have developed a technology designed to improve the efficiency of wind turbine blades.
The researchers said the technology uses sensors and computational software to constantly monitor forces exerted on wind turbine blades.

item.title: GE Drivetrain Technologies Launches Generator and Control System Division, Expanding Wind Industry Portfolio
item.description: GE Drivetrain Technologies, a unit of GE Transportation, announced today that the Company has launched a wind generator and control systems division to serve its wind turbine customers around the globe.

item.title: EU agrees billions to upgrade energy grid
item.description: Europes energy networks will receive a 4 billion euro (3.5 billion pounds) upgrade to make them more robust and flexible in future energy crises following a vote in the European Union assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: DOI to Open Four Renewable Energy Permitting Offices and Create Renewable Energy Teams
item.description: To expedite production of renewable energy on public lands while protecting land, water, and wildlife, Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar pledged to create four Renewable Energy Coordination Offices, one each in California, Nevada, Wyoming, and Arizona, along with smaller renewable energy teams in New Mexico, Idaho, Utah, Colorado and Oregon. Salazar made these remarks at the American Wind Energy Association's WINDPOWER 2009 Conference in Chicago.

item.title: Renewable spending to stay: E.ON
item.description: European energy giant E.ON has pledged to maintain its commitments to investing in renewable and other energy projects despite the economic downturn.

item.title: Huge windfarm vision for Aberdeen
item.description: The largest windfarm in Europe, which generates enough electricity to power 60,000 homes, has been hailed as a vision for the future in Aberdeen

item.title: Bluewater Wind - currently funded, fully operational -
item.description: On May 4, at the University of Delaware, Bluewater Wind President Peter Mandelstam applauded the strong demonstration of support for offshore wind energy expressed by national and state political leaders.

item.title: Denmark Invites Bidders to Build 400-Megawatt Offshore Windfarm
item.description: Energy companies are preparing to go head-to-head in the coming months as Denmark has announced that it is now inviting tenders to build one of Europe's largest offshore windfarms. The Danish Energy Association has invited tenders for a 400-megawatt (MW) offshore windfarm off the west coast of Denmark's Anholt Island. The windfarm will not only be the largest in Denmark but also one of the largest in Europe. The windfarm is expected to be completed and connected to the Danish national grid by 2012 and will provide enough power for 400,000 homes.

item.title: First Phase of Haida Offshore Windfarm Awaits Selection of Bidders by BC Hydro
item.description: NaiKun Wind Energy Group Incorporated (TSXV:NKW) (Vancouver, British Columbia) and ENMAX Corporation, a subsidiary of the city of Calgary, Alberta, are awaiting the BC Hydro and Power Authoritys (Vancouver) selection of applicants to participate in the Clean Power Call. Successful bidders are anticipated to be announced in June or July. NaiKuns first phase of the Haida Energy Offshore Windfarm consists of 110 wind turbine/generators for 396 megawatts (MW) in the Hecate Strait near Prince Rupert, British Columbia, by mid-2014.

item.title: Siemens Puts Medium-Voltage Switchgear Specially Designed For Wind Turbines On The Market
item.description: Siemens Energy has developed the new gas-insulated medium-voltage switchgear NX Plus C Wind. The gas insulated switchgear deployed by Siemens to date for wind turbines operated at a voltage of 24 kilovolts (kV). The new NX Plus C Wind switchgear operates at a voltage of 36 kV. It is also of a more compact design than the previously built 36-kV Siemens switchgear and can be readily accommodated in the tower of a wind turbine.

item.title: 100 more turbines for Solway Firth
item.description: PLANS are being made for a new Solway Firth wind farm which would cover an area almost twice the size of the Robin Rigg offshore turbines site.

item.title: Lewes campus eyes wind turbine
item.description:
Wind power could soon be coming to the Lewes campus of the University of Delaware.
The university awaits a feasibility study on the project, said Ron Ohrel, director of marine public education for the College of Marine and Earth Studies and Sea Grant College Program. He said the report, expected soon, will determine the size and location of the windmill and the next steps for the project.

item.title: Mitsubishi Heavy Targeting US Wind Farm Boom
item.description: A major Japanese industrial machinery maker has set it sights on the rapidly expanding wind power sector in the U.S., aiming to grab a chunk of the business.

item.title: Wind power industry fights drag
item.description:
A nagging issue wound its way through the chatter at what was an otherwise celebratory event for the nation's wind industry in Chicago.
The U.S. has become the world's biggest generator of wind power. Of the electricity production added in the country last year, 42 percent came from wind turbines. But as more megawatts come on line, the problem of getting power from wind-swept plains to places where people actually live becomes more urgent.

item.title: Mayor Daley welcomes Nordex USA, Inc. to Chicago: German Wind Turbine Manufacturer Establishes New North American Headquarters Here
item.description: Mayor Richard M. Daley today welcomed Nordex USA, Inc. to Chicago as the German manufacturer of wind turbines opened its new North American Headquarters at 300 S. Wacker Dr.

item.title: WWF and Statkraft form renewables partnership
item.description: WWF Norway and Norwegian energy utility Statkraft are to join forces to promote the development of renewable energy.

item.title: Wind power outgrowing grid
item.description: The U.S. has become the worlds biggest wind-power generator and of the electricity production added in the country last year, 42 percent came from wind turbines. But as more megawatts come on line, the problem of getting power from wind-swept plains to places where people actually live becomes more urgent.

item.title: Innovative Reactive Power Compensation System for Wind Farms, Power Grids and Industry
item.description: Siemens Energy is expanding its product spectrum of Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS) with its new reactive power compensation system SVC Plus (Static Var Compensator).

item.title: Centrica Interim Management Statement
item.description: Centrica has performed well in the year to date, due mainly to the combination of cold weather which increased demand for gas and power in the UK and North America and falling wholesale commodity prices, caused by consistent supply and weak demand from large industrial users

item.title: High production and solid operations (Regulatory release)
item.description: StatoilHydros (OSE:STL, NYSE:STO) first quarter 2009 net operating income was NOK 35.5 billion, compared to NOK 51.4 billion in the first quarter of 2008. The quarterly result was negatively affected by a 41% drop in oil prices, partly offset by a 23% increase in the average price of natural gas and a 7% increase in lifted volumes of oil and gas

item.title: GE Tries to Exclude Mitsubishi Heavys Wind Turbines From U.S.
item.description: General Electric Co., the biggest maker of wind turbines in the U.S., wants a trade agency to block Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. from importing rival energy equipment to the U.S.

item.title: FOCUS: Windenergy and the Financial Crisis
item.description: The wind power industry has not been able to escape the effects of the global financial crisis. Most major companies,both manufacturers and project developers, have downgraded their expectations for growth in the coming year. Some have even been forced to lay off staff. But the underlying prognosis is that the wind market will continue to expand at an impressive rate, consolidating its position as the most dynamic global renewable energy source.

item.title: José Manuel Entrecanales confirms ACCIONAs commitment to renewable energies in the U.S.
item.description: ACCION s Chairman & CEO voices his support for the Obama Administrations Renewable Energy Initiatives, at the AWEA’s Windpower 2009 Conference and Exhibition, in Chicago.

item.title: INTERVIEW: - RWE, Eon deliberately held back capacity -
item.description: A member of Germanys Green party has filed criminal charges - made public last week - against energy companies Eon and RWE as he alleges they deliberately held back capacity to drive up electricity prices.

item.title: London Array consortium welcomes Government move to increase support for offshore wind
item.description: DONG Energy, E.ON and Masdar, which make up the joint venture, were reacting to the Governments energy proposals. The Government proposes to increase the number of Renewable Obligation Certificates (ROCs) available for offshore wind generation. Recognising the contribution offshore wind will make to reducing the UKs carbon emissions, the Government proposal was to issue two ROCs for every megawatt hour of offshore power produced, doubling the original incentive.

item.title: Quonset to consider Deepwater leases for wind farm staging area
item.description: Deepwater Wind LLC’s proposal to build an offshore wind farm off Rhode Island has taken another step forward with the signing of a letter of intent to lease 117 acres in the Quonset Business Park to use as a staging area for the $1.5-billion project.

item.title: Rhode Island offshore wind farm proponents relieved
item.description: President Obamas Earth Day announcement of new rules to regulate the offshore wind-power industry was hailed yesterday as a major development that will allow Rhode Island to move forward as a national leader in developing its own offshore wind-power projects.

item.title: OceanWind opens UK office
item.description: OceanWind, the Norwegian offshore wind energy company, today opened an office in Bristol, England.

item.title: DONG Energy, E.ON and Masdar give green light to build worlds largest offshore wind farm
item.description: DONG Energy, E.ON and Masdar have today announced that they will invest €2.2bn in building the first 630MW phase of the London Array offshore wind farm in the Thames Estuary.

item.title: Siemens opens European headquarters for wind energy in Hamburg
item.description: Siemens is greatly expanding its wind power activities in Germany and Europe. As part of this expansion, Siemens has now established its European headquarters for wind power sales and project execution in Hamburg. At the same time, the Bremen location is being upgraded to European headquarters in the service business. The new headquarters in Hamburg is starting up operations with about 40 employees. As a result, employees with functions in sales and project execution have relocated to Hamburg from Brande in Denmark and, in some cases, from Bremen. In the medium term, about 70 jobs are expected to be created at Siemens Wind Powers new Hamburg location.

item.title: New contract boost for South Shields shipyard
item.description:
SHIPYARD which was facing the prospect of axing workers has won a multi-million-pound order.
South Shields-based McNulty Offshore has signed a deal to build part of the worlds biggest offshore windfarm.

item.title: China, UK Agree To Develop Cooperation In Energy Sector
item.description: China and UK have decided to develop cooperation in energy sector, especially in nuclear, ocean, wind power and renewable energy, Zhu Guangyao, Chinas assistant financial minister said. Zhu said that China and UK have signed a memorandum of understanding about cooperation in development of sustainable cities, and will select Chinas Wuhan and Chongqing, among other cities, as pilots.

item.title: Outdated electrical grid needs to be smarter
item.description: For the first time in seven decades, a U.S. president has drawn attention to the need for investment in the electrical grid: this time in expanding and modernizing an established grid. Franklin Roosevelt, as part of a larger effort to address the Great Depression, dramatically increased public spending, investing in electrification of rural areas. Now decades later, President Barack Obama has assumed office in the midst of another dismal economy. The federal government is providing billions of public dollars, including a $4.5 billion investment in the transmission grid. Utilities across the country had invested $200 billion in generation of electricity over the past decade, while only about $40 billion in new transmission. These investment levels were seriously out of balance even before the current emphasis on developing renewable sources of generation such as wind power.

item.title: CTC Marine gets first offshore wind contract
item.description: CTC Marine Projects, a member of the Trico Marine Group, has been awarded its first contract in the offshore wind farm industry by E.ON Climate and Renewables UK. The contract is for the lay, installation and burial of 17 subsea power cable arrays linking wind turbine foundations at the Robin Rigg Offshore Wind Farm in the Solway Firth

item.title: CLIPPER WINDPOWER PLC (CLIPPER) RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED IN 31 DECEMEBER 2008 WILL BE ANNOUNCED ON 15 MAY 2009 AT 7AM (LONDON TIME)
item.description:
Clippers management will host a conference call for analysts and shareholders later on the same day at 9am (London time). Dial in details of the conference call are as follows:
Participant Telephone Numbers: +44 (0)20 7806 1956 UK Local +1 718 354 1389 USA Local
Please quote conference code: 8096624

item.title: Siemens exec outlines plans for Kan. plant
item.description: An executive of German conglomerate Siemens AG says the company wants its future wind turbine assembly plant in Kansas to be a showcase for wind energy.

item.title: ACCIONA reports Q1/09 net profit of 149 million euros
item.description:
The company trimmed its 17.897 billion euro debt down to 5.37 billion euros at year-end 2008, and increased investment by 20.4%, to 387 million euros.
Revenues came to 1.395 billion euros, 10.7% down on last year figure, as energy prices fell by 38%.

item.title: Poland on the cusp of an energy revolution
item.description: Poland is on the cusp of an energy revolution in Europe. More wind power was installed in the EU in 2008 than any other electricity-generating technology, according to figures released in February by the European Wind Energy Association. And among those countries involved in a third wave of harnessing wind capacity on the continent, Poland is developing its sector the most intensively.

item.title: Substation platform
item.description: Siemens Energy has awarded a major contract to supply the second substation platform for the Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm to McNulty Offshore Construction, based in South Shields, South Tyneside.

item.title: Worlds largest offshore wind farm supplies first power
item.description: DONG Energys offshore wind farm Horns Rev 2 in the North Sea today supplied the first CO2-free power to the Danish national grid

item.title: Vestas pioneers cost-cutting turbine spider crane
item.description: Company claims new crane design could cut some wind farm maintenance costs by 75 per cent

item.title: Offshore Wind Energy Set to Boom in the Next Few Years Finds Frost & Sullivan
item.description: As the onshore market continues to grow in certain regions and move slowly towards saturation in others, offshore wind is expected to form a greater part of the pie from the meagre 2% that it is now. Onshore wind will always occupy a major share of the wind energy market. However, Frost & Sullivan expects offshore wind to grow from an insignificant part of the pie to a more substantial contributor of electricity generated from wind by 2020. According to Frost & Sullivan estimates, installed capacity of offshore wind is expected to grow from 1,276 MW in 2008 to 18,769 MW by 2015.

item.title: Gunfleet Sands wind farm firm goes under
item.description:
THE project to create a wind farm off Clacton has suffered a blow, with the news the company building it has gone into liquidation.
Aberdeen-based Oceanteam, which specialises in offshore construction support vessels and barges, is being wound up.

item.title: RWE Innogy acquires majority stake in Spanish wind farm operator
item.description: RWE Innogy, through its subsidiary company Agrupació Energías Renovables S.A.U. (AERSA), has increased its share of the Spanish wind farm operator Danta de Energías S.A. from 44% to 93.7%. This extends RWE Innogys wind power portfolio in Spain by about 70 megawatts on a quotal basis to an installed capacity of around 400 megawatts.

item.title: DOE Selects 53 New Projects Focused on Wind Energy for up to $8.5 Million
item.description: U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Secretary Steven Chu today announced selection of 53 new wind energy projects for up to $8.5 million in total DOE funding

item.title: DOE pledges $25m for large US turbine blade testing center
item.description: The Energy Department (DOE) will award Massachusetts $25m from the federal economic stimulus law to accelerate development of the first US large wind turbine blade testing center in the Charleston district in Boston harbour.

item.title: Research Report of Chinese Electrical Power Equipment Industry, 2009
item.description: In 2009, the investments in the electric power will total 580 billion Yuan (84.7 billion USD). The new energy constructions, such as the nuclear power and wind power, will be accelerated obviously.

item.title: Wind turbine breakthrough to create 250 jobs
item.description:
An Irish engineering firm is to create 250 jobs after developing unique wind turbines which generate power even in a light breeze, it was revealed today.
The C&F Group, based in Athenry, Co Galway claims the breakthrough technology is a world-first, generating electricity at speeds as low as 1.2 metre a second and powering homes 350 days a year.

item.title: AMSC & Acciona Sign Deal For Low Voltage Ride Solution
item.description: American Superconductor Corporation (AMSC) announced this week that it has received an order worth more than US $10 million from Acciona Energy for its new Dynamic VAR Ride Through (D-VAR RT) solution

item.title: Foreign firms cry foul over China wind power rules
item.description: Chinas drive into wind power has been a boon to the young industry, but foreign turbine makers say China has stacked the odds so firmly against them that its own clean energy goals could be in jeopardy.

item.title: Spain wind power firms want clearer aid rules
item.description:
New wind power subsidy rules in Spain make future planning in the industry difficult, its wind power firms said on Wednesday.
Spain's wind power sector is the world's third-biggest producer and says it is key to meeting EU renewable energy targets by 2020.
The current subsidy scheme is due to expire in 2012, but producers say a new law enacted last week did not specify whether new wind farms will receive aid after 2010, when total generation capacity is expected to reach government targets.

item.title: Global Wind Energy Market Analysis and Forecasts to 2012
item.description: The report provides detailed analysis and forecasts of the wind power industry, analyzing and forecasting key metrics relating to the installed capacities, market structure and regulatory policies that govern the industry. It provides information relating to the important technological, market, and research and development (R and D) trends and analyzes the growth and development of energy derived from wind power on a global basis. Additionally, it analyses the cost –related aspects of the wind technology. It also gives insightful information on the market shares of the leading companies in the key regions. It provides trends and analysis of investments in the wind energy market as well as deal summary and news flow for the last 6 months. On an all, it helps an investor to gauge the market and technological development of the global wind power market.

item.title: Too many turbines, too ugly and not as green as they think
item.description: WEST Cumbrian people whose homes look out on to the Solway Firth have reacted with fury to news that yet more wind turbines are planned there.

item.title: IBERDROLA POSTS €793 MILLION FIRST QUARTER PROFIT
item.description: IBERDROLA recorded a net profit of €793 million in the first quarter of 2009, a fall of 34.2% over the same period last year, due to sharply lower extraordinary gains and declining business in Spain affected by falling demand and lower prices. Ordinary income, excluding gains from asset sales, increased by 0.4%. Diversification by region and by business over recent years enabled the Company to offset lower income in Spain and achieve a 9% rise in Ebitda to €1,952 million. The contribution of ScottishPower, Energy East and IBERDROLA RENOVABLES has been key to sustaining business in a negative economic climate.

item.title: First six farshore wind wind turbines operational at the Thornton Bank as of 10 May 2009
item.description: Filip Martens, Managing Director of C-Power: “We are very glad to be able to announce that after the successful running of all test procedures, the last of the first six wind turbines was started up on 10 May 2009. So far, the start-up procedure has produced almost 8.5 million KWh. During the coming weeks, the production capacity of the wind turbines will be increased to the peak capacity of 5.25 MW per wind turbine”

item.title: SCOTTISHPOWER RENEWABLES ALMOST DOUBLES INSTALLED CAPACITY IN 2008
item.description: ScottishPower Renewables (SPR) released figures today showing that the installed capacity of their green energy projects almost doubled during 2008, from 382MW to 665MW. This means that the company is now able to power over 370,000 homes with clean, green energy produced from renewable sources.

item.title: ScottishPower Renewables and Vattenfall join forces for Round three
item.description:
Two giants of the renewables industry, ScottishPower Renewables and Vattenfall, have entered into partnership to make joint bids in the third round of offshore wind farm development in the UK.
ScottishPower Renewables, part of the world’s largest wind power operator and developer, Iberdrola Renovables, and Vattenfall, the world’s second largest operator of offshore wind, will jointly participate in the third round of tender bids to develop offshore wind power in the UK.

item.title: SCOTTISHPOWER RENEWABLES AWARDED OFFSHORE WIND SITE – ARGYLL ARRAY
item.description: ScottishPower Renewables (SPR) has been awarded the rights to investigate the potential for an offshore windfarm west of Argyll and the island of Tiree, following the Crown Estate’s Scottish Territorial Waters tendering process.

item.title: LM Glasfiber supplies wind turbine blades to Goldwind
item.description: LM Glasfiber will provide wind turbine blades to Chinese wind turbine manufacturer Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology Co Ltd under a large supply agreement, which has lead LM Glasfiber to establish its third wind turbine blade factory in China.

item.title: Clipper Windpower Reports Revenues Of $737.3 Million In 2008
item.description: Clipper Windpower Plc (Clipper Windpower) has reported revenues of $737.3 million for the year-end 2008, compared with the revenues of $23.9 million in the previous year-end. It has also reported a net loss of $313.3 million, or $2.56 loss per share, for the year-end 2008, compared with the net loss of $192.5 million, or $1.79 loss per share, in the previous year-end.

item.title: Wind Industry Leaders Warn Congress That a Weak RES Could Cede Jobs to Asia, Europe
item.description: A group of representatives from major wind industry companies today released a letter to key members of Congress urging them to strengthen the renewable electricity standard (RES) contained in the draft bill unveiled this week by House Energy and Commerce Committee chairman Henry Waxman

item.title: Nordex brings headquarters to Chicago
item.description: NBC Chicago reports that Chicago is the new North American Headquarters for Nordex, a German wind turbine firm. Nordex said its goal is to make 20% of their revenues in the U.S. There are currently 30 workers hired, with plans to expand to 100 in the next three years. Nordex president Ralf Sigrist is eyeing property along the south lake shore as a possible sight for a wind farm.

item.title: Siemens opens European headquarters for wind energy
item.description: Siemens has now established its European headquarters for wind power sales and project execution in Hamburg

item.title: ACCIONA Confirms Commitment to US Renewables
item.description: CHICAGO - ACCIONAs Chairman José Manuel Entrecanales demonstrated the company's commitment to the American wind industry by visiting its annual gathering, AWEA's Windpower 2009 Conference and Exhibition, in Chicago last week.

item.title: Airtricity obtain consent to develop second dutch offshore wind farm
item.description: Airtricity, the renewable energy development division of Scottish and Southern Energy (SSE), has obtained consent from the Dutch Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management for construction of the offshore wind farm ‘Breeveertien II’, located in the Dutch sector of the North Sea. This follows the consent to develop the ‘West Rijn’ wind farm obtained on 15 January 2009

item.title: Airtricity Granted Exclusivity to Develop Four Offshore Scottish Windfarms with capacity up to 2,700mw
item.description: Airtricity, the renewable energy development division of Scottish and Southern Energy plc ("SSE") has been granted exclusivity by The Crown Estate to develop offshore wind farms at four locations in Scottish territorial waters. The locations are Beatrice, Bell Rock, Islay and Kintyre.

item.title: AMEC plc Interim Management Statement
item.description: Year to-date trading in line with expectations Continued strength in demand, led by Natural Resources and Earth and Environmental Further improvement in group EBITA margin continues to be expected in 2009 Group order book £3.4 billion (April 2008: £2.7 billion; December 2008: £3.3 billion) FY 2009 average net cash before acquisitions expected to be c.£670 million

item.title: Frost & Sullivan predict growth in offshore wind market
item.description: Research and consulting firm Frost & Sullivan expects offshore wind in Europe to grow to a more substantial part of the wind energy market, though onshore wind will always occupy the major share. According to Frost & Sullivan estimates, installed capacity of offshore wind is expected to grow from 1,276 MW in 2008 to 18,769 MW by 2015.

item.title: In 2008, Eneco again made good progress with sustainability strategy
item.description: In 2008, Eneco again made good progress with the continuation of its sustainability strategy. Its three segments (energy company Eneco, infrastructure company Joulz and network company Stedin), each having its own mission, contribute to substantiating the leading principles of the sustainability strategy: sustainable, decentralised and together with customers and partners. Greenpeace elected Eneco to be the cleanest energy company in 2008.

item.title: Prediction Of Waves, Wakes and Offshore Wind
item.description: In most wind farms, the layout of the turbines is evaluated to quantify the power loss due to wind turbine wakes. As wind farms increase in size it has become evident that wake losses in large offshore wind farms are under-predicted (sometimes known as the deep array effect). Hence there are a number of research projects underway to evaluate the cause of these discrepancies and to operationalise new models or modify existing models. A major issue is that wind farm data are confidential and that to date relatively few operators have been willing to allow access in order that models can be evaluated/improved. A further issue is that the comparison of data with models is not straightforward.

item.title: Cleantech Companies Will Stimulate Recovery
item.description: Many indicators show that clean techs may lead any potential worldwide economic recovery. For example, since 2005 many of the leaders in turbine manufacturing have opened U.S. facilities; of the top 10 global suppliers in 2007, seven — Vestas Wind Systems (VWDRY.PK), GE (GE) , Gamesa (GCTAF.PK), Suzlon Energy, Siemens (SI), Acciona (ACXIF.PK), and Nordex (NRDXF.PK) — have an American manufacturing presence. (The other three — Enercon, Goldwind, and Sinovel — do not yet sell into the U.S. market.) In addition, the homegrown Clipper Windpower (CRPWF.PK) has joined GE Energy as a major domestic player in the production of utility-scale turbines, with the two companies together capturing 50% of the 2008 domestic market.

item.title: Aeronautica Wind Power eyeing Quonset for turbine plant
item.description:
A Plymouth, Mass., “green” energy company is considering building a facility in Rhode Island to manufacture wind turbines.
Aeronautica Wind Power has twice visited the state-owned Quonset Business Park, in North Kingstown, to look at a 40,000-square-foot space for a proposed plant, according to Steven J. King, managing director of the Quonset Development Corporation.

item.title: ARGYLL AND BUTE RAISES RENEWABLES PROFILE IN EUROPE
item.description: Argyll and Bute is rapidly becoming the hot topic in Europe’s renewable energy sector, according to the area’s development chief.

item.title: ‘We just flat out don’t have it’: Lack of land sidelined Wichita’s pursuit of Siemens project
item.description: The Siemens Corp. says it never seriously looked at the Wichita metro area when it was deciding where to place the plant, which will employ 400 people in an industrial park in Hutchinson. The German company had been looking for a location in the heart of the country that could reduce shipping costs for its 90-ton nacelles, the structures that house the gearbox, drive train and control electronics on wind turbines. That product is manufactured in Europe.

item.title: McNulty Offshore Wins Order From Siemens Energy
item.description: McNulty Offshore Construction Ltd (McNulty Offshore) has won a order from Siemens Energy to supply a second sub-station platform for a offshore wind farm project. McNulty Offshore will create a second sub-station, called Galloper, for the Greater Gabbard development. The offshore sub-station will be housed within the main platform, 16 miles off the Suffolk coast, connected to an offshore sub-station at Sizewell.

item.title: GE Aims to Provide Energy Storage for Trains, Power Grid
item.description: General Electric (GE) announced that it will build a factory and development center in Niskayuna, N.Y. that will serve as the hub for its new battery business, and one of first products to come out of there will be sodium batteries. CEO Jeff Immelt and New York Gov. David Patterson were on hand for the event.

item.title: Suzlon raises stake in Repower to 76 %
item.description: Indian manufacturer Suzlon Energy Ltd. has completed the payment of € 30 million for the second tranche of Martifer Group’s stake in the German Repower AG on 30th April.

item.title: Siemens Announces Compensation System For Wind Farms, Power Grids And IndustrySiemens Announces Compensation System For Wind Farms, Power Grids And Industry
item.description: Siemens Energy (Siemens) is expanding its product spectrum of Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS) with its new reactive power compensation system SVC Plus (Static Var Compensator). This system operates on the basis of Voltage-Sourced Converter technology (VSC), with continuously variable control through high-power transistors (IGBT). The system allows grid access of fluctuating energy sources, such as offshore wind farms.

item.title: Grid constraints hobble U.S. wind energy
item.description:
A nagging issue wound its way through the chatter at what was an otherwise celebratory event for the nation's wind industry in Chicago last week.
The U.S. has become the world's biggest wind-power generator and of the electricity production added in the country last year, 42 percent came from wind turbines. But as more megawatts come on line, the problem of getting power from wind-swept plains to places where people actually live becomes more urgent.

item.title: Goldwind cuts cost for wind deal with Sinoma
item.description: China-based Goldwind Science and Technology said it cut the value of its wind-blade deal with Sinoma Science and Technology Wind from RMB 650 million ($94 million) to RMB 590 million ($86 million).

item.title: Wind power prediction
item.description: GE Energy and WSI Corporation are joining forces to develop more accurate forecasting tools for wind farm owners and operators, and transmission and distribution providers.

item.title: With the opening of new offices in Paris, Vestas proves its ongoing development in France
item.description: On the day of the opening of the European Wind Energy Conference and Exhibition (EWEC) on 16-19 March 2009 in Marseille, Vestas, the world leader manufacturer of wind solutions, is proud to announce that it has recently opened new offices in Paris, La Défense. The new offices will enable Vestas to be closer to its customers, decision makers and other wind energy actors in France. The establishment of a new office in Paris is a clear sign of the expansion of Vestas in France, it proves the company’s commitment to the development of the wind industry in the country, and it shows the great prospects of the French wind industry, especially in terms of job creation.

item.title: Sale of Vestas Towers factory in Campbeltown, Scotland
item.description: In continuation of Vestas Northern Europe’s local press release No. 7/2008 of 22 December 2008, it is with great pleasure that we can now announce that a positive future for the Campbeltown plant has been secured. As anticipated, the negotiations between Vestas and Skykon have resulted in a sale of the Vestas Towers factory in Campbeltown.

item.title: Vestas celebrates ground-breaking for two manufacturing facilities in Colorado
item.description: Vestas held a ground-breaking ceremony Wednesday for its two new manufacturing facilities – a nacelle assembly factory and blade factory – in Brighton, Colorado.

item.title: Vestas and Boeing to collaborate on technology research projects
item.description: Vestas and Boeing today announced their intent to seek opportunities to work together on joint research projects that further the development of environmentally progressive technologies.

item.title: Annual report 2008 - No. 1 in Modern Energy with wind power at the top of the energy agenda
item.description: Vestas continued its growth in 2008 with the biggest fourth quarter ever – a revenue of EUR 2,481m with an EBIT margin of 15.4 per cent compared to a revenue of EUR 1,884m and an EBIT margin of 12.3 per cent in fourth quarter 2007. Total revenue in 2008 rose to EUR 6,035m from EUR 4,861m in 2007. At the same time, EBIT margin increased to 11.1 per cent from 9.1 per cent the year before From the end of 2007 to the end of 2008, net working capital rose by EUR 367m to EUR 299m equivalent to 5 per cent of revenue. The increase is due to increased stocks and receivables. The latter is due to the large shipments at the end of the year. Cash flow from operations amounted to EUR 277m against EUR 701 in 2007. The growth in Vestas’ underlying profitability is expected to continue in 2009, however, at a lower rate than realised during the last three years.

item.title: Settlement agreement with Enercon GmbH, Mr Aloys Wobben
item.description: In previous company announcements1 Vestas Wind Systems A/S has informed of various patent disputes with Enercon GmbH/Mr Aloys Wobben. In these disputes Mr Aloys Wobben has claimed that Vestas Wind Systems A/S infringes various patents; primarily in the area of grid connection, but also in other technical areas

item.title: DONG Energy and Siemens announce the largest offshore wind turbine supply agreement in history
item.description: Today DONG Energy and the Siemens Energy Sector signed an agreement for the supply of up to 500 offshore wind turbines. The wind turbines to be delivered under the supply agreement have total capacity of up to 1,800 megawatts, and will be deployed on DONG Energy’s coming offshore wind farms in Northern Europe. Permitting procedures and country specific wind regime economics will determine where and when the individual projects will be built.

item.title: Siemens continues to invest in wind energy R&D to reduce investment risks and improve project economics for wind farm owners and operators
item.description: Siemens Energy has entered into a cooperative research and development agreement (CRADA) with Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) to conduct atmospheric modeling research that is expected to help operators and owners operate wind farms more efficiently, while providing more power to power grids. Under the CRADA that will span two years, Livermore will provide high-resolution, numerical weather prediction models to forecast power generated by the wind. Siemens will translate Livermore’s forecasts of wind speed and wind direction at each turbine into power collected.

item.title: REpower celebrates the laying of the foundation stone of its new development centre
item.description: Germany’s third-largest wind turbine manufacturer, REpower Systems AG (Prime Standard, WKN 617703), celebrated today the laying of the foundation stone for a new development and administration centre in Osterrönfeld (district of Rendsburg-Eckernförde). In the presence of the Minister for Science, Economic Affairs and Transport in Schleswig-Holstein, Mr. Werner Marnette, the Mayor of Osterrönfeld, Bernd Sienknecht, and further invited guests, the Executive Board hosted the traditional ceremony on the Kiel Canal site.

item.title: Statkraft – fourth quarter and preliminary financial statements for the 2008 financial year - Best ever year-end result
item.description: Statkraft made a net profit of NOK 33,262 million in 2008 (NOK 6,632 million) , while its underlying net profit came to NOK 8,097 million (NOK 7,030 million). The Group made a net profit in the fourth quarter 2008 of NOK 28,663 million (NOK 2,529 million). The underlying net profit for the quarter came to NOK 2,918 million (NOK 2,986 million).

item.title: Statkraft involved in five new research centres
item.description: Norway’s Petroleum and Energy Minister Terje Riis-Johansen today announced that eight research centres have been named Centres for Environment-Friendly Energy Research (CEER). Statkraft is involved in five of the chosen centres, and has undertaken to provide both funding and expertise. ...Among the research projects that Statkraft is involved in are the development of offshore wind power technology, carbon capture and storage, bioenergy and environment-friendly design.

item.title: Statkraft AS will report first quarter results 2009 on Wednesday 20 May 2009 at 8:00 a.m. CET.
item.description:
Statkraft AS will report first quarter results 2009 on Wednesday 20 May 2009 at 8:00 a.m. CET.
1) Material Quarterly report and PowerPoint presentation will be available at Oslo Stock Exchange, www.newsweb.no, and on Statkraft's Internet pages www.statkraft.com.
2) Conference call in English The conference call starts at 10:00 a.m. CET. A presentation of the first quarter results will be given, followed by a Q&A-session.

item.title: Wind turbine maker Repower sees higher EBIT margin
item.description:
German wind turbine maker Repower (RPWGn.DE) expects to increase its operating margin in 2009/10 despite the growing risk of project postponements, the company said Monday, sending its shares sharply higher.
It said its margin on earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) would increase to 7.5 to 8.5 percent from the 6.3 percent it registered in 2008/09.

item.title: NaiKun Wind Environmental Assessment Accepted
item.description:
Vancouver, British Columbia-based NaiKun Wind Energy Group Inc. has announced that its application for the environmental assessment certificate for its 396 MW offshore wind energy project in Hecate Strait has been accepted for review.
The acceptance of the application by the British Columbia Environmental Assessment Office (EAO) marks the initiation of the formal 180-day review process, which includes a 45-day public comment period.

item.title: Clipper Windpower in $313.3m loss despite 2008 sales surge
item.description: Clipper Windpower, whose 2.5MW Liberty turbine has gained acceptance in the US, made a $313.3m net loss in 2008, compared with $192.5m the previous year, mainly due to costs to repair cracked blades, the company reports.

item.title: Subocean upgrades barges for offshore wind farm work
item.description: Aberdeen-based subsea construction company Subocean Group has invested almost GBP 16 million (US$24.5 million) in cable laying equipment and the re-fit and mobilization of cable-laying barge ATM Discoverer, which is on long term charter to meet demand for services in the offshore wind sector.

item.title: Nordex appointing a new COO Operations- Retirement-related change in the Supervisory Board
item.description: Dr. Marc Sielemann (41) is assuming the position of COO Operations on Nordex AG’s Management Board effective April 1, 2009 and will be responsible for production, sourcing and service.

item.title: Climate change is the biggest global health threat of the 21st century.
item.description:
That is the emphatic conclusion of the world’s leading medical journal in a 40 page report published last week which found that governments must act quickly to reduce carbon emissions and adapt to the affects of global warming on health.
Not only did the report determine that climate change is the biggest threat to global health, it noted that during this century the Earth’s atmosphere is likely to rise more than the two degrees Celsius currently considered to be a manageable increase.

item.title: Ampelmann Company installs wind turbines off the coast of England
item.description: The Ampelmann, a six legged hydraulic platform, plays an important role in the installation of 140 wind turbines of the Greater Gabbard Offshore Wind project off the coast of England. On Friday May 15th the new Ampelmann system will be presented at the RDM Dock in Rotterdam with which the first 42 transition pieces of the wind turbines will be installed this summer. The remaining 78 transition pieces will be installed in the summer of 2010.

item.title: REpower Systems AG exceeds goals for the 2008/09 fiscal year
item.description: In fiscal year 2008/09, the REpower Systems Group (WKN 617703) significantly exceeded the billion limit in terms of sales for the first time and achieved its all-time highest operating result in the history of the company. Totalling 76.9 million EBIT was more than twice as high as in fiscal year 2007 (EUR 28.2 million). Sales increased to EUR 1,209.1 million (Short Fiscal Year 2008: EUR 147.4 million; 2007: EUR 679.8 million), total operating performance rose to EUR 1,220.5 million (short fiscal year 2008: EUR 150.2 million; 2007: EUR 678.2 million). Net earnings (earnings after tax) saw an upswing from EUR 21.1 million by the end of 2007 to EUR 51.9 million (short fiscal year 2008 1.4 million). With an order backlog of 1,317.3 MW, potential sales volume stood at around EUR 1.5 billion as per 31 March 2009. Due to its well-stocked order book and the achieved goals for fiscal year 2008/09, REpower sticks to its forecast for fiscal year 2009/10.

item.title: The next big thing in wind: Slow wind, huge turbines
item.description: With politicians pushing adoption of renewable energy in the United States and Europe, the last few years have seen a surge in plans for wind farms--both on land and sea. But wind power isn't viable everywhere, and prime coastal spots are often already de

item.title: Wind power hopes pick up in Virginia Beach
item.description: From a proposed offshore wind farm with whirling turbines as tall as The Westin in Town Center, to regulations for backyard and rooftop turbines, Virginia Beach is on a wind-to-energy binge.

item.title: Reliable tides should rival UK wind power
item.description:
Cost are falling and catching up with those for offshore wind, Martin Wright, head of Marine Current Turbines Ltd (MCT) said.
"Tidal energy has one huge advantage - that's its predictability" - Wright said. "We will produce renewable energy to a timetable."

item.title: Brussels green lights billions in energy investment
item.description:
The European clean tech sector was celebrating after the European Parliament voted through plans to invest €5bn in new energy infrastructure and broadband development projects as part of the EU's economic recovery plan.
Under the proposals, each of which was passed with a substantial majority, €5bn will be distributed before the end of next year with €3.98bn earmarked for investment in gas and electricity infrastructure, offshore wind parks and carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects.

item.title: Interim financial report Q1 2009 - Vattenfall
Year-end report 2009 - Vattenfall
Norwegian giants catch the wind
item.description: Norwegian state-owned utility Statkraft agreed to buy a 50% stake in a UK offshore wind farm project from Norwegian oil and gas producer StatoilHydro in a Nkr5 billion ($740.5 million) deal.

item.title: Mainstream gets go-ahead for project in Scotland
item.description: Mainstream Renewable Energy, the windfarm company established by former Airtricity boss Eddie O'Connor, has secured permission for a 360MW project in Scotland that is likely to cost in the region of €1.2bn.

item.title: Abu Dhabi has second thoughts about London Array and wind power
item.description: Fresh doubts have emerged over Britain’s plans for a huge expansion of offshore wind power after Abu Dhabi said yesterday that it was reconsidering the viability of a £3 billion scheme to build the world’s largest offshore wind park in the Thames Estuary.

item.title: UFO wind turbine 'broke due to mechanical failure not collision with flying object'
item.description: The £1 million wind turbine destroyed after mysterious glowing orbs were spotted in the sky was not hit by a UFO after all but broke due to mechanical failure, investigators have disclosed

item.title: Floating wind turbine
item.description:
A consortium led by Netherland's-based Blue H Technologies has been selected to take part in a £1.1bn Energy Technology Institute (ETI) initiative to help the UK meet its ambitious renewable energy targets by 2020.
