The Project Deepwater Turbine consortium, which includes BAE Systems, EDF Energy, the Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture, Romax and SLP Energy, will design and assess the feasibility of a 5MW floating wind turbine that is cheaper and more efficient than existing models and able to operate in water depths of 30m to 300m.

item.title: UK Institute Reveals Pledges for $870 Million Investment in Offshore Technologies
item.description:
Waters around the UK could host a 50 billion pounds sterling energy market in wind, wave and tidal power according to the Energy Technologies Institute, as it revealed 600 million pounds sterling of private and public sector funding for research-based projects.
The ETI, based at Loughborough University, has secured commitments from six private sector companies to invest 5 million pounds sterling each per year for the next 10 years, and the UK government has promised to match the private sector total.

item.title: Aberdeen Windfarm in Line for 40 Million Euros of European Funding
item.description:
Plans for Aberdeen’s proposed offshore windfarm received a huge boost today with the news that the European Commission is considering investing 40 million Euros in the project.
A joint venture between AREG (Aberdeen Renewable Energy Group) and Swedish utility company Vattenfall, the Aberdeen windfarm is also working towards gaining demonstrator status from the Crown Estate. This status would propel the project into a new realm in terms of research and development into the latest innovations in technology, skills and manufacturing for offshore wind.

item.title: Wind farm proponent lauds pact
item.description:
The chief operating officer of Deepwater Wind yesterday praised a preliminary agreement between two federal agencies for permitting offshore renewable energy projects.
Chris Wissemann, the founder of a New Jersey-based company proposing a wind farm off the Rhode Island coast, called the agreement reached yesterday between the Department of the Interior and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission “long overdue good news.”

item.title: Thames windfarm execs: We need more subsidy
item.description:
One of the firms participating in the London Array project, under which the world's biggest offshore wind farm would be built in the outer Thames Estuary, has questioned the scheme's economic viability.
The Financial Times reported at the weekend that Paul Golby, chief executive of E.ON UK - which owns 30 per cent of the Array venture - says that "the economics [of the Array] are looking pretty difficult".

item.title: From floating turbines to "washing line" designs, offshore projects get funding boost
item.description: An innovative new wind turbine design that resembles a giant washing line was one of four new technologies to receive development funding yesterday from the recently established Energy Technologies Institute (ETI).

item.title: EDP, Principle Power partner on deep-water offshore wind
item.description: Portuguese utility signs on for floating wind-turbine platforms in an effort to capitalize on the abundant wind resources more than 50 meters off the coast.

item.title: Siemens to provide 175 wind turbines for the world’s largest offshore wind farm London Array
item.description: Siemens Energy will supply 175 SWT-3.6 turbines to the London Array offshore wind project, which is owned by DONG Energy, E.ON and Masdar. Upon completion, the London Array project will be the largest offshore wind farm in the world with a capacity of 630 megawatts (MW). There is also an option to further expand the wind farm up to 1,000 MW in the future.

item.title: AMSC posts first-ever quarterly profit
item.description: Looking forward, the company disclosed a backlog of orders representing approximately $558 million, due primarily to a $450 million, three-year contract for wind turbine core electrical systems the company received from Sinovel Wind Co. in June 2008.

item.title: Vestas selects new President for North American sales and service unit
item.description: Vestas, the world’s leading supplier of wind turbines, has selected Martha Wyrsch as its new President for Vestas Americas, the company’s business unit responsible for wind turbine sales, installation, and service and maintenance United States and Canada.

item.title: US RPS Legislation Weakened in Committee
item.description: Markup on the American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009 is set to begin today in Washington amid critiscism that the legislation and specifically the renewable portfolio standard (RPS) has been watered down in committee.

item.title: Statkraft – Q1 2009 - Satisfactory result from operations
item.description: The Group posted an operating profit, adjusted for unrealised changes in value and material non-recurring items, of NOK 3 943 million in the first quarter of 2009 (NOK 3 838 million). This represents an improvement of 3% compared with the same period in 2008. The improvement in the operating result is primarily attributable to an increase in production as a result of the acquisition of new assets, while the average Nordic system price was on a par with the previous year. Adjusted for unrealised changes in value and material non-recurring items, the underlying profit after tax amounted to NOK 1 786 million (NOK 2 943 million). The interim financial statements are impacted by large unrealised changes in value. Unadjusted for these items, the accounting profit after tax was NOK 2 723 million (NOK 3 803 million)1.

item.title: Fresh wind blows through Brazil's energy sector
item.description: A major boost the industry has been waiting for comes on Nov. 25, when the government holds its first wind power auction in which it is expected to buy up to 1,000 MW in new generating capacity from competing firms. Brazil's wind energy association estimates the auction will generate investments worth about 5 billion reais ($2.4 billion).

item.title: Scotland's wind power firms urged to set sights on China
item.description:
ONE of Scotland's leading renewable energy organisations will today urge the country's green energy companies to grab a lion's share of the rapidly expanding wind power market in China.
In an address to delegates at the opening day of the All Energy '09 exhibition and conference in Aberdeen, Iain Todd of the Aberdeen Renewable Energy Group (AREG) will claim it is vital to seize the "substantial" business opportunities in the Far EasADVERTISEMENTt to reinforce Scotland's status as a global energy leader.

item.title: Deepwater Wind opens office in Rhode Island
item.description:
State leaders joined representatives of Deepwater Wind LLC at the opening Monday of the alternative-energy company's Rhode Island office.
The Exchange Terrace office in downtown Providence is considered yet another signal that the New Jersey-based developer is committed to developing two offshore wind farms off the Rhode Island coast.

item.title: INTERIM FINANCIAL REPORT – Q1 2009
item.description: The Supervisory Board of DONG Energy A/S has today approved the interim financial report for the first quarter of 2009, which developed as follows compared with the first-quarter 2008 results: - Revenue was up 4% at DKK 15,616 million, primarily as a result of higher gas production from the Ormen Lange field. However, this was partly offset by significantly lower oil and gas prices and lower power prices - EBITDA was down 17% at DKK 2,653 million, substantially due to the effects of timing differences in connection with the huge fluctuations in market prices for, especially, oil, gas and coal - Profit after tax was DKK 718 million versus DKK 1,252 million - DONG Energy invested DKK 2.9 billion in new activities and existing plants, including a gas-fired power station project in Wales. In addition, a contract for the acquisition of a Polish wind farm was entered into

item.title: Maine task force to identify offshore wind energy sites
item.description: International energy companies are looking at Maine to test new designs for massive wind turbines and support structures that would float in deep water, out of sight of the coast and in line with the strongest breezes.

item.title: Siemens to produce wind turbines in China
item.description: Siemens is expanding its global manufacturing network for wind turbine plants and is building a new production facility in Lingang New City in Shanghai. By establishing this new rotor blade and nacelle plant, the company is further strengthening its environmental portfolio. This new facility is scheduled to take up operation in the second half of 2010, initially with 400 employees. The wind turbine plants produced in Shanghai will be for the Chinese market and for export. Siemens is investing more than EUR60 million in setting up this new location.

item.title: Nordex with continued double-digit growth in Q1/2009
item.description: In the first quarter of 2009, the Nordex Group (ISIN: DE000A0D6554) continued to grow, achieving a 17% increase in sales to EUR 233.3 million (previous year: EUR 199.3 million) and thus living up to its full-year expectations for 2009. The main growth drivers were rising business volumes in Europe (excluding Germany) and the United States. Whereas turbine assembly output increased by 25% to 262 MW (previous year: 210 MW), Nordex new installed wind power system capacity of around 180 MW, i.e. on a par with the previous year.

item.title: U.S. Wind Power Industry Marks Strong First-Quarter Growth
item.description: The U.S. wind power industry installed more than 2,800 megawatts (MW) of new generating capacity in the first quarter of 2009, according to the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA). The growth rate is strong compared to the overall growth of 8,358 MW in 2008, which averages out to roughly 2,100 MW per quarter, but the growth is relatively weak compared to the fourth quarter of 2008, when the industry installed a record 4,112 MW of wind capacity.

item.title: The Commission calls for proposals for €4 billion worth of energy investments
item.description: The European Commission has launched today a call for proposals covering key energy infrastructure projects such as energy interconnections, offshore wind energy and carbon capture and storage as part of the implementation of the European Energy Programme for Recovery (EEPR), on which the Council and the Parliament recently reached agreement. Project promoters are invited to submit their proposals by 15 July 2009. The Commission expects to sign the first grant agreements and decisions before the end of the year. In total nearly €4 billion worth of financial aid will be available to support new energy-related investments.

item.title: R.I. offshore wind farm will likely be out of sight
item.description:
Because of stronger winds and a sea floor with fewer obstacles to construction, the most favorable places for wind turbines in Rhode Island coastal waters appear to be far offshore, where the turbines will be all but invisible from the mainland.
That preliminary conclusion by state researchers could be extremely good news for Deepwater Wind, the company selected by the Carcieri administration to construct a $1.5-billion wind farm in Rhode Island’s coastal waters.

item.title: Cape Wind secures key permits
item.description: The state Energy Facilities Siting Board voted unanimously yesterday to approve a bundle of permits for the proposed Nantucket Sound wind farm, marking a major milestone for the hotly contested project

item.title: Sea sense amid marine chaos
item.description: The ocean is getting crowded: Fishermen are competing with offshore wind projects, oil rigs with sand miners, recreational boaters, liquefied gas tankers and fish farmers. So a number of groups — including policymakers, academics, activists and industry officials — say it’s time to divvy up space in the sea.

item.title: Garrad Hassan provides technical advice on UK’s 4th largest Offshore Wind Farm. - 22nd May 2009
item.description: Garrad Hassan recently completed an independent technical assessment for Statkraft, analysing their investment in the UK’s Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm. Working to a tight programme, Garrad Hassan provided an independent risk assessment looking at costs, energy yield, operational issues, general programme and technical risks.

item.title: Lehrer: The way the political winds are blowing, coastal insurance rates could go up
item.description: As it girds for hurricane season, Texas has plenty to worry about. The Texas Windstorm Insurance Association (TWIA)—which provides coverage for high risk coastal properties — has ended up at the brink of insolvency paying Hurricane Ike claims. Insurers operating near the coasts have begun to cut back on coverage and make noises about leaving the state. If that wasn't enough, some members of Congress now want to change tax law in a way that will drive already expensive coastal Texas insurance premiums even higher. The tax law change involves something called "offshore affiliated reinsurance" — a rather esoteric product that matters a lot here in Texas.

item.title: Subsea boom for marine projects firm
item.description:
AN offshore engineering firm is enjoying a boom in the marine and subsea sectors, having secured international contracts worth more than £80m this year.
CTC Marine Projects, which has its head office in Coniscliffe Road, Darlington, said the agreements, a combination of new and extended contracts, represented a “significant achievement”.

item.title: Big rotors king for 2010+
item.description: A few years back, it was quite common to see various turbine manufacturers releasing their latest Class IA turbine, followed rather quickly with a class II and III rotor. This was typically just a longer blade with minimal nacelle changes. The Vestas 2WM, Siemens 2.3 MW, and GE 1.5 MW platforms are good examples of this.

item.title: Metoc to monitor installation of UK offshore wind farm
item.description: Metoc is to monitor and report on the installation of wind farm infrastructure for Airtricity which is developing the GBP 1.3 billion Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm off the East coast of the UK in a joint venture with RWE npower renewables.

item.title: Climate change summit hijacked by biggest polluters, critics claim
item.description: A vital meeting in Copenhagen this weekend that will help shape the agenda for the most important climate change talks since the Kyoto protocol has been hijacked by some of the biggest polluters in the world, critics claimed today.

item.title: Blown away by the North Sea
item.description:
SCOTTISH NORTH Sea zones earmarked for offshore wind farms have the potential to produce 40% more electricity than their English equivalents, new research has found.
The study by Edinburgh-based Atmos Consulting and the US space agency Nasa, which follows up on related findings published in the Sunday Herald last month, also indicates for the first time substantial variations in the electricity-generating potential of different areas of the same offshore zone.

item.title: Danish island has energy to spare
item.description: Concerns about energy security may run high elsewhere, but the inhabitants of the windswept Danish island of Samso have achieved a decade-long target of self-sufficiency in renewable power.

item.title: Clipper Appoints Mathews VP Of Wind Turbine Financing
item.description: Calif.-based Clipper Windpower has appointed Andrew Mathews vice president of wind turbine financing. Mathews, who will be based in New York, now holds responsibility for the due diligence process associated with financing Liberty 2.5 MW wind turbines

item.title: Brazil wind energy sector taking off
item.description: Brazil's wind energy sector is expected to take off this year, boosted by the government's first auction for projects in the renewable energy source on November 25

item.title: 2009 Deep Research Report on China Wind Power Equipment Industry Chain
item.description: Published by QYResearch Wind Energy Research Center on Jun 2009.

item.title: MAN Diesel provides clean energy to the Caribbean
item.description: MAN Diesel, in collaboration with wind turbine manufacturer Enercon and planning and consulting firm Econcern, is building the world’s largest wind/ diesel hybrid power plant on the Caribbean island of Bonaire

item.title: Clean Energy Patent Growth Index 1st Quarter 2009
item.description: The CEPGI tracks the granting of patents in the Clean Energy sector and monitors important technological breakthroughs in this field. Victor Cardona, Co-chair of the firm’s Cleantech Group stated, “we are pleased to announce results for the First Quarter 2009 edition of the Clean Energy Patent Growth Index which illustrate the trend of innovative activity in the vital clean energy sector, and identifies the top patent owners, States and Countries. Honda led the other patent owners in the first quarter while the number of Clean Energy Patents fell after reaching an all time high in 2008."

item.title: Analyzing the Global Offshore Wind Power Industry
item.description: The report, Analyzing the Global Offshore Wind Power Industry, explores the importance of offshore wind power in today’s world. The report further looks at the basics of the wind energy industry, economics, issues and barriers, and other such factors.

item.title: A-Power Energy Generation Systems Ltd. Signs Letter of Intent to Partner with Jiangsu Miracle Logistics System Engineering Co., Ltd. for Wind Turbine Components
item.description: ("A-Power" or "the Company"), a leading provider of distributed power generation ("DG") systems in China and a fast-growing manufacturer of wind turbines, today announced it has signed a Letter of Intent ("LOI") with Jiangsu Miracle Logistics System Engineering Co., Ltd. ("Jiangsu Miracle") to source wind turbine components including hubs and main frames from Jiangsu Miracle's subsidiaries.

item.title: Vestas to Boost Global Sales, Add China Workforce
item.description: Vestas Wind Systems A/S, the world’s biggest maker of wind turbines, plans to increase global sales by 20 percent this year as it adds production centers and boosts workforce by a third in China.

item.title: China Rules Block Overseas Bids for Energy Projects, Group Says
item.description: Overseas companies have lost out on 5 billion euros ($6.95 billion) of wind energy projects under China’s economic stimulus plan because bidding criteria make it impossible for them to compete, the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China said

item.title: Foundation work for alpha ventus REpower wind turbines begins
item.description: Kick-off for a further major building phase for the first German offshore wind park alpha ventus: as of today, 24 piles will be driven into the seabed for the foundations of six REpower wind turbines, situated 45 km off the coast of Borkum. The cylindrical piles are between 31 and 44 meters long and with a diameter of 1.80 meters. They will be driven into the seabed up to a depth of 42 meters using a hydraulic hammer and a template. Belgian specialist company, Geosea, are carrying out the pile driving and are using the “Buzzard”, a jack-up barge, for the work.

item.title: Areva Multibrid's Series Production: An Ambitious Growth Path
item.description: MULTIBRID, now owned by French technology giant AREVA, has ambitious plans to launch a major assault on the offshore market with its 5 MW machine.

item.title: AREVA signed a Memorandum of Understanding for 80 offshore wind turbines worth more than €700 million
item.description: AREVA, through its subsidiary Multibrid, has executed a binding Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the company Wetfeet Offshore Windenergy GmbH, to supply eighty M5000 turbines for the offshore Global Tech 1 wind farm (400 MW). Under the terms of the agreements, AREVA will also provide commissioning, testing and maintenance services. Foundations, transport and erection offshore are excluded from the scope.

item.title: Areva Wind Division To Open North American Headquarters
item.description: Cape May, N.J.-based Fishermen's Energy of New Jersey LLC, an energy consortium that is seeking to build an offshore wind project, has welcomed the opening of a North American headquarters for its Areva-Multibrid wind energy division.

item.title: Fundamentally unchanged shareholder structure at Nordex AG following termination of a shareholders’ agreement
item.description: At Nordex AG a long-standing agreement on the assignment of shares held by the major shareholders CMP und Goldman Sachs has expired on schedule.

item.title: Stream of renewable placements may run dry
item.description: Recent share placements by renewable energy companies suggest the industry has passed through a financial bottleneck, but investor appetite for further stock sales could vanish as quickly as it surfaced.

item.title: Airtricity secures Siemens wind turbines for the Butendiek offshore wind farm in Germany
item.description: Airtricity, the renewable energy division of Scottish and Southern Energy (SSE), signed an agreement with Siemens Energy for the delivery of 80 SWT-3.6-107 wind turbines for the Butendiek offshore wind farm in the German North Sea. The offshore project, with a capacity of 288 megawatts (MW), shall be commissioned in 2012.

item.title: World's First Floating Wind Turbine
item.description:
The world's first water-based, electricity-generating wind turbine is set to be installed off the coast of Norway this coming weekend.
Alexandra Beck Gjorv of the Norwegian-based energy concern Statoil told reporters this weekend that the new floating wind power station, known as the Hywind, "should help move offshore wind farms out of sight".

item.title: Multinationals look to grow in the wind
item.description:
On the outskirts of Shanghai, German engineering giant Siemens began construction on a 581-million-yuan wind power equipment plant in late May that marks the company's entry into China's wind energy market.
The new 180,000-sq-m facility will at first produce blades for turbines with capacity of 2.3 mW and 3.6 mW, and then manufacture nacelles. At startup it will make equipment with a combined annual capacity of 500 mW.

item.title: Siemens to acquire 25 percent stake in BGZ Beteiligungsgesellschaft Zukunftsenergien AG - CEO Peter Löscher: “Siemens is becoming greener” - Investment in wind, solar and bio energy
item.description: Siemens is acquiring a roughly 25 percent stake in BGZ Beteiligungsgesellschaft Zukunftsenergien AG (BGZ AG). The investment will enable the company to ensure its access to further innovative projects in the field of sustainable power generation and thereby expand its portfolio of products, systems and services.

item.title: Siemens to open European wind power headquarters in Hamburg
item.description: Siemens is significantly expanding its activities in the field of wind power in Germany and Europe. As part of its expansion activities, Siemens is to locate its European sales and project management headquarters for the wind energy sector in Hamburg. At the same time, it is restructuring its facilities in Bremen and turning them into its European service centre.

item.title: Siemens to Build Wind Turbine Production Facility in Shanghai
item.description: Siemens recently announced it is building a new rotor blade and nacelle production facility in Lingang New City in Shanghai. The company reports that the new facility is scheduled to take up operation in the second half of 2010, initially with 400 employees. The wind turbine plants produced in Shanghai will be for the Chinese market and for export. Siemens is investing more than 60 million euros in setting up this new location.

item.title: Rhode Island sees a green future in energy
item.description:
The commissioner of the state Office of Energy Resources says the fledgling wind-power industry in Rhode Island could eventually generate 4,000 to 5,000 jobs.
“There’s a prospect for a substantial number of jobs coming in that industry,” Andrew Dzykewicz said Wednesday at a clean-energy jobs forum sponsored by the Rhode Island council of MoveOn.

item.title: ACCIONA consolidates its sustainable business model of Energy, Infrastructure and Water as a way of beating the crisis
item.description: ACCIONA Chairman & CEO José Manuel Entrecanales reaffirmed today in his address to the Company’s Annual Shareholders Meeting his belief in ACCIONA’s business model, based on the concept of sustainability, and centred on energy, infrastructure and water, as a differentiated and efficient formula for beating the current international crisis.

item.title: Romax Technology and DHI-DCW sign 5MW gearbox contract
item.description: Romax Technology has entered into a new contract for 5MW wind turbine gearbox development and a progressive collaborative agreement with DHI-DCW

item.title: Vestas board touring Colorado manufacturing plants
item.description:
The board of directors for Danish wind power giant Vestas Wind Systems A/S was in Colorado Monday touring manufacturing plants owned by the company’s American subsidiary.
The 12-member board, along with Ditlev Engel, Vestas’ president and CEO, flew to Colorado on Sunday and had a one-hour meeting with Gov. Bill Ritter, said Roby Roberts, senior vice president for external relations for Vestas Americas, the American arm of the company.

item.title: China Blocks $69 Billion of Polluting Projects to Cut Emissions
item.description: China rejected 473 billion yuan ($69 billion) of polluting projects last year as developed nations urged the world’s biggest producer of greenhouse gases to adopt limits in heat-trapping emissions.

item.title: Clean energy investment seen down 26%-39% in 2009
item.description: New investment in the worldwide clean energy sector this year will total between $95bn and $115bn, down between 26% and 39% from $155bn in 2008, New Energy Finance, an industry research firm, reported on Friday.

item.title: 2009-2013 Investment Analysis Report on China wind turbine blade Industry
Despite Changes,US Renewable-Pwr Mandate Still Faces Hurdles
item.description: Despite whittling down a proposed federal renewable-energy mandate to a fraction of its previous strength, Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., still faces a tough sell to gain enough support for passage.

item.title: IBERDROLA COMPLETES SALE OF 10% STAKE IN GAMESA
item.description: IBERDROLA has closed the sale of a 10% stake in Gamesa Corporación Tecnológica, leaving its shareholding at 14.1046%.

item.title: Technology breakthrough in monitoring wind turbine operational efficiency
item.description: Ferroperm Piezoceramics has discovered a means of turning blade vibrations into electricity which can be used to collect and transmit valuable information wirelessly to a remote monitoring centre

item.title: Protectionist fears over China stimulus
item.description: A senior European business representative has accused Beijing of deliberately locking foreign suppliers out of contracts under its Rmb4,000bn ($586bn, €421bn, £365bn) stimulus package.

item.title: Green industry demands low-carbon dollars
item.description: Top executives from companies likely to win from climate change policies demanded on Tuesday that governments turn away from fossil fuels when they sign a new climate pact, expected in December.

item.title: Ilkka Hakala appointed as WinWinD Group CEO
item.description: Ilkka Hakala has been appointed as Group Chief Executive Officer of WinWinD Group on 1.6.2009.

item.title: WinWinD listed amongst the top 50 Most Promising Nordic Cleantech Companies
item.description: WinWinD the technology leaders in the global wind energy market has been conferred with being in the top 50 Most Promising Nordic Cleantech Companies.

item.title: Wind energy developers call for turbine price cuts
item.description: Spanish wind energy developers, faced with a possible reduction in subsidies which would spark a sector-wide cost-cutting battle, called on turbine makers to cut their prices.

item.title: Acciona to present new plan in September-chairman
item.description: Spanish conglomerate Acciona will present a new strategic plan in September after selling one of its non core businesses before July, chairman Jose Manuel Entrecanales said on Thursday at a shareholder meeting.

item.title: Acciona Seeks EU1.5 Billion of 2-Year Loans to Buy Enel Assets
item.description: Acciona SA, Spain’s second-largest construction company, is seeking 1.5 billion euros ($2.1 billion) of two-year loans to buy wind farms from Italian utility Enel SA, said two people familiar with the deal.

item.title: Sea zones earmarked for offshore wind farms
item.description: SCOTTISH NORTH Sea zones earmarked for offshore wind farms have the potential to produce 40% more electricity than their English equivalents, new research has found.

item.title: Metoc to monitor installation of UK offshore wind farm
item.description: Metoc is to monitor and report on the installation of wind farm infrastructure for Airtricity which is developing the GBP 1.3 billion Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm off the East coast of the UK in a joint venture with RWE npower renewables.

item.title: Centrica plc Non-Executive Director declaration
item.description: Centrica plc announces that Mary Francis, its senior independent non-executive director, has been appointed as a non-executive director of Cable & Wireless plc with effect from 1 July 2009.

item.title: DONG looks to more UK offshore wind farms
item.description: Denmark's DONG Energy is looking to build more UK offshore wind farms the head of the company has indicated at an energy conference.

item.title: Maine seeks federal funds for wind power research
item.description: U.S. Secretary of Energy Steven Chu expressed interest Friday morning in a plan that seeks to put the University of Maine at the forefront of a national offshore wind power research effort

item.title: DONG Energy joins the ITF fold
item.description: ITF, the Industry’s Technology Facilitator has announced another new international member. DONG Energy is the latest operator to join ITF, underlining an ongoing industry commitment to research and development (R&D) despite the economic downturn

item.title: Gore makes plea for climate deal
item.description: Climate-change heavyweights U.N. chief Ban Ki-moon and Nobel prize winner Al Gore urged more than 500 business leaders Sunday to lend their support to reaching a global deal on reducing greenhouse gases.

item.title: Changing wind means action on green schemes
item.description: The Budget prompted press coverage devoted to the parlous state of the nation’s finances, the need for spending cuts and the tax burden – however, important “green” measures in the Budget went largely unnoticed.

item.title: Dutch green energy company bends under crisis
item.description: A Dutch court has approved Econcern’s bankruptcy protection application while it tries to find ways to reply its creditors.

item.title: Dutch energy firm Econcern files for receivership
item.description: Dutch-based sustainable energy company Econcern said on Tuesday it had filed for voluntary receivership after it failed in a bid to secure refinancing.

item.title: Foundations for the first six alpha ventus wind turbines laid
item.description: On June 1 the last of six foundations for the AREVA Multibrid M5000 wind turbines was anchored successfully in the seabed at the construction site of Germany’s first offshore wind farm 45 kilometres off the coast of the island of Borkum.

item.title: MarineWind Alliance to seek UK Offshore wind energy rights
item.description: A consortium of world leaders in wind power, maritime operations and renewable energy investments has announced that it has submitted a joint bid aimed at winning exclusive rights from the Crown Estate to develop offshore wind farms in UK waters.

item.title: OceanWind plans 1000 MW wind farm in the North Sea
item.description: Norwegian offshore wind developer OceanWind has submitted a planning notice for The Ægir Offshore Wind Farm to The Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate (NVE).

item.title: EU 20% Renewable Energy Target Can Deliver 2.8 Million Jobs
item.description: Reaching the 20 percent renewable energy source (RES) target in 2020 is expected to deliver approximately 2.8 million jobs in the renewable energy sector and generate about 1.1 percent of European GDP, according to a new European Commission study.

item.title: RES Group Makes Sunday Times Top Green Companies List
item.description: Leading independent renewable energy company RES Group, which is based in Kings Langley, has been described as one of the greenest businesses in Britain, according to the Sunday Times 2009 list published this week

item.title: RWE Innogy puts money into Spanish wind
item.description: Via its Spanish subsidiary Agrupació Energías Renovables S.A. (AERSA), the company previously held 44 % of Danta. RWE Innogy thus increases its wind power portfolio in Spain by about 70 MW to a total of 400 MW.

item.title: Clean energy depends on wider economy growth
item.description: Clean energy has strong guaranteed government backing in long-term subsidies but its future growth hinges on wider economic recovery and European targets are in doubt

item.title: Crisis cuts costs for big wind players
item.description: Wind farm costs have fallen significantly for companies big enough to finance their own projects as the economic crisis cripples competitors for turbines, an executive from RWE Innogy said on Wednesday

item.title: SSE seeks funds for future capital expenditure
item.description: Scottish & Southern Energy is in talks with the European Bank of Investment to raise funds for new wind projects in Britain

item.title: ScottishPower Renewables Awarded Offshore Wind Site – Argyll Array
item.description: The Crown Estate is awarding ScottishPower Renewables (SPR) an exclusivity agreement in order that it can investigate the potential for an offshore windfarm west of Argyll and the island of Tiree, following the recent Scottish Territorial Waters tendering process

item.title: Wind turbine generator company Danotek Motion Technologies unveils new manufacturing centre
item.description: Danotek Motion Technologies, a US-based wind turbine generator manufacturer, is opening a manufacturing centre for the production of electric generators for wind turbines.

item.title: Sweden's Vattenfall easing way on Nuon deal-report
item.description: Swedish utility group Vattenfall is prepared to make concessions to smooth its planned takeover of the production and supply arm of smaller Dutch peer Nuon, Morgenpost Online reported on Tuesday. The deal would create Europe's largest producer of offshore wind power.

item.title: Offshore windfarm to be scaled down
item.description: Plans for a huge offshore windfarm near the Aberdeen coast will be scaled down to allay fears about shipping safety and helicopter operations.

item.title: Vattenfall £800m Thanet Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: Swedish electricity producer Vattenfall AB has begun work on a £800m Thanet offshore wind farm, off England's north Kent coast.

item.title: wpd procurement team managed to sign all delivery contracts for Germany’s first commercial offshore wind farm Baltic I.
item.description: This week the purchase contract between EnBW and Siemens Windpower for delivery of 2.3 MW SWP turbines for the Baltic I project in 2010 was published

item.title: Siemens to produce turbines in China
item.description: In the future, Siemens AG wants to produce rotor blades and nacelles in China. For this purpose the company is building a new factory in Shanghai that will start operations in mid-2010.

item.title: Coastal grid ‘needs cash injection’
item.description: Offshore energy projects around Scotland’s coast risk being strangled at birth unless the Scottish and UK governments invest £2.5 billion to £5 billion in an offshore energy grid, according to one of the sector’s leading executives.

item.title: Mass. map to allocate ocean’s use
item.description: As the nation increasingly looks to its oceans for energy, Massachusetts is putting the final touches on a vast regulatory map designed to plot out where wind farms, and other offshore projects, can be located in its coastal waters.

item.title: ABB cables to strengthen Danish power grid
item.description: ABB has won an order from SEAS-NVE, a leading Danish energy company, to provide a cable solution to strengthen the existing transmission grid and enable the integration of more wind power from the Rødsand II offshore wind park, expected to be commissioned in late 2010.

item.title: UK wind industry requires more financing
item.description: There needs to be significantly more government investment in onshore and offshore wind power projects if the UK government is to reach its renewable energy targets, it has been warned

item.title: UK leads in marine energy, lags in wind
item.description: Britain is determined to harness its huge marine energy potential and export it around the world after blowing the opportunity to be a global wind power leader. The British Isles have some of the world’s strongest tides, waves and winds but the country has trailed others including Spain and Germany in wind energy growth.

item.title: Turbine or not turbine
item.description: Last-week’s decision to give the go-ahead to the London Array offshore wind farm was a welcome boost to a renewables industry that has been hit hard by the economic downturn

item.title: European Supergrid Concept of Using Green Energy
item.description: Even if it may sound like science fiction, the vision of the European Union is to be able to power the entire Continent with Green Energy: from solar panels to wind and wave turbines, from geothermal to hydroelectric power stations. ... Adam Bruce, chairman of the British Wind Energy Association (BWEA), thinks that the European “supergrid” is only a matter of time

item.title: As Climate Bill Passes Tough Committee, Why Am I So Worried?
item.description: Late Thursday night, the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted 33-25 to pass landmark legislation that promises to address our nation’s urgent energy challenges and help avert potentially catastrophic climate change. The legislation, known as the American Clean Energy and Security Act (or ACES), also presents an unprecedented opportunity to renew our economy and position the United States at the forefront of a burgeoning global market for clean and affordable energy technology.

item.title: Wind Capital Group President Named To AWEA Board
item.description: Tom Carnahan, president and CEO of Wind Capital Group, has been named to the board of the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA). Carnahan, who founded Wind Capital Group in 2005, has quickly established the company as one of America's leading wind energy developers.

item.title: AP Interview: Siemens CEO eyeing green energy tech
item.description: Global demand for more renewable sources of energy and more efficient products will drive future growth for the German industrial conglomerate Siemens AG, its CEO said Tuesday

item.title: Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: MT Højgaard is carrying out the 90 foundations for the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm.

item.title: Wind energy industry pulling back and shedding jobs
item.description: If the wind doesn't blow, wind turbines can't make electricity, and if credit markets don't flow, the entire wind-energy business grinds to a standstill.

item.title: DOTI Prepares for First Six Alpha Ventus Turbines In Germany
item.description: Local company Deutsche Offshore Testfeld und Infrastrukturgesellschaft have installed the foundations for the Areva Multibrid M5000 5MW wind turbines at a German offshore wind farm.

item.title: O power of Scotland, we'll see your like again (and again and again)
item.description: THE world's largest renewable energy company wants to build Europe's five biggest wind farms in Scotland.

item.title: Iberdrola sidesteps SSE sale rumours
item.description: Ignacio Sanchez Galan, the chairman of Scottish-Power owner Iberdrola, yesterday body-swerved questions about the possibility that Scottish & Southern Energy (SSE), a rival and joint venture partner, could lose its independence amid rampant industry consolidation.

item.title: UK to miss clean energy goals on govt under-spend
item.description: Britain will miss 2020 clean energy targets and the supporting certificate scheme "will die" if the government does not spend more to support renewables, the CEO of clean energy developer Climate Change Capital said on Tuesday.

item.title: Inauguration of NSW's New Submarine Cable Plant
item.description: Coinciding with its 110th anniversary, the German cable making company Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke GmbH (NSW), a General Cable subsidiary, has just inaugurated a new submarine cable production plant in the town of Nordenham.

item.title: Wind power company WinWinD chooses Fujitsu's Patja
item.description: Wind power company Winwind Oy and ICT services supplier Fujitsu Services Oy have entered into a three-year Patja services agreement whereby Fujitsu assumes overall responsibility for the IT availability and information security and support services of WinWindD. The agreement also covers end-to-end product services.

item.title: Iberdrola buys out Greek Rokas Group
item.description: Spain-based Iberdrola Renovables announced it has wholly acquired Greece-based Rokas Group. The transaction was authorized by the Capital Market Commission, the Greek stock exchange regulator

item.title: RI lawmakers debate new plan for funding wind farm
item.description: The state's dominant electricity distributor would be forced to buy power from renewable energy producers under a deal struck Wednesday that could remove a major financial obstacle to building a windfarm off Rhode Island.

item.title: Raitt feared she'd be blamed for budget leak
item.description: Natural Resources Minister Lisa Raitt, in a previously unreleased excerpt from a recorded conversation she had with a former aide, is quoted as saying she's afraid the prime minister will blame her for leaking details of the federal budget tabled earlier this year.

item.title: Not so windy: Research suggests winds dying down
item.description: The wind, a favorite power source of the green energy movement, seems to be dying down across the United States. And the cause, ironically, may be global warming — the very problem wind power seeks to address.

item.title: Wind Energy Industry Lobbies for Higher Mandate
item.description: This article in the Des Moines (IA) Register says officials with the industry, along with a governor from a state that is really making headways in wind energy, were on Capitol Hill to warn Congress that the current proposed legislation doesn’t support the same continued growth:

item.title: Paying the difference
item.description: Various windfarm projects have been in the news recently, with the usual statistics of 'x' MW capacity to supply enough electricity for 'y' thousands of homes. The 'greens' love them; the sceptics emphasise the low utilisation factors. But nowhere is it possible to assess whether they will actually, overall, reduce CO2 levels.

item.title: To date, most offshore wind farms proposed in the United States have been in the Northeast
item.description: Cape Wind, a project off the shores of Cape Cod in Massachusetts, is awaiting a federal go-ahead, and similar ventures are in the offing near the coasts of Delaware, Rhode Island and New Jersey.

item.title: Transpower sets up offshore wind farm converter: report
item.description: A new type of converter station for wind power is set to be installed near the site of an offshore wind farm in the North Sea.

item.title: IN-DEPTH: Charting out planned maintenance activity
item.description: The performance of a site is a complex issue, and will generally evolve over time. In this context, a utility or a site owner goes through several challenges for maintenance as the project progresses.

item.title: Fluor exec sees stability here
item.description: The current economic downturn is affecting companies large and small, and Fluor Corp. is no exception, said David Seaton, newly named senior group president in charge of three of the company's major operating groups.

item.title: Statoil Hydro prepares Hywind for tests
item.description: The world’s first full-scale floating wind turbine has been towed to its final destination and is ready to be moored to the seabed, says Norwegian firm Statoil Hydro. The 2.3 MW unit reached the site off the coast of Norway in early June and will be prepared for a two-year testing period that is scheduled to start in the autumn.

item.title: Hywind: Siemens and StatoilHydro install first floating wind turbine
item.description: StatoilHydro and Siemens installed the world’s first large-scale floating wind turbine. The turbine is located approximately 12 km south east of Karmøy in Norway at a water depth of about 220 meters. The Hywind project was developed by StatoilHydro, and Siemens supplied the SWT-2.3 MW wind turbine with a rotor diameter of 82 meters. Over the next two years the floating wind turbine will be tested to provide a thorough analysis of this innovative concept. The Hywind turbine will be connected to the local grid and is expected to start producing power in mid-July.

item.title: Enabling new business
item.description: Vestas has launched a new type of crane that attaches directly to wind turbine masts, designed to make maintenance and repair work easier. Scotland’s ITI Energy is working on similar technology.

item.title: With American zeal and Teutonic precision, Siemens sets out stall for the future
item.description: There are not very many laughs at Siemens these days. Europe’s oldest and most highly regarded engineer finds itself battered by a vicious recession just as it recovers from a sharp judicial spanking for bribery and corruption. Even so, Peter Löscher, its chief executive, had to struggle to prevent his face from breaking into a grin.

item.title: Wind power could follow ethanol's boom-bust cycle
item.description: Wind power is booming - at the moment. Companies are flocking to build turbine and blade plants in the United States, such as the one Siemens will build in Hutchinson. The amount of energy harvested from wind rose 50 percent last year to 25,300 megawatts.

item.title: Acciona expects 20 percent fall in wind turbine costs
item.description: Spanish renewable energy company Acciona Energia on Tuesday estimated factory gate costs for wind turbines will fall by 20 percent in three years, a factor the wind power industry says is crucial to their future

item.title: Rhode Island offshore wind farm moves closer to reality
item.description: Nearly identical bills that would pave the way for National Grid to set up long-term contracts to purchase renewable energy have unanimously passed key committees in the House and Senate.

item.title: Iberdrola sells off stake in Gamesa
item.description: Spanish utility group Iberdrola has closed the sale of a 10% stake in wind turbine manufacturer Gamesa Corporación Tecnológica, leaving its shareholding at just over 14%.

item.title: U.S. Investors Can Now Buy Iberdrola Shares
item.description: Spanish energy company Iberdrola Renewables has obtained authorization from the Securities and Exchange Commission to operate a sponsored Level I American Depositary Receipts (ADR) program, which allows U.S. investors to acquire shares in the company.

item.title: IBERDROLA RENOVABLES BOOSTS ITS GLOBAL LEADERSHIP BY REACHING 10,000 MW
item.description: By the end of June, IBERDROLA RENOVABLES will have installed capacity of 10,000 MW, boosting its world leadership in wind power(1). This capacity, equivalent to 10 average-sized Spanish nuclear power plants, could avoid the emission of 8,000,000 tonnes of CO² a year and supply power to some 20 million Spaniards (45% of the population).

item.title: IBERDROLA RENOVABLES REITERATES ITS COMMITMENT TO BEING A DRIVER OF ECONOMIC RECOVERY
item.description: “At a time like now, IBERDROLA RENOVABLES reaffirms its commitment to being a driving force of economic activity and the real driver of economic recovery in the countries in which it operates” said the company’s chairman, Ignacio Galán, at the General Shareholders’ Meeting held today in Valencia.

item.title: Corporate Responsibility Report 2008
Vattenfall - one of the largest producers of renewable energy in Europe
item.description: Today's Dagens Nyheter (9 June), a Swedish newspaper, describes Vattenfall's efforts concerning the climate in a very critical manner. The focus is on how large a proportion of our investments are in renewable energy production. The paper also says we have a distorted self-image. We would like to address these claims.

item.title: Comment to press coverage on the steering of Vattenfall
item.description: In an article in the Swedish daily newspaper Dagens Nyheter Mrs. Maud Olofsson, Minister for Enterprise and Energy and Deputy Prime Minister, stated that there is a need to review the articles of association for Vattenfall, as they currently do not reflect the fact that Vattenfall is a European energy company

item.title: Europe's onshore and offshore wind energy potential
item.description: The European Environment Agency has published its report - Europe's onshore and offshore wind energy potential. This report provides a Europe-wide resource assessment of onshore and offshore wind potential in a geographically explicit manner. In addition to calculating raw wind resource potential, this study also introduces and quantitatively analyses the environmental and social constraints on wind sector development. Concerns addressed include the noise and visual impact of wind power, as well as the deaths of birds and bats that fly into rotor blades. The report also evaluates the future costs of wind energy production across Europe in order to gauge the potential output at competitive rates.

item.title: Wave energy racing to catch up with wind
item.description: Wave energy could catch up with commercially more advanced offshore wind power within five years, the head of pioneers Aquamarine Power Ltd told Reuters

item.title: Democrats Struggling for Consensus on Climate Bills
item.description: Democratic allies remain at odds over provisions of a House climate bill and a Senate energy bill, even as congressional leaders and Obama administration officials are pressing to complete work on the legislation.

item.title: Wind turbine viability is shaky
item.description:
IN THE “Online” column (Times & Star, May 22) a Mr Donnelly offers views on wind turbines.
He writes that wind turbines for the proposed second Solway offshore wind farm would operate at capacity around 35 per cent of the time, maybe more.
British Wind Energy Association publicity on wind turbines indicates that rated output is achieved at wind speeds equating to ‘near gale’ on the Beaufort scale (around 33.5mph).

item.title: Leaders agree 20% 2020 renewable energy target
item.description: EU leaders agreed yesterday to combat climate change by ordering that a fifth of Europe's energy mix should come from renewable sources within 12 years

item.title: Siemens Sees U.S. Stimulus Plan Spurring Wind-Energy Growth
item.description: Siemens AG, the German engineer that built a power line from New Jersey to Long Island, said it may benefit from the U.S. economic stimulus plan by providing technology to connect planned wind farms to energy users.

item.title: Sustainable energy company Econcern’s core activities to be taken over by Eneco
item.description: Sustainable energy company Econcern, has entered into bankruptcy proceedings. Econcern is the holding company of Ecofys, Evelop, Ecostream, OneCarbon and Ecoventures.

item.title: Tilting at windmills may be costly for taxpayers
item.description: THIS report concludes that an investment of €14.75bn in wind energy projects would also be capable of supporting in excess of 10,500 jobs up to 2020.

item.title: Wind in Deep Water: Wind Foundations and Special Structures
item.description: In deep water, offshore wind turbines need sophisticated foundations. One rapidly-growing German offshore wind market steel equipment supplier is WeserWind.

item.title: Offshore Firm Set To Expand
item.description: Aberdeenshire-based Subocean Group has announced that they are to create 50 new jobs as the result of a round of contract wins for the company. Subocean, based in Westhill, have already taken on an additional 75 staff in the past twelve months, bucking the trend during a serious economic recession where most companies are busy laying off workers. The company specializes in laying sub-sea cable and is planning to double the size of its premises at Arnhall Business Park. They currently employ 75 people onshore and 100 offshore, and the 50 new jobs will all be offshore positions to help the company meet its new contracts.

item.title: Today is Global Wind Day
item.description: The European Wind Energy Association (EWEA), which initiated the Wind Day campaign, has joined forces with the Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC) to hold the first ever Global Wind Day today.

item.title: Laying foundations for growth in the Highlands and Islands
item.description:
Modern industries including life sciences and renewable energy are making strong progress in the Highlands and Islands, according to the region's development agency.
Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE) has demonstrated a "highly productive" performance in its 2008/09 end-of-year results which were reviewed by board members this week.

item.title: Safety breaches cost blade company nearly £500,000
item.description: BREACHES of health and safety regulations cost Vestas Blades nearly £500,000, a court was told. The Newport turbine blademaker, which is set to close, was fined a maximum £10,000 by Island magistrates and told to pay £25,000 of the Health and Safety Executive’s costs

item.title: Vestas awards suppliers
item.description: Vestas awards four suppliers for their commitment and results, helping the world’s largest manufacturer of wind turbines achieve its objectives.

item.title: A-Power Energy Generation Systems: Headwind or Tailwind?
item.description: A-Power Energy Generation Systems (APWR) is a provider of distributed power generation systems (DG) in China and is in the process of launching a wind power business. Its stock price has more than tripled this year as investors considered the company a proxy for the fast-growing alternative energy sector in China, especially the wind power market.

item.title: Airtricity, Port of Rømø to develop wind service center
item.description: ROMO, DENMARK: Scottish and Southern Energy division Airtricity has signed an agreement with Port of Rømø to develop a service and maintenance center for the proposed Butendiek offshore wind farm in the German North Sea. The development includes buildings and shore facilities for offshore access systems by fast crew tender vessels and helicopters.

item.title: R.I. Senate approves alternative energy for National Grid
item.description: In a near-unanimous vote, the state Senate on Wednesday approved a bill that will allow electricity utility National Grid to sign long-term contracts to purchase power from alternative-energy suppliers.

item.title: Eon staff to protest over job cuts threat
item.description: Thousands of Eon employees are expected to rally in front of the power company’s German headquarters on Thursday in protest at cutbacks and the threat of redundancies.

item.title: Eneco Acquires Core Parts of Econcern
item.description: Eneco has reached an agreement with the receivers of Econcern on the take-over of the core parts of Econcern. Eneco will purchase parts of the subsidiaries Evelop and Ecofys and a part of the bio mass activities. Parties will continue talks on the acquisition of Ecostream. This take-over will strengthen Eneco’s sustainability strategy. Eneco has the intention to transfer over 400 employees of Econcern. Parties do not make any statements with regard to the purchase price.

item.title: Nuon shareholders accept Vattenfall offer
item.description: Amsterdam, Stockholm, June 17, 2009 - At the Nuon Extraordinary General Shareholder Meeting, a majority of over 90% accepted Vattenfall’s offer to acquire the shares of Nuon. The transaction is expected to close on 1 July 2009, subject to competition clearance by the European Commission is expected before 1 July.

item.title: China's potential wind power resources alone are sufficient to meet its entire electricity demand
item.description:
China's potential wind power resources alone are sufficient to meet its entire electricity demand, the country's top wind power research institute has said.
Xiao Ziniu, director of the National Climate Center (NCC), said China's onshore wind power potential has been evaluated at between 700 gW and 1,200 gW, exactly within the range of the country's 790 gW power generating capacity for 2008.

item.title: Senate Energy Bill Includes Renewable Electricity Standard
item.description: By a vote of 15 to 8, the U.S. Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources has approved the American Clean Energy Leadership Act, which includes a 15% by 2021 federal renewable electricity standard (RES).

item.title: Ireland has launched its first major study into employment opportunities from the green economy.
item.description: The Irish Wind Energy Association's (IWEA) Jobs and Investment in IrishWind Energy Study was launched yesterday on Global Wind Day. In the first major study to be compiled on the opportunities arising in the industry island-wide, the joint IWEA and Deloitte report, identifies billions of euros of investment. Jobs in construction and development of wind energy projects across Ireland, north and south ,will involve approximately €14.75billion of investment - €5.1billion of this could be retained in the Irish economy

item.title: Global Marine Systems, Visser & Smit Marine launch Seabed Power
item.description: Global Marine Systems and Visser & Smit Marine Contracting have formed a joint venture, Seabed Power, focusing on the growing demand for subsea power cable installation in Europe.

item.title: Quayside cable facility to open next month
item.description: A £20M facility making underwater cables for the world’s largest windfarm will officially open next month, creating about 80 jobs.

item.title: "Buy Chinese" policy could handicap foreign wind turbine makers
item.description: A controversial "Buy Chinese" policy could leave overseas manufacturers of wind turbines and other renewable energy technologies locked out of the bidding for new low-carbon projects undertaken as part of China's $586bn (£361bn) economic stimulus package.

item.title: Biologist: Planning can help birds, wind farms co-exist
item.description: GORHAM, MAINE: As planners and developers zero in on locations for offshore wind turbines along the Maine coast, researchers such as Wing Goodale are trying to follow the birds.

item.title: Officials check on maritime move
item.description:
OFFICIALS from the Department of Energy and Climate Change were today due to visit Forresters Business Park, in Estover, to learn about a new maritime qualification being launched by two city companies.
The Barge Master's Certificate, the first of its kind in Europe, has been developed by Plymouth-based firms Howard Marine and Maritime Training in response to the recent growth in offshore construction, primarily because of energy wind farms.

item.title: Hong Kong's first wind farm plan passes assessment
item.description: Engineering consultants BMT Asia Pacific have completed a positive Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for Hong Kong’s first offshore wind farm, bringing the 200 megawatt project a step closer to reality.

item.title: Wind farm off Dorset coast could start by 2015
item.description:
BUILDING of a huge £175 million wind farm off the Dorset coast could start by 2015 as part of one of the largest construction projects in the world.
Crown Estate officials told councillors from Bournemouth and Christchurch that the plan is to derive 15 per cent of UK energy – and 30 per cent of its electricity – from renewable sources by 2020.

item.title: U.S. lags on offshore wind power
item.description: Imagine a renewable energy source so large it can provide enough power for 750,000 homes, or a quarter of all homes in London, England, especially when the fuel is free. It's called the London Array and when built it will be the world's largest offshore wind farm.

item.title: OFGEM REGIME WILL OPEN WAY TO INVESTMENT IN OFFSHORE WIND POWER
item.description: Ofgem and the Department of Energy and Climate Change have unveiled the finalised regime for regulating the undersea networks and other infrastructure that will carry power from offshore wind farms. The regime opens the gates for new investors to join a multi-billon-pound programme that will deliver vital contributions to GB’s drive to meet climate change targets and provide secure energy supplies while bringing value for money to consumers.

item.title: Studies aim to protect harbour porpoises
item.description:
THREE studies are to be carried out into the likely impact of marine renewables on the underwater environment around Scotland.
The Scottish Government research will include an attempt to estimate the risk of collision of harbour porpoises and marine renewable devices

item.title: Baltic States sign up to EU energy plan
item.description: European Union countries from the Baltic region have signed up to a Baltic Energy Market Interconnection Plan in an effort to more closely integrate the region's energy sector hitherto dominated by Russia.

item.title: Taiwan renewable energy law promises huge business opportunities for PV and wind power
item.description: Taiwan's Renewable Energy Development Statute enacted on June 12 will generate business opportunities with an estimated value of NT$360 billion (US$11.1 billion) for photovoltaic (PV) power and some NT$200 billion for wind power for the next two decades, according to industry sources

item.title: CCC Challenges Cape Wind Certificate Issued By EFSB
item.description: The Cape Cod Commission (CCC), a regional land-use planning and regulatory agency, has begun the process of appealing a decision by the Massachusetts Energy Facilities Siting Board (EFSB) to grant a Certificate of Environmental Impact and Public Interest for the construction of electric transmission lines by Cape Wind Associates. CCC contends that the decision attempts to override local and regional permitting processes.

item.title: ADB mulls USD 2 bn clean energy investments in Asia
item.description: Asian Development Bank (ADB) is considering to double its clean energy investments in Asia to USD 2 billion from a previous target of USD 1 billion a year with a view to accelerate its energy efficiency initiatives

item.title: A formula to increase wind turbines' efficiency level
item.description:
A new study has provided a formula for calculating how much usable energy do wind turbines produce, which will help increase their efficiency level.
The study, carried out by Abolfazl Ahmadi and Mehdi Ali Ehyaei of the Department of Mechanical Engineering, at Iran University of Science and Technology-Arak Branch, in Arak, investigated the "exergy" of wind power .

item.title: Hong Kong's first wind farm plan passes assessment
item.description: Engineering consultants BMT Asia Pacific have completed a positive Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for Hong Kong’s first offshore wind farm, bringing the 200 megawatt project a step closer to reality.

item.title: More offshore wind power coming to the U.K.
item.description: In early April, the British Wind Energy Association (BWEA) was asking the government of the United Kingdom for intervention to help the country's renewable energy prospects, warning that the global economic crisis was putting projects, particularly offshore wind projects, at risk. The trade body's pleas were answered later that month as the government announced its support for offshore wind energy with around GBP 525 million (US$760 million) in Renewable Obligation Certificates (ROCs) rather than direct funding.

item.title: Tom Sgouros: Trash-to-ash scheme will gut R.I. green
item.description: I was passing through Portsmouth a couple of weeks ago, and couldn’t help noticing that the town is now home to a second giant wind turbine, which seemed pretty cool to me. The new turbine is owned by the town, and generating electricity that the town sells to National Grid. Electricity isn’t the only thing Portsmouth sells, though.

item.title: Nantucket Sound Wind Farm Permit Appealed
item.description: A regional planning agency, a town and an environmental group have appealed a "superpermit" given a proposed offshore wind farm in Massachusetts, records show.

item.title: E.ON chief Paul Golby strives to generate debate about green goals
item.description: Energy says Britain needs a policy roadmap if it is to achieve carbon emissions targets

item.title: CanWEA welcomes New Brunswick government in its continued effort to develop wind power
item.description: New RFP for 100 MW of wind energy furthers New Brunswick's goal of reaching 400 MW of wind power by 2010

item.title: NYPA: Wind farm project moving quickly
item.description: Less than two months after he stood outside, in Buffalo's windswept Inner Harbor, New York State Power Authority president and CEO Richard Kessel came to the Falls on Tuesday to say plans for the Great Lakes Offshore Wind project are moving forward fast

item.title: O'Connor's Mainstream purchases US portfolio
item.description: Renewable energy company Mainstream Renewable Power is to invest $1.69 billion over four years to develop a portfolio of wind power projects in the USA.

item.title: EU power lines 'too old to deliver 2020 renewables target'
item.description: Ageing grid cannot transfer energy over the long distances demanded by renewable power stations, say academics

item.title: ABB committed to development of offshore wind power in China
item.description: ABB, the leading power and automation technology group, announced it will supply advanced 40.5kV ring main unit gas-insulated switchgears (GIS) to China’s first offshore wind farm, the Donghai Bridge Offshore Wind Farm Project in Shanghai. The company’s advanced products and technology will help China develop clean energy sources as part of the country’s long term sustainable energy plans.

item.title: Building a Continental Renewable Super Grid
item.description: As the planet warms and the economy cools, renewable resources are emerging as a realistic means to solve both problems in a timely fashion. Advocates of renewable energy want trillions of dollars spent in the coming decades on a continental-scale smart grid that will slash global greenhouse gas emissions and turn society toward a prosperous and ecological future.

item.title: Low Cost but Totally Renewable Electricity Supply for a Huge Supply Area
item.description: Many of the nations within the area of consideration are emerging nations bounding on Europe with renewable potentials far in excess of national demand. Due to this circumstance, the possibilities of wide-area interconnection promise unprecedented economic and technical benefits for all participating nations. The investigations have confirmed that a totally renewable electricity supply is well within the range of current technology, delivering the electricity at costs if at all only slightly above the current cost of electricity even if future equipment cost reductions are neglected.

item.title: Plambeck Neue Energien operates offshore reference field Altenbruch II
item.description: The wind farm developer Plambeck Neue Energien AG has completed production of the Altenbruch II wind farm near Cuxhaven, which has been designed as an offshore reference field. Nine wind-energy systems with a nominal output of 25.8 MW together have been set up here. Amongst them, there are six offshore systems from the Vestas and Siemens manufacturers. Plambeck Neue Energien AG will be owner and operating the wind farm itself.

item.title: Plambeck Neue Energien AG achieves leap in results in the 1st quarter of 2009
item.description: The wind-farm planner Plambeck Neue Energien AG has completed the first quarter of the 2009 fiscal year successfully. Compared with the previous year's period, the overall performance was increased by around 212% from 28.4 mill. Euro to 88.9 mill. Euro as per March 31, 2009

item.title: Citi Appointed Depositary for Iberdrola Renovables’ ADR Program
item.description: Citi’s Global Transaction Services business, acting through Citibank N.A., today announced that it has been appointed by Iberdrola Renovables, a global leader in the renewable energy sector, as the depositary bank for its American Depositary Receipt (ADR) program. In making this appointment, Iberdrola Renovables has designated Citi as the sponsor of what had previously been an unsponsored ADR program.

item.title: Econcern to sell OneCarbon to France's Orbeo
item.description: Troubled Dutch renewables firm Econcern has offloaded its carbon-credit origination business, OneCarbon International, as well as its sustainable electronics offshoot, Betronic

item.title: Baltic countries to join EU internal power market
item.description: Yesterday, the Memorandum of Understanding of the Baltic Energy Market Interconnection Plan (BEMIP) was signed by the relevant Heads of State and the European Commission. This is a timely step underpinning the integration of large quantities of wind power in Europe, believes the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA). The BEMIP is a step towards a future pan-European electricity grid in the Baltic region, and extends the successful Nordic electricity market rules to the three Baltic States.

item.title: Long-term Transmission System Plan identifies need for critical transmission system investments
item.description: Several critical transmission infrastructure projects are needed between 2010 and 2017 to meet the current and future electricity needs of Albertans, the Alberta Electric System Operator (AESO) said today in the latest update of its Long-term Transmission System Plan (the Plan).

item.title: Denmark to power electric cars by wind in vehicle-to-grid experiment
item.description: Cars could be the solution to the intermittent nature of wind power if a multimillion European project beginning on a Danish island proves successful. The project on the holiday island of Bornholm will use the batteries of parked electric cars to store excess energy when the wind blows hard, and then feed electricity back into the grid when the weather is calm

item.title: Tilting at windmills may be costly for taxpayers
item.description:
THIS report concludes that an investment of €14.75bn in wind energy projects would also be capable of supporting in excess of 10,500 jobs up to 2020.
This may indeed be true, but what about beyond 2020?
Deloitte and others may be able to pin down a figure for investment, and extrapolate job numbers from this quite accurately, but no one can claim to accurately call the true cost of an energy grid which by then will be hugely reliant on wind as our renewable power source.

item.title: U.S. Ramping Up Wind Power Programs Even As Concerns Surface About Possible Declines In U.S. Wind Strength
item.description: Just as the United States is boosting its reliance on wind power, a new academic study set for release in August says that U.S. wind forces may be getting weaker.

item.title: Denmark-based Siemens Wind Power to relocate 100 jobs to Germany
item.description: Danish renewable energy solutions firm Siemens Wind Power AS is planning to move about 100 jobs from Denmark to the German city of Hamburg, according to a report in financial newspaper Boersen on Friday.

item.title: Suzlon looks to cut manufacturing costs for REpower
item.description: Suzlon Energy Ltd, which now controls about 91 per cent of REpower Systems AG of Germany, plans to reduce costs for the German wind turbine manufacturer by sourcing parts from low cost manufacturing centres.

item.title: Wind Could Power Europe Many Times Over
item.description: A new report from the European Environment Agency has concluded that wind power's potential in 2020 is as much as three times greater than Europe's expected electricity demand, rising to a factor of up to seven times demand by 2030.

item.title: Maritime qualification is brainchild of city firms
item.description:
TWO Plymouth firms have linked up to launch an innovative new maritime qualification for workers building structures at sea.
Howard Marine and Maritime Training are behind the Barge Master's Certificate, the first of its kind in Europe, which they created in response to the recent growth in offshore construction, primarily energy wind farms.

item.title: Transmission system difficulties stall wind power progress
item.description: WASHINGTON -- Wind has become the nation's most viable renewable energy option, and industry experts see plenty of potential in Wisconsin as policymakers demand that a larger proportion of energy come from wind, the sun and other clean-energy sources.

item.title: National Grid publishes report on how electricity supply and demand could be balanced in 2020
item.description: The National Grid’s electricity supply system is set to become more complex in the coming decades with large amounts of variable wind generation and much larger nuclear power stations connecting to the networks. The company has published a report showing how these challenges can be met.

item.title: Nantucket Sound wind farm saga continues
item.description: Now that the Cape Cod Commission is appealing the Massachusetts Energy Facilities Siting Board's approval of the proposed wind farm on Nantucket Sound to the state's highest court, it's important to consider the stakes involved. This is not about the merits or demerits of the project. The appeal is about the ability of a state board, made up of nine gubernatorial appointees, to overrule a regional authority simply because the project developer submitted an application to the Cape Cod Commission.

item.title: Fourth US carbon allowance auction raises $104.2mn
item.description: Ten Northeastern US states raised $104.2mn in a fourth quarterly auction of carbon allowances, officials in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative said Friday.

item.title: NIST Releases Report On Smart Grid Development
item.description: The U.S. Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology has released for public review a report+ that identifies issues and proposes priorities for developing technical standards and an architecture for a U.S. Smart Grid.

item.title: Baltic Energy Market takes shape
item.description: Eight Baltic Sea states last week (17 June) launched an action plan to connect Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to EU energy networks, providing a signpost for the Swedish Presidency's agenda for the Baltic Sea region, EurActiv reports.

item.title: Martifer Group and Hirschfeld Industries Create Joint Venture to Manufacture Wind Power Components
item.description: Martifer Energy Systems, part of Martifer Group, and Hirschfeld Wind Energy Solutions, part of Hirschfeld Industries (“Hirschfeld”), announce the creation of a joint venture for the manufacture of wind towers and related components in the United States of America to serve the North American markets.

item.title: Japan to join international renewable energy body
item.description:
Japan will shortly become a member of the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), which was established this year, the government has decided.
Following the U.S. government's decision to join the organization, Japan is expected to become a member of the intergovernmental body, which promotes renewable energies including solar and wind power, at its meeting starting in Egypt next Monday.

item.title: SHI Advances into the US Wind Power Facility Market
item.description: Samsung Heavy Industries announced its successful entry into the US wind power generator market, which it achieved by concluding an LOI on May 21 with Cielo, a US-based firm, for the installation of three 2.5MW wind power generators by 2011 in Texas.

item.title: Asian Development Bank policy targets clean energy for Asia
item.description: The Asian Development Bank’s board of directors has approved a new energy policy to help Asia and Pacific countries secure adequate energy supplies while cutting levels of greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Siemens Predicts 15 Billion Euros in Stimulus Orders
item.description: Siemens AG, Europe’s largest engineering company, said it expects to win orders of about 15 billion euros ($21 billion) from economic stimulus programs as it aims to overcome the drop in private investment.

item.title: Siemens embraces solar as stimulus funds start flowing
item.description: On the bright side, Löscher expects to see white-hot sales of Siemens' wind turbines and high-voltage direct current (HVDC) electricity transmission lines over the next few years, which are being snapped up to link Europe’s growing network of offshore wind farms to onshore grids. Siemens is the world’s leading maker of offshore wind turbines, and ranks sixth in the overall market for turbines. ...Between now and 2012, Löscher precits an annual growth rate of 20% for offshore wind turbines; 20% for HVDC technology; and 24% for solar-power equipment

item.title: U.S. Ramping Up Wind Power Programs Even As Concerns Surface About Possible Declines In U.S. Wind Strength
item.description: Just as the United States is boosting its reliance on wind power, a new academic study set for release in August says that U.S. wind forces may be getting weaker. ...The findings come at time when the United States is making a serious push to increase the amount of electricity that's generated by wind turbines grouped into so-called wind-power "farms." Attempts to harness the wind are part of a broader national - or even global - commitment to "green" energy sources as a way of reducing dependence on oil and other fossil fuels for power generation.

item.title: Siemens Sees $21 Billion Worth of Orders for 2010-2012
item.description:
Siemens said on June 22 that it expects around 15 billion euros (US$21 billion) in orders worldwide between 2010-2012 thanks to government economic stimulus plans.
Roughly 40% of that figure would concern environmental or "green" technologies, the company said.

item.title: Lobbyists prove influential in RI energy debate
item.description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) - As Rhode Island moves to expand its renewable energy market, lobbyists at the Statehouse are finding the debate provides a different form of green power: cash.

item.title: Senate Committee Passes Legislation as RES Coalition Formed
item.description: In a 15-8 vote, the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee passed energy legislation that includes a renewable electricity standard (RES) of 15% by 2021, with states allowed to fulfill up to 4% of the requirement through energy efficiency measures.

item.title: EU conditionally okays Vattenfall's buy of Nuon
item.description:
