BRUSSELS, June 22 (Reuters) - Swedish energy group Vattenfall won conditional EU regulatory approval on Monday for its 10.3 billion euro ($14.27 billion) acquisition of Nuon after it agreed to sell the Dutch utility's retail units in Germany.
'Vattenfall agreed to this divestment to remedy competition concerns the Commission had in relation to retail supplies of electricity to small commercial and domestic customers in Hamburg and Berlin,' the European Commission said in a statement.

item.title: National Grid report says it can handle variable wind power
item.description: The variability of renewable energy sources such as wind, often cited as the sector’s Achilles’ heel, does not have to be a problem, according to a new report from the National Grid

item.title: EWEA's opinion: Make way for an accelerating clean, green economy
item.description:
Yet another study shows that a shift away from traditional polluting jobs to those that fall into the so-called low carbon category is already occurring and will help Europe battle its way out of the current recession.
Called ‘Low carbon jobs for Europe’, the WWF publication released last week indicates that about 3.4 million jobs in Europe are related directly to renewable energies, sustainable transportation and energy efficient goods and services, compared with 2.8 million jobs in polluting industries like mining, electricity, gas, cement, iron and steel

item.title: A-Power Energy Generation Systems Ltd. Announces Pricing of $40 Million Senior Convertible Notes
item.description: SHENYANG, China /PRNewswire-Asia-FirstCall/ -- A-Power Energy Generation Systems, Ltd. (Nasdaq: APWR; "A-Power" or "the Company"), a leading provider of distributed power generation systems in China and a fast-growing manufacturer of wind turbines, today announced it has signed a Securities Purchase Agreement with several institutional investors. The institutional investors have agreed to purchase Senior Convertible Notes with an aggregate principal amount of $40 million, plus warrants. The Company anticipates using the proceeds for expansion of production capacity, enhancement of research and development, and general corporate purposes.

item.title: Funds scarce for alternative energy projects
item.description: At one point last year, renewable energy advocate Burton Hamner envisioned 90 wind turbines and wave energy converters up and down the coast from Ocean Shores to Grayland.

item.title: Climate change bill to hit House floor this week
item.description: In a surprising development, House Democrats have reached an agreement to bring a sweeping climate change bill to the floor by the end of the week, Democratic aides announced late Monday night.

item.title: Sinovel develops 3MW offshore wind turbine
item.description:
On Dec 12, 2008, the Sinovel Wind Co Ltd and the China Renewable Energy Scale-up Program (CRESP) Management Office signed the CRESP Wind Turbine Technology Transfer (WTTT) Subcomponent Donation agreement.
The company applied for and secured financial support from the World Bank to research, produce, install, test and certify a 3MW offshore wind turbine system, in a bid to bridge the gap in China's wind energy sector. The company is also seeking to conform with a national initiative aimed at encouraging the development of large-MW wind power turbines and the establishment of a number of offshore wind farms.

item.title: Siemens aims for RMB 20 bln in contracts from China
item.description: Siemens AG, Europe's largest engineering conglomerate, said on Monday that it expects to sign RMB 20 billion worth of new contracts in China, eyeing the RMB 4-trillion stimulus package funds that will be spent during the next three fiscal years, the Shanghai Daily reported.

item.title: Can Wind Power Get Up to Speed?
item.description: A new study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science (PNAS) says yes. A team led by Michael McElroy at Harvard University assessed the global capacity for wind power — the total amount of sheer energy that's being carried on the breeze — and found that current technology could harness enough power to supply more than 40 times the planet's present-day levels of electricity consumption

item.title: Brussels clears RWE takeover of Essent
item.description: European antitrust officials gave a green light to the acquisition of Holland’s Essent by German power utility RWE, but subject to a divestment to address competition concerns in Germany’s wholesale electricity and gas markets

item.title: Wind energy race on as feds grant first offshore leases
item.description: WASHINGTON — The federal government on Tuesday issued its first exploratory leases for wind energy projects on the Outer Continental Shelf, the first step of what could be a race to harness the powerful Atlantic winds not far from major population centers on the East Coast.

item.title: Fairfield Introduces Complete Line of High-Torque Jack-Up Drives
item.description: Fairfield recently introduced their new line of High-Torque Jack-Up drives at the May 2009 Offshore Technology Conference, held at Reliant Park in Houston, TX.

item.title: Engineers call for halt to wind farm investment
item.description: A new report from the Academy of Engineering will today call for a halt to investment in wind farms and power interconnections because of the huge cost it will place on industry.

item.title: China commits to offshore renewable energy
item.description: China is planning to construct a number of 10 GW wind power bases in the coming years, in a bid to further boost the development of the country's renewable energy industry, the country's top energy official said recently

item.title: AESO issues RFP for Wind Power Forecasting Service in Alberta
item.description: The Alberta Electric System Operator (AESO) has issued a Request for Proposal (RFP) for a centralized wind power forecasting service in Alberta as part of its continuing efforts to integrate more wind power into Alberta's Interconnected Electric System.

item.title: Wind, Backup Power and Emissions
item.description: More than 8,300 MW of wind plants were installed last year, comprising about 42 percent of all new electric capacity added in 2008. Nevertheless, myths continue to persist about wind, including that wind does not reduce fossil fuel use and associated emissions and, related to that, myths about the need for "backup power" from fossil fuel power plants. In reality, each megawatt-hour (MWh) produced by a wind plant replaces a MWh that would have been produced by another power plant.

item.title: Dudgeon Offshore Wind gears up for construction and operation
item.description: Dudgeon Offshore Wind Limited (DOW), a subsidiary of Warwick Energy Limited, has applied for offshore consents to construct and operate its proposed Dudgeon offshore wind farm.

item.title: Wood Group awarded Sheringham Shoal wind farm contract
item.description: Wood Group Engineering (North Sea) Ltd., a subsidiary of international energy services company John Wood Group Plc, has been awarded the design and project management of two offshore substations by AREVA T&D on the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm.

item.title: Econcern enters UK crown estate round 3 bid
item.description: Econcern, the dedicated sustainable energy solutions company, has entered the UK Crown Estate Round 3 (R3) offshore licensing process.

item.title: Nexans wins 12 million Euro infield cable contract for Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: Nexans, the worldwide leader in the cable industry, has been awarded a 12 million Euro contract by the Norwegian Groups StatoilHydro ASA and Statkraft for the supply of 81 km of infield cables and equipment for the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm.

item.title: EnBW Acquires Four Offshore Wind Projects
item.description: Utility company Energie Baden-Wuerttemberg AG (EnBW) has acquired offshore wind farm companies Eos Offshore AG and Offshore Ostsee Wind AG. Both companies are subsidiaries of wpd offshore GmbH and hold the rights to offshore wind developments.

item.title: China’s Wind Turbine Bidding Process Unfair, Say Foreign Firms
item.description: Foreign manufacturers say they are being unfairly excluded from competing for state renewable energy projects resulting from China’s economic stimulus package

item.title: Siemens plans wind plant for North Sea market
item.description: Germany's Siemens (Xetra: 723610 - news) is studying building an offshore wind turbine assembly plant in one of four European countries around the North Sea, the chief executive of Siemens Wind Power said on Wednesday.

item.title: WinWinD Appoints Ilkka Hakala as its Group CEO
item.description: WinWinD the technology leaders engaged in the design, manufacture and supply of wind turbines for the global wind energy market announced the appointment of Mr. Ilkka Hakala as the Group Chief Executive Officer of WinWinD.

item.title: Leases awarded for windmills studies off NJ, Del.
item.description: The federal government has given permission to four companies to start exploring whether wind off the coast of New Jersey and Delaware can be harnessed to make electricity.

item.title: EDF funds 30 megawatts of offshore wind in Belgium
item.description: France’s EDF Energies Nouvelles has commissioned a first round of bond funding to cover 30 megawatts of development (EDF) at the Thorntonbank offshore wind farm being built in Belgium.

item.title: Windfarm could bring jobs to Wells
item.description:
Work could soon begin on improvements to Wells har-bour which would help the town cash in on a £1bn wind-farm being built off the coast.
Wells is the preferred operational base for the Sheringham Shoal project, with 88 turbines due to power the equivalent of 220,000 homes by the end of 2011.

item.title: Gamesa, Vestas in race to buy Suzlon stake in Hansen
item.description: MUMBAI: Spanish wind turbine maker Gamesa and Vestas of Denmark are in the race to acquire London-listed Hansen Transmissions from Pune-based Suzlon Energy. A person close to the deal said Tulsi Tanti-controlled Suzlon, the world’s fifth-largest and India’s biggest turbine maker, is expected to seal the deal by this weekend.

item.title: Dong to acquire Danish offshore services firm A2SEA
item.description: Dong Energy says it will spend DKK700m ($131m) to purchase fellow Danish firm A2SEA, one of the few major players in the booming offshore-service sector for wind farms, as it seeks to streamline and “industrialise” its offshore wind operations.

item.title: EDP Says More U.S. States Are Now Attractive for Wind Energy
item.description: EDP-Energias de Portugal SA, the owner of wind farms from New York to Oregon, said more U.S. states are offering investment opportunities for wind power development as local governments encourage renewable energy.

item.title: Dong Energy buys A2SEA
item.description: DONG Energy buys A2SEA for app. DKK 700 mill. from Dansk Kapitalanlæg, Lønmodtagernes Dyrtidsfond, Clipper projects and a serie of minor shareholders

item.title: Better energy grid would help Europe cut carbon
item.description: A truly pan-European energy market, with the grid infrastructure to support it, would make renewables a more attractive investment and help bring down the continent's carbon footprint.

item.title: Businesses should go for wind farm cash
item.description: Businesses have been urged to cash-in on a new green energy building boom off the East Anglian coast after ministers put billions of pounds of windfarm contracts up for grabs.

item.title: UK Finalizes Plans for 25 GW of Wind and Opens $24.7 Billion Grid Tender
item.description:
The UK government has cast in stone a plan to install 25GW of offshore wind capacity by 2020, paving the way for the Crown Estate to proceed with its round three call for developers of farms.
This accompanied news that the government's GBP 15 billion ($24.7 billion) tender to build power cables connecting offshore farms to the grid in conjunction with regulator Ofgem, was officially open

item.title: Offshore wind farms could meet a quarter of the UK's electricity needs
item.description: Offshore wind has the potential to power every home in the UK and provide up to 70,000 jobs, according to the government

item.title: East Coast Governors Say National Transmission Grid Limits Local Energy
item.description: On May 4th, 2009, Governors from 10 East Coast states sent a sign-on letter opposing the current House & Senate bills to expedite transmission line planning and siting. The states that signed onwere Virginia, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Delaware, Maine, Maryland, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont.

item.title: Havgul to sell Havsul I offshore wind farm
item.description: Havgul AS has today announced that it has contracted to sell the projected wind farm Havsul I, which is due to be built off the northwest coast of Norway at Sandøy, Møre og Romsdal, to Vestavind Kraft AS.

item.title: Masdar to launch clean-tech fund
item.description: Masdar, Abu Dhabi’s renewable energy initiative, plans to launch a new clean-technology fund this year with capital of at least $250m as it seeks out investment opportunities created by the global economic turmoil.

item.title: Gamesa denies interest in making bid for Hansen
item.description: Spanish wind turbine manufacturer Gamesa says that it is not interested in acquiring Belgian gearbox maker Hansen Transmission from India’s Suzlon.

item.title: Rhode Island law mandates renewable energy use
item.description: Rhode Island's governor signed a law Friday that requires the state's largest electric utility to buy power from renewable energy producers, a move intended to smooth the way for what could be the first offshore wind farm in the United States.

item.title: The Odd Couple: Renewables and Transmission
item.description: The tension between the growing number of renewable energy projects and limited transmission capacity is reflected in Washington’s legislative agenda of establishing a national renewable portfolio standard and new transmission lines dedicated to moving renewable energy coast-to-coast. Even if those ideas become law, hurdles to the happy marriage of renewables and transmission remain.

item.title: Consultant: Wind turbine prices fall 18% globally
item.description: Prices for wind turbines have fallen 18 percent globally since the renewable energy industry slumped with the recession, a consulting firm reported Monday.

item.title: 7 wind power bases to be set up by 2020
item.description: China plans to build seven wind power bases with a minimum capacity of 10 gigawatts (gW) each by 2020, in a move to dramatically increase the use of the clean energy. ... Besides onshore wind power, which has seen rapid growth in China, the country has also started to develop offshore wind power projects. China is now building its first offshore wind power project, the Shanghai Donghai Offshore Wind Farm, which is also the first offshore project outside Europe

item.title: QDC OKs 10-year leases for Deepwater
item.description: Deepwater Wind has agreed to lease 117 acres in the Quonset Business Park to use as a staging area for its $1.5-billion proposal to install more than 100 wind turbines off the Rhode Island coast.

item.title: Vestas Offshore Sets its Sights on China
item.description: Vestas, the global wind energy leader, intends to play an active role in China’s offshore wind energy sector, as underlined by being the lead sponsor of Offshore Wind China 2009 Conference and Exhibition

item.title: Fair Play
item.description: China reassures foreign companies they are still welcome to invest in government-funded projects

item.title: Seajacks vessels contracted by Dong for wind farm work
item.description: Seajacks has been awarded a contract from Dong Energy A/S for the provision of liftboats Seajacks Leviathan and Seajacks Kraken for installation of wind turbines on the Walney 1 and Walney 2 wind farms in the Irish Sea.

item.title: Asian eyes on Centrica wind farm
item.description: A super-rich Asian businessman is reported to be looking at buying at stake in a recently built UK offshore wind farm.

item.title: Ofgem Regime Will Open Way to Investment in Offshore Wind Power
item.description: Ofgem and the Department of Energy and Climate Change have unveiled the finalised regime for regulating the undersea networks and other infrastructure that will carry power from offshore wind farms.

item.title: Hochtief Construction builds new head-quarters for Nordex
item.description: Hochtief Construction has concluded a long-term lease agreement with Nordex for a new office building: The Hochtief subsidiary is expected to complete the new headquarters for the wind turbine manufacturer by the end of 2010 on the grounds of the former Ochsenzoll hospital in Hamburg

item.title: GE Energy Supports Swedish Renewables Investment
item.description: Total Supply of 57 2.5xl Wind Turbines to Arise Windpower Marks First Use of GE’s Most Advanced Wind Technology in the Nordic Region

item.title: ACCIONA becomes the first Spanish company to create a Sustainability Committee
item.description: ACCIONA’s Board of Director’s has given the official go ahead for the creation of a Sustainability Committee whose responsibility it will be to orientate and supervise the Company’s Social Responsibility policy, based on a commitment to sustainability.

item.title: Nordex moving its headquarters to a new administrative building
item.description: Nordex AG is making further preparations for its continued business growth. The producer of wind turbines has now successfully completed all the preparations for the construction of its new headquarters in the Langenhorn suburb of Hamburg.

item.title: Charles Kleekamp: Offshore wind: Europe surges, U.S. dawdles
item.description: IMAGINE A renewable-energy source so large it can provide enough power for 750,000 homes, or a quarter of all homes in London, especially when the fuel is free. It’s called the London Array, and when built it will be the world’s largest offshore wind farm.

item.title: Wind power geared for investment
item.description: China's ambitious plan to increase wind power capacity could attract up to US$150 billion (HK$1.17 trillion) in investment, but the central government will have to get serious about revamping regulations and building much needed infrastructure.

item.title: ANALYSIS - China wind companies poised for green policy boost
item.description:
China's ambitious plan to increase wind power capacity could attract up to $150 billion in investment, but Beijing will have to get serious about revamping regulations and building much needed infrastructure.
China is set to raise its wind power capacity to 100 gigawatts (GW) by 2020, eight times its current level and more than Britain's entire current power capacity, as part of a stimulus package aimed at boosting renewable energy.

item.title: Vestas Offshore to open office in China this year
item.description: Denmark's Vestas Wind Systems is sponsoring a major offshore wind energy conference and exhibition in China and plans to open an 'offshore' office this year

item.title: Wind-Turbine Orders Fell 50% in First Half of 2009, MAKE Says
item.description: Wind turbine makers around the world reported 50 percent fewer orders in the first half of 2009 than a year earlier and the market won’t improve until the last three months of the year, an industry consultant said.

item.title: Thornton Bank Offshore Project Officially Commissioned
item.description: Thornton Bank, Belgium's first offshore wind farm, has been officially inaugurated

item.title: RWE receives permission to build Tromp Binnen wind farm
item.description: RWE Innogy received permission from the Dutch Ministry of Transport and Hydraulic Engineering (Rijkswaterstaat) to build the Tromp Binnen offshore wind farm.

item.title: Obama's green energy drive may hamper Scotland
item.description:
Barack Obama's drive to boost renewable energy in the US poses a serious threat to Scotland's ambitions of becoming a world leader in the supply of green electricity.
That was the caution from Nick Horler, chief executive of ScottishPower, at a seminar in Edinburgh where he also warned that Scottish household bills must rise to pay for electricity grid improvements to cope with more renewable generation.

item.title: US issues exploratory leases for offshore wind
item.description: The USA has reached a new milestone in the development of its renewable energy industry by issuing leases to investigate the offshore wind power potential in two northeastern states

item.title: Gorleston offshore firm wins contract
item.description:
A GORLESTON offshore engineering firm has secured its biggest contract to date to put up wind turbines in the Irish Sea.
The deal with Dong Energy will see Seajacks earn up to $79m (£48m) for 15 months' work on the Walney 1 and Walney 2 windfarms.

item.title: Land work starts on offshore windfarm
item.description:
After five years of planning, a brief funding crisis and objections from the Ministry of Defence, work on a £1bn north Norfolk wind farm has at last begun.
Workers have started onshore preparations for the massive cable which will transport the energy created by the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm's 88 turbines, situated 17km off the coast.

item.title: Wind Paces New EU Power Projects
item.description: Wind energy outpaced all other forms of new electricity-generating capacity built in the European Union in 2008, the European Wind Energy Association said in a report released

item.title: Nordic Windpower Offered $16 Million DOE Loan Guarantee to Expand its US Wind Turbine Production
item.description:
Nordic Windpower USA, Inc. announced today that it has received a conditional commitment for a $16 million loan guarantee offer from the US Department of.
Energy (DOE), supported through the 2009 American Recovery and Reinvestment Act. Nordic is among the first companies to receive the DOE’s loan guarantee offer. The company, based in Berkeley, CA, will use funds from the US Federal Financing Bank to support the expansion of its assembly plant in Pocatello, Idaho.

item.title: European Renewable Grid Initiative Launched
item.description: Non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and transmission system operators (TSOs) have joined forces to create The Renewables-Grid-Initiative (RGI), which demands a new mandate for energy regulators to enable the development of a European grid architecture capable of rapidly and efficiently transmitting renewable energies.

item.title: Minister - Offshore wind could power 20m homes
item.description: The UK has the potential to generate an extra 25GW of offshore wind energy on top of the 8GW that is already planned - providing enough power for 20 million homes and supporting up to 70,000 new jobs.

item.title: Crown Estate to extend existing offshore wind leases to 50 years
item.description:
The Crown Estate yesterday announced that it is willing to extend leases for offshore wind farm developers to up to 50 years, ending uncertainty over the future of some of the UK's older offshore wind developments.
The initial Round One wind farms were originally granted 22-year leases, the first of which are due to expire in the early 2020s, while the Round Two sites with a capacity of less than 500MW that are currently being built have leases lasting 40 years.

item.title: Boltight Introduces New Foundation/Base Bolt Tensioner For The Wind Industry
item.description: Specialist bolt tensioner manufacturer Boltight Ltd. has designed a new range of hydraulic bolt tensioners called Tempest specifically for wind turbine base and foundation bolts.

item.title: 25GW Wind Power connection 'to cost £10.4bn'
item.description: Meeting ambitious targets to harness wind energy in the UK will cost some £10.4bn just to connect to the grid, according to the government.

item.title: Bard Group names special ship
item.description: The wind farm Bard Offshore 1 can come. In Lithuania, the construction vessel Windlift 1 has been launched. Bard has thus completed the infrastructure for series erection of offshore wind farms.

item.title: Npower sees Welsh offshore wind farm start this week
item.description: Npower Renewables expects to start producing the first electricity from its 90-megawatt Rhyl Flats offshore wind farm in north Wales this week, a company executive said on Wednesday

item.title: THE CROWN ESTATE REPORTS ON ITS PERFORMANCE IN SCOTLAND
item.description: The Crown Estate has announced today, a gross surplus for its Scottish estates of £15.5 million for the year ending 31 March 2009, compared to £11.4 million in the previous year. This represents 6.4% of The Crown Estate’s total gross surplus of £243.2 million for the UK as a whole. The surplus goes towards public spending for the benefit of all UK taxpayers.

item.title: U.K. Crown Estate Bets Wind Output Will Boost Revenue
item.description: The Crown Estate, the state agency that manages the British monarchy’s commercial real estate, is betting the U.K.’s drive for alternative energy will boost its revenue as bigger wind farms are built on its marine territory.

item.title: Subsea power lines should be considered instead of Beauly to Denny pylons
item.description: For CBI Scotland to support the Beauly to Denny power line, apparently without condition, demonstrates myopic and lamentable short-termism. The Scottish Government is rightly promoting the potential for Scotland to exploit renewable sources of electricity generation in Scotland, particularly from on- and offshore wind turbines, and wave sources. John Swinney, the Finance Secretary, in launching the Renewable Action Plan last week, said the "pace of change requires a constantly evolving framework". Every effort should be encouraged to support and exploit opportunities to develop a long-term industrial base to harvest these natural resources.

item.title: Council of Ministers OKs funds for renewables
item.description: The EU Council of Ministers has approved a long-awaited energy stimulus package, after months of political quarrels with the European Parliament over whether to focus the funds on fossil fuels or renewable energy.

item.title: Pickens's pullback could signal shift in the wind
item.description: Oil billionaire T. Boone Pickens's step back from his plan to build the world's largest wind farm in Texas shows how a brutal recession could change the way the United States invests in renewable energy.

item.title: Greater Gabbard gets going
item.description: Utility Scottish and Southern Energy says it is getting ready to start construction of its Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm towards the end of this year in partnership with RWE npower.

item.title: World's Largest Windfarm London Array Uses 4Projects
item.description: 4Projects Ltd are celebrating after London Array Limited elected to deploy 4Projects' award-winning web-based collaboration tool on the world's largest offshore windfarm – London Array – in the Thames Estuary.

item.title: U.S. Adds Wind Farms, But Transmission Infrastructure Lags
item.description: The U.S. gets a solid “B” for its 2008 progress toward reaching the 20 percent of electricity supply from wind energy by 2030, but only a C- grade for its transmission efforts, according to the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA). AWEA is calling for a strong and immediate national policy commitment to renewable energy to meet the “20% Wind” commitment by 2030

item.title: New Renewables Grid Initiative touts for more members
item.description: The newly formed European Renewables Grid Initiative has confirmed it is looking to recruit further members from across the continent's energy sector as it seeks to bolster its lobbying efforts.

item.title: Study: significant opportunity for Canada wind exports
item.description: A recent study by Massachusetts-based Power Advisory LLC, commissioned by the Canadian Wind Energy Association (CanWEA), has found potential for wind energy exports from the Maritime Provinces to the United States northeast.

item.title: 20% WIND REPORT CARD: B OVERALL, TRANSMISSION LAGS AT C-
item.description: The U.S. gets a solid “B” for its 2008 progress toward reaching 20% of electricity supply from wind energy by 2030, but could be “at the high-water mark” for wind without a strong and immediate national policy commitment to renewable energy, the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) said today.

item.title: Myth of wind variability problems debunked - report
item.description: A Greenpeace-commissioned report into the energy-generating potential of wind in the UK claims to debunk the myth of ‘variability of supply’.

item.title: Centrica and npower set to green light huge offshore wind farm projects
item.description: Centrica and RWE npower are close to signing off on two huge offshore wind farms costing an estimated £3bn to build in further signs that the logjam holding up offshore projects is easing. It follows a government announcement in April to increase subsidies available for offshore wind projects, which are crucial for the UK to have any hope of meeting its 2020 renewable targets

item.title: Cable layers unearth historic sites
item.description: Archaeologists have found a number of previously unknown sites of historic interest thanks to investigative trench work along the route of an onshore cable route for an offshore wind farm. The onshore side of the operation to build the 315 megawatt Sheringham Shoal wind farm will see a 13 mile long cable laid between Weybourne and Salle, near Reepham.

item.title: Ofgem drops Scots energy 'tax'
item.description: PUNITIVE charges that would have seen Scottish green energy companies paying out ten times more to get their electricity to the national grid have been dropped by the UK power regulator. Ofgem has been considering changing the way it charges power companies to access the electricity grid.

item.title: Wind Projects at a Standstill
item.description: The Obama administration has made offshore wind energy a priority and an important part of its plans to create jobs and combat climate change, but even such favorable political breezes have not been strong enough to propel the nation's first projects. The economy has intervened, and an unfamiliar federal approval process could hold up leading projects.

item.title: E.ON to study Humber Estuary wind farm
item.description: E.ON will investigate the potential for a wind farm in the Humber Estuary by installing an anemometry mast. The mast, used to measure wind speeds and other offshore environmental data, will be around 85 meters (278 ft) in height and is due to be installed 7 kilometers (4.4 miles) off the Holderness Coast

item.title: The power struggle
item.description: Any strategy to generate 15% of Britain's energy from renewable sources by 2020 will create some dissent, but the lobbying in advance of this week's white paper is dispiriting evidence of why Britain lags behind most of Europe in renewable energy.

item.title: Mitsubishi Corporation and ACCIONA sign an international strategic alliance focused on sustainability
item.description: Mitsubishi Corporation, the Japanese general trading company (sogo shosha), and ACCIONA, the Spanish leader in renewable energies, infrastructure and water services, have signed a strategic alliance to develop and operate renewable energy projects and share innovation aimed at leading the development of sustainable solutions worldwide

item.title: Chinese Wind Power Developments
item.description:
The construction of the Shanghai East Sea Bridge Wind Power Plant has marked a good start for development of the country's offshore wind power generation.
The first set of 34 wind power turbines for the country's first offshore wind power farm began the construction in March this year. The $336.56 million project is expected to generate 267 GWh of electricity annually, and will supply clean power to the 2010 World Expo in Shanghai.

item.title: Major European Wind Turbine Manufacturer Signs Agreement to Supply Wild Brush With up to $200 Million in Turbines
item.description: Wild Brush Energy has signed a Letter of Intent with major Scandinavian wind turbine manufacturer WinWinD Oy of Finland. This agreement outlines WinWinD's commitment to supplying Wild Brush Energy with up to $200 million in turbines.

item.title: Investing in the Smart Grid
item.description: Our current electrical grid system is ill suited to handle the variability of new sources of electrical power. Solving the transition to new power sources is only half the battle. After generating the power, you need to distribute it to where it is needed at the right time, in the right amounts and at a lower cost.

item.title: EDF Energy welcomes CBI report on energy policy
item.description: EDF Energy welcomed the publication today of the CBI’s Energy Report which provides an independent assessment of the UK’s prospects for low-carbon, secure, affordable energy. The report analyses the impact of the current energy policy framework on likely investment decisions, and the impact these decisions will have on energy bills and climate change.

item.title: CBI: 'Let's cut back on wind power'
item.description: There's too much emphasis on wind power in the government's plans to combat climate change, the Confederation of British Industry has said. instead, there should be a greater emphasis on nuclear power and so-called 'clean coal'. However, Greenpeace has said that nuclear power is less effective than wind power at tackling global warming.

item.title: Iberdrola Renovables hopes to secure $400-500 million in government aid over the coming months
item.description: The US Department of the Treasury yesterday announced an estimated minimum of $3 billion for the development of renewable energy projects. IBERDROLA RENOVABLES, the world’s leading wind energy company(1), (through its US subsidiary IBERDROLA RENEWABLES), plans to start up and bring on stream some 850 MW of wind energy installations this year for commercial purposes, which could be eligible for $400-500 million in Treasury aid over the coming months. The grants must be put to use solely in the US.

item.title: DONG Energy soon to inaugurate Horns Rev 2 offshore wind farm
item.description: Denmark's leading energy concern DONG Energy expects to inaugurate the 91-turbine Horns Rev 2 offshore wind farm, which will generate 209 MW, in mid-September

item.title: JDR opens new manufacturinge facility at Hartlepool
item.description: JDR Cable Systems celebrated the opening of its new deepwater quayside facility at Hartlepool dock in North East England The new purpose-built state-of-the-art 100,000 sq ft facility incorporates two 2,200 tonne carousels and is the only site in the UK designed specifically to manufacture subsea power cables for the oil and gas sector and the burgeoning offshore renewables market. The location at Hartlepool dock allows the cables to be spooled directly onto cable-laying vessels.

item.title: Number of wind turbines to quadruple under Renewable Energy Strategy
item.description: Ministers have put wind power at the heart of a Renewable Energy Strategy, which is due to be released on Wednesday. It will outline how Britain is to meet its target of a 34 per cent cut in CO2 emissions by 2020

item.title: It's time to stand up to the energy giants
item.description: Against the backdrop of the worldwide economic downturn, it is ironic that the area often said to have the least business certainty, the renewables sector, is one of the few success stories. Globally this industry is bucking the trends, creating millions of new green jobs, increasing countries' energy independence and reducing climate-changing emissions. So it is scandalous that the CBI should come out attacking the prime minister and the climate change secretary Ed Miliband's commitment to boosting this industry in Britain just days before the launch of a fresh government initiative.

item.title: U.S. to press China on tariffs on clean energy trade
item.description: The United States will press China this week to lower its tariffs on clean energy technology as one of many steps the two countries can take to fight global warming, U.S. officials said on Monday.

item.title: First Offshore Wind for Germany Germany goes offshore: EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall have
item.description: Germany has its first offshore wind turbine: the consortium of EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall, DOTI (Deutsche Offshore- Testfeld und Infrastruktur GmbH), has successfully completed construction today of the first of a total of 12 wind turbines for the alpha ventus offshore wind farm in the North Sea. A team of 50 specialists are on location at the open sea construction site. The 5-megawatt turbine is situated 45 kilometres north of the island of Borkum. All 12 turbines are scheduled to be in operation by the end of this year, making alpha ventus the first offshore wind farm in German waters. 250 millions euros have been invested in this pioneering project. The power produced annually by alpha ventus will meet the energy needs of 50,000 households.

item.title: Port attracts another wind turbine company
item.description: Spanish-based Gamesa Corp. will be the seventh wind turbine manufacturer to ship its products to the U.S. via the Port of Corpus Christi. The first vessel is expected mid-August.

item.title: Dutch Eneco acquires Ecostream
item.description: Eneco Holding N.V. in the Netherlands will take over the activities of Ecostream, the German solar company. Until now Ecostream was part of the Econcern group, which became insolvent at the end of May. With Eneco as the new owner Ecostream will be able to continue its business as usual.

item.title: E.ON CEO: 'It's now or never if we're to win the fight against climate change'
item.description: Energy company E.ON has today (WED) welcomed the Government's energy White Paper but stressed that, if the fight against climate change is to be won, the right framework needs to be in place and everyone has to take responsibility for that fight.

item.title: REpower and Vattenfall sign 150 megawatt contract for offshore wind farm off the British Isles
item.description: REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703) and Ormonde Energy Limited (OEL), a subsidiary of Vattenfall AB, concluded an agreement today on the supply of 30 REpower 5M offshore wind energy turbines with a total rated output of 150 megawatts. For REpower, this is the largest offshore agreement to date for the UK. The turbines are intended for the Ormonde wind farm, on which construction is to begin at the start of 2011 around 35 kilometers away from the town of Barrow-in-Furness on the northwest coast of England.

item.title: Rhyl Flats wind farm first power export delayed by bad weather
item.description: Plans for the commercial start up of RWE npower's Rhyl Flats offshore windfarm, have been delayed by bad weather.

item.title: Government finally takes control of renewables drive
item.description:
The government has today announced it will intervene directly to accelerate the rollout of renewable and low-carbon technologies as part of its wide-ranging Low Carbon Transition Plan.
Presenting the new strategy to the House of Commons, energy and climate change secretary Ed Miliband said that he would exercise powers in the Energy Act that allow the government to take direct control over the grid access regime that manages how renewables projects are connected to the grid.

item.title: Deepwater Wind to get permits for data-collecting equipment
item.description: The state Coastal Resources Management Council is set to issue permits to Deepwater Wind to install a meteorological tower and other equipment on Block Island and in nearby waters to collect weather data for the company’s proposed offshore wind farms.

item.title: Climate change billions have yet to yield any gold
item.description: Despite Ed Milliband's boasts, clean energy investments from the likes of Virgin and HSBC have bombed over the past 12 months

item.title: Wind farm boom for Crown Estate over green expansion
item.description: The Crown Estate, which handles the Queen's property empire, is to spearhead a multi-million pound scheme to build offshore wind farms. It will choose its partner companies next month from among more than 100 energy groups that have applied for licences to build turbines in the North Sea.

item.title: New Study Sheds Light on the Growing U.S. Wind Power Market
item.description: For the fourth consecutive year, the U.S. was home to the fastest-growing wind power market in the world in 2008, according to a report released by the U.S. Department of Energy and prepared by Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (Berkeley Lab).

item.title: DOE to fund 28 new wind energy projects
item.description: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has selected 28 new wind energy projects for up to US$13.8 million in funding, including US$12.8 million in Recovery Act funds. These projects will help address market and deployment challenges including wind turbine research and testing and transmission analysis, planning and assessments.

item.title: UK-London: electricity distribution and related services
item.description:
Title attributed to the contract by the contracting authority: First tender round for the grant of offshore transmission licences for transitional projects (first transitional tender round). This is a voluntary OJEU notice and the process followed will not correspond to any process stipulated by the Public Contract Regulations 2006.
The subject matter of this OJEU Notice is the proposed grant of a number of offshore transmission licences to successful bidders for the purposes of connecting a number of wind farms to the GB onshore grid. Britain already has more offshore wind power than any country in the world – and the UK government plans to increase this significantly by 2020.

item.title: Wind turbine protest: 'The company is only out to make profit'
item.description: Steven Morris speaks to one of the workers occupying the Vestas wind turbine factory in Newport, Isle of Wight, who claims the company is not living up to green values

item.title: Nordex To Start Building Arkansas Wind Turbine Production Plant
item.description: Nordex USA Inc. will begin construction this week on its first U.S. manufacturing plant in Jonesboro, Arkansas. The announcement comes after a decision by the supervisory board of the parent company, Nordex AG

item.title: Workers at wind turbine factory stage sit-in protest
item.description: Workers at a wind turbine factory on the Isle of Wight have staged a sit-in protest over its imminent closure

item.title: China wind turbine makers blow over foreign rivals
item.description: Overseas companies fall out of top three suppliers as Chinese firms take dominant market share

item.title: Scotland to Japan: Join us for low-carbon future
item.description: Scotland’s Cabinet Secretary for Finance and Sustainable Growth is inviting Japanese companies and universities to work with their Scottish counterparts to find new ways to meet renewable energy goals, move toward a low-carbon economy and tackle climate change.

item.title: China has shown it can build wind farms, but can it connect them economically to the grid?
item.description: Seeking to rein in its emissions of greenhouse gases, China is on an ambitious spending spree in wind power. The government is working on plans to shell out 1 trillion yuan ($146 billion) to build seven massive wind farms with a combined capacity of more than 120 gigawatts, roughly equal to the world's total installed wind power plants last year.

item.title: Rhode Island tweaks renewable energy law
item.description: An amendment to a state renewable energy law is expected to encourage wind and solar power by making it easier for projects to be paid when they produce more electricity than they use.

item.title: London Array seeks loan from EU Investment Bank
item.description: The consortium developing the London Array offshore wind project has submitted an application for a £1bn ($1.6bn) loan from the European Investment Bank (EIB) as it looks to give itself a broad range of financing options.

item.title: Smoke-Choked China’s $585 Billion Stimulus Lifts ABB
item.description: Three years after passing the U.S. to become the world’s biggest air polluter, China is attracting green energy technology, driving profit at Western power-grid builders as their home markets slump

item.title: Wind power plan blown off course
item.description: Closure of turbine factory undermines Government's green pledges

item.title: New partnership to advance wind-power technology
item.description: It is predicted that wind energy could provide as much as 13 per cent of global electricity demand in 2020 and as much as 25 per cent in 2030. A partnership announced today [Wednesday 22 July] aims to advance wind-power technology using composite materials.

item.title: Iberdrola hit by fall in demand
item.description: Iberdrolayesterday revealed a 23 drop in first-half net profits, as Spain's biggest electricity group was hit by a sharp decline in domestic demand and prices combined with lower extraordinary income and negative currency factors

item.title: U.S. Lags in Global Clean Energy Technology Marketplace, Senate Panel Told
item.description: The U.S. Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works last week continued a series of hearings that assesses how proposed energy and climate change legislation could impact industry and economy. Last week’s hearing was titled, “Ensuring and Enhancing U.S. Competitiveness while Moving toward a Clean Energy Economy.”

item.title: IBERDROLA RENOVABLES POSTS FIRST HALF PROFIT OF €148.5 MILLION WITH LARGER CONTRIBUTION OF INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS
item.description:
IBERDROLA RENOVABLES, world leader in the wind power segment by installed capacity and output(1), posted a first half consolidated net profit of €148.5 million, down 23% on the same period in 2008, amid falling prices and a contraction in energy demand in Spain.
However, strong performance from international business –chiefly the United States business– and its greater contribution to earnings, drove a 6% advance in EBITDA to €581.6 million. In the US, wind business EBITDA grew 74.3%, while in the UK it advanced 65.3%. Operating cash flow grew 7% to €444.3 million.

item.title: PPG gears up for booming Asian wind energy market
item.description:
PPG Industries (NYSE: PPG), one of the world’s only suppliers of both fiber glass and coatings, showcased its latest fiber glass reinforcements, blade coatings, tower coatings and services for the wind energy market at Wind Power Asia 2009, the 6th Asian Wind Energy Exhibition and Conference, July 8-10, in the China International Exhibition Center (CIEC).
PPG’s advanced fiber glass and coatings technologies can enhance the efficiency, performance and longevity of key wind power generation components. The PPG wind energy team offers comprehensive technical expertise and global resources, providing in-depth knowledge and services relating to supply chain, high-performance materials, application equipment, the manufacturing process and chemicals management to help improve production efficiency.

item.title: Looking for 200 Gigawatts
item.description: The excellent summary of the ocean power scene by Peter Asmus in Issue 6 of the Energy Central Renewables Topic Center highlighted a number of matters that are of increasing importance as ocean power technology matures...

item.title: WindFloat project moves ahead
item.description: ABS in cooperation with its affiliated company ABS Consulting, has conducted a hazard identification study (HAZID) as the first step in the Preliminary Planning and Advice (PPA) stage for Principle Power's WindFloat, a novel floating support structure for large offshore wind turbines.

item.title: New GE Technology Boosts Wind Turbine Output, Increasing Revenue for Wind Farm Operators
item.description: GE Energy today introduced the WindBOOST™ control system upgrade, designed to increase the output of its 1.5sle wind turbine—one of the most widely used machines in the global wind industry—resulting in greater revenues for wind farm operators The WindBOOST™ control system upgrade enables the turbine blades to spin faster and can increase the turbine output by 100 kilowatts, from 1.5 to 1.6 megawatts. By generating more power from the same unit, turbine operators can increase their profitability. Depending on the wind and other site conditions, the new feature has the potential to increase annual revenues up to $15,000 per unit.

item.title: Police make more arrests at wind turbine factory protest
item.description: Two men detained outside Vestas plant on Isle of Wight as owners erect fence around site in response to demonstration against its closure

item.title: Global trend for sit-ins and occupations as mass redundancies continue
item.description: Trade union leaders warned tonight that the direct action seen at the Vestas factory was likely to be repeated elsewhere as workers refused to "bend their knee and accept their fate" in the face of mass redundancies caused by recession

item.title: Wind turbine makers seek suppliers
item.description: INDIANAPOLIS -- U.S. wind turbine manufacturers with large, experienced European parents are seeking long-term partnerships with American suppliers to provide turbine components.

item.title: EDF fined £2m for poor customer service
item.description: EDF Energy Networks is to be fined £2 million by regulator Ofgem for failing to connect new customers on time

item.title: China sets benchmark on-grid wind power rates
item.description: Chinese officials set benchmark tariffs for new wind projects on Friday, giving clarity to power producers in the world's top generator of greenhouse gases, but analysts said the move might be too little to lure new investment.

item.title: New Electricity 42% Wind Says DOE
item.description: Last year almost half the new electricity capacity added to the grid (42%) was wind power, according to Secretary Chu of the U.S. Department of Energy.

item.title: Wind firms given green energy grants
item.description: The government has announced a multi-million pound investment into offshore wind technology. Energy secretary Ed Miliband said that the £10m grant will help generate green jobs and develop Britain's role as the "leading country in the world for the generation of offshore wind". As part of the investment, the Vestas Wind Systems firm at the centre of a political dispute over jobs will receive £6m

item.title: Belwind offshore wind energy project secures financing
item.description: Financing has been secured for the construction and operation by Belwind of the 165MW first phase of the Bligh Bank offshore wind farm, located 47 km off the Belgian coast near Zeebrugge. ASN Bank, Dexia Bank Belgium and Dexia Crédit Local and Rabobank International will serve as mandated lead arrangers, and Rabobank and Participatie Maatschappij Vlaanderen as mezzanine lenders. The European Investment Bank will provide funding for an amount of €300m and is assuming, for the first time, project finance risk for an offshore wind farm.

item.title: Infrastructure woes hamper China wind farms' push for profitability
item.description: Chinese wind farm operators are struggling to earn a profit as a lack of wind resources and an insufficient power infrastructure has hampered efforts to provide clean energy to the grid.

item.title: Texas Taking Lead in Race for US’ First Offshore Wind Farm?
item.description: Texas start-up Baryonyx awarded two offshore wind energy leases

item.title: Government all at sea on wind power
item.description:
As ministers have sounded the fanfare for hundreds of thousands of “green jobs”, the demise of the Vestas wind turbine plant on the Isle of Wight has provided a mocking counterpoint.
The closure of one factory with the loss of 600 jobs does not in itself say much about the success or failure of the government’s strategy. However, the decision by Vestas is an uncomfortable reminder that the vision of a vibrant industry growing up to meet the challenge of cutting carbon dioxide emissions for Britain and the world is little more than an aspiration.

item.title: Offshore farms make waves in US
item.description:
The Cape Cod resort area, famous for sandy beaches and centuries-old fishing villages, could in the next few years claim a new title of home to the United States' first offshore wind farm.
The US experienced a surge in investment in wind power over the past four years, more than tripling its ability to turn wind into electricity. But construction has been entirely on land and largely in America's rural midsection – leaving open the costly challenge of how to transmit power to the densely populated coasts where it is most needed.

item.title: Vestas court action delayed until next week
item.description: MOVES aimed at ending an occupation of a wind turbine factory have been delayed until next week. Vestas Wind Systems was due to go to court to seek repossession of its plant on the Isle of Wight, which has been occupied by a group of 25 workers since last week. But the case was not heard and has been put back to next Tuesday.

item.title: RPT-Vestas says will shut UK wind turbine blade plant
item.description:
COPENHAGEN, July 28 (Reuters) - Danish wind turbine maker Vestas (VWS.CO) will go ahead with plans to close its blade factory on the Isle of Wight in Britain, the company said on Tuesday.
"As a result of the current market conditions in Northern Europe and the planning process in the UK, Vestas has decided not to move forward with its plans to convert the factory into the production of 44-metre blades," Vestas said in a statement

item.title: Alarming news for US market pull down Vestas stock
item.description: The shares in Vestas Wind Systems A/S (CPH: VWS) retracted after yesterday's report by the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) showed the Danish turbine maker as only the fourth largest player on the key US market in the second quarter of 2009

item.title: Government £1bn funding for wind power too late for Vestas jobs
item.description: As a standoff between police and protesters occupying the Vestas wind turbine factory moves into its second week the government has announced more than £1bn of funding for the wind power industry.

item.title: Britain's Old Industries See Renewable Boost
item.description: Across the UK traditional industries are turning their hand to renewable energy, seeing the potential the booming sector offers for the future.

item.title: Winds of change with standard fees - China
item.description:
CHINA has standardized tariffs for wind power projects to ensure profitability for the plants after a survey showed that some of them suffered losses.
The standard tariffs replace a public tendering system as the survey conducted by the nation's electricity regulator revealed that the wind power plants suffered low profit margins, or even losses, due to low utilization rates under the public bidding system.

item.title: Seajacks evaluating strategic alternatives
item.description: The Board of Directors of Seajacks International Ltd. has initiated a process to evaluate strategic alternatives available to the company.

item.title: PNE Wind Given Go-ahead for Gode Wind II Wind Farm
item.description: Wind-farm developer PNE Wind AG has been given the go-ahead for the "Gode Wind II" offshore wind-farm from the Federal Agency for Marine Shipping and Hydrography (BSH).

item.title: Repower Systems AG announces interim results for Q1 2009/10 (April 1, 2009 - June 30, 2009)
item.description: According to initial calculations, REpower Systems AG (Prime Standard, WKN 617 703) generated a total operating performance of EUR 287.1 million in the first three months of fiscal year 2009/10, compared with a total operating performance of EUR 240.9 million in the same period of the previous year. Sales increased year-on-year from EUR 231.8 million to EUR 300.7 million. Earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) for the period from April to June 2009 totaled EUR 10.7 million compared with EUR 10.2 million in the previous year.

item.title: Pieter Wasmuth, CFO of REpower Systems AG, leaves the company per 31 August 2009
item.description: Pieter Wasmuth (age 43) will terminate his employment with REpower Systems AG and resign as a member of the management board of the company in mutual amicable agreement as per 31 August 2009.

item.title: Wind Power Grows by 33% in First Half
item.description: Approximately 1.2 gigawatts worth of wind turbines were installed in the U.S. in the second quarter, according to the American Wind Energy Association, bringing the total for the first half of the year to 4 gigawatts.

item.title: Vestas to supply 165 MW offshore wind turbines in Belgium
item.description: 30 July 2009 - Danish wind-turbine maker Vestas Wind Systems A/S (CPH: VWS) said Thursday it will supply 55 units of its V90-3.0 MW offshore turbine for a power plant in Belgium.

item.title: American Superconductor Soars on Quarterly Profit
item.description:
American Superconductor is profiting from a focus on the growth of China’s wind energy market, where the company provides electrical components to closely held Sinovel Wind Co., said Chief Executive Officer Gregory Yurek. Sinovel is China’s largest wind turbine supplier and American Superconductor’s biggest customer.
“With Sonovel continuing to gain market share, many of our other wind turbine manufacturers set to commence production over the next 12 months, and power grid demand on the rise worldwide, AMSC’s outlook is stronger than ever,” Yurek said in the statement.

item.title: China Wind Systems signs wind tower flange contract
item.description:
China Wind Systems (OTC: CWSI) has signed a US$14 million contract to supply wind tower flanges to Chengxi Shipyard Co.
The agreement with Chengxi indicates that China Wind Systems will deliver 800 to 1,200 tons per month of wind tower flanges from September 2009 to June 2010, although the timing and price may be subject to adjustment by Chengxi.

item.title: The New US-Government Substantiates Offshore Wind Projects
item.description: An early and clear exchange of experience between European offshore companies and the United States is the subject of the 1st Offshore Summit: European-North American Dialog taking place on the 10th and 11th of September 2009 in Rostock, Germany. The British Wind Energy Association (BWEA), the American Wind Energy Association as well as representatives from the states of New Jersey, Massachusetts, Virginia, Maryland and Maine who will be reporting about their offshore activities.

item.title: Update on the Situation at Vestas’ Blade Factory on the Isle of Wight, UK
item.description:
On 28 April 2009, Vestas announced it expected to lay off approximately 1,900 employees at the company’s production units in Northern Europe, primarily in Denmark and UK, as part of a wider capacity reduction strategy in Northern Europe.
The announcement was made in response to conditions in the Northern European markets not having met the company’s expectations. The current market conditions are caused by the credit crunch, weak currencies and a lack of local political action in certain markets. At the same time, Vestas is investing in a significant production base in the US. The expansion in the US has created substantial excess production capacity in Northern Europe, which has so far also manufactured turbines for the US market. Unfortunately, demand on the Northern European market cannot absorb the excess capacity.

item.title: Nordex to invest $100m in its first US manufacturing plant
item.description: Nordex USA has started construction work for its first US manufacturing plant in Jonesboro, Arkansas.

item.title: The Big Six's Green Energy Tariffs
item.description: Everybody's getting into green (renewable) energy these days - including the Big Six energy providers. Here's a rundown of the various green tariffs available from the energy giants.

item.title: Lower generation volumes, but relatively good earnings
item.description: Vattenfall today presents its interim report for the first half of 2009. · Net sales rose 19.5% during the second quarter, to SEK 42,128 million (35,259), and 17.3% for the first half of the year, to SEK 94,656 million (80,663). · Operating profit for the second quarter decreased by SEK 6.9% to SEK 5,881 million (6,316), and increased for the first half of the year by 5.6%, to SEK 18,741 million (17,742). · Profit for the period after tax decreased by 35.1% for the second quarter to SEK 2,625 million (4,043), and by 4.6% for the first half of the year to SEK 10,716 million (11,227).

item.title: Decision near for new UK offshore wind
item.description: After the UK government declared its decision to double the Renewables Obligation Certificates scheme to support the renewable energy industry Centrica has said it is prepared to make a decision soon on its next offshore wind farm.

item.title: Pickens has changed energy debate
item.description: A year ago today, T. Boone Pickens brought his crusade for energy independence to Kansas, including to the offices of The Eagle editorial board. The economy would later take some of the air out of the effort, as would lower oil and gas prices. Many have questioned Pickens' motives. But he's had an undeniable impact, converting many people to the cause of breaking the nation's $700 billion-a-year addiction to foreign energy.

item.title: EDF Energies Nouvelles Announces Steep Rise in Interim Results
item.description:
Financial performance: • EBITDA: up 64.6% to €140.2 million • Net income, Group share: up 53.7% to €41.8 million
Objectives confirmed: • 2009 EBITDA: between €280 and €300 million • Installed capacity at year-end 2012: 4,000 MW net including 500 MWp in solar capacity

item.title: Cuomo unveils ethics code for wind energy firms
item.description: Some 16 companies representing most of the wind energy activity in New York have agreed to an ethics code designed to prevent improper relationships between wind development companies and local government officials, state Attorney General Andrew Cuomo announced Wednesday

item.title: Series of tenders for transmission licenses introduced in the UK
item.description: Ofgem has called for bids to win offshore transmission licenses connecting nine offshore wind farms to the Great Britain grid.

item.title: US energy utility Puget Sound Energy to focus on energy efficiency and wind under new energy strategy
item.description: Heightened energy efficiency, the development of more renewable power and additional natural gas-fired power generation are the linchpins of US energy utility Puget Sound Energy’s newly updated strategy for meeting customers’ growing energy needs, the company said.

item.title: NaiKun Wind Issues Project Update
item.description: NaiKun Wind Quarterly Shareholder Update Welcome to the NaiKun Wind Quarterly Shareholder Update for July-September 2009. The focus of this issue will be on the decision released this past Monday by the British Columbia Utilities Commission (BCUC; BC's electricity industry regulator), as our share price suffered seriously in its wake and we feel that investors may be acting on inaccurate information. In addition, we will explain progress made with several key development objectives, including our environmental assessment and strategic partnering

item.title: DOE Announces Up To $30 Billion In Lending Authority For Renewable Energy Projects And $750 Million To Modernize Grid
item.description: U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Secretary Steven Chu has announced that it will provide up to $30 billion in loan guarantees, depending on the applications and market conditions, for renewable energy projects. Another $750 million will support several billion dollars more in loan guarantees for projects that increase the reliability, efficiency and security of the nation’s transmission system. Loan guarantee program encourages the use of energy technologies to help foster clean energy projects.

item.title: Wind turbine factory closure date put back
item.description: The planned closure date of a wind turbine factory which is being occupied by workers as part of a campaign to save their jobs has been put back.

item.title: Britain's low-carbon bonanza will go to foreign firms
item.description: The government has put wind energy at the centre of its plans to remake Britain’s energy infrastructure. Crucially, though, the bane of the industry — planning — remains unresolved. The average onshore windfarm takes two years to get planning approval, one of Vestas’ biggest complaints. The government’s new Infrastructure Planning Commission, which will decide on big applications, should help speed up offshore wind projects but won’t help onshore developers. The commission can only decide on projects of 50MW or greater; the average onshore project is 30MW. Furthermore, the Tories have opposed the planning commission and have vowed to overhaul it.

item.title: ABB participates in Desertec industry initiative
item.description:
Inaugural meeting of Desertec industrial initiative brings carbon-neutral power supplies a step closer
The idea of generating clean electricity in the world’s deserts is making progress: European companies, including ABB, met in Munich on July 13th to sign a memorandum of understanding on the Desertec industry initiative.
"ABB has been a collaborator on the Desertec project for many years,” said Peter Smits, regional manager of ABB in central Europe. “We believe our technologies and expertise will contribute to the continued success of this pioneering project."

item.title: Are wind farms a health risk? US scientist identifies 'wind turbine syndrome'
item.description: Noise and vibration coming from large turbines are behind an increase in heart disease, migraine, panic attacks and other health problems, according to research by an American doctor

item.title: CanWEA Supports the BC Government's Continued Desire to Pursue New Renewable Energy Projects
item.description: The Canadian Wind Energy Association (CanWEA), today voiced its support for the BC Government’s continued desire to pursue new renewable energy projects as evidenced by Minister Lekstrom’s, Minister of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources, response to the recent ruling by the British Columbia Utilities Commission (BCUC) on the Long Term Acquisition Plan proposed by BC Hydro.

item.title: China's installed wind power capacity doubles in H1
item.description: China's installed wind power capacity that transmits power into the national electricity grid rose 11.81 million kilowatts in the first half of this year, doubling the figure of a year earlier, an industry expert told Xinhua over the weekend.

item.title: RMT keeps up pressure on Vestas in advance of court hearing
item.description: OFFSHORE ENERGY UNION RMT kept up the pressure on Vestas and the government today in the run up to tomorrows re-scheduled court hearing for repossession and as the occupation of the wind turbine factory on the Isle of Wight heads into its third week.

item.title: Vestas Receives 165-MW Offshore Order for Bligh Bank Project
item.description: Vestas has received an order for an offshore wind power plant with a total capacity of 165 megawatts (MW). The wind power plant, Bligh Bank Offshore Wind Farm, consists of 55 units of the V90 3-MW wind turbine and will be located 46 kilometers off the coast of Zeebrugge, situated in the zone dedicated by the Belgian Government for the construction of wind farms.

item.title: Falling Behind On Green Tech
item.description: America confronts three interrelated crises: an economic crisis, a climate crisis and an energy security crisis. We believe there's a fourth: a competitiveness crisis. This crisis is particularly evident in America's worldwide standing in the next great global industry, green technology.

item.title: SSE protests as it misses out on wind-farm subsidy
item.description: One of Britain’s biggest energy companies will miss out on renewable energy subsidies worth more than half a billion pounds because it placed an order to buy equipment for a huge offshore wind farm too early.

item.title: Ofgem says electric companies must spend £6.5bn upgrading network
item.description: Ofgem has ruled that electricity companies must spend £6.5bn on upgrading the network into a low-carbon "smartgrid". The move will add £4 to household bills over five years.

item.title: UM wind project advances in Senate measure
item.description: AUGUSTA, MAINE: The U.S. Senate has approved $5 million for a University of Maine research program seeking to develop wind turbine technology capable of operating in the harsh conditions in the Gulf of Maine.

item.title: Acciona’s profits soar on Endesa deal but revenues sluggish
item.description: Spanish energy and construction group Acciona saw its net profits soar by 343% to €7.35bn on its sale of its stake Endesa, but its underlying profits fell by 45.5% to €68m.

item.title: Weak global turbine demand drags Suzlon to Q1 loss
item.description: Indian wind-turbine maker Suzlon suffered a loss of 4.5bn rupees ($94.5m) in the quarter ending 30 June, as consumers in Europe, India and the US continue to delay purchasing decisions while they wait for an economic rebound.

item.title: ANALYSIS: Europe leads in offshore wind
item.description: An estimated EUR21.6 billion (US$31.1 billion) will be spent on offshore wind power projects through 2013, according to UK-based energy business analysts Douglas-Westwood Ltd. (DWL). Globally, DWL predicts that 6.6 GW of new capacity will be installed over the next four years, with installation activity peaking in 2011, before declining somewhat in 2012 and 2013. Current installed offshore wind power capacity is just over 1.5 GW.

item.title: Less May Be More for Wind Turbines
item.description: One of the first R&D grants to a renewable-energy developer from the economic-stimulus funds approved by Congress this spring could have a dramatic impact on the design of wind turbines. The $16 million loan guarantee offered by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) to Berkeley, CA-based Nordic Windpower will accelerate commercialization of the company's Swedish-designed, two-bladed wind turbines, marking the first utility-scale alternative to the industry's dominant three-bladed design in over a decade.

item.title: Cape Cod Wind Farm Closer, but Still Generating Opposition
item.description: A proposed offshore wind development off of Nantucket Sound, Maine, continues to polarize the public. The project, which would produce about 75 percent of the electricity needed by the area, is fiercely opposed by tourism advocates, who fear that the wind turbines, towering 440 feet over the water, would decrease the tourism trade, Reuters reports.

item.title: US opens multi-billion dollar renewable energy treasure chest
item.description: The US Treasury and Department of Energy formally launched a flagship renewable energy funding programme on Friday, announcing that project developers could now apply for direct payments from a new fund worth over $3bn (£1.8bn).

item.title: Hong Kong gives nod to 200MW offshore wind farm
item.description: Hong Kong’s environmental regulatory agency has approved a 200-megawatt (MW), HK$7bn ($903m) offshore wind farm, which would become the first major offshore wind farm ever built in Asia.

item.title: Vestas wins repossession order for UK blade factory
item.description: Wind turbine maker Vestas won a re-possession order on Tuesday to remove workers staging a sit-in at the company's British turbine blades factory on the Isle of Wight.

item.title: Sinovel Ups AMSC Turbine Component Shipments
item.description: American Superconductor Corporation has amended its multi-year contract with Sinovel Wind Corporation Limited, China's largest wind turbine manufacturer, to enable Sinovel to meet increased demand in China for its 1.5-megawatt (MW) wind turbines.

item.title: Harnessing the winds of change
item.description: Offshore wind undoubtedly presents a great opportunity for the UK. While many onshore wind farms have been thwarted by a lack of adequate government support and widespread resistance at local level, offshore wind is less prone to local objection (in theory at least) and has the potential to shoulder the bulk of the weight of meeting our 2020 renewable energy targets. If all goes well, we should start to see many new offshore windfarms popping up round the coast over the next decade. Designing, manufacturing, constructing, operating and maintaining these new turbines will require a large workforce.

item.title: StatoilHydro: Solid performance in a demanding m (Regulatory release)
item.description: StatoilHydro's (OSE:STL, NYSE:STO) second quarter 2009 net operating income was NOK 24.3 billion, compared to NOK 62.6 billion in the second quarter of 2008. The quarterly result was negatively affected by a 40% drop in oil prices, an 18% decrease in the average price of natural gas and a 9% reduction in liftings of liquids, partly offset by a 4% increase in lifted gas volumes and improved margins for natural gas.

item.title: Energy firms warn Ofgem over costs of network upgrades
item.description: OFGEM, the UK energy regulator, has demanded that Scotland's two regional electricity distributors improve customer service, modernise networks and cut carbon dioxide emissions at a cost of £1.4bn over five years - although both companies contend it will cost them much more.

item.title: Industry slams reports of "Wind Turbine Syndrome"
item.description: British Wind Energy Association argues there is ample evidence to reject claims from US doctor that wind turbines are responsible for health problems

item.title: Fears of more windfarms off North Wales coast
item.description: MOVES to allow wind farms to expand have sparked fear of more turbines along the North Wales coast. Power companies are now able to extend offshore wind farms to provide a further 2GW capacity. Activists say the government’s decision could involve the growth of existing wind farms at North Hoyle, the currently under construction Rhyl Flats, and the future Gwynt y Môr development.

item.title: Arguments fly over onshore wind farm
item.description: A CONTROVERSIAL onshore wind farm in Tendring should not be built because the district is already providing a giant offshore wind farm, it is claimed. Peter Balbirnie, district and parish councillor for Little Clacton and Weeley, told an inquiry into the proposed five-turbine wind farm at Earls Hall Farm, between Clacton and St Osyth, that Npower Renewables’ plan should not be allowed.

item.title: SSE fears it may lose out on cash support
item.description: Scottish and Southern Energy (SSE) said yesterday that, as UK Government proposals to subsidise wind energy projects currently stood, the company might miss out on support for its £1.3billion Greater Gabbard offshore windfarm.

item.title: US Department of Energy offers $30bn in loan guarantees for renewable energy projects
item.description: The US Department of Energy will offer up to $30bn in loan guarantees for renewable energy projects. Another $750m will support the billion-dollar loan guarantees for projects that increase the efficiency and security of the nation’s transmission system

item.title: Chinese Wind Power Industry Has Received the Policy Support from Chinese Government
item.description: The support policies will greatly promote the development of Chinese wind power industry. The regulation of the benchmark electricity price will stimulate significantly the enthusiasm of investors of wind power farms and operator electricity network companies.

item.title: A matter of priorities
item.description:
Engineers are wearily resigned to the wider world’s general indifference over how something is produced. Most people are far more concerned with how effectively an engineered product works and how much it will cost them and, on the whole, glaze over at the first mention of the manufacturing process behind it.
Natural enough I suppose, but Don Potts, an environmental advisor to Volvo, makes the valid point that if we want to shift our economy onto a genuinely sustainable base we all need to be a lot more aware of the whole picture.

item.title: Defiant workers still in factory
item.description: SIX WORKERS battling to save their jobs remain barricaded in the Vestas plant in Newport today (Wednesday), despite a court order being issued on Tuesday saying they should leave the factory.

item.title: DOE to Provide $30 Billion More in Loan Guarantees for Renewable Technologies
item.description: The Department of Energy (DOE) announced last week that it would make available an additional $30 billion in loan guarantees for renewable energy projects. At the same time, it pledged another $750 million in subsidy costs to support projects that increase the reliability, efficiency, and security of the national grid.

item.title: China Wind Power International to trade on TSX
item.description: Common shares of China Wind Power International Corp. (TSX-V: CNW) will commence trading on the TSX Venture Exchange on August 5 as a Tier 1 Issuer under the ticker symbol "CNW".

item.title: Areva and Sway cooperates on offshore wind
item.description: Areva and Sway will cooperate to offer new solutions and deliver the technology that makes it possible to exploit the offshore wind in deep water to produce energy, according to a joint press release from Areva and Sway Wednesday.

item.title: Govt may have to buy carbon credits from private sector
item.description:
The proportion of renewable energy used by government departments has actually dropped in the last year, according to the environmental audit committee (EAC).
The news could not have come at a worse time for ministers, who are currently attempting to position themselves as leaders on the world stage prior to the Copenhagen summit while facing accusations of failing to prevent the closure of the Vestas windfarm at home.

item.title: EIA report on the proposed offshore wind farm project approved
item.description: In Hong Kong, Wind Prospect and CLP have welcomed the approval of the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) Report on the proposed offshore wind farm project.

item.title: AWEA releases Q2 market report
item.description: The US wind energy industry installed 1,210MW of new power generating capacity in the second quarter, bringing the total added this year to just over 4,000MW, by comparison with the 2,900MW added in the first six months of 2008, according to the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) in its second quarter (Q2) market report

item.title: Number of wind turbines to quadruple under Renewable Energy Strategy
item.description: Ministers have put wind power at the heart of a Renewable Energy Strategy, which is due to be released on Wednesday. It will outline how Britain is to meet its target of a 34 per cent cut in CO2 emissions by 2020. The Government’s plans are likely to include more than 4,000 additional onshore turbines by 2020, many built at beauty spots and on high ground which would make them visible across miles of open countryside. Another 3,000 turbines would be installed at sea — some of them visible from the coast, though others could be up to 100 miles offshore. Ministers are considering several measures to push wind farm planning applications through more quickly.
