item.title: Canadian Hydro Developers to test laser wind sensors
item.description: Catch the Wind Ltd. (TSX-V: CTW.S) will supply eight test units of its Vindicator laser wind sensor (LWS) to Canadian Hydro Developers, a diversified renewable energy company, as part of a new trial agreement signed yesterday.

item.title: Galicia looks to China for energy joint ventures
item.description: As the world's second largest energy consumer, China is drawing-up ambitious multi-trillion yuan investment plans to promote the uptake of renewable energy sources.

item.title: Seabed Power awarded cable installation for UK's Walney offshore wind farm
item.description: Seabed Power has been awarded two contracts by DONG Energy for the transportation and installation (laying and burial) of more than 92km 33kV array cables and 44 and 43km 132kV export cables in two different routes for the UK's Walney Offshore wind farm project.

item.title: Extensions Offered to Offshore Wind Farms
item.description: The Crown Estate iss to offer Round 1 and 2 offshore windfarm operators the opportunity to apply for area extensions where appropriate.

item.title: US energy utility National Grid applies for stimulus funding for smart grid deployment
item.description: US energy utility National Grid has applied to the US Department of Energy for $200m in stimulus funding to develop smart grid deployment in New York, Massachusetts and Rhode Island

item.title: Vattenfall Plans 400-Megawatt Dantysk Offshore Windfarm Near Germany
item.description: Researched by Industrial Info Resources (Sugar Land, Texas)--Vattenfall Europe Windkraft GmbH (Hamburg, Germany) is planning to build a 400-megawatt (MW) offshore windfarm 45 kilometers north of Sylt, an island in the North Sea. The Dantysk windfarm will be located at the maritime border between Germany and Denmark. The Vattenfall subsidiary, specialized in the construction and operation of onshore and offshore windfarms, plans to erect 80 wind turbines with a capacity of 5 MW each by the end of 2012. The project's estimated cost is about $900 million.

item.title: Analysis: China pulls to the forefront in creating 'green collar' jobs for low-carbon economy
item.description: Following the global economic downturn, both the US and Europe aim to spur jobs in a green push to fight climate change and boost energy security, but China may leapfrog both this year in new wind power - a key measure.

item.title: GE Wins Ruling in Bid to Block Mitsubishi Turbines
item.description: General Electric Co., the biggest maker of wind turbines in the U.S., won a key decision in its effort to block Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. from importing rival energy equipment to the U.S.

item.title: Vestas UK chief says Britain must speed up windfarm construction
item.description: Rob Sauven, managing director of Vestas Technology UK, says turbine manufacturers are at disadvantage compared with those in China and Spain

item.title: Offshore wind power continues to attract increased investment interest
item.description: While the global recession continues to play havoc with most national economies, it is worth noting that the fledgling offshore wind power industry has recently been the recipient of some exceptionally good news.

item.title: Crown Estate makes most of power struggle
item.description:
THE Queen’s property manager is set to pocket a £2.5 billion windfall from the offshore wind energy revolution.
The Crown Estate manages all royal property assets, including the seabed for 12 nautical miles from the coast. It is currently holding confidential negotiations with energy companies over 20-year rental agreements on parcels of seabed designated for huge wind farms capable of producing up to 25GW of power, equal to roughly a third of the UK’s total power generation today

item.title: Deal signed for Barrow wind turbines
item.description: Repower Systems will bring 30 turbines to the new wind farm, which will have a combined output of 150 megawatts, the North West Evening Mail reports.

item.title: CEO Nordex China: “The feed-in rate is an impetus for growth and a key driver for meeting national targets”
item.description: Nordex China welcomes the new NDRC directive, according to which electricity fed into the grid from wind farms is to be paid for on the basis of a fixed rate in the future. “Thanks to this transparent and secure long-term rate structure many wind projects that in the past could often not be economically realized using tender procedures are now commercially feasible.

item.title: Vattenfall runs turbine tender for Germany's Dantysk
item.description: Vattenfall Windkraft is currently running a tender for the wind turbines and offshore work at its 400-megawatt (MW) Dantysk project off the coast of northern Germany, with an eye towards commencing construction in 2012.

item.title: Research and Markets: The World Offshore Wind Report 2009-2013: Current and Future Prospects, Technologies and Markets for the Offshore Wind Energy Sector
item.description: The new edition of The World Offshore Wind Market Report examines the current and future prospects, technologies and markets for the offshore wind energy sector The industry is now moving quickly, and construction and tendering activity is at an all-time high. Offshore wind is forecast to see euro21 billion of capital expenditure in the coming five year period as 6.5 GW of new capacity is installed. With just over 1.5 GW of capacity currently installed, this represents significant market growth and leads to an annual capital expenditure of over euro5.6bn by 2013.

item.title: Subsea cable installed at Hywind project
item.description: A 13-kilometer (eight-mile) submarine cable to carry electricity from StatoilHydro's Hywind floating wind turbine has been installed and tested in the sea northwest of Stavanger. Contractors Nexans and Siemens worked on the installation.

item.title: Focus on smart grid solutions: Siemens and Viridity Energy to cooperate on virtual power plants
item.description: As part of the move to convert existing power supply networks into smart grids, Siemens Energy and the American energy service provider Viridity Energy, Conshohocken, Pennsylvania, are to cooperate in the field of virtual power plants. The two companies have now concluded a technology partnership to offer power supply companies and network operators the necessary technology for implementing virtual power plants. Virtual power plants provide opportunities in the energy market that are not open to operators of individual plants.

item.title: Offshore Wind Energy: Vattenfall secures submarine cables for Kriegers Flak from Berlin
item.description: The power company Vattenfall now has the network connectivity for the planned offshore wind farm (OWP) Kriegers Flak with sea and land cable tender. The tender includes five lots, including a Sea cable connection of about 58 km from Krieger Flak 1 to Baltic 1 and a sea and land connection from Baltic 1 to Bentwisch substation (about 64 km submarine cables, about 36 km Land Cable). The contract for the project ends on 31.08.2012.

item.title: Siemens a big player in growing market to harness wind
item.description:
Siemens Energy Inc. executives Jan Kjaersgaard and Michael Revak of Orlando speak of the power of wind with gusto.
There are Texas breezes that swoop into canyons, gain speed and then roar faster up the opposite slopes. Air currents wash across Dakota plains for days without wavering in speed or direction. Colorado winds collide with foothills of the Rocky Mountains and erupt into turbulence like a whitewater river.

item.title: PNE WIND enters Canadian wind energy market
item.description: PNE WIND AG is extending its international activities once more and taking its first steps into the Canadian wind energy market. Its subsidiary, Plambeck New Energy USA Inc., has concluded a joint venture agreement for the future cooperation with the Canadian company BCP Renewable Energy Ltd. As joint venture partners, the companies will participate in requests for tender for wind-farms in the Canadian province of Saskatchewan. In Saskatchewan, wind-farm projects are tendered by the provincial electrical utility company, SaskPower. Such a request for tender is anticipated in the near future.

item.title: PNE Wind's H1 revenues bounce as it looks offshore
item.description: German wind-farm developer Plambeck Neue Energien (PNE) saw its revenues soar 41.7% to €94.7m ($134m) in the first half of 2009 as it brought eight new onshore projects on line, but says its future lies in the offshore sector.

item.title: DONG Energy - INTERIM FINANCIAL REPORT - FIRST HALF-YEAR 2009
item.description: • Revenue was DKK 959 million ahead at DKK 28,779 million, reflecting higher gas production from the Ormen Lange field, partly offset by significantly lower oil and gas prices and lower Danish power prices • EBITDA was down DKK 1,885 million at DKK 4,766 million, substantially due to the effects of timing differences in connection with the huge fluctuations in market prices for oil, gas and coal • Profit after tax was DKK 1,335 million versus DKK 3,082 million • DONG Energy invested DKK 8.5 billion in new activities and existing facilities, including gas-fired power station projects in Wales and the Netherlands, a Polish wind farm and the wind turbine installation company A2SEA.

item.title: E.ON designates new chief to catch up with peers
item.description: E.ON, the world's largest utility, designated a new chief executive on Monday as it works to earn more money from 18 billion euros ($25.54 billion) of acquisitions in Italy, Spain and Russia and match the profitability of peers. The chief operating officer and current deputy chief executive, Johannes Teyssen, will succeed chief executive Wulf Bernotat in May 2010, E.ON said after markets had closed.

item.title: Mainstream Renewable Power appoints North American Leader
item.description: Mainstream Renewable Power, the global renewable energy company, has announced the appointment of Adrian LaTrace as chief executive of North America operations. LaTrace is the former vice president and general manager of Acciona Windpower North America. The appointment follows the company’s recent acquisition of a portfolio of wind farm projects in the state of Illinois with a potential capacity of 787 megawatts. It is expected these projects will be fully operational by 2013 and will produce enough power to supply almost 200,000 homes in the U.S.

item.title: Statkraft AS - Release of second quarter results 2009
item.description: Statkraft will release second quarter results 2009 on Tuesday 18 August 2009 at 8:00 a.m. CET.

item.title: DSME buys U.S. wind turbine manufacturer
item.description: Irvine, California, based Composite Technology Corporation (OTCBB: CPTC) says it has reached agreement to sell substantially all of the operating assets and operating liabilities of wind energy turbine manufacturer DeWind Inc., including its subsidiaries and certain assets of DeWind Ltd. to Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co., Ltd. (DSME) of Korea.

item.title: Fluor reports 2Q results
item.description: Fluor Corp announced financial results for its second quarter ended June 30, 2009. Net earnings attributable to Fluor were $169 million, or $0.93 per diluted share, compared with $208 million or $1.12 per diluted share for the same period last year.

item.title: NaiKun Wind Releases Results From EA Public Comment Period-Validating Strong Support for the Project
item.description: NaiKun Wind Energy Group Inc. (TSX VENTURE: NKW) released today a summary of responses to comments received during the 45-day public comment period for the harmonized federal-provincial environmental assessment (EA) review of its proposed offshore wind energy project in Hecate Strait.

item.title: Vestas factory closes despite campaign
item.description:
The Danish windfarm company Vestas told more than 400 UK employees today that they had been made redundant, marking the official closure of its Isle of Wight factory that had been occupied for 18 days by angry workers.
The campaign to save the only major wind turbine blade manufacturer in the UK became a cause celebre for unions and green activists, who argued the move undermined the government's promise of a "green revolution" that would result in the installation of 10,000 wind turbines by 2020 and create thousands of jobs.

item.title: Offshore wind power from the North Sea: alpha ventus supplies first kilowatt hours to the German power grid
item.description: For the first time, offshore wind power flows from the North Sea to the German power grid: The consortium of EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall has now successfully started up and adjusted for the regular electricity generation the first three of a total of twelve wind turbines at the alpha ventus wind farm.

item.title: Wind power company WinWinD chooses Fujitsu's Patja
item.description: Wind power company Winwind Oy and ICT services supplier Fujitsu Services Oy have entered into a three-year Patja services agreement whereby Fujitsu assumes overall responsibility for the IT availability and information security and support services of WinWindD. The agreement also covers end-to-end product services.

item.title: Renewables: AREVA acquires PN ROTOR
item.description: AREVA has signed an agreement to acquire PN Rotor GmbH, a German manufacturer of high performance rotor blades for offshore wind turbines from Prokon Nord Energiesysteme GmbH.

item.title: E.ON Raises Profit Outlook After Expanding Abroad
item.description: E.ON AG posted higher first-half profit and said 2009 earnings may drop less than anticipated as Germany’s biggest utility increased power generation by a fifth after expanding in Italy, France and Spain.

item.title: Dong Steps up Wind Investment
item.description:
Denmark’s Dong Energy massively increased wind power investment in the first half of 2009 to DKK 8.5bn, compared to DKK 2.79bn in 2008. However, it plans to cut back spending next year.
The 2009 investment includes DKK 3.33bn for wind power development, made up of DKK 0.7bn for acquiring A2SEA, and DKK 0.92bn and DKK 0.91bn for two offshore wind farms: Horns Rev 2 and Gunfleet Sands.
Total investments this year are projected to amount to DKK 20bn on par with earlier projections but the economic downturn has meant 2010 and 2011 investments are projected at DKK 15 to 20bn per year – a drop from the proposed DKK 20bn.

item.title: US Government Continues To Fund Renewable Energy R&D
item.description: Last month, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) made yet another round of funding announcements for renewable energy projects and initiatives again showing its ongoing commitment to the greening of the American economy. The following announcements were reported in the EERE Network News.

item.title: Gamesa goes offshore
item.description: Gamesa now bets on developing offshore wind power project in a joint company with Spanish Capital Energy. To date Gamesa has consistently rejected any talk of going offshore. However, to industry observers, the joint venture is no big surprise. Offshore wind is where many of the great technological advances are to be conquered, and the market for offshore wind is expected to show explosive growth rates.

item.title: Suzlon to divest stake in Hansen, says Tanti
item.description: India’s biggest wind turbine maker, Suzlon Energy, is planning to divest either fully or partially its stake in its Belgian subsidiary, Hansen Transmission International.

item.title: REpower Systems AG announces financial figures for first quarter
item.description: REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703) posted sales of EUR 300.7 million in the first quarter of fiscal year 2009/10 compared to EUR 231.8 million in the same period of the previous year (comparison period 01 April to 30 June 2008). Therewith, sales rose tight 30 percent. The operating result (EBIT) increased moderately in the reporting period from EUR 10.2 million to EUR 10.7 million. After taxes and interest this results in positive net earnings of EUR 2.2 million after EUR 5.9 in the corresponding period last year.

item.title: New offshore wind farm will make Sund & Bælt CO2 neutral
item.description: Just north of the island of Sprogø, which lies at the western end of the Great Belt bridge connecting Sealand and Funen, work has started on the construction of seven offshore wind turbines which will make the state-owned company Sund & Bælt one of the first infrastructure companies to be CO2 neutral in its operations.

item.title: Wind energy manufacturing boom taking shape in the U.S.
item.description: The news that Nordex USA, the U.S. subsidiary of a German wind turbine manufacturer, broke ground on a new plant in Jonesboro, Ark. in July was only the latest in a growing list of signs that wind energy manufacturing is setting up shop in the U.S.

item.title: Offshore Construction Vessel Goliath Delivered
item.description: One of the world’s largest multi-purpose offshore construction vessels (OCVs), the OSA Goliath, built for Singapore-based Coastline Maritime, has been built to ABS standards.

item.title: RWE remains well on course despite financial crisis
item.description: Despite difficult economic conditions, RWE successfully navigated through the first half of fiscal 2009. A decline in industrial sales was offset by stable residential customer supply and grid business. "The first half of the year is confirmation that we can expect to meet our key earnings targets for 2009 despite the economic crisis", said Dr. Juergen Grossmann, CEO of RWE AG.

item.title: Windworks Engineering Inc.: Prototype Erected
item.description: Windworks Engineering Inc. is proud to announce that the first prototype of its revolutionary Vertical Axis Windturbine has been erected at the company's testing facility north east of Perth, Western Australia.

item.title: Naikun Wind stock gets lift from investment plan
item.description: Shares in Naikun Wind Energy Group Inc climbed 7.4 percent on Thursday after the renewable power developer said a native Indian group plans to buy a 40 percent stake of its Pacific (002790.KS - news) offshore wind project.

item.title: Recommendations on an integrated Europe-wide renewable energy grid
item.description: A new report makes recommendations on how to develop a fully integrated, pan-European grid that can secure reliable electricity for the future while incorporating more renewable energy.

item.title: Several companies want to be the first to develop an offshore wind farm in the U.S.
item.description: For months, Rhode Islanders have been hearing sometimes breathless claims from government and business leaders that the Ocean State will have the first offshore wind farm in the nation.

item.title: REpower: Denver new Headquarters for US subsidiary
item.description: REpower USA Corp., the wholly-owned subsidiary of German wind energy manufacturer REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703), will have a new US headquarters location beginning in early September. The US office for all administrative, sales and project management functions, previously located in Portland, Oregon, will move to Denver, Colorado. The company will make the official announcement at a press conference in Denver today which will be attended by the CEO of REpower USA, Steve Dayney, by the Governor of Colorado, Bill Ritter, and by the Mayor of the City and County of Denver, John Hickenlooper

item.title: Wind power industry blown off course by 'archaic' planning laws
item.description:
Wind turbines are the symbol for the UK's green revolution but as factories close the industry has warned it is being kept in the slow lane by "archaic" planning laws.
As the recession bites every harder on UK companies, Government estimates that a burgeoning eco industry could provide hundreds of thousands of new jobs were enthusiastically welcomed.

item.title: Bring on solar power; wind turbines are noisy and blot the horizon
item.description: The British Wind Energy Association says: “Well-designed wind turbines are, generally, quiet in operation and, compared [with] the noise of road traffic, trains, aircraft and construction activities . . . the sound of a wind turbine generating electricity is likely to be the same level as noise from a flowing stream 50 m to 100 m away or the noise of leaves rustling in a gentle breeze.”

item.title: Rhyl Flats windfarm nearing completion
item.description:
WORKERS at the Port of Mostyn are preparing for the installation of the Rhyl Flats offshore windfarm next month.
Port boss Jim O’Toole said the successful completion of the latest part of the project leaves Mostyn’s onshore renewable energy services base well-placed to win work on similar projects in future.

item.title: Germany´s first offshore wind power plant feeds eco-energy into German network
item.description: MAN subsidiary Renk supplies gear units for North Sea wind park

item.title: Skykon prepares to start expansion of Scottish turbine factory
item.description: Danish wind turbine manufacturing firm Skykon has confirmed that it is to start expansion works at its Campbeltown turbine factory in Scotland, which it acquired from Vestas in March, next month

item.title: Vestas receives orders with a volume of 247 MW
item.description: Vestas has received a 165 MW order for the Belgian offshore wind farm Bligh Bank and an 82 MW order for the Orites project on Cyprus.

item.title: Taiwan and China working on tapping wind power: forum
item.description: Taiwan and China are planning to invest NT$300 billion (US$9.1 billion) to explore the potential of wind power generation in Penghu, said TECO Electric & Machinery Co Ltd (????) chairman Liu Chao-kai (???), who is also the chairman of Taiwan Wind Energy Association.

item.title: Cable contract
item.description: Seabed Power has been awarded a contract for the transportation, installation and testing of submarine cables for the Ormonde Offshore Wind Farm by Vattenfall subsidiary Ormonde Energy.

item.title: Germany has blown into the offshore wind market with its first development sparking up from three turbines.
item.description:
The Borkum 1 wind farm, near the Island of Borkum 45 km (28 miles) off northern Germany in the North Sea began producing power from three 5 Megawatt turbine towers which rise a huge 100 m (328 ft) above sea level.
Developed for €250 m ($360 m) by three German power companies, Vattenfall, E.On and EWE, the project has been dubbed Alpha Ventus, and has been described as a test facility, called the Offshore Test Field and Infrastructure Foundation by the three German energy partners.

item.title: EDF's network auction attracts powerful bidders
item.description: French power group EDF will next month kick off the £4bn auction of its UK electricity distribution network, according to weekend press reports.

item.title: Wind of change blows across the Great Lakes
item.description: The New York Power Authority hopes to create a giant wind farm as it looks to new and sustainable technologies

item.title: Wind-power issue heats up
item.description: Wind-power developers are protesting a proposal that calls for the industry to bear a greater share of the cost of building transmission lines to move its product

item.title: Vestas expands wind turbine manufacturing in China and US as British demand collapses
item.description: Vestas chief says wind power industry is showing signs of recovery, and blames nimbyism for blocking projects in Britain

item.title: Suzlon aims for steady growth after rapid expansion
item.description: “The industry has grown rapidly in the last four to five years,” he said. “But [in 2009] it will be a continuation of the status quo.” Suzlon, now the world’s fifth largest wind turbine maker, would see growth of 10-15 per cent in revenues in 2009, he (Tulsi Tanti) said.

item.title: Scotland opens Green Energy research centre
item.description: The Scottish government's plan to establish the country as one of Europe's top clean energy hubs has received a dual boost following the opening of a new Green Energy research centre and confirmation of plans to expand one of the UK's few wind turbine factories at Campbeltown.

item.title: Interim financial report, second quarter 2009 - No. 1 in Modern Energy retains its forecast for 2009
item.description: Vestas generated second-quarter revenue of EUR 1,211m, an increase of 11 per cent, realising a decline in EBIT of 15 per cent to EUR 78m relative to Q2 2008. In general, quarter-on-quarter fluctuations are due to changes in the activity level and variations in the contract types. Net working capital stood at 11 per cent of expected annual revenue, against (1) per cent the year before. The order backlog of firm and unconditional orders amounted to EUR 4.0bn at 30 June 2009. In spite of the weak order intake since the onset of the credit crisis, Vestas retains its forecast for 2009. Since the end of the reporting period, Vestas has recorded an order intake of EUR 0.7bn with unchanged payment patterns. Additionally, Vestas’ corporate Contract Review Board will be evaluating several contracts with a total value of more than EUR 4.4bn in the upcoming period. On 28 April, Vestas announced the necessity of lay-offs in Northern Europe due to lack of demand. In Denmark, 1,142 employees were laid off, whilst 425 employees were made redundant in the UK last week. At the same time, Vestas continues to expand its new factories in the USA and China. As from Q2 2009, Vestas will be reporting on quarterly developments in its non-financial highlights in order to give prominence to the performance in achieving its environmental and safety targets.

item.title: Top-two China wind energy providers look to cooperate with Taiwan-based Teco
item.description: Sinovel Wind and Goldwind Science and Technology, the two largest China-based providers of wind power-generating solutions and equipment, expressed their willingness to cooperate with Taiwan-based Teco Electric & Machinery to tap markets in China and other countries at a Taiwan-China Wind Energy Forum taking place in Taipei on August 17-18.

item.title: Wind R&D confirmed by Vestas
item.description: Investment in research and development of wind turbine blades in the UK has been confirmed by Denmark's Vestas despite the closure of its blade manufacturing plant on the Isle of Wight last week with the loss of 425 jobs.

item.title: Last phase of building the Hamina Factory reached
item.description: The last phase of building of the WinWinD Hamina turbine factory has been reached. The so called Topping Out Ceremony was held 13th of August

item.title: Ill winds abate for battered sector
item.description:
Wind energy has suffered a battering in the financial storm of the past year but, as one of the most mature renewables, it looks set for a period of calm.
The industry, dominated by European companies, offers steady returns over the lifespan of a turbine – two to three decades – but requires intensive capital spending, and projects are often at the mercy of government subsidies.
In 2008 it showed strong growth. Global wind power capacity increased 29 per cent to 121 gigawatts, more than double the 48GW that existed in 2004, according to the Global Wind Energy Council. The market for installing turbines was worth $47.5bn.

item.title: Statkraft expansion depends on extra government capital
item.description: Statkraft plans to invest NKr90bn ($14.65bn) in new generation capacity over the next six years, but this depends on a capital injection from its owner, the Norwegian government.

item.title: American Wind Energy Association says manufacturing tax credit will create jobs, boost wind power
item.description: The American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) has welcomed the release of details for the renewable energy manufacturing tax credit, which was enacted earlier this year as part of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA).

item.title: Statkraft – Q2 2009 - Acceptable results in a turbulent market
item.description: The Statkraft Group’s gross operating revenues rose by 8 per cent in the six months to 30 June. The increase is primarily attributable to earnings from the power plants acquired from E.ON AG at the turn of the year. The rise in revenues was, however, less than expected owing to the sharp fall in German electricity prices compared with first-half 2008. Lower gas power production in Germany coincided with a fall in earnings from Norwegian hydropower, bringing about a weaker underlying result.

item.title: Staehr appointed as Welcon chairman
item.description: WELCON Towers, the wind turbine shaft maker based in Campbeltown, yesterday unveiled Per Staehr as its chairman. Welcon was setup in March after Danish firm Skykon bought the former Vestas facility in Argyll

item.title: Hyundai Heavy Industries Orders Initial Wind Turbine Electrical Systems from AMSC
item.description: American Superconductor Corporation (NASDAQ: AMSC), a global energy technologies company, today announced that it has received an initial order for 17 sets of full wind turbine electrical systems from Hyundai Heavy Industries Co., Ltd. (Korean Stock Exchange: HHI). Based in Ulsan, South Korea, HHI : is the world’s largest shipbuilder, a global leader in turnkey power plants

item.title: Proposal would increase wind farms' connection costs
item.description: Wind industry advocates say a proposal to nearly double the cost of connecting wind farms to the Upper Midwest power system would stricken the burgeoning wind industry in places like South Dakota.

item.title: US wind industry warns of soaring grid connection costs
item.description: Industry lodges official complaint over proposed changes to transmission funding regime

item.title: Alpha ventus supplies first kWh
item.description:
Germany has marked a milestone in the development of its offshore wind power industry with the startup of the Alpha Ventus wind farm in the North Sea.
A consortium of E.On, Vattenfall and RWE says that the first three of the wind farm’s 12 wind turbines have supplied electricity to the German power grid. A further five turbines have already been completed and the consortium expects that all 12 units will be in operation by the end of 2009.

item.title: Companies vie to develop first U.S. offshore wind farm
item.description:
PROVIDENCE, RHODE ISLAND: For months, Rhode Islanders have been hearing sometimes breathless claims from government and business leaders that the Ocean State will have the first offshore wind farm in the nation. Governor Carcieri has led the refrain, repeating his catchphrase, "Spin, baby, spin," at green energy events across the state.
Despite two crucial developments within four days in June, Deepwater Wind, the startup company selected by the state, still has much to do before it can install more than 100 turbines in the ocean off the Rhode Island coast

item.title: CLP provision adds profit pain
item.description: CLP Holdings (0002) posted a 42.3 percent slump in interim net profit to HK$3.24 billion on the lower permitted return, weak electricity demand in China, a one-off provision of HK$346 million for an Australian solar system investment, and currency fluctuations.

item.title: New study on offshore grid connection
item.description: A combined offshore grid connection between Germany, Sweden and Denmark is technically possible. That is according to a joint pre-feasibility study carried out by Vattenfall Europe Transmission in Germany, Svenska Kraftnät in Sweden and Energinet.dk in Denmark.

item.title: AWEA and WOW oppose transmission policy change
item.description: The American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) and Wind on the Wires (WOW) filed a protest with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) opposing a proposal by the utility transmission system operator in the Midwest that, if approved, will discourage the development of wind resources in a region that has been termed “the Saudi Arabia of wind.”

item.title: Offshore Wind Projects Launched in the USA - European Technology is in Demand
item.description: DUSSELDORF, Germany, August 19 /PRNewswire/ - 1st "Offshore Summit: European-North American Dialog" on the 10th and 11th of September 2009 in Rostock (Germany) Offering US-Based Companies the Unique Opportunity of Profiting From the Early Exchange of Offshore Wind Project Experiences to Take Place Between the European and American Participants

item.title: Ontario to launch wind forecasting service in 2010
item.description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia (Reuters) - The Canadian province of Ontario plans to launch a centralized wind forecasting service next year, its bulk electricity manager said on Tuesday, as it tries to add more wind-generated energy to its grid

item.title: New York State Retirement Fund Invests $200 Million in Green Indexes
item.description: Green Strategic Investment Program, established to commit $500 million to green investment strategies, chooses the FTSE Environmental Technology 50 and the HSBC Global Climate Change Index as benchmark indexes.

item.title: Areva targets offshore wind sector
item.description: Areva is to strengthen its presence in the fast-growing offshore wind sector through the acquisition of PN Rotor GmbH, a German manufacturer of high performance rotor blades.

item.title: Green energy hit by 'faceless Nimbys'
item.description: Last month, the government announced plans to boost the green energy sector, yet within weeks Vestas UK, the UK's only manufacturer of wind turbine blades, closed its plant on the Isle of Wight. The Report's Simon Cox examines the obstacles which could prevent the government's green rhetoric turning into reality

item.title: First power from the first Round 2 offshore wind farm — DONG Energy’s Gunfleet Sands project
item.description: DONG Energy’s offshore wind farm Gunfleet Sands in the Thames Estuary off the East coast of England today supplied the first CO2-free power to the national grid. It is the first electricity to be generated under the entire Round 2 of constructing offshore wind farms in the UK as laid out by The Crown Estate in 2003.

item.title: Norway Opposition Vows Sale of Statoil Shares, State Assets
item.description:
Norway’s Progress Party vowed to reduce or eliminate state ownership in 13 companies including StatoilHydro ASA to raise money for infrastructure investments and tax cuts after next month’s election.
The group will reduce ownership in StatoilHydro, Norsk Hydro ASA and Telenor ASA to 34 percent, cut the 14 percent stake in airline SAS AB and sell shares in utility Statkraft AS to the public, according party finance spokesman Ulf Leirstein

item.title: Boing and DONG Energy cooperates on energy innovation
item.description: The two companies have signed a cooperation agreement to develop energy-related technology innovation and business opportunities. Boeing Company and DONG Energy has today published a new cooperation agreement designed to pave the way for innovation in energy-related technologies and business opportunities.

item.title: Vestas nails offshore turbine contract for Gode Wind 2
item.description: Germany's Gode Wind 2 offshore wind farm, which together with the adjacent Gode Wind 1 project will total 800 megawtats (MW), will be supplied by Vestas turbines, according to developer Plambeck Neue Energien (PNE).

item.title: The Global Wind Sector Weathers Financial Upheaval
item.description: On the endless laundry list of markets that have struggled to muddle through the financial mess known as the global economic crisis, the wind sector seems to be showing signs of a rebound, albeit a small one. A recent article featured in the Financial Times highlighted the “period of calm” that wind producers and investors, alike, are more than relieved to see return in the market.

item.title: Cape Wind Would Have Provided Significant Power as Region’s Electric Demand Peaked Tuesday Afternoon
item.description: As the temperature in Boston climbed to 95 degrees and New England’s electric demand reached its peak so far this year at 3PM on August 18, the sea breeze on Nantucket Sound would have allowed Cape Wind to supply 300 megawatts (71% of total capacity) of electricity during that crucial hour, according to data collected at Cape Wind’s Scientific Data Tower on Horseshoe Shoal.

item.title: EWEA's opinion - Using wind power to help mitigate climate change
item.description:
From Germany to China to South Korea, the complex and potentially catastrophic global warming conundrum led the news last week while negotiations prior to the United Nations climate change conference in Copenhagen continued to intensify.
As negotiators met in Bonn to try and reach a new and strengthened post-Kyoto treaty, Ends Europe reported on the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, which revealed that greenhouse gas emission reductions pledged by rich countries for 2020 amount to between 15% and 21% below 1990 levels.

item.title: Siemens inaugurates new wind power training center in Bremen
item.description: Siemens has officially opened a new wind power training center in the city of Bremen. With immediate effect, the technology company now offers a broad-based qualification program for customer personnel and service technicians from around the globe. The training center is an important part of the European service headquarters for wind power in Bremen and, together with three other training facilities in Europe and the U.S., meets Siemens global training needs for wind power services.

item.title: Nordex Gets Council's OK to Raise Bonds to $125M
item.description:
The Jonesboro City Council last week approved Nordex USA's request to increase its industrial development bonds to $125 million.
The city had authorized up to $100 million in bonds, but the company thought that might not be enough to cover the construction costs of the approximately $100 million wind turbine manufacturing plant, said Nordex chief counsel Richard Casey.

item.title: Keep the Blades Turning
item.description: Wind farm O&M covers turbines and the critical connection to the grid. Here, tips on how to improve operations and decrease costs. Wind turbines are like every other power generation technology: where there are moving parts, there's wear and tear. Ongoing maintenance is crucial. But the source of stress on a wind turbine is unique -- constant exposure to the elements -- and utility-scale wind farm operational history is still being written. “Many of the country’s wind farms are still relatively new and preventative maintenance will become more important as they age,” said Richard Esce, business development manager at HMT Inc., a New York-based company that provides high voltage maintenance and engineering services to wind farms.

item.title: Offshore Wind Farms Could Power 37 Million Homes by 2020
item.description:
Global offshore wind farm capacity will grow at a compound annual rate of 32 per cent in the coming decade, according to a new report by energy consulting firm ODS-Petrodata.
The International Offshore Wind Market to 2020 report predicts that by the end of 2020 global offshore wind farm capacity will have soared to 55 gigawatts, or enough to power almost 37 million European homes. Current installed capacity is under two gigawatts.
Based on an analysis of more than 700 projects and prospects in the company's database, ODS-Petrodata forecasts USD 61.4 billion of capital expenditure in the sector between now and 2014. For 2016 to 2020, total capital expenditure could be double that.

item.title: Iberdrola to Pump Money into Clean Technologies
item.description: Spanish utility Iberdrola has announced plans to boost expenditure on research, development and innovation focusing on clean energy and renewables.

item.title: Maine alternative energy leaders hit Europe on trade mission
item.description: Maine Gov. John Baldacci and a group of clean energy business officials are heading to Europe next month to showcase the state’s wind and ocean energy capabilities to the world’s leading renewable energy developers. ...Maine has lofty goals for wind farm development — some 2,000 megawatts installed by 2015 and 3,000 megawatts by 2020 — and developing projects offshore will likely be necessary to achieve that goal. A 2007 task force on wind power development suggested that some 10 percent of the state’s 2020 goal could come from offshore resources, yet Germany is one of the few places that has successfully brought offshore wind power online and industry experts expect European developers to find attractive projects in Maine.

item.title: Alternative energy groups vie for subsidies
item.description:
With more than $11 billion in subsidies up for grabs, Congress and state governor's offices are getting lots of attention from lobbyists as the solar and wind energy industries maneuver for the lions' share.
The Solar Energy Industries Association spent $540,000 on lobbying in the second quarter of this year, which is more than it spent on lobbyists in all of 2007.

item.title: EWEA predicts wind energy increase
item.description:
New research by the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA) estimates that 8,600MW of new wind energy capacity will be installed in the European Union (EU) in 2009, a growth of one per cent compared to 2008.
This would take the EU’s cumulative installed capacity to 73,535MW, up from 2008’s cumulative capacity of 64,935MW.
The forecast is encouraging in a year where the financial crisis has affected most industries and where electricity demand is declining in tune with overall economic activity.

item.title: Australian renewables law to spark wave of wind projects
item.description: The wind energy industry is expected to dominate the revitalised Australian renewables sector, much to the dismay of solar and geothermal project developers

item.title: Ford’s EV Charging System Allows Driving Using Only Renewable Energy
item.description: Ford Motor Company has developed an intelligent charging system that previews how its production vehicles will interact with the grid. The unnamed system enables all-electric and plug-in hybrid vehicle owners to restrict charging to when electricity prices fall below a certain threshold, or even “when the grid is using only renewable energy such as wind or solar power,” according to Ford.

item.title: ABB solution to help strengthen Mexican power grid
item.description: ABB, the leading power and automation technology group, has won an order from Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE) to provide a Static VAr Compensator (SVC) solution to help strengthen the transmission grid in southern Mexico. The unit will be installed at the La Ventosa substation, close to the city of Ixtepec in the state of Oaxaca.

item.title: GE Energy to Acquire Offshore Wind Turbine Supplier ScanWind of Norway
item.description: On August 12, Morphic Technologies AB signed an agreement to sell ScanWind to GE Energy. ScanWind Group AS, headquartered in Trondheim, Norway, was founded in 1999 to develop and commercialize direct drive wind turbine technology suitable for offshore deployment. The company has approximately 45 employees, a subsidiary in Karlstad, Sweden, and an assembly plant in Verdal, 90 kilometers north of Trondheim, real estate that is excluded from the deal with GE.

item.title: China powers ahead as it seizes the green energy crown from Europe
item.description: China is running away with the green technology prize. It has conquered a third of the world market for solar cells and is on a breakneck course to build 100 gigawatts of wind turbines by 2020, doubling again the global capacity for wind power across vast stretches of Inner Mongolia and Xinjiang.

item.title: European Wind Energy Association predicts growth in wind energy installations
item.description: Research by the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA) has provided estimations that 8,600MW of wind energy will be installed in the EU-27 by the end of 2009.

item.title: GE to push ahead with plans to build turbines in Brazil
item.description: US engineering giant GE will push ahead with plans to build wind turbines in Brazil as the South American country gears up for its first wind energy tender in November, according to industry sources.

item.title: REPORT: Offshore wind generation capacity to hit 55 GW
item.description:
Global offshore wind farm capacity will grow at a compound annual rate of 32 percent in the coming decade, according to a new report by ODS-Petrodata.
The International Offshore Wind Market to 2020 report predicts that by the end of 2020, global offshore wind farm capacity will have soared to 55 GW, or enough to power almost 37 million European homes. Current installed capacity is under two GW

item.title: Powerful Ideas: Wind Turbine Blades Change Shape
item.description: Morphing blades made of advanced composite materials that can rapidly change their shape depending on the wind could help lead to advanced wind turbines that perform better and last longer.

item.title: SIAG involved in WEA-steel towers production in the U.S.
item.description: SIAG Schaaf Industrie AG has acquired through "signing and closing" an existing steel tower factory. The plant is located in Chattanooga, Tennessee, USA, and now produces wind turbine towers for the North American market.

item.title: China vows green commitments: road to Copenhagen
item.description:
As a participant in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Kyoto Protocol, China on Monday vowed "utmost sincerity" in pushing for the success of climate talks in December in Copenhagen, Denmark.
Xie Zhenhua, Vice Minister of the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), made the remarks in a report delivered to the 10th session of the 11th National People's Congress Standing Committee.

item.title: Randers (Denmark) will test giant wind turbines
item.description:
A sparsely populated area of Randers municipality (Denmark) may be chosen as placement of a serie of 250 meter high wind turbines.
The government has decided to create a national test center for wind turbines, and Randers municipality is considering to offer himself.

item.title: German wind power moves further out to sea
item.description:
FRANKFURT (Reuters) - A pioneering German wind power plant's new high-tech equipment, to capture higher winds further offshore and for longer periods, is exciting the industry.
The Alpha Ventus wind park started this month and operates 45 km off the German-Dutch coast. Existing European wind parks operate only 20 km offshore at the most.

item.title: FACTBOX-Approved German offshore wind farm projects
item.description:
The Federal Maritime and Hydrographic Agency (BSH) has approved the following offshore wind farm projects in the North Sea in a move to help diversify Germany's renewable energy mix. Only Borkum West, also known ADVERTISEMENT
as Alpha Ventus, has started sending power to the German grid. But once the offshore wind industry takes off, these projects already have licences to start construction.

item.title: Nordex with robust growth in the first half of the year
item.description: Hamburg, August 25, 2009. In the first half of 2009, the Nordex Group (ISIN: DE000A0D6554) achieved a 10 percent increase in sales to EUR 512.5 million (previous year: EUR 465.9 million) in line with expectations. This was accompanied by quarter-on-quarter growth of around 20 percent in its business volumes. Sales in the second quarter of 2009 amounted to EUR 279.2 million (Q1 2009: EUR 233.3 million). During the period under review, the major source of growth was in the United States, where Nordex achieved around 12 percent of its sales for the first time, up from roughly one percent in the previous year. Contributing around 80 percent to sales, business in Europe remained stable.

item.title: Firm tests Loch Ness site for wind possibility
item.description:
A power company is to monitor weather conditions on mountains above Loch Ness to assess their suitability for future windfarm developments.
Airtricity Developments Ltd, an offshoot of Scottish and Southern Energy, has lodged five separate planning applications for meteorological equipment near Fort Augustus.

item.title: South Carolina tests the waters for offshore wind farm
item.description: South Carolina's entry into the high-stakes race to build an offshore wind farm began quietly this year when crews placed two strings of yellow buoys off the Grand Strand. Packed with weather instruments, these buoys will measure wind speeds to identify a sweet spot, a place close enough to shore so crews can more easily build and maintain a wind farm, but far enough into a powerful belt of winds that regularly blows off the coast -- winds strong enough to spin massive rotors on towers taller than the Statue of Liberty.

item.title: NaiKun Wind Welcomes Clarity on BC Hydro Clean Power Call
item.description:
NaiKun Wind Energy Group Inc. (TSX VENTURE:NKW) ("NaiKun Wind") today provided an update to shareholders based on an announcement from BC Hydro regarding the Clean Power Call.
BC Hydro announced that it anticipates awarding Electricity Purchase Agreements for successful Clean Power Call participants in fall of 2009. The provincial utility also said that it will be assessing the status of First Nations consultations to determine whether Clean Power Call participants have conducted adequate consultation with respect to their power sale proposals.

item.title: Renewables Grid Initiative advocating new transmission lines
item.description: NGOs and TSOs join forces Historically, environmentally conscious NGOs and Transmission System Operators (TSOs) were for the most part diametrically opposed on the subject of high-voltage transmission lines. This makes it all the more remarkable that now two NGOs, including WWF, have joined an initiative that advocates an enforcement of the European transmission grid. Such enforcement is considered necessary to enable the integration of renewable energy systems.

item.title: China plans for renewable energy
item.description:
China's top legislature yesterday turned its attention to the creation of specific plans for more renewable energy, such as nuclear, wind and solar power.
The move would not only create more energy that is desperately needed in China, but would also spur industry and business development, environmental experts say.

item.title: Favorable Political Winds Blow E.U. Turbine Producers to the U.S.
item.description:
After an early lead in wind power generation, the United States was completely overtaken by Europe in the 1980s and 1990s, when countries such as Denmark, Germany and Spain subsidized the industry and helped it survive some very lean years. Now, those investments have paid off. Denmark's Vestas, which started making turbines in 1979 and has since increased its efficiency by 100 times, is now the world's largest producer of wind turbines.
Spain's Gamesa and Germany's Siemens are also big players in the industry. But the pace of onshore turbine installation in northern Europe has tapered off lately and the offshore sector is still in its infancy, plagued by technical and financial difficulties, so companies like Vestas are looking for continued growth elsewhere. With the Obama administration promising big investments in green energy, wind turbine producers see the United States as the key to the industry's future.

item.title: Windturbine manufacturer waiting to start
item.description: The manufacturer of wind turbines should soon return to its previous growth path. After the global market leader, Vestas has made the industry with an optimistic outlook and courage The Hamburg competitor Nordex also eyes positive signs for the next months. "At the turn of the new business, I am still optimistic," said Nordex CEO Thomas Richterich on Wednesday when presenting the financial figures for the first half year.

item.title: Make Consulting: Fewer bidding rounds in the future of China's onshore market
item.description:
There will be fewer of the big state licensing rounds in the Chinese wind market in the future. At least when it comes to projects in the country, according to the forecast by wind consultancy company Make Consulting.
- Based on our assessment of projects under development, we foresee a diminished share of the bidding rounds in the near future. And at some time the bidding round will disappear from the Chinese market, states Make Consulting in a memo. ... - We believe that the remaining bidding rounds will take place in China's offshore sector, states the memo.
China is one of the major areas of focus for the Danish wind turbine producer Vestas future.

item.title: Technical Due Diligence on wind turbines
item.description: Sky Power Corp., Canada’s leading independent renewable energy company, awarded SGS Wind Energy Services the contract for Technical Due Diligence on the Fuhrländer 1.5 MW wind turbine technology.

item.title: Big German wind farm opportunity
item.description: Germany's Federal Maritime and Hydrographic Agency – the BSH - has approved a host of new offshore wind farms which will provide a massive opportunity for the renewable energy supply sector.

item.title: DONG Energy, E. ON and Peace. Olsen Renewables forming consortium to bid for the third round of "The UK Offshore Wind Farm Program"
item.description:
DONG Energy, E. ON and Fred.Olsen Renewables has announced today that they have formed a consortium to bid on thousands of mega watts in the form of offshore wind capacity in British waters.
Konsortiet har budt på eksklusive rettigheder til et antal zoner, som en del af ”The Crown Estate's Round 3 Offshore Wind Farm Programme”. The consortium has bid for exclusive rights to a number of zones, as part of "The Crown Estate's Round 3 Offshore Wind Farm Program.

item.title: NaiKun Wind Welcomes Government's Recommitment to Renewable Energy
item.description: NaiKun Wind Energy Group Inc. (TSX VENTURE: NKW) ("NaiKun Wind") is pleased with the British Columbia government's strong, ongoing commitment to renewable energy developments contained in today's Speech from the Throne.

item.title: Marine energy a £2.5 billion boost for Scotland
Areva hopes to develop Va. wind projects
item.description: A state senator wants to clear the way for offshore wind energy projects in Virginia, which could help Areva develop a new manufacturing facility in the state. Harnessing wind power was one topic that Virginia's Manufacturing Development Commission discussed Tuesday in a meeting at Areva's Old Forest Road office. Sen. Frank Wagner, R-Virginia Beach, presented a draft of a bill that would create a state agency to coordinate offshore wind projects

item.title: Wind power is ready for the downturn
item.description: The European wind turbine manufacturers feel a distinct slowdown in order intake. Many energy projects are being postponed or called off entirely. Nevertheless, the wind power industry still make a decent income - and thus do better than the solar industry

item.title: SüdWestStrom with first offshore project
item.description: SüdWestStrom Windpark GmbH & Co KG has with the planned offshore wind farm "BARD Offshore 1" presented the first big project. Approximately 100 kilometers northwest of the island of Borkum is the site of the new offshore wind farm "BARD Offshore 1" on an area of about 60 km ²

item.title: New wind turbines in the North Sea to supply 35 million European homes
item.description: Towards 2015 there will be established new wind turbines in the North Sea with a total capacity of 16.7 GW, according to a report from the Danish company Make Consulting. It is enough to power 35 million European households with environmentally friendly power. Siemens Wind Power and Vestas is today significant suppliers of turbines, even though General Electric has announced his arrival with the acquisition of a Norwegian company

item.title: German ministry proposes independent power grid
item.description:
Germany's high voltage power networks should club together in one entity in which the state would have a minority stake, the country's environment ministry said in a statement to Reuters on Thursday.
'The state as a co-owner should ensure in the future that power grids are built up to suit demand and efficiency criteria,' said deputy Environment Minister Matthias Machnig of the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD).

item.title: Siemens acquires a majority holding in two Chinese companies
item.description: Siemens Energy has acquired a majority holding in the Chinese metalworking company Yangtze Delta Manufacturing (YDM) and the Chinese aluminum foundry GISAP (GIS Steel & Aluminium Products), both headquartered in Hangzhou. The acquisitions are intended to help Siemens Energy expand its global production network for high voltage circuit breakers in China and adding to its manufacturing chain from foundry work via machining to final product assembly. YDM and GISAP together posted revenue totaling approximately EUR65 million in 2008 and today have a combined work force of approximately 600. The purchase price was not disclosed.

item.title: PG&E to build plant to store wind energy
item.description:
Already an aggressive investor in renewable energy projects such as solar power, PG&E on Wednesday said it is seeking to build its first-ever facility that would pump compressed air into an underground cavern, using mainly wind energy produced during nonpeak hours, and release it to generate electricity during periods of peak demand.
The 300-megawatt facility, to be built in Kern County, is projected to cost $356 million and take five years to design and build, said PG&E spokesman Paul Moreno.
On Wednesday, the San Francisco-based utility filed for $25 million in federal funding to be used for initial analysis and design costs.

item.title: Vestas will take part in offshore boom
item.description:
Thousands of wind turbines will be raised up in Denmark in the next 5 to 6 years. And Vesta will take part in the mill party. According to new figures from Make Consulting, the number is 16.7 gigawatts, which represents 5,566 of the largest Vestas wind turbines. If this happens, the market for offshore wind will be a large proportion of the total market for wind power.
Vestas is willing to bet unyielding in the future market for offshore wind turbines. "We aim to stay in the offshore. Our plan is that we must be part of the market, coming now, said Anders Søe-Jensen, director of Vestas Offshore.

item.title: AMSC Receives Second D-VAR Order For Chinese Power Grid
item.description: American Superconductor Corporation (AMSC) has received its second order for a D-VAR system to meet dynamic reactive compensation requirements for the Chinese power grid. China National Machinery Industry Complete Engineering Corporation (CMCEC) will deploy the D-VAR system to meet local grid interconnection requirements for Phase I of the Guanting Wind Farm, located in the Beijing area. AMSC expects to deliver the D-VAR system to CMCEC by the end of 2009.

item.title: Vattenfall Treasury publishes interim report
item.description: Vattenfall Treasury AB (publ) publishes its Interim Report for the period January 1 – June 30, 2009.

item.title: New Multi-Million Dollar 'Green' Manufacturing Facility Opens; Making More Mechanical Drives for Wind Turbines
item.description: Winergy Drive Systems Corp. and Siemens Drive Technologies officially opened a second plant in Elgin, Ill., today. The new plant, representing an investment of more than $20 million, enables the company to meet the growing demand for alternative and renewable energy sources. Winergy is the largest producer of wind turbine gear drives in the United States

item.title: Skykon to treble turbine ouput and staff as Campbeltown plant expansion approved
item.description:
SKYKON, the Danish wind turbine maker, has revealed that expansion work will begin next month at its Campbeltown factory after the firm received fast-track planning approval.
The purpose-built facility will allow Skykon to treble tower production and boost staff from 100 to 300

item.title: Wind farm assurances welcomed
item.description: ANGUS MP Mike Weir has welcomed assurances he has been given from Airtricity, the company behind the proposed Bell Rock offshore wind farm, that they appreciate the concerns of local fishermen and will ensure that early and detailed consultation is undertaken with them.

item.title: Search still on for heads of energy, economic development
item.description:
The state is still searching for permanent directors of two government agencies that play crucial roles in the development of Rhode Island’s economy.
The Rhode Island Economic Development Corporation, which is responsible for creating jobs and bringing new companies to the state, has been without a permanent executive director since Saul Kaplan resigned last December. J. Michael Saul has been in charge on an interim basis for the past 10 months as the state’s unemployment rate has continued its climb to second-highest in the nation.

item.title: Another Monster Contract for Seajacks International Ltd
item.description: Seajacks has been awarded a contract from Dong Energy A/S for the provision of 'Seajacks Leviathan' and 'Seajacks Kraken' for installation of wind turbines on Walney 1 and Walney 2 windfarms, which are to be located in the Irish Sea.

item.title: Signs of Impact
item.description: Project numbers and developer feedback indicate that the economic stimulus package is on the right path to bolster activity within the wind industry. On July 9, the U.S. Treasury Department and U.S. Department of Energy released the guidance for how wind farm developers can access cash grants in lieu of the investment tax credit. The grants, which were part of the American Reinvestment and Recovery Act (ARRA, also known as the stimulus bill), are expected to help get wind projects built while capital markets remain difficult. The program began accepting applications at the end of July.

item.title: EDF may help infrastructure M&A regain some spark
item.description:
EDF's possible sale of British or French power networks worth billions of euros suggests infrastructure dealmaking is set to recover after a dismal year for the once-hot asset class.
The French utility owns Britain's biggest electricity distribution network and France's power grid RTE. It has not begun any formal sales process for either, but bankers and investors say advisers are working toward possible sales

item.title: Mott MacDonald is lenders engineer on offshore wind farm
item.description: Mott MacDonald marked the financial close on the largest offshore wind farm to be financed on a non recourse basis this month. The global management, engineering and development consultancy was appointed as lenders engineer by lenders ASN Bank, Dexia Bank Belgium, Dexia Credit Local, Rabobank, PMV, EKF and the European Investment Bank (EIB) for the €545 million credit facilities they arranged for the project.

item.title: Minister Cansfield Confirmed as Keynote Speaker at North American Offshore Wind Conference
item.description: Wind Energy Update have a strong relationship with Trillium Power Wind Corporation and their CEO, John Kourtoff will give a presentation at the summit on Moving from theory to practice: taking the next steps in North American offshore wind development. With John's strong network and many years of work in the space, it was not long before Minister Cansfield was notified of the event and expressed a keen desire to inform the leading players in the industry of the Ontario Governments plans for offshore wind

item.title: DNV launches the world’s first class notation for offshore wind turbine installation units
item.description:
In response to the emerging offshore wind power market, DNV is launching the world’s first class notation for offshore wind turbine installation units.
The market for wind turbine installation units is growing rapidly as the offshore wind industry picks up pace. The classification of these units is based on DNV’s Offshore Service Specification DNV OSS-101 ‘RULES FOR CLASSIFICATION OF OFFSHORE DRILLING AND SUPPORT UNITS’, which was originally developed for classifying drilling and production vessels used in the oil & gas industry.

item.title: Liebherr Delivers First MTC 78000 Heavy Lift Offshore Crane
item.description: At the end of June, Liebherr delivered the first heavy lift offshore crane type MTC 78000 straight from its manufacturing plant in Rostock. The MTC 78000 is one of the biggest offshore slewing cranes worldwide. With a maximum dynamic torque of 78,000mt, the MTC 78000 is the most powerful machine within the extensive range of cranes and material handling machines offered by the Liebherr group of companies. Four units of the new heavy-lift crane have already been ordered to date.

item.title: Wind farms offshore U.S. at least a year off
item.description: Permits for the first offshore U.S. wind farms remain at least a year away but are on track to be approved, Interior Department officials said. "We are going to see this commercial development occurring, both offshore and solar. You will continue to see tangible progress toward that," Deputy Interior Secretary David Hayes said.

item.title: Miliband takes action on queue to connect new power generation to the grid
item.description: New rules to revamp the way power plants get connected to the UK’s power grid are proposed today by Energy and Climate Secretary Ed Miliband. The shake-up will help new projects waiting to get a date to feed electricity into the grid to get out of the queue, and will in particular help renewable energy projects such as wind farms.

item.title: Energy firms find wind at their back
item.description:
China's emphasis on wind energy is creating a new source of green for many American companies, as the country's wind capacity continues to advance with gale-force strength.
In recent years, China has blown past its own ambitious goals for wind energy development, making it the fourth-largest wind power producer, behind the US, Germany and Spain.

item.title: Suzlon in talks to sell gearbox unit, Hansen
item.description: Suzlon Energy, the world’s fifth-largest wind turbine maker, is in discussions with a consortium of wind equipment component manufacturers in Belgium, in addition to some leading turbine manufacturers in Europe, such as Vestas, to sell off its gear box manufacturing subsidiary, Hansen Transmission.

item.title: German wind power moves further out to sea
item.description:
A pioneering German wind power plant's new high-tech equipment - to capture higher winds further offshore and for longer periods - is exciting the industry.
The Alpha Ventus wind park started this month and operates 45km off the German-Dutch coast. Existing European wind parks operate only 20km offshore, at most.
"Alpha Ventus is navigating uncharted waters for us to see what problems could be encountered in the offshore wind industry globally," said Thorsten Herdan, executive director of VDMA Power Systems, which represents German equipment makers.

item.title: Fife's Renewable Energy Report gets Council backing
item.description:
A report on Fife’s Renewable Energy opportunities – Growing Fife’s Economy - was given the backing of council members at the recent Enterprise, Environment & Transportation Committee.
The document covers the major Renewable Energy projects that are planned or already operating within Fife. The details on each project include the amount of electricity generated, carbon emissions saved and jobs created. The report also highlights the significant economic opportunities there are within various Renewable Energy sectors and how Fife can fully exploit them.

item.title: Vattenfall to Sell WEMAG Utility Holding to Co-Owners
item.description:
Vattenfall AB, Germany’s fourth- largest power supplier, agreed to sell its 80.3 percent stake in WEMAG AG to co-owners of the municipal utility to trim debt.
Some 268 municipalities in the states of Mecklenburg- Western Pomerania and Brandenburg will buy the stake for 170 million euros ($243 million), raising their holding in the energy supplier to 100 percent, Stockholm-based Vattenfall said in a statement today.

item.title: North Dakota wooing wind turbine manufacturers
item.description: North Dakota's potential for generating wind power should help lure businesses that make equipment for the industry, economic development officials believe, but analysts say the state will face stiff competition.

item.title: EDITORIAL: Offshore wind power with a Lynchburg link
item.description: LYNCHBURG, VA.: A Lynchburg firm best known for its nuclear power plants just might be interested in developing wind power off the Virginia coast. That was the news last week from a meeting of Virginia's Manufacturing Development Commission, which met at Areva's offices on Old Forest Road.

item.title: Earnings up for Amec
item.description: Global offshore services group Amec has reported interim earning's up 25% to £94.5 m to June 2009 from £75.9 m last year.

item.title: ABB to provide network management solution for National Grid in US
item.description: ABB, the leading power and automation technology group, will implement its Network ManagerTM SCADA/EMS (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition/Energy Management System) solution in the U.S. for National Grid, a leading energy utility. National Grid will deploy the technology in its up-state New York and New England electric operations control centers to manage the transmission and distribution networks in the region

item.title: Britain facing blackouts for first time since 1970s
item.description: Britain is facing the prospect of widespread power cuts for the first time since the 1970s, government projections show.

item.title: Stattkraft still waiting for answers about the increased equity
item.description:
Statkraft need a speedy clarification of the situation around the capital.
In February, The Statkraft group requested that the equity would be strengthened with eight billion in the first half of 2009. Statkraft is still waiting for a response from the Trade and Industry Ministry.

item.title: Power Capacity from new renewable energy sources reached 280.000 MW in 2008
item.description:
During 2008, a number of governments enacted new policies, and many countries set ambitious targets. Today, at least 73 countries have renewable energy policy targets, up from 66 at the end of 2007.
During 2008, a number of governments enacted new policies, and many countries set ambitious targets. Today, at least 73 countries have renewable energy policy targets, up from 66 at the end of 2007. In response to the financial crisis, several governments have directed economic stimulus funding towards the new green jobs the renewable energy sector can provide, including the U.S. package that will invest $150 billion over ten years in renewable energy.

item.title: Steady European market for wind turbines in 2009
item.description: New research by the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA) estimates that 8,600MW of new wind energy capacity will be installed in the EU-27 in 2009: an annual growth rate of 1% compared to 2008 installations.

item.title: Green energy 'can create 1,300 new jobs'
item.description:
Over 1,300 ’green’ jobs could be created by expanding the North’s renewable energy industry, a conference will be told tomorrow.
At the same time increasing renewable resources presents a huge opportunity to make a big reduction in fossil fuel dependence and save cash.
The Irish Wind Energy Association (IWEA) is holding its inaugural Northern Ireland Wind Workshop at the Culloden Hotel outside Belfast and more than 100 delegates are expected to hear from a diverse range of speakers representing the regulator and public and private bodies.

item.title: NaiKun Wind appoints new chair and announces Q3 results
item.description: NaiKun Wind Energy Group Inc. has announced the appointment of Philip Hughes as Chair of its Board of Directors, effective October 1, 2009, and the retirement of Michael C. Burns, current Board Chair, effective September 30, 2009.

item.title: Enova seeking approval for offshore wind farm Delta North Sea 2
item.description: The Federal Maritime and Hydrographic Agency issued the offshore-wind farm North Delta GmbH approval for the offshore wind farm Delta North 2. The North Sea Project Delta 2 is immediately adjacent to the project area Delta North Sea 1, north of the island of Juist.

item.title: Nexans Introduces New Fiber Switch Model for Wind Turbines
item.description: Nexans (Paris:NEX), the worldwide leader in the cable industry, introduces the new iSwitch G 1043E, an intelligent Fast/Gigabit Ethernet switch system for harsh environment applications

item.title: China's Goldwind plans to list in HK's main board
item.description:
Chinese wind power producer Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology Co plans to float shares worth about $1 billion on Hong Kong's main board, with an eye toward expansion, according to a company statement on Wednesday and Reuters calculations.
Goldwind will issue shares of no more than 15 percent of its enlarged equity capital after the Hong Kong share offer to overseas institutions, corporate and individual investors, it said in a filing to the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

item.title: European Businesses See China Protectionism ‘Specter’
item.description: European businesses urged China to speed the opening of its markets and pull back from protectionism, saying they are “increasingly concerned” at local companies being favored over foreign-invested counterparts.

item.title: European businesses urged China to speed the opening of its markets and pull back from protectionism, saying they are “increasingly concerned” at local companies being favored over foreign-invested counterparts.
item.description: SSB Service celebrated the official opening of the new Competence Center on 13 August in Hamburg and Norderstedt

item.title: DOE and U.S. Treasury Award $502 Million for Renewable Energy Projects
item.description: The U.S. Treasury Department and DOE jointly announced $502 million in American Recovery and Reinvestment Act cash assistance on September 1 to energy companies in lieu of earned federal tax credits. This first round of awards is designed to create additional upfront capital, enabling companies to create jobs and begin construction on projects that may have been stalled until now. Ultimately, the program is expected to provide more than $3 billion in financial support for clean energy projects by providing direct payments rather than federal tax credits. These payments will support an estimated 5,000 biomass, solar, wind, and other types of renewable energy production facilities in all regions of the country.

item.title: Dutch plan new wind farm 75km out in the North Sea
item.description: Amsterdam - A consortium in the Netherlands plans to build a wind farm in the North Sea 75 kilometres off the coast, the furthest ever distance from land for such a venture. The group, which includes major energy providers RWE, Offshore Wind and Eneco, presented their plan to Dutch Economy Minister Maria van der Hoeven on Wednesday.

item.title: Ballast Nedam: Heavy Lift Vessel Svanen at Work for Belwind
item.description: Ballast Nedam's heavy lift vessel Svanen left the port of Rotterdam last weekend. The Svanen has been commissioned by Van Oord Dredging and Marine Contractors to drive 56 steel piles for the foundations of the Belwind offshore wind farm off the coast of Zeebrugge (Belgium). This is the first phase of the Belwind project, which will eventually encompass a total of 110 wind turbines.

item.title: President Obama's Lack Of Environmental Leadership
item.description: During the campaign, President Obama laid out his vision for combating global climate change. Unfortunately, President Obama's original vision seems to have been all but forgotten. His original proposal included a call for a national renewable energy standard (RES) where, by the year 2025, a full quarter of the nation's electricity would be generated by renewable sources. He seems to have lost sight of this vision.

item.title: Offshore wind plan shapes up
item.description: Michigan officials and lawmakers must decide whether to adopt offshore wind turbine recommendations the council made this week. The group spent much of this year studying the most favorable spots for giant windmills to be set in Michigan's Great Lakes bottomlands, as well as permitting criteria, public input processes and both needed legislative and administrative changes.

item.title: EASAC: can we run Europe on renewable energy?
item.description: Sustainable Energy Europe examines the latest report of the European Academies Science Advisory Council (EASAC) on transforming Europe's electricity supply and asks the question: can we run Europe on renewable energy?

item.title: Oceans of Opportunity - editorial note
item.description: From 14 to 16 September, over 1,000 representatives of the offshore wind industry, policy makers and energy specialists will gather in Stockholm to explore and discuss the future of offshore wind energy during the third biennial European Offshore Wind Conference and Exhibition. Organised by the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA), the EOW2009 will debate the future of offshore development in Europe

item.title: Cable array contract awarded for Belwind offshore wind farm
item.description: Parker Scanrope has won a purchase order from Rotterdam-based Van Oord Dredging and Marine Contractors to supply array cables worth more than €7.8m ($11.1m) for phase 1 of the Belwind wind farm offshore of Belgium.

item.title: A new Dutch research and demonstration programme for offshore wind energy
item.description: As a follow up of the We@Sea programme a new research and demonstration programme for offshore wind energy is launched: FLOW (Far and Large Offshore Wind). The programme is focused on the development of wind energy far out at sea. The consortium comprises of RWE Offshore Wind, Eneco, TenneT, Ballast Nedam, Van Oord, IHC Merwede, 2-B Energy, XEMC Darwind, ECN and TU Delft.

item.title: Deepwater proposes installing wind turbines on Block Island
item.description:
Deepwater Wind has submitted a proposal to National Grid for a contract to provide alternative energy to Block Island, which has some of the highest electricity rates in the country.
Deepwater, a New Jersey-based start-up company, proposes installing five to eight wind turbines in waters about three miles from the island by 2012. The small wind farm, which would be the first of two the company is proposing in Rhode Island, would provide more than enough power for Block Island when the wind is blowing. Any excess would be fed through an underwater cable to the mainland and the grid that supplies power to the rest of the state.

item.title: Test areas found for offshore wind power
item.description: PORTLAND, MAINE: The state has identified seven offshore areas that it believes could be suitable places for testing wind power technology. Under a state law adopted in June, state officials must select at least one site, and as many as five, before Dec. 15. One site will be designated as a wind energy research center operated by the University of Maine. Private companies would be sought to develop projects on any other sites.

item.title: State officials discourage Delaware Bay wind farm
item.description: New Jersey and Delaware environmental officials say a wind farm planned for the Delaware Bay could disturb an important flyway for birds.
