item.title: Northern Ireland has backed wind energy to be the country's 'foundation' for a renewable future.
item.description: The country's environment minister, Edwin Poots, put his full backing into wind when he spoke as keynote speaker at yesterday's (2 September) Irish Wind Energy Association Workshop in Belfast.

item.title: Wind Technology Center Installing a Dynamic Duo
item.description:
The clean wind energy industry must expand significantly in the next two decades to fulfill a strategy of generating 20 percent of the nation's electricity. To provide the technological foundation for that dramatic growth, the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) is embarking on significant improvements at its National Wind Technology Center (NWTC).
Engineers are installing the two largest turbines ever tested at the laboratory — a 1.5-MW turbine manufactured by General Electric and a 2.3-MW turbine from Siemens Power Generation.

item.title: GE Sues Mitsubishi Over Patents for Wind Turbines
item.description:
-- General Electric Co., the biggest maker of wind turbines in the U.S., sued Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd., seeking payment after a trade judge found infringement.
U.S. International Trade Commission Judge Carl Charneski said in August that GE’s patent rights were violated by Mitsubishi Heavy, Japan’s largest heavy-machinery maker. GE asked for unspecified damages in the lawsuit filed yesterday in federal court in Corpus Christi, Texas.

item.title: REpower celebrates topping-out ceremony for new Technical Center in Osterrönfeld (Schleswig-Holstein, Germany)
item.description: REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703) celebrates the topping-out ceremony for its new Technical Center today in Osterrönfeld, Rendsburg-Eckernförde. Next spring, some 470 employees – primarily from the Research and Development, Technical Support and Service departments – will move in to the new complex on the Kiel Canal. These departments were previously based at two locations in Rendsburg and Büdelsdorf.

item.title: All-party consensus on the wind
item.description:
Bremen Companies from the wind industry to discuss with top candidates
Bremen (iwr Press Service) - The Bremen-based company invited some of the wind power industry (wpd, Bremer Landesbank, German wind technology, REETEC, Siemens, NW Insurance, Energiekontor and Enercon) were held on Tuesday, 01.09.2009, the leading candidate for the election of Bremer parties came together in a panel discussion. Theme this round of discussions was the importance of wind power for the region of Bremen. Clearly this was a quick cross-party consensus on the further expansion of renewable energies. But a distinction in the details of the positions of party leaders was also clear.

item.title: Latest Energy Review Highlights Importance of Sector to Scotland and the UK
item.description: The latest Energy Review is unveiled by ACSEF (Aberdeen City and Shire Economic Future) in advance of OE09 - Europe's largest oil and gas event to be held in Aberdeen from 8 - 11 September. ... There are significant opportunities in renewable energy and Aberdeen City and Shire is well place to capitalize on these and is already making in-roads with key projects in onshore and offshore wind, marine renewable and biomass.

item.title: Deepwater proposes installing wind turbines
item.description:
Deepwater Wind has submitted a proposal to National Grid for a contract to provide alternative energy to Block Island, which has some of the highest electricity rates in the country.
Deepwater, a New Jersey-based start-up company, proposes installing five to eight wind turbines in waters about three miles from the island by 2012. The small wind farm, which would be the first of two the company is proposing in Rhode Island, would provide more than enough power for Block Island when the wind is blowing. Any excess would be fed through an underwater cable to the mainland and the grid that supplies power to the rest of the state.

item.title: Offshore potential
item.description:
UPPER THUMB — In a new report, the Michigan Great Lakes Wind Council recommends Lansing adopt legislation permitting the placement of wind turbines six miles or more offshore of most of the state’s shoreline.
The council’s report, which was submitted to Gov. Jennifer Granholm Tuesday and issued Wednesday by the Department of Energy, Labor and Economic Growth (DELEG), is intended to provide a roadmap for the sustainable development of offshore wind energy resources in Michigan’s Great Lakes.

item.title: Offshore wind farm could be the size of a small town
item.description: A Chapel Hill entrepreneur hopes to tap the formidable wind resources off the coast of North Carolina.

item.title: Will Areva lead Virginia into a wind-powered future?
item.description: Areva completed the installation of six wind turbines in the North Sea off of Germany in August. Each wind turbine stands about 475 feet above the waterline. The company is looking to expand its wind turbine manufacturing capacity and says Virginia is a possibility.

item.title: Manx role in big windfarm
item.description: A MANX shipping company is making waves with a major windfarm project. Ramsey-based Mezeron is acting as agent for the owners of a 10,000-tonne barge UR101 being used to lay subsea electricity cables for the Robin Rigg windfarm seven miles off the coast of Maryport in Cumbria. The barge calls in to Ramsey for crew changes and to take on supplies. It has also taken shelter in Ramsey bay from south westerly gales that have hampered operations in the Solway Firth

item.title: Wind energy cluster "German wind" is presenting itself in Berlin
item.description: Bremerhaven (iwr Press Service) - The wind-driven clusters "German wind" from the metropolitan area of Bremen-Oldenburg in the northwest has presented itself fully during a joint parliamentary evening, with the metropolitan region.

item.title: Nordex lays foundation for future growth
item.description: CEO Richterich: "Hamburg is an ideal base for our international expansion"

item.title: Iberdrola, the only power company in the world to appear in all 10 editions of the Dow Jones Sustainability Index
item.description: In the 2009 edition of the Dow Jones Sustainability Index, the world benchmark for companies’ contribution to sustainable development, IBERDROLA has once more been included in the utilities sector. The annual review of the ranking was published today and the company has strengthened its leading position in the sector, thanks to the success of its strategy, whose highlights in recent years have included the integration of ScottishPower and Energy East and the stock-market flotation of IBERDROLA RENOVABLES.

item.title: UK's first 'pure-play' offshore wind company: SeaEnergy
item.description: Scotland's Ramco Energy has unpacked plans to exit the oil and gas industry and become the UK’s first publicly listed firm to focus exclusively on offshore wind. It will also formally adopt the name of its renewables subsidiary, SeaEnergy.

item.title: WINDFARM PLAN: FISHERMEN WILL BE CONSULTED
item.description:
THE COMPANY behind the proposed Bell Rock windfarm, Airtricity, has reassured Angus MP Mike Weir that they appreciate the concerns of local fishermen with regard to their plan and will ensure that early and detailed consultation is undertaken with them. Mr Weir had contacted the company following approaches by local fishermen concerned about the possible impact of the development on their businesses.
The MP, who had raised concerns about the impact of offshore developments on the fishing industry as far back as 2004 during the committee stages of the Energy Act, said: "The assessment of the site is at an early stage including a strategic environmental assessment which is being undertaken by the Scottish Government

item.title: Nexans Will Install Cable for Belgian Offshore Windfarm
item.description: Nexans, a major cable provider, said yesterday they had signed a contract to become the cable supplier for the Belwind Offshore Windfarm proposal. The project, set to be constructed in Belgium by Dutch EPC contractor, will submit wind harnessed electricity to 165,000 Belgian residences through the Nexans-supplied subsea power export cables once completed.

item.title: The future is cloudy, windy and wet
item.description:
With its own supplier of green electricity Hamburg wants the coal and nuclear group to get hold of Vattenfall customers in northern Germany.
...The supplier, a 100-percent subsidiary of Hamburg's urban water utilities must generate green electricity in the short term itself. Two wind turbines at the port, which can meet the needs of 8,000 households, will be put into operation next year. Investments in wind farms in the region as well as offshore in the North and Baltic Sea will be sought. "Energy from the region for the region" was the short-term goal, says CEO Michael Beckereit.

item.title: StatoilHydro inaugurates floating wind turbine
item.description: The world’s first full-scale floating wind turbine – StatoilHydro’s Hywind pilot – is being officially inaugurated in the North Sea today, 8 September.

item.title: Swedish Arise Windpower raises SEK330m fresh capital
item.description: Swedish wind farm developer Arise Windpower AB said today it has raised some SEK330m in a private placement for investments in new projects. The private placement was directed to existing shareholders and new institutional investors, including state-owned pension fund the Third AP Fund, which became one of the large shareholders in Arise Windpower

item.title: LGC Skyrota Wind Energy Corp. Acquires UK Wind Energy Business
item.description: LGC Skyrota Wind Energy Corp. ("LGC Skyrota" "the Company") (TSX-V: LGS) today announced it has completed the acquisition of the business and assets of Limavady Gear Company ("LGC"), a leading European provider of wind turbine maintenance services.

item.title: PNE WIND AG: US subsidiary concludes joint venture with Renewable Solutions
item.description: The wind-farm developer PNE WIND AG (ISIN: DE000A0JBPG2) is accelerating its international expansion strategy. The company signed a joint venture agreement for the future cooperation between its subsidiary PNE WIND USA, Inc. and the US company Renewable Solutions.Together the joint venture partners are planning to develop more than 300 MW of wind-farm projects located in Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. In total, the investment volume is expected to amount to approximately $600 million.

item.title: New Partnership - RWE
item.description: The RWE Group wants to cooperate even more closely, in the future with the University of Siegen. ... The contract with an initial duration of five years, sees the promotion of energy projects, in research and teaching and knowledge sharing. One was the aim of strengthening mutual cooperation. The plan is, that a mini-wind turbine will be placed on the university campus in the Adolf-Reichwein-Strasse. The cooperation should take place mainly between the Group and the faculties of electrical engineering and computer science, business studies and media studies.

item.title: Composite Technology Completes Sale of Turbine Business to DSME Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering to Accelerate Growth Plans of DeWind
item.description: Composite Technology Corporation (CTC) (OTCBB: CPTC) is pleased to announce that its subsidiary DeWind Inc. has completed a sale of substantially all of its operating assets and liabilities, including its subsidiaries and certain assets of DeWind Ltd., to Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co., Ltd. (DSME) of Korea

item.title: Grid Connectivity: Invest in Alternative Energy's Missing Link
item.description: In Great Britain, more than 60 gigawatts (GW) of power, a quarter of that from renewable sources, reportedly is waiting to be connected to the nation’s power grid. In California, electric utilities say they have little hope of meeting the state’s mandate of achieving 20% of their generation from green sources by 2010 largely because of delays in getting transmission lines licensed and built. Meanwhile in Brazil, work is underway on what will be the world’s longest power line, which is being built with high-voltage, direct-current (HVDC) technology because it is ideally suited for hooking up renewable energy sources located in remote regions of the country.

item.title: Seajacks - Strengthening Executive Management
item.description: Seajacks International Ltd today announced that Mr Wes L. McDonald has joined the company as Operations Manager.

item.title: Taking a Load Off Turbines
item.description:
Commercial-scale 2-megawatt turbines installed around the country today cost about $3.5 million each, including construction, according to Windustry, a Minneapolis-based nonprofit that promotes renewable energy use.
Construction costs are much higher for off-shore wind farms than for upland wind farms, according to Jason Fredette, director of investor and media relations for American Superconductor Corp., manufacturer of superconductor wires based in Devens. So in order to make wind power more readily available for consumers, off-shore wind farms would want to build as few turbines as possible to generate needed power.

item.title: Offshore Wind Turbine Market Will Grow 45% Annually, MAKE Says
item.description: The global market for offshore wind turbines will grow an average 45 percent per year from 2009 to 2015 as governments are pledging to support wind parks at sea, an industry consultant said.

item.title: Winergy Approves Mobilgear SHC XMP 320 For Second-Fill Applications in GE Wind Turbines
item.description: Further highlighting its leadership in the field of wind turbine lubrication technology, ExxonMobil today announced that its Mobilgear SHC XMP 320 has received approval for second-fill applications in Winergy gearboxes featured in GE 1.5 MW turbines.

item.title: Key Issues For Future Of Wind Energy In Spain
item.description: The journal Energy Policy has recently reported two studies that highlight some key issues for the future of wind energy in Spain. A team of engineers from the University of Zaragoza believes it is "technically viable and economically reasonable" for wind energy to account for 30% of Spain's overall energy production. A report by two researchers from the University of Alcalá (UAH) and the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA), meanwhile, says the number of jobs generated by this sector in the European Union has increased by 226% since 2003.

item.title: The largest crane vessel in the world is busy at alpha ventus: “Thialf” is placing the foundations for the REpower turbines
item.description: The superlative meets the pioneering spirit: "Thialf", the most powerful floating crane in the world is helping with the completion of Germany's first offshore wind farm, alpha ventus. Currently, the construction vessel is placing six steel foundations 30 metres deep on the seabed of the North Sea, approximately 45 kilometres north of the island of Borkum. Using these so-called ‘jacket’ foundations, the consortium of EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall will shortly erect six REpower 5M wind power turbines, each with a height of 155 metres above sea level.

item.title: GL Signs Measurement Deal with Sinovel
item.description: Germanischer Lloyd (GL) has signed a wind turbine measurement deal with Sinovel Wind Co. Ltd. Services include load-, power performance- and power quality as well as acoustic noise measurements.

item.title: China Excess Capacity a Global Trade Concern, EU’s Ashton Says
item.description:
China’s excess production capacity is an “international concern” as goods that can’t be sold locally may be sent to markets that have shrunk amid the global slump, European Union Trade Commissioner Catherine Ashton said. ... No foreign wind-turbine maker has won a bid since 2005, it added last week. “There is a marked lack of consistency in the application of qualification criteria” for public procurement projects, the chamber said in an annual position paper on China.
General Electric Co., Suzlon Energy Ltd., Gamesa Corp. Tecnologica SA and Vestas Wind Systems A/S were among companies bidding for 25 wind-energy projects with generation capacity of 5.25 gigawatts, according to the chamber.

item.title: First power produced by E.ON's Robin Rigg offshore wind farm
item.description: Energy company E.ON has today announced that the first power had been produced by its Robin Rigg offshore wind farm in the Solway Firth. The company has switched on the first turbine at the wind farm and it has been successfully generating power since yesterday.

item.title: Newts are OK so windfarm work goes ahead
item.description:
Work has begun on a multi-million pound substation at Salle as part of the Sheringham Shoal offshore windfarm development.
The final hurdle before construction started was the granting of a newt licence from Natural England.
Before work could start on the preparation of the substation site, the developers had to safeguard some possible site inhabitants, great crested newts.
The great crested newt is the UK's largest newt species but due to diminishing numbers it has legal protection against harm and destruction of its natural habitat

item.title: EWEA's opinion: European wind power reaches a milestone
item.description:
It is true, as the ancient proverb declares, that time waits for no man. It is equally true that, according to a variety of sayings, the world can be changed by dreams, imagination and hard work.
The latest validation of those two axioms presented itself this past week when the perpetual counter established by the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA) reached a milestone by recording wind power in Europe had generated more than 100 GWh of electricity since 1 January 2009. ... Europe is also in the process of replicating this considerable success story with the booming offshore wind sector, which is set to experience an immense expansion in the next few years.
Once the necessary offshore power grid is built, the supply chain is streamlined and the administrative obstacles are sorted out, the offshore wind sector will create for Europe staggering amounts of new, green, local, and affordable electricity.

item.title: Deepwater Wind Considering Wind Project Off Block Island
item.description: Deepwater Wind is conducting an array of environmental studies on and around Block Island, Rhode Island, as part of its preparations for a proposed Block Island offshore wind farm.

item.title: Iberdrola to Boost U.S. Wind-Energy Investment
item.description:
Iberdrola SA, the Spanish renewable-energy giant, says it will spend $2 billion it raised Tuesday in a bond issue to keep growing in the U.S.
The company is already the second-largest wind-farm operator in the U.S., after Florida-based FPL Group Inc.'s NextEra Energy. The cash will strengthen Iberdrola's push to build more wind farms in the U.S., the world's largest market for wind power.

item.title: States Sharing the Sea for Wind Industry
item.description: BOSTON -- Plans are brewing to promote a network of offshore wind farms all along the East Coast connected by a transmission "spine" and shared shipping ports where local turbines will embark for deepwater power fields over the horizon

item.title: Renewables Global Status Report 2009 Update
item.description: Future targets for renewable energy now exist in over 73 countries, up from 45 in 2005. Many such trends continue and are documented in this summary of the REN21 annual report.

item.title: Areg unfazed by Dutch windfarm plan
item.description:
Plans for a large demonstrator windfarm off the Dutch coast have strengthened the resolve of a group trying to establish such a facility near Aberdeen.
A consortium of industry and academic partners including German energy giant RWE and Dutch rival Eneco aims to develop the demonstrator offshore the Netherlands as part of a research and development programme on offshore wind technology.

item.title: Offshore Wind Energy is Set to be Worth $20 Billion in 2010
item.description: The offshore wind energy in Coastal North America and Great Lakes industry is set to be vast. With government backing, proven technology and massive financial rewards, you need to act fast if you want to claim your share.

item.title: Hope, Fears Aired at Offshore Wind Forum
item.description: Sep. 10--ELLSWORTH, Maine -- Enthusiasm for aggressively exploring the possibilities of offshore wind power development and wariness of what sort of undesirable consequences may arise were two themes that dominated the tenor of public comments made Wednesday night at a meeting about proposed offshore wind power test sites

item.title: Yes to Havsul 1
item.description:
The government gives the company Vestavind Offshore permission to build up to 78 offshore wind turbines on a 49 square-kilometer area in the sea off Sandøy municipality. ... Oil and energiminster Terje Riis-Johansen, announced this at a press conference at Tafjord Power in Ålesund this afternoon.
This project is referred to as Havsule. Plans for a major wind farm off the Giske and Haram, Havsul 2, is put on hold.

item.title: KONECRANES UK to supply four SMD cranes to the Smulders Projects wind turbine
item.description: KONECRANES UK, based in East Kilbride in Scotland, has won another order to supply four SMD cranes to the Smulders Projects wind turbine base production facility in Belgium. The previous order being delivered in September 2009 is for 2 x 240t and 2 x 15t cranes.

item.title: Trico bags $50m jobs swag
item.description: Nasdaq-listed Trico Marine has won $50 million in new contracts, with about $35 million of that from subsea work in Norway, Mexico and the US.

item.title: WePOWER's Wind Turbines (VAWT) 'Approved' by California Energy Commission and American Wind Energy Association
item.description: WePOWER LLC, a leading global manufacturer and developer of Vertical Axis Wind Turbines (VAWT) is pleased to announce their wind energy systems have been fully approved by the California Energy Commission ("CEC") as being eligible to qualify for rebate payments and simultaneously acknowledged by the American Wind Energy Association ("AWEA") as being a "commercially proven equipment provider."

item.title: Shipyard secures new wind turbines deal
item.description:
Harland & Wolff has continued its push into the renewable energy sector by securing a new contract to build 30 wind turbines.
It is understood that an order had been received for 30 turbines, each of which could produce five megawatts of electricity.
The deal is thought to be worth £10m but the company has not officially disclosed who it is.

item.title: Frost & Sullivan Sees Investment Opportunities in China Wind Power Industry
item.description: With the availability of credit and the confidence of investors both declining, 2009 is a difficult year for the global wind power industry. However, the global wind power industry is estimated to grow steadily under the concerns for energy security and global warming, the increasing electric demand in developing countries and the gradual reduction of wind farm construction costs. Besides, since wind power is one of the main solutions to reducing the emission of CO2, with government support by offering preferential policies. Policies and other factors will also help the development of wind power industry through the current financial crisis.

item.title: UK project to reduce costs of offshore wind generation goes ahead
item.description: The UK’s Energy Technologies Institute (ETI) has launched a £5 million project that promises to reduce the cost of offshore wind generation. The project will develop and demonstrate a system for monitoring the condition and performance of wind turbines and predict maintenance needs for damage occurs. The monitoring system could lead to benefits of up to £50,000 per turbine per year, through reduced downtime and maintenance costs, and improved output.

item.title: Offshore Wind Power Group Promotes Interstate Collaboration to Jumpstart US Development
item.description:
Let's face it, the US seriously lags behind Europe in terms of offshore wind farms...way behind. Which makes the New York Times piece on the US Offshore Wind Collaborative all the more interesting. The idea is to develop greater cooperation among states to really develop a complete offshore wind power industry in the US, rather than just plans for individual wind farms:
The idea is to develop shared facilities such a manufacturing "headquarters" and maintenance stations, as well as greater cooperation in developing new transmission infrastructure and everything else needed to really get the US into the offshore wind power game.

item.title: Euro wind producers want billions for sea turbines
item.description: European wind power producers are calling for billions of euros (dollars) in investments to generate energy from wind turbines planted in the sea.

item.title: Nordex Breaks Ground in Jonesboro, Plans to Hire 700
item.description: Nordex USA Inc. of Chicago broke ground Friday morning on a $100 million plant in Jonesboro where some of the world's largest wind turbines will be manufactured.

item.title: Offshore Wind May Provide One-Fifth of EU Electricity
item.description:
Offshore wind may provide as much as 17 percent of European Union electricity demand by 2030, surging from almost nothing now as the bloc promotes renewable energy, an industry group said.
Total installed capacity of offshore wind may jump to 150 gigawatts in 2030 from the current 1.5 gigawatts, the European Wind Energy Association said in a report released today. The share of EU energy consumption coming from renewables must more than double to 20 percent on average by 2020 under a new law for the bloc. Renewable sources include solar power and biomass.

item.title: GE plans 3.5MW wind turbine after ScanWind takeover
item.description: GE has firmly planted its flag in the offshore wind sector by finalising its takeover of Norwegian turbine technologist ScanWind, and unveiling plans to progress development of a 3.5-megwatt (MW) turbine for offshore markets.

item.title: Vestas launches V112-3.0 MW turbine for offshore
item.description: Today, at the European Offshore Wind Conference in Stockholm, Sweden, Vestas will announce a new turbine for the offshore market. The V112-3.0 MW offshore model is optimised for the conditions at sea and will be a hard working, reliable turbine. The V112-3.0 MW Offshore can generate more power than any other turbine in the 3 MW class. It offers an exceptional rotor-to-generator ratio for greater efficiency, and delivers high reliability, serviceability and availability under all wind and weather conditions – setting a whole new standard for turbine performance and efficiency. It features an extended production envelope, and delivers optimal output in average wind speeds up to 9.5 m/s. The V112-3.0 MW will be class individually IECS certified for each separate offshore project.

item.title: Opening up offshore
item.description: Europe is facing the global challenges of climate change, depleting indigenous energy resources, increasing fuel costs and the threat of energy supply disruptions. Harnessing its largest domestic energy resource – offshore wind – would provide an answer to all of these problems. Chris Rose and Sarah Azau investigate what stage the rapidly maturing sector is at and what still needs to be done.

item.title: Siemens launches 3.6 MW wind turbine featuring a 120 meter rotor diameter
item.description:
Siemens has released a 3.6 MW wind turbine featuring a 120 meter rotor diameter.
The SWT-3.6-120 turbine is based on the proven technology of the SWT-3.6-107 ? the world's most popular offshore wind turbine. The new machine will be equipped with 58.5 meter long rotor blades.

item.title: SKF invests in China - SKF doubles Dalian factory capacity and forms strategic partnership with Sinovel Wind Co. Ltd.
item.description:
SKF has today inaugurated its previously announced investment in Dalian factory, Liaoning Province. The SEK 638 million investment was initiated in May 2008, and was the second phase of a project started in 2005, which brings the total investment up to SEK 1.1 billion. A 25,000 ? facility has been added adjacent to the existing factory, doubling the manufacturing capacity.
The aim for this investment is to increase the manufacturing capacity for large and medium size bearings in China. This is in order to support the continuous business growth in China and other parts of Asia, especially in the areas of renewable energy, metalworking, mining, construction and industrial transmission industries. The number of employees will increase from currently 305 to a total of around 600 people when the production is running at full capacity. SKF in Dalian has received the Dalian Preferred Employer Award 2008 and the Dalian Trusted Employer Award 2009.
Today SKF also signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for strategic partnership with Sinovel Wind Co. Ltd., one of the largest wind turbine manufacturers in China. This MoU will create a platform to build a preferred supplier/customer relationship between SKF and Sinovel. The cooperation under this MoU will cover supply chain service system optimization, staff training and development, engineering development and design, as well as resources management.

item.title: Europe’s ports compete for new offshore wind business
item.description: Europe’s coastal ports, some of which have struggled to maintain their economic viability, are enjoying a major boost from the growing offshore wind business. One estimate is that the value of wind farm construction work, excluding turbine manufacture, available to UK ports alone could be as much as £1 billion in the period up to 2020. The result has been increasing competition to gain a slice of this new business opportunity.

item.title: Germany considers plan for 40 new offshore wind farms
item.description: Plans to build up to 40 offshore wind farms could lead to thousands of new jobs in the renewable energy sector and lower Germany's dependence on nuclear energy, according to Transport Minister Wolfgang Tiefensee.

item.title: Funding obstructs EU offshore wind boom - EWEA
item.description:
Enough offshore wind projects are planned to meet one tenth of Europe's energy needs, but not all will emerge due to scarce finance and connections to the power grid, the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA) says. Wind farm capacity on land grew by around 30 percent a year during an explosive decade of growth up to 2004, and EWEA has targeted similar growth for the European Union offshore sector in the next decade. That would lead to cumulative investments of around 57 billion euros ($83 billion) until 2020 to build 40 gigawatts of generating capacity, which could meet about 4 percent of EU energy needs. But bigger plans are already under way, with over 100 gigawatts of offshore wind projects in some stage of planning, EWEA says in its report 'Oceans of Opportunity'.
'If realised, these projects would produce 10 percent of the EU's electricity,' said the report, which will be launched on Monday

item.title: Denmark's DONG Energy said on Monday it had enrolled around 20 corporate and municipal customers for power from its new Horns Rev 2 wind park, which will be inaugurated this week off the west coast of Jutland.
item.description: The Horns Rev 2 wind park in the North Sea will be the world's biggest, with 91 turbines and a total capacity of 209 megawatts. "Alone in August and September, three new partners have signed up (for supplies from Horns Rev 2), so DONG Energy is now up to 20 altogether," Executive Vice President Lars Clausen said in a statement. "And there are more on the way."

item.title: Event news: Fact or fantasy – can offshore wind really deliver by 2020?
item.description: STOCKHOLM - Are European offshore sector players fantasising when they bandy about phrases like 50 per cent wind power by 2050? Given that offshore wind energy currently supplies under per cent of Europe’s power, and that substantial grid and technology development needs to happen before it expands much further, isn’t the industry being unrealistic?

item.title: Event news: Europe’s offshore wind future needs new transnational power grid
item.description:
STOCKHOLM — Building a new energy system for Europe by 2030 may seem like a daunting task since it will require thoughtful planning, exhaustive research, proper engineering, billions of Euros and faith that the end product will be efficient, affordable and long lasting.
But the quicker that a pan-European electricity super highwaystarts taking advantage of the vast potential of wind energy located in the North, Irish and Baltic Seas, the better.

item.title: Hexagon Metrology Introduces Gantry CMMs for Large-Scale Gear Inspection
item.description: NORTH KINGSTOWN, R.I., Sept. 15, 2009 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Hexagon Metrology Inc. today announced the immediate availability of the new Leitz PMM-G gantry CMM series at Gear Expo 2009 being held this week in Indianapolis, IN. With improved specifications and additional size availability, the new Leitz CMM is used for high precision inspection of extremely large components such as gears used for the windpower industry, as well as gear segments, gear racks and geared shafts of up to 5,000 mm in diameter.

item.title: Iberdrola confirms its commitment to Andalusia, where installed wind capacity is set to rise 60% by 2010
item.description: At this morning’s meeting, held at the regional government’s headquarters in Seville, Ignacio Galán outlined to José Antonio Griñán the company's recent successes which have seen it become one of the five leading utilities in the world and one of the four largest companies on the Spanish stock exchange. He also explained its strategy, growth plans and overseas expansion plans. IBERDROLA is currently the leading wind energy producer and one of the world’s major utilities, employing 33,000 people in over 40 countries.

item.title: US Department of Energy Allocates $354 Million to 22 States to Reduce Emissions and Create Green Jobs
item.description: US Energy Secretary Steven Chu announced today that more than $354 million in funding from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act is being awarded to 22 states to support energy efficiency and conservation activities. Under the Department of Energy’s Efficiency and Conservation Block Grant (EECBG) program, these states will implement programs that lower energy use, reduce carbon pollution, and create green jobs locally.

item.title: The world’s biggest wind turbines to be built in Britain
item.description:
The UK is set to be the birthplace of the world’s biggest wind turbine blades, according to Energy and Climate Secretary Ed Miliband.
Miliband said, ‘With strong government backing, the UK is consolidating its lead in offshore wind energy. We already have more offshore wind energy than any other country, we have the biggest wind farm in the world about to start construction, and now we’ll see the biggest turbine blades in the world made here in Britain. Our coastline means the offshore wind industry has the potential to employ tens of thousands of workers by 2020, manufacturing, transporting, installing and operating new turbines.’

item.title: Wind Technology Trends: Why Small Steps Matter
item.description: Although the current slide in overall wind market demand means 2009 figures are unlikely to match recent booms, the dip has not come at the expense of wind technology innovation.

item.title: Baltic Coast Rezoned to Speed Development of Offshore Windmills
item.description: Germany approved changes to zoning rules for the Baltic Sea and the North Sea coastlines to speed development of offshore wind-energy installations.

item.title: Business leaders demand urgent political action on offshore wind energy
item.description: This week European business leaders are signing up to an extraordinary pledge to make it possible to tap Europe's largest energy source - and calling on national governments and the EU to give the necessary political and legislative support.

item.title: Denmark Builds Worlds Largest Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: The world's largest offshore wind farm, with an estimated capacity of 209 megawatts, will begin operation on Thursday. Constructed by Danish energy company Dong Energy, this wind farm's 91 turbines could power a total of about 200,000 households. These wind turbines stand at a height of 114.5 meters and have a rotor diameter of 93 meters, about 30% larger than most new turbines

item.title: Md. turning to offshore wind energy
item.description:
State considers huge turbines off Ocean City, launches impact study The state began its pursuit of offshore wind generation Tuesday, a move that could lead to building 400-foot-tall turbines off Ocean City.
The Maryland Energy Administration asked wind developers to express their interest in building industrial-size windmills a dozen or more miles off the state's 31-mile coastline. At the same time, the energy agency said it is launching a study to gauge the economic viability and environmental impact of such a project.

item.title: Clipper to develop UK blade plant with government grant
item.description: US wind turbine manufacturer Clipper Wind Power will build a plant in the North East of England to manufacture blades for its planned 10 MW offshore turbines with the help of a government grant.

item.title: CEO meets UK energy minister in London
item.description: Chief executive Helge Lund and UK minister for energy and climate change Ed Miliband met in London on Tuesday 15 September, to discuss issues relating to our business in Britain.

item.title: HRH Crown Prince Frederik inaugurates world’s largest offshore wind farm: Horns Rev 2
item.description: This Thursday at noon, His Royal Highness Crown Prince Frederik inaugurated the world’s largest offshore wind farm, Horns Rev 2. The wind farm was constructed and is owned by DONG Energy, and its 91 wind turbines in total will generate green power corresponding to the annual power consumption of 200,000 households

item.title: Vestas announces new initiatives in the offshore sector
item.description: Vestas launches an offshore version of its V112 turbine and enters a partnership with Norwegian research institute Nowitech which has expertise in floating foundations

item.title: GE WIND MIGHT OPEN FACTORIES IN DENMARK
item.description: Denmark is unmatched in the world as the country with most knowledge on offshore wind power. That may attract GE Wind to Denmark.

item.title: Furlander chief affirms Montana as wind turbine assembly plant site
item.description: Furlander’s chief executive will be visiting Montana in the “near future” to advance plans to locate the company’s first US wind turbine assembly plant.

item.title: Airtricity seeks offshore wind co-investors -sources
item.description:
The owner of the largest planned wind farm in the Netherlands, Airtricity, is looking for investors to join its Dutch and German offshore wind projects, people familiar with the matter have said.
Airtricity, which was acquired by Scottish & Southern Energy (SSE.L) (SSE) in February 2008, has approached utilities on joining its 350 megawatts (MW) Breeveertien II and 260 MW West Rijn projects, which received their final permits this month

item.title: Moventas focuses on renewable energy
item.description: Moventas, the biggest wind power player in Finland and globally the third largest wind turbine gear manufacturer will according to its new strategy focus on mechanical power transmission in renewable energy. The company continues also with industrial gears manufacturing that has a supporting and balancing role in the operations. The greatest growth potential, however, is believed to be found in wind power.

item.title: Grid plan for North Sea unveiled
item.description: Plans for a North Sea super grid have been published which would seek to wire up the whole of the offshore sector and connect wind farms which cold feed power into Europe.

item.title: THANET OFFSHORE WIND FARM VESTAS CHOSEN AS PREFERRED TURBINE SUPPLIER
item.description: Thanet Offshore Wind Limited (TOW), a subsidiary of Warwick Energy Limited, has chosen Vestas Offshore A/S (Vestas) as the preferred supplier of wind turbines for the 300MW Thanet project. Vestas will supply 100 of their 3.0MW rated, V90 turbines for the project.

item.title: Wind-powered stations to reach profitability by 2017
item.description:
The energy source is currently heavily subsidised by the Government as it rushes to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and produce 20pc of all power from renewables by 2020 in line with European climate change targets.
However, Rene Umlauft, chief executive of the Siemens division, believes that the rising price of gas and other fossil fuels will make wind farms commercially viable within eight years.

item.title: Gordon Brown bids to secure Siemens wind turbine plant
item.description:
Gordon Brown is wooing the boss of Europe's largest engineering group in a desperate attempt to secure a major new wind turbine plant and reinvigorate the UK's stuttering "green" energy strategy.
The prime minister will meet Peter Löscher, chief executive of Siemens, in the next two weeks to reassure him that Britain can offer an attractive financial package and genuine market growth

item.title: Smart grid development could be a huge money-spinner for Denmark
item.description: With smart grids now being seen as a massive future market opportunity, Denmark is in the fortunate position of being an acknowledged frontrunner

item.title: Clipper plans to produce 10 MW turbine in UK by 2015-16
item.description: US wind turbine manufacturer Clipper Windpower plans to be have “significant quantities” of its planned 10 MW offshore wind turbine available for delivery by 2015-16.

item.title: Warren Buffett in UK wind bid
item.description:
AMERICAN investor Warren Buffett is considering making a £1 billion bet on Britain’s green energy revolution.
The government wants to make Britain the world’s largest offshore wind energy generator, but the plans require hundreds of miles of undersea cables to bring the electricity ashore to the national grid.
The network is expected to cost more than £12 billion and regulator Ofgem has launched an auction for the rights to build and maintain it.

item.title: Offshore future for UK windfarms
item.description:
Onshore windfarms may have little future in the UK as turbine companies fear local opposition and laborious planning processes.
The difficulty is forcing some traditionally onshore wind-turbine companies to consider offshore installations as their entryway into the UK wind-energy market

item.title: Event news: Offshore wind power can help revolutionise Europe’s energy future
item.description:
STOCKHOLM — It is fitting that a new plan to power Europe in the future with a massive increase in offshore wind energy was released today here in this historic 13th century city of islands on Sweden’s southeast coast where Lake Malaren meets the relentless Baltic Sea.
Swedish mariners have known for more than eight centuries that the combined power of wind and water is an unstoppable force to be reckoned with, feared, admired and exploited.

item.title: Alpha Ventus Success for Norwind
item.description: NorWind successfully installed six jackets for offshore wind at Alpha Ventus, Germany’s first offshore wind farm. NorWind has successfully built and installed the world’s first jackets for the offshore wind industry based on the concept of pre-installed piles. The Alpha Ventus Project is Germany’s first offshore wind farm situated 45 km to the north of the Borkum Island in the German Bight.

item.title: Benefits likely from offshore wind farm
item.description: State officials are now taking steps to explore the potential for developing wind energy off Maryland's coast, which could result in inexpensive, clean and renewable energy for hundreds of thousands of homes in the future.

item.title: Offshore Wind: Europe Now, U.S. When
item.description:
Every two years, the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA) holds a major conference on offshore wind energy.
The last time EWEA convened its offshore event, in December 2007 in Berlin, the mood was relatively somber. Several major offshore wind projects had been completed, but had run into unforeseen technical and economic challenges. European policies and regulations for the next phase of offshore wind energy were in flux. Although everyone was convinced that offshore wind was going to be a significant growth sector in the European energy mix, there were real doubts as to when such opportunities would actually come to fruition.

item.title: Wind Energy: The Fall in Orders in 2009 Will Affect Revenues in 2010. New Growth Strategies Are Now Essential, Says Frost & Sullivan
item.description: Due to the strong growth and placement of wind turbine orders in 2008 and the lead time between placing the orders and shipping them out to customers, the top line for wind turbine manufacturers in 2009 has been relatively unaffected. However, the fall in orders in 2009 will affect revenues of these companies in 2010. Therefore, it is essential for companies to adopt new strategies to keep their margins intact. And some companies have already started taking extraordinary and urgent measures to sustain and accelerate growth in a tough environment.

item.title: Connections chance to export wind energy
item.description:
The Single Electricity Market (SEM) on this island and future links to Wales and Scotland offer an opportunity to make Ireland a leading European exporter of wind energy.
That's according to Minister for Communications, Energy and Natural Resources, Eamon Ryan TD, who was speaking at a conference in Stockholm.

item.title: We Can Do That! U.S. States Scent Opportunity and Jobs in Wind Manufacturing
item.description: In early summer, state reps attended the AWEA 2009 event in Chicago in force, vying for the attention of the European wind manufacturers that they hope will bring their states much-needed jobs. ... State governments outside the nation’s windy midsection also are competing for renewable energy jobs. In the northeast, New York and Canada want to attract offshore wind farms, each to their own side of the Great Lakes, knowing that manufacturers tend to locate close to projects to avert transportation costs.

item.title: Eddie O’Connor wins Leadership award at Ernst & Young Global Renewable Energy Awards
item.description:
Eddie O’Connor, founder and CEO of Mainstream Renewable Power, was presented with the first ever Leadership award at the annual Ernst & Young Global Renewable Energy Awards in London’s Science Museum last night. EU Energy Commissioner, Andris Piebalgs was also nominated for the award.
Former CEO of Airtricity, Dr. O’Connor founded Mainstream Renewable Power in February of last year and during this time has created a significant pipeline of onshore and offshore wind farm projects in Europe, North America, South America and South Africa. Mainstream was also shortlisted for the “Entrepreneurial Developer of the Year” award at last night’s ceremony.

item.title: Port of Esbjerg could make a fortune from North Sea offshore wind
item.description: Energy business analysts Douglas-Westwood reckons the port of Esbjerg is well placed to capitalise on the huge potential of offshore wind in the North Sea

item.title: GE Energy Signs Service Agreements with Customers Looking to Maximize Performance in Close to 1000 Megawatts (MW) of Wind Turbines
item.description: North American GE 1.5 megawatt (MW) wind turbine owners and operators are benefiting from the flexibility and scope that GE Energy’s wind service program provides. The company recently signed three customized operations and maintenance (O&M) agreements for projects encompassing over 600 1.5-megawatt (MW) wind turbines located in diverse environments across North America.

item.title: Wind-powered stations to reach profitability by 2017
item.description:
The energy source is currently heavily subsidised by the Government as it rushes to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and produce 20pc of all power from renewables by 2020 in line with European climate change targets.
However, Rene Umlauft, chief executive of the Siemens division, believes that the rising price of gas and other fossil fuels will make wind farms commercially viable within eight years

item.title: Vestas buys extra land to attract its sub-suppliers to locate in US
item.description:
Denmark's Vestas Wind Systems, the world's leading manufacturer of wind turbines, is setting its sights on attracting sub-suppliers to locate around its US manufacturing facilities in Colorado, writes financial daily newspaper Børsen.
Vestas has a blade factory in upstate Windsor, which started up in March 2008, and has since announced three further facilities in the Centennial State: a second blade factory and a nacelle assembly plant in Brighton, both expected to be operational in 2010, and what it has billed as the world's largest turbine tower factory to be built in the steel town of Pueblo.

item.title: Wind Power Giant Shows Interest in State ; Maine Officials Pitch the State's Turbine Siting Potential to Iberdrola, a Spanish Company That Owns CMP. Series: TRADE MISSION TO EUROPE
item.description: On the first official day of a trade mission focused on renewable energy, Gov. John Baldacci and about 10 business people from Maine visited Iberdrola, the parent company of Energy East. Energy East, in turn, is the parent of Central Maine Power Co., which has 600,000 customers in the state and employs more than 1,200 people. ... Iberdrola has wind farms in Connecticut, Texas and on the West Coast. As Maine aggressively pursues wind projects for both the interior of the state and the embryonic offshore market, having Iberdrola, the "world leader in renewable energy," set up a project in the state would "back up Maine on the world stage," Baldacci said

item.title: Ontario to upgrade power grid to deliver more renewable energy
item.description: Ontario Province will invest C$2.3bn over the next three years to expand and modernize its power transmission grid in preparation for delivery of more green electricity.

item.title: New wind turbines arrive at port
item.description:
WORK on a giant off shore wind farm close to the Essex coast is continuing a pace.
These massive turbine parts could be seen at the Port of Felixstowe over the weekend on their way to nearby Harwich before going to the Gunfleet Sands windfarm, off the coast of Clacton-on-Sea.
Developers Dong Energy said some 20 turbines have now been installed - with five already commissioned and working.

item.title: Vattenfall’s CEO becomes UN climate advisor
item.description: Vattenfall’s CEO, Mr. Lars G Josefsson, has accepted an invitation from the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr. Ban Ki-moon, to join his new Advisory Group on Energy and Climate.

item.title: Iberdrola Renewables awarded nearly $251m in Treasury Grants to generate clean energy
item.description: Spanish renewable energy giant Iberdrola Renewables confirmed it has received US Treasury Department approval of three additional grants totalling $250,953,367. These grants represent investment by Iberdrola Renewables of approximately $860m in US wind power in three states.

item.title: Ofgem announces offshore wind connection short list
item.description:
Several of Europe's largest energy and infrastructure firms were celebrating today after Ofgem announced a shortlist of thirteen bids for projects to build and run nine high-voltage transmission links to offshore wind farms.
The tenders – worth £1.15bn in total – will grant licences to build and run links to nine separate wind farms generating over 2,000MW of electricity. The successful bidders will own the links and charge energy firms to transmit electricity across them for a 20 year period under a regulated income.

item.title: EDP to issue U.S.$ 1,000,000,000 of Notes
item.description: EDP Finance B.V. launched and priced today an offering of a total of U.S.$ 1,000,000,000 of Rule 144A and Regulation S notes, maturing in October 2019 with a coupon of 4.9% (the "Notes").

item.title: EWEA's opinion: One more step towards realising a European transnational offshore grid
item.description: Somewhat obscured in the cascading avalanche of information surging throughout the crowded hallways and meeting rooms of last week’s highly successful Offshore Wind 2009 conference in Stockholm, was a declaration from the fourth European Policy Workshop on Offshore Wind Power Deployment.

item.title: Vestas is 11 billion behind
item.description: Vestas wind turbines need to sell for billions, if the company must make up its target for the year's turnover.

item.title: WinWinD commissions first plant in Chennai
item.description: WinWinD Power Energy (P) Ltd on September 9 inaugurated its first wind turbine generator facility. Located at Vengal, some 50 km from Chennai, the modern facility will design, develop and manufacture utility grade turbines in the megawatt and multi-megawatt category

item.title: Nasdaq eyes European players for new UK power market
item.description: Next month's launch of the N2EX exchange and clearing facility will encourage European physical power traders and financial institutions to enter the British wholesale power market, the head of Nasdaq OMX Commodities said.

item.title: Wind Prospect awarded consultancy contract by GE Energy
item.description: Wind Prospect’s consultancy division has signed a five-year contract to provide development and technical services to GE Energy.

item.title: Gamesa and Iberdrola implement their strategic agreement
item.description: Gamesa Energía and Iberdrola Renovables have announced the implementation of the strategic agreement they signed in June 2008 to jointly promote, develop and operate wind farms in Europe.

item.title: Global wind leaders push climate legislation
item.description:
The wind power business will grow at a slower pace, buffeted by stiff competition from Europe and China, unless Congress approves climate change legislation, global industry leaders said Thursday.
The leaders pressed their case at a Washington, D.C., news conference called as federal legislation is pending that would curb carbon emissions and require utilities to generate a percentage of electricity from renewable sources.

item.title: Cumbrian firm wins offshore wind contract
item.description:
A technology firm in Cumbria has won a government contract to carry out aerial surveys of sites that could potentially be used for windfarms.
Whitehaven-based HiDef will carry out the service through the deal with the Crown Estate, the News and Star newspaper reports.

item.title: Bidders chosen for £1bn offshore links tender
item.description:
Thirteen companies are in the running to buy £1.15bn-worth of electricity transmission links to nine offshore windfarms as part of a £15bn plan to improve competition in the UK's green energy infrastructure.
The new regime from regulator Ofgem comes against the backdrop of the Government's target for another 33 gigawatts of offshore wind – or around 50 per cent of the current installed capacity – be built by 2020.

item.title: ABB’s first locally designed and manufactured 3-phase shunt reactor rolls off the production line in China
item.description: ABB, the leading power and automation technology group, recently announced the rolling off of its first locally designed and manufactured 3-phase shunt reactor at ABB Chongqing Transformer Co. Ltd. The new reactor will be deployed as part of the power grid project managed by SP PowerGrid Ltd., a member of the Singapore Power Group. It’s further evidence of ABB’s successful technology transfer and local R&D in China, greatly improving the competitiveness of “Chinese Manufacturing

item.title: Tender: UK-Warwick: electricity distribution
item.description:
Title attributed to the contract by the contracting entity: Anglo-Scottish HVDC Western Link. The design and engineering and potentially detailed design and engineering, procurement, manufacture, installation, construction, testing and commissioning (maintenance may be included) of an HVDC link between Scotland and England/Wales with an anticipated in service date of 2015.
It is envisaged that the project will develop in phases, subject at each stage to the relevant funding and regulatory consents.

item.title: No Off-Shore Wind NIMBYism, Gigantic Potential for Mid-Atlantic States
item.description:
An amazingly high percentage of people who live down the Mid-Atlantic Seaboard from New York to Virginia want wind turbines off their coast.
Even if they can be seen from the shoreline, 67% support off-shore wind power, according to a new poll of coastal residents of New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, and Virginia , jointly commissioned by governors of the five states, in trying to see if there was any agreement on coastal development

item.title: Dong Energy: 'Clean' Denmark's dirty secret
item.description: The Danes like to think of themselves as green. Denmark is home to the world's largest wind turbine manufacturer, Vestas. And today, the giant state-owned energy company, Dong Energy, opens the world's largest windfarm. But the Danes have a dirty secret. For Dong Energy, while greening its image at home, is busy building coal-fired power stations elsewhere in Europe. First in Germany, and now in Scotland.

item.title: China Backs Market Price for Wind Power
item.description:
BEIJING -- A top Chinese energy policy official said Friday the price for wind power and other renewable energy should be set by market forces, rejecting calls for fixed prices, a system used in some countries to promote the use of renewable energy.
As China looks to renewables to fill more of its energy needs, many Chinese power companies are looking to develop wind energy but are worried about profitability and thus looking for price guarantees.
"Calls to set renewable energy prices at a high level through a fixed government price are mainly coming from investors," said Zhang Guobao, vice minister of the National Development and Reform Commission, at a press briefing. "But the result, if prices are fixed too high, would be to impact the widespread use of renewable energy."

item.title: Floating turbines open wind potential
item.description: In the scramble to harness ocean wind power, floating turbine technology may be the holy grail. Turbines that can be floated into position and anchored in deeper water are the solution to much of the politics that confronts shallow-water projects, according to proponents of the concept.

item.title: Are Wind Turbine Step-up Transformers The Weak Link In The Wind Energy Supply Chain
item.description: In the rush to cash-in on wind energy, developers are often trading low first costs for higher total costs of This head long rush to install more and more wind turbines has outstripped the usual developmental learning curve, where new technologies mature by a process of trial and error, resulting in defining equipment suited for the job at hand.

item.title: Crown to net up to £2bn from sale of offshore wind turbine sites
item.description: The Queen's property manager, the Crown Estate, will next week update the industry on the auction of offshore windpower rights that could generate billions of pounds for the Crown from up to 7,000 turbines around the coast. For months the Crown Estate has been negotiating with dozens of companies for 20-year leases to operate wind turbines in nine areas.

item.title: Scottish and Southern provides major projects update
item.description: Scottish and Southern Energy plc (SSE) will enter its close period on 1 October 2009, prior to the publication on 11 November 2009 of its financial report for the six months to 30 September 2009.

item.title: Companies Call on EU to Develop Wind Industry
item.description: More than 140 company representatives in 38 countries have signed the European Offshore Wind Declaration, calling on national governments and the EU to give the necessary political and legislative support to develop a new multi-billion Euro offshore wind industry.

item.title: Vestas deploys SEE Electrical electrical design software
item.description: Selecting IGE+XAO’s SEE Electrical as the electrical design reference software was key to Vestas China. The company was looking for a software package which would allow to design both electrical schematics and wiring diagrams, manage wires, cables and shielding and hence generates automatically all types of lists (product, wire, cable and terminal lists).

item.title: Maine wind trade mission yields pact
item.description:
AUGUSTA, Maine—The wind-power trade mission to Europe led by Gov. John Baldacci has brought about an agreement with a Norwegian firm for further study into deep-water offshore generation.
Baldacci and Habib Dagher, director of the University of Maine's Advanced Structures and Composites Center, signed the agreement with StatoilHydro to collaborate on research and development to see whether the Norwegian company's offshore turbine would work in the Gulf of Maine.

item.title: Canadian Hydro Acquires World's Largest Offshore Wind Prospect
item.description: Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc. ("Canadian Hydro" or the "Company") (TSX:KHD - News) has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the rights to a 4,400 MW offshore wind prospect ("Offshore Wind Prospect") in Ontario from Wasatch Wind, Inc., a private U.S.-based renewable energy company. When completed, this facility would be the largest offshore operation in the world, supplying enough renewable energy to power over two million homes. The agreement is subject to customary due diligence and the terms are confidential.

item.title: Leviathan readies for Greater Gabbard start
item.description: Newbuild jackup installation vessel Seajacks Leviathan was heading out to start construction work on the UK's next largest offshore wind farm this week after being accepted for delivery.

item.title: European Investment Bank to help fund new wind farms and undersea cable between Ireland and Wales
item.description:
The European Investment Bank (EIB) is to lend €500m (£460m) to Ireland's national grid operator and main power supplier to help with the development of renewable energy infrastructure.
It will give EirGrid €300m to help with the construction of an undersea cable between Ireland and Wales to allow the import and export of wind power, while a further €200m will be given to the Electricity Supply Board towards financing wind farms that are expected to deliver 248MW of new capacity by 2012.

item.title: Samsung deal just the start
item.description:
When asked about the Ontario government's decision last week to restrict development of solar "farms" on prime agricultural land, Milfred Hammerbacher offered an honest, reasonable response.
"It would be almost offensive for us to complain about this," said Hammerbacher, an executive at solar module manufacturer Canadian Solar Inc.
Sure, we're hearing complaints from the wind industry about arbitrary turbine setbacks and how it will kill wind projects. We're also hearing the big solar developers sounding off about the building ban on Class 1 and 2 agricultural lands and how it will, well, kill solar projects.

item.title: Slowdown signs - US wind power growth rate slows down
item.description: Reuters reported that United States will add 6,000 MW in wind power this year down by nearly 30% YoY as the credit crisis slowed expansion of the renewable energy source. Wind power has been one of the fastest growing sources of power generation, and the 2009 additions are equivalent to about six coal fired power plants.

item.title: Welding defects delay Greater Gabbard
item.description: Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm developer Scottish and Southern Energy has revealed that welding defects have been found in the first batch of monopile turbine foundations built for the project which has been delayed.

item.title: SWAY Seeks Concession For Test Turbine In Øygarden, Norway
item.description: Sway A/S (Sway) has applied for a test concession from the Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate for constructing a test turbine in Naturgassparken in Øygarden (West Coast of Norway). The construction of the prototype will be conditional on financial support from Enova. The wind turbine will have a capacity of 10 MW and a rotor diameter of 145 meters.

item.title: Siemens looking at North-East sites for new factory
item.description:
The German firm is understood to have looked at a number of locations in North Tyneside where it already owns a turbine servicing company.
The move could potentially create hundreds of jobs. However, Siemens said that, although it was planning two factories, the UK was just one candidate with a spokeswoman saying it had not decided on a country or region.

item.title: Norway's StatoilHydro, Statkraft seen frontrunners for UK Dogger Bank wind power development
item.description: The wind-power industry expects that Norwegian oil major StatoilHydro ASA (OSL: STL) and state utility Statkraft AS will get the contract for the development of offshore wind farm Dogger Bank, Matthew Knight, business development director for Siemens (ETR:SIE) in the UK, told Norwegian business daily Dagens Naeringsliv (DN) on Tuesday.

item.title: [Euro]300bn for Offshore Windfarms
item.description: SOME [euro]300 billion is set to be invested in European offshore windfarms over the next 20 years, according to a new report from wind turbine manufacturer Siemens.

item.title: Offshore wind-turbine monitoring
item.description:
Strathclyde engineers are helping to develop and demonstrate a new monitoring system that could reduce the cost of generating electricity from offshore wind farms.
The £5m condition-monitoring project is funded by the Energy Technologies Institute (ETI), and is being led by UK-based wind turbine blade monitoring specialist Insensys in partnership with Strathclyde, EDF Energy, E.ON, Romax Technology, and SeeByte

item.title: Improving Energy Security and Reducing Carbon Intensity in Asia and the Pacific
item.description: The developing Asia Pacific (DAP) region is at a critical juncture today, needing energy to continue its rapid economic growth and provide for the millions of its poor while at the same time facing the challenge of developing in a more sustainable manner than it is now. A detailed analysis of the socioeconomic conditions and the energy resource endowment within countries of the region, their perceptions of energy vulnerability, an assessment of what are perceived to be real options to overcome the vulnerability and the barriers to exercising these options reveals an interesting, but challenging, mosaic of issues that would need to be address to facilitate the transition to a clean and secure energy future.

item.title: AMSC To Supply Sinovel 3-MW Turbine Parts
item.description: Beijing-based Sinovel Wind has signed a contract worth more than $100 million with American Superconductor Corporation (AMSC) for core electrical components to be utilized in Sinovel's 3 MW wind turbines.

item.title: REpower: First turbine for alpha ventus offshore wind farm installed
item.description: Today, REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703) has erected the first of a total of six REpower 5M turbines for the alpha ventus offshore test field. The systems each have a rated power of five megawatts (MW), with a blade tip height of 155 meters above sea level. The first German offshore project is being built by a consortium of companies consisting of EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall. The alpha ventus offshore wind farm is located approximately 45 kilometers north of the island of Borkum.

item.title: Potential Investment in Clipper Windpower Plc
item.description: The Directors of Clipper Windpower Plc (“Clipper” or “the Company”) announced that the Company, as a result of a comprehensive capital raising process, has initiated discussions and received approaches from a number of parties comprising both industrial multinationals and financial investors that could lead to a significant investment in the Company. Subject to the size and structure of any transaction, it is expected that Clipper's new partner could range from owning a substantial minority position, investing at or around the current market price, to acquiring all of Clipper's outstanding share capital. These competitive discussions are at an advanced stage and it is anticipated that an investment could be announced and completed before the Company's financial year end. Any investment would be subject to shareholder approval. Despite the current advanced status of the discussions, there can be no certainty as to terms or structure, or that an investment will happen.

item.title: PNE WIND AG Presented at Jefferies 8th Global Clean Technology Conference
item.description:
PNE WIND AG announced that Martin Billhardt, chief executive officer, presented at the Jefferies 8th Global Clean Technology Conference on September 30, 2009, at 11:45 a.m. Central European Summer Time. A webcast of the presentation can be accessed at the following link: http://www.wsw.com/webcast/jeff39/pne3/
The archived webcast will be available at this link for 90 days following the live presentation.

item.title: Acciona studies part-sale of wind turbine unit
item.description: Spanish energy engineering and construction company Acciona SA is considering the sale of part of its wind turbine manufacturing business, a company executive told the Jefferies clean energy conference in London. "Probably Acciona doesn't need 100 percent of that," investment relations spokeswoman Ines Prieto Ortega told Reuters. "I don't think you'll see an announcement in the short term, we shall see." The company would first concentrate on absorbing excess wind turbine inventory through 2010, Ortega said, adding that the business "is not going through its best year".

item.title: Hyundai Heavy Enters US Wind Turbine Market
item.description: Hyundai Heavy Industries (HHI) signed a contract with Wave Wind, LLC to provide six 1.65MW wind turbines on September 30. The companies also agreed to expand cooperation in the 100MW capacity wind turbine project

item.title: Wind, solar execs eye U.S., China for growth
item.description: U.S. and China markets are driving recovery in the global clean energy industry, after a sharp fall in investment this year, but uncertainty over government support is clouding the 2010 outlook.

item.title: Outlook for US Offshore Wind Projects: Favorable with High Gusts
item.description: The United States is viewed as one of the next big markets for offshore wind generation. Now that the Cape Wind project is considered more likely than not to proceed and the favorable political climate towards renewables, it is not a question of whether U.S. offshore wind farms will get built but how many.

item.title: Ofgem Reveals Shortlist for £1.15 Billion Offshore Grid
item.description: Researched by Industrial Info Resources (Sugar Land, Texas)--The United Kingdom's energy regulator Ofgem has revealed a shortlist of 13 companies that will be allowed to bid for nine multimillion pound contracts to build and operate high-voltage transmission links with offshore windfarms.

item.title: Strathclyde engineers are helping to develop and demonstrate a new monitoring system that could reduce the cost of generating electricity from offshore wind farms
item.description: The £5m condition-monitoring project is funded by the Energy Technologies Institute (ETI), and is being led by UK-based wind turbine blade monitoring specialist Insensys in partnership with Strathclyde, EDF Energy, E.ON, Romax Technology, and SeeByte. The consortium will develop and demonstrate advanced systems to monitor the condition and performance of turbines and predict future maintenance requirements for key components so they can be corrected before expensive damage occurs.

item.title: Propulsion system for breakthrough wind farm ship
item.description: Germany’s Voith Turbo is developing a new marine propulsion system for installation into a special mobile offshore construction vessel which will be used for the installation of offshore wind farms.

item.title: Renewable energy? It's an offshore thing
item.description: Radical plans are afoot in Britain to build wind farms in the North Sea. Terry Macalister sees how it works in Lillgrund, Sweden. Imagine what it is like to open the bonnet of your car, stand on top of the engine and be hoisted 85m above the North Sea on a perilously narrow pole. The view on a clear day is breathtaking, but when the wind is blowing so hard the whole contraption swings 4m from side to side, it is grim – even for Leif Bolther.

item.title: Briefing held on progress of proposed wind farms
item.description: Rhode Island’s congressional delegation met with Governor Carcieri and other officials on Friday for a briefing on the progress of two wind farms being proposed in state coastal waters.

item.title: Turbine ship proves to be an idea with legs
item.description: One of the world’s oddest looking ships will anchor off the Suffolk coast this week. Think of a giant table, with legs nearly 290ft long, bobbing upside down in the sea. That is more or less what the Leviathan looks like. There are only two other “jack-up” boats like it — built to install the giant offshore windmills the government hopes will soon ring the British Isles.

item.title: Bill Includes $5M to Study Offshore Wind
item.description: A budget bill that appears headed for final passage in Congress includes $5 million for research and development of offshore wind turbines at the University of Maine in Orono.

item.title: Arrival of Seajacks Leviathan Liftboat Marks Start of Contract at World’s Largest Offshore Wind Development
item.description: Seajacks, the UK jack-up liftboat operator, has delivered its Leviathan vessel to Fluor Ltd on time and on budget, marking the start of its offshore charter works at Greater Gabbard, the world’s largest offshore wind energy development under construction. Fluor, working for project owners Airtricity and npower renewables, will install 140 turbines at the site, 25 kilometres off the East coast of England in the outer Thames Estuary.

item.title: TN EDITORIAL: Wind power has merit
item.description: Researchers at UNC Chapel Hill have concluded what many North Carolinians have long surmised: Strong winds in the coastal region mean there's a potential for large-scale wind energy generators — offshore and perhaps in part of eastern Pamlico Sound.

item.title: Lisbon Treaty puts wind in sail of EU's renewables targets: EWEA
item.description: Ireland’s resounding approval of the Lisbon Treaty over the weekend gives a “significant boost” to plans to expand renewable-energy generation and build electricity networks and interconnectors across the EU, according to the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA).

item.title: Pioneering Wind Farm Faces Another Delay, This Time Over Indian Sites
item.description: Final approval for Cape Wind is stalled, aggravating developers of the Massachusetts offshore wind project and igniting concerns that the latest roadblock -- over American Indian ceremonies -- could jeopardize other ocean-based energy proposals.

item.title: EC To Grant More Than GBP100 Million Funds For Wind Farm And Transmission Project In Scotland
item.description: European Commission (EC) will provide more than GBP100 million for two green enery projects in Scotland, news.scotsman.com reported. The commission will grant GBP37 million for a planned offshore wind power project in Aberdeen coast and another GBP47 million for a transmission project off the north coast of Scotland. The funding will be formally announced in later October 2009.

item.title: Duke Energy Plans Offshore Wind Pilot Project
item.description: North Carolina could become the first state in the country to see wind turbines planted in offshore waters.

item.title: GC China Turbine Corp. Announces Signing of Definitive Agreement With GC Nordic -- Provides Additional Details Regarding the Company
item.description: GC China Turbine Corp. (OTCBB: GCHT) (the "Company") wishes to provide notice of a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) this week, outlining a Material Definitive Share Exchange Agreement (the "Agreement") with Wuhan Guoce Nordic New Energy Co. Ltd., a People's Republic of China Company ("GC Nordic"), as a requirement of the previously announced voluntary share exchange transaction.

item.title: GE buys more than a 3.5-MW turbine manufacturer
item.description: GE says it has acquired ScanWind, a developer of advanced gearbox-free drive trains aimed at offshore deployment. The company manufacturers and markets direct-drive wind turbines from its headquarters in Trondheim, Norway and a design-engineering center in Karlstad, Sweden. Direct drives connect the rotor to a generator that operates at low rotational speeds creating a simpler and more reliable drive train. The company has 11 of the turbines operating on the Norwegian coast.

item.title: National Grid plans world's longest underwater power cable between Britain and Norway
item.description: Britain and Norway are planning the world's longest underwater power cable to share wind farms in the North Sea and help bring down electricity prices. National Grid, the UK's network operator, yesterday made an agreement with its Norwegian equivalent, Statnett, to draw up proposals for a link-up that is likely to cost around £1bn.

item.title: Harland's Steel Giant Gets Ready to Set Sail
item.description: A SPECTACULAR Belfast-made steel structure designed for processing renewable energy will set sail for Germany tomorrow. The 7,500 tonne offshore transformer, partly built by Harland and Wolff in a multi-million pound contract, will sit on the seabed north of Germany where it will convert the energy of 60 offshore wind turbines and connect it to the European grid system.

item.title: Dong/CEO: Declines in revenue hit wind and offshore
item.description: The Danish energy giant Dongs plans on setting up wind farms on land and at sea, is being hit by decreasing willingness to invest.

item.title: European offshore wind is unlocking the supergrid
item.description: Siemens Wind Power chief executive Andreas Nauen spoke for many at the European Offshore Wind conference in Stockholm, Sweden when he avowed that the world is on the cusp of a “new age of electricity”.

item.title: Wind power centre will keep Scotland in vanguard of renewable energy
item.description: Glasgow secured a major jobs boost yesterday with the announcement by Scottish and Southern Energy (SSE) that 300 jobs are to be created over the next three years in a new research and management centre for wind farm projects.

item.title: Roxtec to Supply World’s Largest Offshore Windfarm
item.description: Bury-based international safety-seal giant Roxtec has signed a major deal to supply the world’s largest offshore wind farm in the North Sea. Swedish-owned Roxtec will supply a range of cable seals to the Greater Gabbard wind farm off the Suffolk coast currently being developed by Scottish and Southern Energy and RWE npower renewables.

item.title: UK expects $160 billion offshore wind investment
