item.description: Britain expects around 100 billion pounds ($159 billion) of investment in a third round of offshore wind projects by 2020 and about 5 billion in its Pentland Firth marine energy scheme, the agency in charge of the coastal seabed said.

item.title: Norwegian firm builds Wells base
item.description: A NORWEGIAN energy firm is preparing to build its long-term base in Wells after dredging works began to improve access to its £1bn offshore windfarm. A deal was signed in June which confirmed the town as the operational hub for the planned Sheringham Shoal project, whose 88 turbines are due to be generating power by the end of 2011.

item.title: GE Win in Mitsubishi Turbine Case to Be Reviewed
item.description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. persuaded a U.S. trade agency to review a finding that it infringes General Electric Co. patents for wind turbines and should be banned from the U.S.

item.title: Offshore Wind: Time for a Market Take-off?
item.description: Offshore wind activity is experiencing significant growth now in terms of capacity installed. However, the industry is struggling with the costs of development, which have more doubled in 5 years.

item.title: States Have the Wind at Their Backs in the Offshore Debate
item.description: Eastern states advanced their commitment this week to quell the fierce competition around building the nation's first offshore wind farm and cooperate toward creating and pushing a web of ocean-based turbine facilities.

item.title: Norway's prime minister open to more stringent CO2 reductions
item.description: Newly re-elected Norwegian Prime Minster Jens Stoltenberg re-iterated his pledge to raise his country’s 2020 carbon emissions-reduction target from 30% to 40% over its 1990 level if doing so helps break the political deadlock anticipated in Copenhagen.

item.title: Need to Expand on Offshore Energy Highlighted
item.description: JOINT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNICATIONS: IRELAND IS falling well behind other countries in the development of offshore renewable energy, an Oireachtas committee has heard. The target of producing 40 per cent of our energy needs from renewable sources by 2020 is easily achieveable, David Manning, public affairs manager of Airtricity, told the Joint Committee on communications, energy and natural resources. However, progress was urgently needed in creating the grid to deliver this energy to customers.

item.title: European offshore wind projects confront challenging seas
item.description: As the winds blowing over Lolland Island turned a morning drizzle into a cold shower, Bjarne Haxgart told his crew that, as on many days this past August, they would stay indoors. 'This year we have had an awful lot of wind,' said Haxgart, site manager of the Rødsand 2 offshore wind farm. 'It's a big difference for the people who are out there doing the work. If it's a little windy, they would be green in the face by the time we got there.'

item.title: Northeast States Rush to Build Nation's First Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: US states in the Northeast are uniting to take advantage of their greatest potential renewable energy source: the blustery winds off the Atlantic coast. It's extremely tricky business, but states from New Jersey to Maine are ready to get plans for the nation's first offshore wind farm off the ground.

item.title: Canadian Renewable Energy Star to Brighten the Stage at FiReGlobal : West Coast
item.description: FiReGlobal : West Coast is proud to announce that Sea Breeze Power Corp. has been selected as a FiReStar company to be featured at the FiReGlobal : West Coast conference. FiReStar companies, both local and global, are pre-selected based on their potential to bring positive change to the world.

item.title: Ramboll wins detailed design of Gwynt y Môr Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: Following an international process we have been selected to deliver the detailed design of the wind turbine foundations for stage one of the Gwynt y Môr offshore wind farm, off the North Wales coast. The contract is for the first phase of foundation design works, and focuses on the first 92 foundations which form part of the more extensive Gwynt y Môr Offshore Wind Farm, one of the largest round 2 offshore wind farms to be consented in the UK.

item.title: Building permit for the Swedish wind farm Finngrunden requested
item.description: wpd think energy GmbH & Co. KG, a Bremen, Germany, located manager and developer of systems for renewable energy, has applied for the permission of building the wind farm Finngrunden in Sweden.

item.title: Offshore wind turbines by Sprogø receive tech overcoat
item.description: Muehlhan A/S is in charge for rust protection of the seven, 70 meters tall offshore wind turbines, which from December will deliver green energy for the Great Belt Bridge and Oresund Bridge.

item.title: Vestas could lose market worth billions due to turbines at sea
item.description: The world's largest wind turbine manufacturer Vestas is left behind on the potential offshore market worth billions. The market is now dominated by the rivalen Siemens. Among analysts, however, confident that Vestas regain the market presence.

item.title: Lindo Offshore Renewable Center gets ready for start-off
item.description: Already before Christmas the foundation should be in place for the new powerhouse for green energy. It was a result of yesterday's meeting.

item.title: New, large offshore wind turbine on its way from Vestas
item.description: Vestas is now trying to get back into the battle against competitor Siemens when it comes to offshore wind turbines. Lastly, the offshore wind turbine V112-3.0 was launched, but in connection with the third quarter the industry giant is expected to unveil an even bigger offshore wind turbine.

item.title: Vestas Offshore A/S are Confirmed as Conference Speakers at the Offshore Wind Energy in North America and Great Lakes conference
item.description: The worldwide manufacturing leader of wind turbines gives exclusive insight into the next generation of turbine designs for offshore generation at the leading North American offshore wind conference

item.title: Government initiatives in Denmark driving the wind energy sector, finds Netscribes
item.description: Netscribes (India) Pvt. Ltd., launches its Wind Energy - Denmark report covering an industry with strong growth potential. The strong electricity export market is expected to boost the wind energy sector in Denmark.

item.title: Wind of change
item.description: The target to install 25GW of offshore wind power by 2020 has been discussed many times in the press and at wind energy conferences. Ideas are coming to light about how to make this possible, looking at supply-chain issues and installation methods, for example.

item.title: Duke Energy floats US offshore wind pilot
item.description: US energy giant moves forward with plans for three trial turbines. The race to build the first US offshore wind farm heated up this week when Duke Energy announced plans for a pilot project involving three demonstration turbines off the east coast.

item.title: Pump Up the Volume: Using Hydro Storage to Support Wind Integration
item.description: Grid operators and utilities in countries around the globe are grappling with the new challenge of incorporating large amounts of variable renewables, such as wind power, onto their systems.

item.title: Vestas in lack of orders
item.description: Group Vestas in Randers lacks orders for billions of dollars to meet its targets for sales of new wind turbines.

item.title: Wind power puts American Superconductor in play
item.description: The allure of a bigger share of the fast-growing wind power market might force larger engineering companies to target American Superconductor Corp, a maker of electrical systems that run wind farms and turbines.

item.title: Offshore Wind Energy Firms Hopeful of Major EU Support
item.description: OFFSHORE WIND energy producers are hoping major support for the industry will be signalled by EU Commissioner for Energy Andris Piebalgs, when he addresses their annual conference in Dublin today.

item.title: JDR Cables, Blowing in the wind
item.description: TM assistant editor Edward Machin meets JDR Cable Systems’ managing director, Patrick Phelan, to discuss the company’s rapid ascent into best in class manufacturing of subsea cables for the offshore renewable sector.

item.title: Airtricity’s renewable energy development business to be renamed SSE Renewables
item.description: Dublin-based energy company Airtricity has today announced that its renewable energy development division, the leading developer of renewable energy in the UK and Ireland, is to be renamed SSE Renewables. The rebrand will take effect from 1st January 2010.

item.title: Utility seeks input on wind farm off Grand Strand
item.description: A consortium led by Santee Cooper is studying the feasibility of building a wind farm off the Grand Strand.

item.title: Energy policy changes are needed to hit key 'green' targets, Government told
item.description: Urgent policy changes are needed to encourage the £200bn development of wind farms, nuclear power and other forms of renewable energy to reduce costs and carbon emissions the Government was told yesterday.

item.title: Denmark gets new test center for offshore wind power
item.description: An area in Nissum Bredning at Limfjord has just been appointed as the testing area for experimental wind turbines.

item.title: Approval for Finland's first large offshore wind farm filed
item.description: wpd think energy GmbH & Co. KG, Bremen manager and developer of systems for renewable energy, has requested approval for the offshore wind farm Suurhiekka in Finland.

item.title: Offshore wind farms are without relevant impact on the water exchange between the North and Baltic Sea
item.description: Are all offshore wind turbine parks, currently planned or requested build in the western Baltic Sea, the effect is negligible on the salinity of the deep water of the Baltic Sea. This is the result of an international consortium of scientists come under the direction of the IOW, after a four-year project.

item.title: Vestas to expand its wind turbine blade R&D facilities in UK and Denmark
item.description: In both Jutland, Denmark and on the Isle of Wight in the UK, Vestas will significantly expand its wind turbine blade research units, known as Blades R&D.

item.title: EU's €20bn wind power support to focus on security of supply
item.description: MASSIVE European Union support of up to €20bn to fund the development of wind energy will be aimed at improving security of supply rather than combating climate change, a conference heard yesterday.

item.title: Prokon fills fund for offshore investment
item.description: The company Prokon Nord, one of the pioneers of the emerging offshore wind industry is gearing up for new investment. By means of a bond should therefore be collected fresh capital amounting to 50 million euros.

item.title: KBR Announces Plan to Attend British Wind Energy Association (BWEA) Annual Conference
item.description: KBR announced today that it will participate in the annual British Wind Energy Association (BWEA) conference in Liverpool, England as part of developing plans to expand KBR’s participation in the burgeoning alternate energy sector in the UK.

item.title: A Vancouver company is proposing to build an offshore wind farm in northwestern B.C., using unique marine construction techniques and equipment developed in Europe
item.description: NaiKun Wind Energy Group is developing plans for the construction of the NaiKun Offshore Wind Energy Project. The project would be located in the shallow waters off the northeast coast of Hecate Strait, between Haida Gwaii (the Queen Charlotte Islands) and Prince Rupert on the B.C. mainland.

item.title: National Wind Challenges President Obama
item.description: Earlier this week, National Wind CEO Leon Steinberg, challenged President Obama to take a stand by insisting that legislators pass an energy bill establishing a federal oversight committee to implement an interstate transmission highway. Steinberg likens the challenge as similar to President “Ike” Eisenhower’s initiative of creating a federal interstate system. The only difference is that while the nation’s interstate system is for cars, the transmission highway is for electricity.

item.title: Spanish renewables law shift could cap subsidies
item.description: Spain's parliament is due this week to vote on a law which could lead to caps on renewable electricity plants qualifying for existing subsidies for the power they sell to the grid. Catalan nationalist party CIU's proposals to scrap a law which allows renewable energy plants access to existing tariffs even if they overshoot state targets, were passed by Spain's senate last week and could be approved in congress on Thursday.

item.title: Scotland and India sign renewables development pact
item.description: The governments of Scotland and India have signed an agreement that will see them collaborate on renewable-energy technologies, while supporting each other's goal to massively ramp up their supplies of wind energy, solar power and biofuels.

item.title: E.ON: more players needed for turbine-makers to raise game
item.description: Fresh from starting up power production from the 60-megawatt (MW) Alpha Ventus offshore wind farm in Germany, and the 180MW Robin Rigg project in the UK's Solway Firth, E.ON Climate & Renewables (EC&R) is preparing the next stage of its offshore expansion.

item.title: Siemens / Dir: Wind Power Turbine Prices are lower than last year
item.description: The financial crisis has been brutal for financing conditions for wind park developers, thus lowering demand for new turbines, and it has also affected prices, says CEO of Siemens Wind Power, Andreas Nauen, the news agency Direkt.

item.title: Horns Rev II inaugurated
item.description: At a ceremony attended by Danish prime minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen, DONG Energy chairman Fritz H. Schur, CEO of DONG Energy Anders Eldrup and CEO of Siemens Wind Power Andreas Nauen, Denmark's Crown Prince Frederik inaugurated the world's largest offshore wind farm, Horns Rev 2. The wind farm, which consists of 91 Siemens 2.3 MW wind turbines, was constructed and is owned by DONG Energy.

item.title: SKF and Sinovel agree on partnership
item.description: The Swedish bearing specialist SKF has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Chinese turbine manufacturer Sinovel.

item.title: Centrica speeds up wind-park plans to qualify for subsidies
item.description: Centrica is accelerating plans to build two giant offshore wind parks in the North Sea to allow it to qualify for extra subsidies that could be worth hundreds of millions of pounds.

item.title: E.ON reaches Milestone in the largest Baltic Sea Wind Farm
item.description: E.ON Climate & Renewables has reached a further milestone in the expansion of offshore wind power in the Baltic Sea. Rödsand lies between the German island of Fehmarn and the Danish island of Lolland. Half of the foundations and the first cables to carry the electricity from the ninety wind turbines to the transformer station have already been successfully laid and the cable work continues. All work is running to schedule and the wind farm will be connected to the grid in the autumn of 2010, as planned.

item.title: Environmental and labor groups want to end delays on Cape Wind
item.description: A coalition of environmental and labor groups sent a letter to Interior Secretary Ken Salazar yesterday urging the department to quickly grant approval to the Cape Wind offshore wind energy project, while discounting a key argument that has fueled the most recent delay.

item.title: America's Offshore Wind Race is On: Can the US Compete with Canada?
item.description: For years the promise of North America's first offshore wind farm has been just that – a promise. The reality has been a big disappointment: proposals pigeonholed by Bush-era dirty energy policies and NIMBY (not-in-my-backyard) opposition.

item.title: Lord Mandelson urged to support plans for Sussex wind farm
item.description: Lord Mandelson is being urged to support the East Sussex economy when reaching a decision on plans for an offshore wind farm between Brighton and Newhaven.

item.title: UK is told to justify price discrimination against green power
item.description: The UK Government has been challenged by the European Commission to justifies why renewable energy projects in the north of Scotland have to pay much more to transmit green power, while those in the south of England are subsidised.

item.title: Connecting the US from Coast to Coast
item.description: A big factor limiting solar and wind power growth across the US is the current transmission network. It is disconnected. A new project proposed by Tres Amigas LLC in New Mexico would link the nation’s main power grids across the US and, therefore, give hundreds of thousands (if not millions) of households links to already existing renewable energy sources.

item.title: Sempra buys Hawaii wind energy, battery storage project from Shell
item.description: Sempra Energy’s generation unit has acquired Auwahi Wind Energy, a company developing a 22-megawatt wind energy and battery storage project in Maui, Hawaii, from Shell WindEnergy, a subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell.

item.title: Siemens to launch 120 m rotor span, 3.6 MW wind turbine
item.description: Siemens unveiled a new wind turbine with a rotor span of 120 m in the 3.6 MW class at the European offshore wind conference in Stockholm. The SWT-3.6-120 extends on the technology used in the SWT-3.6-107, the world's most successful offshore wind turbine according to Siemens.

item.title: Secretary Chu Announces New Investments in Cutting-Edge Wind Energy Research Facilities
item.description: Washington, DC th U.S. Energy Secretary Steven Chu announced new investments today in three university-led wind energy research facilities that will enhance the United States' leadership role in testing and producing the most advanced and efficient wind turbines in the world. The funding is from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, and the research will focus on improving both land-based and offshore wind generation.

item.title: National Grid rejects power offer from Deepwater Wind
item.description: Plans to build the first offshore wind farm in Rhode Island have suffered a setback after the developer failed to reach an agreement to sell electricity to the state’s largest electric utility.

item.title: Maine pulls in $8M for floating offshore wind farm
item.description: The University of Maine has received $8 million in federal stimulus funding to move forward on its 10-year plan to create the country’s first floating deepwater offshore wind farm.

item.title: Funding boost for renewable power
item.description: Scottish renewable energy projects are in line for more than £100m of European Commission funding. Among the projects to benefit are a proposed hub for a sea-bed electricity power grid, and a demonstration zone for wind turbines.

item.title: Dynamic wind farm load patterns recorded by long range DTS
item.description: The biggest Danish utility owner has successfully completed the installation of LIOS’ Single Mode DTS equipment to monitor the power cable temperature of an offshore UK wind farm.

item.title: E.ON condemns overambitious targets for green energy
item.description: Government plans to generate 30 per cent of UK electricity from renewable sources by 2020 are doomed to failure, according to the chief executive of one of the world’s biggest utility companies.

item.title: Vestas unveils integrated wind production base in China
item.description: Danish wind turbine producer says it has invested more than $380 million in the state-sponsored development area in northern China.

item.title: Clonmel firm wins E25 million windfarm deal
item.description: Clonmel-based engineering firm, SEPAM, has won a E25m contract to build a huge wind farm in England.

item.title: Wind Hits 4GW Barrier - Now Powers 2.3 Million Homes in UK
item.description: The UK wind industry will today celebrate the important milestone of 4 gigawatts of installed wind energy capacity, as the industry gathered for the UK's biggest wind, wave and tidal energy conference in Liverpool.

item.title: Integration of Large-scale Wind Power
item.description: Today, the 15th of October 2009, the Top-level Research Initiative opens a call for user driven research projects within the sub-programme “Integration of large-scale wind power”.

item.title: 500 millions to offshore wind
item.description: Wind Energy industry wants Enova-money for pilot project of offshore wind turbines in Norway.

item.title: Unique experiment paves the way for more reliable design of wind turbines
item.description: Risø DTU has just completed a comprehensive full-scale experiment on a windmill in Tjæreborg meadows near Esbjerg. It is the first time someone has measured detailed pressure distributions on a 40 meter high wing under natural wind conditions and thus obtained a detailed picture of how wind affects a turbine blade.

item.title: Steel crisis boosts wind power
item.description: The steel crisis has a winner: Wind turbines are now at much more favorable prices than a year ago. "We can make our products around ten percent cheaper," said Ralf Peters, Nordex Group of Hamburg, one of the largest construction plants in Europe

item.title: Wind Power To Bypass Nuclear Power In UK By 2012
item.description: The UK wind power industry will be celebrating today as it achieves an important milestone - 4 gigawatts of installed wind energy capacity across the nation. According to the British Wind Energy Association (BWEA), the UK wind power sector now powers the equivalent of all Scotland's household needs, or 2.3 million homes.

item.title: LEWES: University of Delaware signs deal to build coastal wind turbines
item.description: The first wind turbine to go up off the Delaware coast might not be a generator in the Bluewater Wind project after all. On Monday, officials of the University of Delaware and Gamesa, the world's third-largest wind-turbine manufacturer, signed a contract that signals the parties' intent to build a small offshore wind research project -- with perhaps one or two turbines -- in the Delaware Bay off Lewes in 2012.

item.title: Offshore wind park towers transported upright
item.description: Wind turbine towers for the world's biggest offshore wind park are being transported upright on board a BBC Chartering and Logistic ship.

item.title: Group says developers use federal grants to add wind power; manufacturing remains sluggish
item.description: Armed with nearly $1 billion in federal grants, wind farm developers installed more capacity and got projects off the drawing board in the third quarter. Yet turbine manufacturers struggled amid excess supply, a trade group reported Tuesday.

item.title: US unveils plans for giant renewable energy hub
item.description: New Mexico announces project to link US energy grids, providing means to transmit solar and wind energy across the country. One of the largest barriers to the development of renewable energy in the US could soon be removed, thanks to an ambitious new project to more effectively link areas rich in solar and wind energy resources to population centres across the country.

item.title: Natural Power and E.ON sign technical services framework contract
item.description: Natural Power has announced the signing of a framework contract with wind farm developer and operator, E.ON Climate & Renewables, for the provision of technical services on mainland Europe including the execution of measurements and wind appraisals.

item.title: Offshore Wind Could Surge
item.description: Offshore wind production could surge forward. Both European and U.S. advocates say that the construction of such energy projects could take off assuming that both continents stick with their carbon-free energy themes.

item.title: Cabling contract for offshore wind farm
item.description: Nexans has won a contract worth approximately Euro39m to supply the subsea power export cables for phase one of the Belgian Belwind offshore wind farm project. On project completion, Nexans’s cable technology will transmit environmentally friendly power to some 165,000 households in Belgium.

item.title: UK radar research may release large wind projects
item.description: Government-funded research on radar may pave the way for wind projects that have been held back because they interfere with aviation radar, the British Wind Energy Association (BWEA) said. BWEA said in a statement late on Tuesday the 5.15 million pound research should help release the six gigawatts of wind projects, including offshore, which could power as many as 3.4 million homes.

item.title: Grand Valley State University’s wind turbine testing project for Muskegon Lake is shifting in a new direction
item.description: Instead of a wind turbine at the east end of Muskegon Lake, GVSU’s Michigan Alternative and Renewable Energy Center now is planning to move a wind test platform to Lake Michigan, where data can be collected on the pros and cons of turbines on a major lake.

item.title: Financial meltdown slows momentum of wind power
item.description: The U.S. has enough wind power to fuel the equivalent of nearly 9 million homes, up almost 23 percent from the start of the year, the American Wind Energy Association reported yesterday.

item.title: Wind industry reveals plan for radar-friendly stealth turbines
item.description: Wind turbines coated with similar material to make stealth bombers invisible to radar could soon be used to address long-standing concerns that wind farms could disrupt air traffic control systems.

item.title: First IPC applications dominated by nuclear, wind and grid
item.description: The Infrastructure Planning Commission (IPC) has revealed the first projects likely to use it, and the schemes are dominated by energy projects with a single road scheme.

item.title: First floating wind turbine delivers electricity
item.description: For the first time ever, a floating megawatt-scale wind turbine is delivering electricity. StatoilHydro, of Norway, and Siemens are cooperating in this field and hope to use the research project, which was officially launched on September 8, 2009, to demonstrate that wind turbines that are not permanently anchored to the ocean floor can also make a significant contribution to power supply.

item.title: QinetiQ and Vestas claim world first
item.description: QinetiQ – a technology provider and consultancy to the energy and environmental sectors – and Vestas Wind Systems – the market-leading supplier of wind power solutions – have announced the successful trial of a unique radar mitigation technology for wind turbines.

item.title: Google and Microsoft eye wind farm investments
item.description: Google and Microsoft are looking at possible investments in offshore wind farms in Britain, as part of their strategy to 'green' their electricity use

item.title: Utility’s letter says it’s willing to resume wind-energy talks
item.description: National Grid is willing to resume negotiations with Deepwater Wind over a power-purchase agreement if certain conditions are met first, according to a letter from the utility to the offshore wind farm developer.

item.title: Temporary use for offshore
item.description: The Container Terminal Bremerhaven will in the future be utilized for the loading of wind power plants. This was confirmed of Bremerhaven Economic Development to Radio Bremen. Thus, especially the offshore companies will be attempted to be housed permanently at the site.

item.title: Natural Power signs wind appraisal agreement with E.ON
item.description: Natural Power has announced that they have signed a contract with the Germany utility giant’s subsidy, E.ON Climate & Renewables, to provide technical services to sites in mainland Europe which will include measurements and wind appraisals.

item.title: Germans conquer the world by tilting at wind turbines
item.description: As the workforce at the only wind-turbine factory in Britain was laid off at the end of April, Rene Umlauft, boss of the renewable-energy division of Siemens, the industrial giant, was enjoying a run of turbine sales. He had sold more than 120 in Britain, Turkey and at home in Germany.

item.title: Scotland’s £30bn offshore bounty
item.description: Scottish Gas owner Centrica might be best known for supplying blue flames to kitchen hobs, but the flickers of excitement surrounding the company are of a very different order at the moment.

item.title: Applications to develop offshore wind on Great Lakes overwhelms ministry
item.description: Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources says it has received more than 100 applications representing more than 500 wind-energy projects on the Ontario side of the Great Lakes. Overwhelmed, the ministry has temporarily stopped taking applications until it can review what it has and make sure proper processes are in place for granting approvals.

item.title: Centrica to sell wind stake for 400 mln stg-report
item.description: Centrica (CNA.L), the acquisitive owner of British Gas, is to raise 400 million pounds ($666 million) to fund expansion after selling half its stake in the world's largest wind farm, The Sunday Times Reports.

item.title: Outcry over Crown Estate rent rise for wind farms
item.description: Plans by the Crown Estate to treble its revenues from offshore wind parks have angered energy companies, who say that the move could jeopardise the viability of important new projects and undermine government hopes to boost renewable energy in Britain.

item.title: Siemens to pursue wind power tech for growth
item.description: It was a sunny and windy afternoon in Beijing. Richard Hausmann, president and CEO of Siemens China, could hear the wind whistling outside his office located in the northern part of the city. "China has rich wind energy resources, and Siemens is now taking an active role in the country's wind power sector," said Hausmann, who is also CEO of Siemens Northeast Asia.

item.title: Green jobs lost to overseas firms
item.description: Greater Gabbard is a £1.3bn wind farm project off the Suffolk coast which is due to be completed by 2012. With 140 turbines it will be the biggest offshore wind farm in the world.

item.title: Ireland exiting peat power, faces hurdles
item.description: Ireland will stop using peat to produce electricity by about 2025 to 2030 as it moves toward renewable sources, although it faces infrastructure and financing hurdles, the state-owned peat energy company said.

item.title: UK firm joins local windfarm plan
item.description: A leading British renewable energy development company is planning to enter a partnership with a Taiwanese firm to further develop wind power in Taiwan, a recent newsletter published by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) in Taipei said.

item.title: Wind Energy Center opened in Esbjerg
item.description: Vattenfall today opens their new wind energy center in Esbjerg. The center will be responsible for management, operation, and monitoring of all of Vattenfall's windmills in Denmark.

item.title: Dong Energy and Better Place behind energy venture
item.description: Friday October 23rd, Frederikshavn Municipality and Energy town Frederikshavn are signing two new partnership agreements with, respectively, Dong Energy and Better Place Denmark.

item.title: Start of cabel laying operation for offshore wind farm Rödsand II
item.description: E. ON Climate & Renewables has reached an important sub-ordinate target at the Baltic Sea offshore wind farm Rödsand II. Half of the ninety foundations for the wind turbines are set in the seabed, now the first cables that guide the flow of the wind turbines to the substation have been successfully relocated.

item.title: Danish wind-turbine-knowledge to support Norway in large offshore center
item.description: In Norway over the coming years huge investments will be made in environmental research, and in one of the major priorities there has been summoned assistance from Danish researchers. Wind energy experts from Aalborg University will play a central role in a new Norwegian research center, which opens Tuesday - and Denmark will in return get part in the Norwegian offshore experience from the oil and gas industry.

item.title: Siemens signs cooperation agreements with Joschka Fischer and Madeleine Albright
item.description: Siemens AG has retained former German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer and former U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright as consultants on topics relating to foreign affairs and corporate strategy.

item.title: Belgium's Hansen reports €9.6m loss on weak gearbox demand
item.description: Belgian gearbox maker Hansen Transmissions reported a pre-tax loss of €9.6m ($14.4m) in the first half of the year, as it continues to re-calibrate its business in response to the weak global market for wind turbines and turbine components.

item.title: R.I. delegation urges federal support for wind power
item.description: Rhode Island’s congressional delegation has written a letter in support of the state’s application for federal stimulus funding to improve infrastructure in the Quonset Business Park for the staging of offshore wind energy projects there.

item.title: Wind farm cable lay time cut by 50%
item.description: Offshore installation specialist Subocean claims to have cut offshore wind farm cable installation times by 50% using a dynamically positioned vessel for work on the North Sea 100-turbine Thanet wind farm off the UK southeast coast.

item.title: Seajacks Leviathan set to work on world's largest offshore windfarm development
item.description: Seajacks International Ltd, the UK jack-up liftboat operator, has delivered the self-propelled jack-up Seajacks Leviathan vessel to Fluor on time and on budget. This marks the start of Seajacks' charter at Greater Gabbard, the world's largest offshore wind energy development.

item.title: The electrical grid of tomorrow will be flexible and self-healing
item.description: A smart electrical grid has the potential to play a key role in the effort to lower energy costs for consumers, achieve energy independence and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. How can all of this be realised and what can government do to ensure such a grid can be made a reality? Dr Richard Charnah explains.

item.title: Annual balance for wind energy generated in 2008
item.description: Stable domestic market – moderate impact of the financial crisis – world market continues to grow Berlin (Germany). Today in Berlin, the German Wind Energy Association (Bundesverband WindEnergie, BWE) and the Association of German Machinery and Plant Manufacturers (Verband Deutscher Maschinen- und Anlagenbau, VDMA) announced that the German market has maintained a steady level in 2008 amidst a continually growing world market.

item.title: Vestas looks to double revenues
item.description: Vestas Wind Systems on Tuesday targeted a doubling in revenues by 2015 as countries step up investment in renewable energy to combat climate change. Ditlev Engel, chief executive, announced the goal after the Danish company reported a 70 per cent increase in third quarter net profits.

item.title: Vestas to develop 6MW offshore wind turbine
item.description: Danish wind turbine manufacturing giant Vestas has revealed it will develop and launch a 6-megawatt (MW) machine for offshore wind farms within the next few years. Vestas chief executive Ditlev Engel unveiled the plan for a big new wind turbine for offshore markets as he presented third quarter results to analysts in New York.

item.title: SeaEnergy and TGC to develop windfarms in Taiwan
item.description: British renewable energy company SeaEnergy said on Tuesday it will build offshore windfarm projects in Taiwan with the Taiwan Generations Corporation (TGC), an energy project development company.

item.title: Reduced energy demand sees Vattenfall profits drop 74 per cent, slow return predicted
item.description: Swedish energy company Vattenfall has reported a 74.9 per cent drop in after tax profits to SEK622m (€60.3m), blaming a drop in power demand. The renewables project developer saw operating profits for the quarter drop 37 per cent to €341.6m, and 4.6 per cent for the nine month period as a whole, to €2.1bn. The profit comes despite a 19 per cent increase in sales, reaching €4.3bn over the financial year so far.

item.title: Hawaii gets $5.3 million in federal funds to modernize power grids
item.description: Hawaii is getting $5.3 million in federal stimulus money that will be used for projects modernizing the state's power grids. The funding is part of a $3.4 billion nationwide effort for renewable energy promoted by President Barack Obama on Tuesday.

item.title: ‘Smart grid’ grants announced
item.description: President Obama yesterday unveiled $3.4 billion in government grants for equipment to improve the efficiency of the nation’s electrical transmission network. The grants, ranging in size from $400,000 to $200 million, will be used to develop and install “smart grid’’ technology to make electricity transmission more reliable and aid the transmission of energy generated from sources like wind and solar power.

item.title: US firm invests in Centrica's wind farms
item.description: Gas supplier Centrica has received planning permission for the construction of a wind farm project off the coast of Lincolnshire. The 270 megawatt offshore wind farm has received final investment approval, and construction work on it will start in 2010.

item.title: Windfarm deal shows new investor interest
item.description: Centrica, owner of the British Gas brand, will sell a 50% stake in three wind farms to US based TCW, signalling renewed investment interest in an industry where recession has crimped financing

item.title: Centrica to invest £725 million to build 270MW offshore wind farm
item.description: Centrica plc, the parent company of British Gas, says that its 270 megawatt (MW) Lincs offshore wind project has received final investment approval, and that construction is expected to begin in 2010.

item.title: National Grid Gets Solar Okay, Rejects Deepwater Wind
item.description: In a surprising development, National Grid, an East Coast regional utility, has gotten a thumbs up from the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities for its five planned solar installations. The development is only surprising in view of the fact that National Grid recently put the screws to Deepwater Wind, an offshore wind farm planned for Rhode Island, off the coast of Block Island, by refusing to buy the electricity generated.

item.title: Centrica issues green energy warning
item.description: Firm to go ahead with £725m windfarm but says renewable targets will not be met unless government continues current subsidy levels. Centrica gave the go-ahead to one of the UK's largest offshore windfarms today but warned the government that its 2020 renewable energy targets would be missed unless the current level of subsidy was maintained.

item.title: Wind farm planned for Taiwan Strait
item.description: Scotland-based energy company SeaEnergy Renewables has signed an agreement with the Taiwan Generations Corporation to build a 600MW wind farm off the west coast of Taiwan. The Changhua Offshore Windfarm will be located in the Taiwan Strait off Changhua county, about 2.5km to 10km from the shore, in water depths up to 30m.

item.title: Offshore wind industry to be marketed
item.description: Aberdeen, Inverness and Glasgow have been chosen to hold the first of a series of events where the offshore wind industry will be marketed to those wishing to get involved in the burgeoning development of sustainable power.

item.title: Vestas aims for new large orders and maintains expectations
item.description: With one large order already in house and another even larger expected on its way, the Danish wind giant Vestas has landed contracts on wind mills for a total of more than 400 MW the past couple of days, say several Danish media.

item.title: Canadian Hydro Terminates Offshore Wind Prospect Agreement
item.description: Canadian Hydro Developers, Inc. (TSX:KHD) ("Canadian Hydro" or the "Company") has terminated its previously-announced definitive agreement with Wasatch Wind, Inc. ("Wasatch") to acquire a subsidiary of Wasatch that is developing a 4,400 MW offshore wind prospect located in Lake Erie (the "Agreement"). Wasatch is a private U.S.-based renewable energy company. Terms of the Agreement remain confidential.

item.title: E.ON's Humber Gateway offshore wind farm moves one step closer
item.description: E.ON has taken the next step in developing its Humber Gateway offshore wind farm by submitting a planning application to build a new substation on industrial land near Salt End. The substation would connect the proposed wind farm, located approximately 8km off the Holderness coast, to the national grid via 30km of underground cable.

item.title: Iberdrola receives extra $96 mln in US state grants
item.description: Spanish power group Iberdrola (IBE.MC) will receive an extra $96 million in U.S. state grants to develop smart grids in the country, according to statements from chairman Ignacio Galan on Iberdrola's website on Thursday.

item.title: Ofgem to confirm £300m of European funding towards offshore wind farms
item.description: Ofgem will announce on Friday £300m of European funding for investment in power lines from offshore wind farms, as the regulator tries to encourage the "forgotten infrastructure" behind Britain's green revolution.

item.title: Pavilion Energy Resources Pursuing Additional Offshore Wind Farm Locations
item.description: Pavilion Energy Resources, Inc. (PINKSHEETS: PVRE) announced that it is a 10% equity partner in a joint venture (JV) that has submitted a multi-billion dollar proposal to the state of Texas to develop a massive wind energy project located in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of South Padre Island.

item.title: E.On starts testing of 180 MW offshore wind farm in UK
item.description: The sixty 3 MW wind turbines supplied by E.On’s compatriots Siemens Windpower are now all in place and the wind farm - which has required an investment of €400 million - is practically ready for connection; planned by E.On for the end of the year. Nevertheless, the the German multinational’s 180 MW Robin Rigg wind farm is already supplying electricity to the UK’s national grid generated during the present test phase.

item.title: Research and Markets: This Essential Report Analyzes the Global Offshore Wind Power Industry
item.description: Historically land-based wind energy has been dominant and is likely to remain dominant in the immediate future also. But of late installations at sea are becoming increasingly important. Compared to onshore wind, offshore wind is more complex and costly to install and maintain but they also come with certain advantages. The winds are much stronger and stable at sea, which automatically results in higher production per unit installed.

item.title: Siemens Energy and EnBW Energie Baden-Württemberg AG have signed a contract for the supply of 21 SWT 2.3-93 wind turbines for the Baltic 1 offshore wind farm
item.description: Baltic 1 will be located 16 kilometers (10 miles) north of the Darss/Zingst peninsula and will cover an area of around seven square kilometers (2.7 square miles). Maritime civil engineering work will commence in early 2010. The 48.3-MW wind farm is scheduled to come on line in the last quarter of 2010.

item.title: Deepwater to Add Wind Turbines to Project Off Block Island
item.description: One issue disputed by Deepwater Wind and National Grid in their negotiations over a power purchase agreement has been resolved by an amendment to a state renewable energy law. Both chambers of the General Assembly approved new language in the law late Thursday night.

item.title: TransAlta cancels offshore wind power project
item.description: Utility giant TransAlta Corp. has put its stamp on green power generator Canadian Hydro Developers Inc., forcing the cancellation of a deal it inked last month to build an offshore wind power project in Lake Erie.

item.title: EIB considers wind-farm funding
item.description: The European Investment Bank and Ofgem E-Serve have announced that the EIB is considering the provision of £300m to investors in high-voltage transmission links to offshore wind farms in Britain. The funding will be available for six projects, including Sheringham Shoal (315MW), Ormonde (150MW) and the Greater Gabbard (504MW) development.

item.title: The European Commission has proposed a 500 million euro (£460m) financial package to support offshore wind energy efforts over the next two years
item.description: And, as part of a five billion euro European Economic Recovery Plan, the Commission also said 1.250 billion euros (£1.15bn) should go towards supporting development of carbon capture and storage projects. The Recovery Plan came as the Commission laid out its thoughts on an international climate change agreement to be discussed in Copenhagen this December.

item.title: BazeTechnology outlines the exciting developments taking place in the wind industry
item.description: Before making his trip to the event, he wanted to make clear his views on what he considers to be currently the main issues and areas for development within the wind industry in the future.

item.title: Vestas to expand research and development
item.description: Wind turbine manufacturer is set to employ hundreds of new researchers with an expansion of its R&D department. Wind turbine manufacturer Vestas is pushing ahead with development plans and is looking to increase its stable of employees by an extra 600 positions.

item.title: A £27bn opportunity is blowing our way
item.description: NOW is the time to stake a claim for a part in the impending "wind generation" of energy production. That was the message to Humber businesses as our area prepares to cash in on a jobs bonanza that could unfold as offshore turbines are rolled out in their hundreds in the coming years.

item.title: What Growth Will be Seen in Wind Turbine Control Systems?
item.description: The Wind Turbine Control systems market is well positioned to experience extraordinary growth for the next several years due to the volatility in oil cost, worldwide push for clean energy, favorable government incentives, and available investments funding for this area in the world financial community, according to a new ARC Advisory Group study.

item.title: EIB To Finance Connection Of Offshore Wind Energy To Grid In UK
item.description: The European Investment Bank (EIB) may provide about GBP300 million ($496 million) for linking offshore wind parks to the UK’s power grid, Bloomberg reported. The loans will be given to 13 bidders to own and operate power cables from six wind farms being built by companies including Scottish & Southern Energy Plc (Scottish & Southern Energy), which is constructing 504 MW Greater Gabbard project. The six projects have a combined capacity of 1.6 GW.

item.title: Eneco obtains concept permits for 2 offshore wind farms
item.description: The Ministry of Transport, Public Works and Water Management today granted Eneco concept permits for the construction of two offshore wind farms. This offers two Eneco divisions – both New Energy and Evelop - the prospect of realising an offshore wind farm. Both divisions have already gained experience with the construction and maintenance of the Princess Amalia Wind Farm off the coast of the city of IJmuiden, which became operational in 2007 and performs optimally.

item.title: Lowestoft wind farm project gathering pace
item.description: A £1.2m project to turn Lowestoft harbour into the operational base for the world's largest offshore wind farm is gathering pace with the completion of the main headquarters building.

item.title: Decision on Cape Wind project by year end-Salazar
item.description: A decision will be made by the end of 2009 on whether the go ahead will be given to the massive Cape Wind electricity project off the shore of Massachusetts, U.S. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said on Monday.

item.title: WindSentinel to Reduce Costs for Offshore Wind Power
item.description: A Virginia based company specialized in wind power called Catch the Wind Ltd. has deployed its first laser wind sensor on a buoy in Race Rocks Island, British Columbia, for an initial assessment of a new offshore wind power farm. The goal is also to compare the assessment potential of small floating platforms or buoy-based systems with conventional systems.

item.title: Owners abandon Seabed Power due to EU anti-trust concerns
item.description: Global Marine Systems and Visser & Smit have jettisoned their plans to jointly establish Seabed Power, a firm dedicated to offshore renewables, due to impending changes to EU anti-competition laws.

item.title: StatoilHydro changes name, visual identity
item.description: StatoilHydro has changed its name to Statoil ASA. The company has also adopted a new visual identity.

item.title: Aarsleff signs contract for the world´s largest offshore wind farm
item.description: Aarsleff and Germany’s Bilfinger Berger GmbH today entered into a contract for the execution of the first phase of the London Array, world’s largest offshore wind farm. The offshore wind farm will be built in the Thames estuary, approximately 20 kilometres off the coasts of Kent and Essex.

item.title: Maldives to build £160m wind farm
item.description: Maldivian president Mohamed Nasheed has announced an ambitious £160M offshore wind project that will supply close to half of the island nation’s electricity requirements. Plans have been outlined for the construction of 30 large wind turbines, 40 miles north of the capital Male.

item.title: Ofgem to inject £1bn into green electricity projects
item.description: Energy regulator Ofgem yesterday proposed funding arrangements of up to £1 billion over the next two years for green electricity transmission grid projects, mostly in Scotland.

item.title: Panel to monitor offshore leases
item.description: A new group is being formed to address offshore leases for renewable energy projects. Now the question: Who gets a seat at the table? On Nov. 19 a task force of local, state, Wampanoag and federal officials is scheduled to meet for the first time at Massachusetts Maritime Academy in Buzzards Bay to discuss commercial leases for projects such as wind turbines in federal waters off the coast of Massachusetts.

item.title: Bilfinger Berger to begin construction on world’s largest offshore wind farm
item.description: German construction and development firm Bilfinger Berger has secured a contract to begin the construction of the 1,000MW London Array wind farm off the coast of the UK.

item.title: EU, US to increase cooperation through Energy Council
item.description: Officials from both sides of the Atlantic launched a new EU-US Energy Council was launched today in Washington. The launch was attended by EU Energy Commissioner Andris Piebalgs and US Secretary for Energy Steven Chu.

item.title: Garrad Hassan's offshore wind specialists help to drive Dudgeon's 560MW Round 2 project forward
item.description: Dudgeon Offshore Wind Ltd has appointed Garrad Hassan to provide continued technical support as it pushes ahead with the project, in parallel with a planning approval process, in order to chase a 2013 commercial operation date.

item.title: Maldives Announces Plans for a Wind Farm that Could Provide 40 Percent of its Power
item.description: New reports now show that plans for a new wind farm are set to make Maldives the country with the highest proportion of renewable energy in the whole world. The country is proposing a 30 turbine wind farm that will be located close to Male its capital. This wind farm will be able to deliver 75 megawatts of electricity when at full capacity. This is enough power to provide electricity to the whole capital, surrounding resorts, and the airport.

item.title: Wing broke in two at Norwegian wind farm
item.description: A nearly 45 meter long and 10 tons heavy turbine blade broke in the weekend at a test site in Norway.

item.title: ENERTRAG AG expands internationally
item.description: ENERTRAG is expanding its international business. In France, the company from Uckermark, has completed the planning of more than 500 MW wind power projects, since the beginning its commitment in 1999.

item.title: Nexans wins 50 million Euro submarine high voltage power cable contract for Centrica’s Lincs offshore wind farm project
item.description: This new project illustrates once again Nexans’ position and competence in the energy infrastructure market. Nexans, the worldwide leader in the cable industry, has been awarded a 50 million Euro contract by Centrica to design, manufacture and supply the high voltage (HV) subsea power export cables for the Lincs wind farm project.

item.title: Senergy leads the way as European renewables’ forum debuts in Scotland
item.description: Scottish diversified energy services company Senergy took part in a major European renewable energy forum in Dundee (Fri, October 30) as the only UK representative involved in an offshore grid consortium.

item.title: 4GW wind farms power 2.3 million UK homes
item.description: British Wind Energy Association (BWEA), the leading renewable energy trade association in the UK, said that the country is producing sufficient wind energy-generated electricity to serve all Londoners living south of the river. With 30 wind turbines off Essex coast generating electricity, the UK now has enough four-gigawatt capacity to power 2.3 million homes, equivalent to half of England or the whole of Scotland.

item.title: Offshore wind energy - where is it going?
item.description: The Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU) is specifically funding research in offshore wind energy. Last year alone, the BMU approved about 40 million euro for research and development projects in wind energy.

item.title: Exide Technologies Launches ReStore Energy Systems Division to Develop New Renewable Energy Storage and Lithium Ion Energy Systems for High-Growth Global Markets
item.description: Exide Technologies (NASDAQ: XIDE, www.exide.com), a global leader in stored electrical-energy solutions, today introduced ReStore Energy Systems, a new division dedicated to the development and pursuit of new markets for renewable energy storage and lithium ion energy systems.

item.title: Government agencies come to grips with wind turbine-caused clutter for U.S. radar systems
item.description: Electricity-generating wind turbines are considered an essential part of reducing U.S. reliance on fossil fuels, yet these massive multi-bladed structures can cause big problems for the nation's radar systems that watch for enemy aircraft and threatening weather.

item.title: Future of wind farms in doubt
item.description: BRITAIN’s biggest developer of offshore wind farms has hired Rothschild to sell stakes in its projects because it cannot afford to build them. The move by Dong Energy, the Danish power giant, casts fresh doubt on the government’s carbon-reduction plans just six months after it ramped up subsidies to keep the offshore wind sector afloat.

item.title: Germany goes offshore: EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall have constructed the first wind turbine for alpha ventus
item.description: Germany has its first offshore wind turbine: the consortium of EWE, E.ON and Vattenfall, DOTI (Deutsche Offshore- Testfeld und Infrastruktur GmbH), has successfully completed construction today of the first of a total of 12 wind turbines for the alpha ventus offshore wind farm in the North Sea. A team of 50 specialists are on location at the open sea construction site.

item.title: Rise of the monster wind farms
item.description: A £125bn plan to generate a third of the UK’s energy needs offshore may prove too ambitious. Picture a field of enormous windmills, each the height of London’s Gherkin skyscraper with blades as long as a jumbo jet. Does this sound fantastical? The government doesn’t think so. Ed Miliband, the energy secretary, recently stumped up £4.4m of public money to help finance the first of these monster turbines, to be built at a former shipyard in Blyth, Northumberland.

item.title: Wind farm all but disappears in coastal simulation
item.description: Large wind turbines would be clearly visible two miles off the Carolina coast but would all but disappear into the haze eight miles out to sea, a new photo simulation shows. Clemson's South Carolina Institute for Energy Studies created the simulation as part of Santee Cooper's research into the viability of building a wind farm off the Grand Strand.

item.title: Wind farm safety system could be a £200m money-spinner for Scots firm
item.description: An innovative Scottish company that has designed a safety system for wind farm maintenance is on the verge of tapping into a £200 million global market. Limpet Technology, based at Granton in Edinburgh, has won its first contract for 100 of its systems from a major European wind turbine maker.

item.title: Wind Farm Developers Team Up on Scottish Projects
item.description: A group of wind farm developers are teaming up for four offshore projects located in Scottish territorial waters, it has been announced. The four projects, located in the outer Firths of Forth and Tay, will have a 2,470MW combined capacity.

item.title: MA Governor Deval Patrick responds to Historic Preservation decision
item.description: Just as the lengthy federal review process for the Cape Wind offshore wind project seemed to be winding down, the state’s historic preservation officer declared that Nantucket Sound ought to be considered for listing on the National Historic Register based on its cultural significance to the Wampanoag tribes – a view in opposition to the ruling made by the federal agency leading the review.

item.title: Stimulus Bucks Fund New Hampshire/Maine Wind Project
item.description: A consortium of New England schools will get $700,000 in federal stimulus money to develop three deepwater wind energy test sites in the Gulf of Maine.

item.title: Study: Offshore winds a mega-resource
item.description: There is more than enough wind off the mid-Atlantic seaboard to power every coastal state from North Carolina to Massachusetts, according to a new study presented in Rhode Island.

item.title: Energy Secretary Ed Miliband lays Out Plans To Transform UK's Energy Infrastructure
item.description: Faster and fairer planning decisions on new energy infrastructure were a step closer today as Energy and Climate Secretary Ed Miliband laid before Parliament draft texts setting out the national need for a low carbon secure energy mix. He also set out an ambitious new policy for the transition to clean coal.

item.title: Can Offshore Winds Spin a Market for U.s.-Made Turbines?
item.description: Middle Eastern oil is one energy dependency. Another, looming in the future, could be a growing array of wind turbines, situated along the Eastern Seaboard, manufactured by European companies and feeding electricity to nearby American cities. That's what government and industry experts are trying to avoid -- a new addiction.

item.title: PNE wind remains expanding
item.description: The wind farm developer Wind PNE AG has continued its growth in the first nine months of this financial year. Compared to the previous year the overall performance increased by 22.5 percent from 81.8 million euros to 100.2 million euros, the company announced on Monday.

item.title: NRG Energy (NYSE: NRG) to Buy Bluewater Wind
item.description: NRG Energy (NYSE: NRG) said Monday that it bought offshore wind developer Bluewater Wind, as the power company looks to bolster its supply of renewable energy, according to Associated Press. NRG, based in Princeton, N.J., said it bought Bluewater from Babcock & Brown (NYSE: FLY) and Arcadia Windpower with cash on hand. Terms were not disclosed.

item.title: Just Energy Will Purchase Wind RECs Iberdrola Wind Farms In New York
item.description: Under a five-year agreement with Iberdrola Renewables, Just Energy has announced that it will purchase renewable energy certificates (RECs) sourced from a variety of wind farms in New York state.

item.title: Wind planning policy statements published
item.description: Onshore projects over 50MW and offshore projects over 100MW to receive approval decision in a year. Energy and climate change secretary Ed Miliband today published national policy statements for wind power that will help hasten the progress of 700MW of wind projects stuck in the planning system.

item.title: Spain’s wind turbines supply half of the national power grid
item.description: Spain was celebrating its commitment to renewable energy yesterday after wind turbines dotted across the country produced more than half of all its electricity for the first time. High winds across Spain on Sunday meant that for over five hours, over 53 per cent of the country’s power came from wind energy.

item.title: GE 1.5-Megawatt Wind Turbine Commissioned for DOE Program Designed to Move US Wind Energy Technology Forward
item.description: GE 1.5-Megawatt Wind Turbine Commissioned for DOE Program Designed to Move US Wind Energy Technology Forward. As part of a U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) initiative to drive new levels of performance in wind turbine technology, which will help ensure further U.S. wind industry growth, a GE (NYSE: GE) 1.5-megawatt wind turbine today was commissioned at the National Wind Technology Center (NWTC) in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: PNE Wind aims to generate 25 percent of sales in U.S.: CEO
item.description: German wind park developer PNE Wind aims to generate a quarter of its sales in the United States in three year's time, its chief executive told Reuters on Tuesday. "Our goal is to generate 25 percent of sales there in three years," Martin Billhardt said in an interview.

item.title: LGC Skyrota Wind Energy Corp. Achieves Significant Growth in Turbine Refurbishment Division
item.description: LGC Skyrota Wind Energy Corp. ("LGC Skyrota" "the Company") (TSX-V: LGS) announced today that its large wind turbine maintenance and refurbishment division, LGC, reported exponential growth in both its customer base and number of units serviced during its 2009 financial year. The Company expects to report fourth quarter and year-end financial results in January 2010.

item.title: RWE Innogy granted permission to build the 300 MW offshore wind farm Tromp
item.description: RWE Innogy received final permission from the Dutch Ministry of Transport and Hydraulic Engineering (Rijkswaterstaat) to build the offshore wind farm Tromp and for the realisation of an offshore meteo mast. The installation of an offshore meteo mast is the first step towards the realisation of the offshore wind farm.

item.title: Experts bag Borkum work
item.description: Expert authorities Noble Denton and Germanischer Lloyd have been selected to provide support for the Borkum West II wind farm offshore Germany. The deal - awarded by Trianel, a consortium of regional and local government energy suppliers formed in 1999 and backed by German utilities Eon, Vattenfall and Vattenfall – covers technical support and project management services for the Borkum phase II development, 45 km (28 miles) offshore near the island of Borkum.

item.title: Md., Del., Va., In Offshore Wind Power Partnership
item.description: Maryland, Delaware and Virginia are joining forces to promote the offshore wind power. The governors of the three states announced Tuesday that they have signed an agreement to work together on promoting federal policies, transmission strategies and other issues to advance offshore power in the Mid-Atlantic region.

item.title: Markey urges federal Cape Wind approval
item.description: Although U.S. Rep. Edward J. Markey is chair of a congressional climate change committee and a co-sponsor of clean energy legislation, he’s never explicitly come out in favor of the proposed Cape Wind project in Nantucket Sound. Yet today, Markey wrote a strongly worded two-page letter to U.S. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar urging him to approve the Cape Wind project before next month’s international climate talks in Copenhagen.

item.title: Deutsche Windtechnik Service GmbH & Co. KG
item.description: Deutsche Windtechnik Service GmbH & Co. KG: More than 500 wind turbines under contract. Deutsche Windtechnik Service reports already before the end of a year of over-budgeted figures. The young company, which celebrated its second anniversary in September, and specializes in vendor-independent service for the wind turbine manufacturers NEG-Micon and Vestas, already announced in November a positive result of a strong market presence.

item.title: The Netherlands approves three offshore wind farms
item.description: The Dutch government has approved three major offshore wind farms totalling nearly 700 megawatts (MW), including one being developed Germany’s RWE Innogy and two by Dutch utility Eneco.

item.title: U.S. Offshore Wind Sector Sees Major Developments
item.description: Key developments for U.S. offshore wind this week could give that sector a much-needed boost: On Monday, NRG Energy acquired offshore wind developer Bluewater Wind, and on Tuesday, the governors of Maryland, Virginia, and Delaware formed a tri-state partnership for the deployment of offshore wind energy in the Mid-Atlantic coastal region.

item.title: Report Charts Path for U.S. Offshore Wind Power Development
item.description: A new report calls for coordinated activities among government agencies, universities, and businesses to nurture and develop offshore wind power in the United States. The U.S. Offshore Wind Collaborative (USOWC) released its study "U.S. Offshore Wind Energy: A Path Forward" in late October as a call to action for this renewable resource.

item.title: Yes to wind turbine park
item.description: Eon wins the right of the environmental court to build wind turbines. Environmental Court sees no problem with a wind farm off the coast of Kårehamn. It was the kammarkollegiet appealing about the wind park project to the environmental court. They urged denial of permission for Eon to build power plants at sea.

item.title: GE, E.ON Sign Operations And Maintenance Deal For U.S. Wind Turbines
item.description: GE and E.ON Climate & Renewables (EC&R) North America have signed a seven-year operations and maintenance (O&M) agreement covering EC&R's complete fleet of 529 GE wind turbines installed in the U.S.

item.title: Increasing revenues and profits for Repower
item.description: The wind turbine manufacturer Repower increased revenues and profits in the first six months of this current financial year. The subsidiary of India's Suzlon Group build 185 Wind turbines with a capacity of 386 megawatts, REpower announced on Thursday in Hamburg.

item.title: European renewables bank on 2010 as demand looks up
item.description: European renewable companies posted moderate to sharp declines in quarterly results but sounded more upbeat for 2010, as costs cuts and an expected pickup in demand help lift profits after a year of turmoil.

item.title: Acciona grows nine month net profits by 255 per cent, renewables capacity reaches 7,308MW
item.description: Spanish engineering, construction and infrastructure company Acciona has announced a 255 per cent growth in profits for the first nine months of 2009 compared with the same period last year, a total of €1.29bn. The company’s renewable energy capacity also reached 7,308MW.

item.title: UK energy companies compete for £100 billion wind projects
item.description: Future plans for wind projects, 50 times the size of any large wind farm today, are now underway. To be constructed off the UK coast, the project is anticipated to be valued at £100 billion. The project is too large for any energy firm to handle alone. It is expected that deals will be given to consortiums of major utilities.

item.title: Eon pledges to use local firms
item.description: JOBS could be created in the region after energy giant E.on promised to seek local labour in the construction of a massive offshore wind farm. If the Government gives the go ahead for the 85-turbine development - which could provide energy for 195,000 homes - work could begin in 2011.

item.title: Britain's renewable energy targets are 'physically impossible', says study
item.description: The Institution of Mechanical Engineers' 'battle plan' for climate change includes geo-engineering and nuclear power. It will be physically impossible for the UK to meet its renewable energy targets in both the short and long term, according to a group of engineering experts.

item.title: Ramco Energy to concentrate on offshore wind business
item.description: Suil Na Mara Shipping reports that Ramco Energy PLC has made a decision to divest its oil and gas interests and will now focus purely on its offshore wind business. As a result the company has changed its name to SeaEnergy PLC which through its 80 per cent owned subsidiary SeaEnergy Renewables Ltd has interests in two offshore wind farm sites.

item.title: Loan guarantee 'crucial' to wind farm
item.description: NRG wants Congress to extend the program. NRG Energy officials are counting on Congress to reauthorize a loan guarantee program that the firm says is "crucial" to the success of a planned wind farm off Rehoboth Beach.

item.title: Lowestoft aims to lure windfarm builders
item.description: A MAJOR push began last night to persuade green energy firms to make Lowestoft their operations base when building wind turbines off the East Anglian coast. The latest round of licences from the Crown Estate to build offshore windfarms includes “zone five” - an area just 25 kilometres out of Lowestoft. Yesterday the 1st East Urban Regeneration Company and Associated British Ports (ABP) and a series of public and private sector partners began to lobby for investment in the town.

item.title: Tories will build a 'marine energy park' off coast
item.description: A marine energy park should be built on the Kent coastline to take advantage of its close proximity to the Continent, claims an influential MP. Shadow energy and climate Change secretary Greg Clark says if the current Government had funded such an initiative 10 years ago, the county could already be leading the way in using wind and tidal power to provide electricity to the rest of Europe.

item.title: First stealth windmill in testing
item.description: The Bundeswehr has filed an appeal against new wind farms, since they apparently cause shadow to the surveillance radar. Novel stealth blades are to prevent the that soon. The sums are huge: 100 million euros in Schleswig-Holstein are ready for investments in wind turbines. In Lower Saxony, it is as high as 400 million euros.

item.title: Scan Energy plans IPO on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange
item.description: Scan Energy, a major independent producer of renewable energy in Europe, plans to issue new shares and is seeking a listing on the Regulated Market (Prime Standard) on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. Founded in 2003, Scan Energy, headquartered in Denmark, and operational headquarters in Hamburg, is an independent power producer with a presence in European markets.

item.title: Gamesa profits more than halved
item.description: The surplus fell to 86 million. euros in the first nine months of the Spanish wind manufacturer Gamesa. Last year the company had a surplus of 288 million. euros in the same period.

item.title: REpower Systems AG: Last turbine for alpha ventus completed
item.description: Today in the early morning, REpower Systems AG (WKN 617703) erected the last of a total of six REpower 5M wind turbines for the alpha ventus offshore test field. This means that the goal of the companies involved to complete the wind farm this year has been achieved. Alpha ventus is located 45 kilometers north of the island of Borkum and was built by a consortium of companies including EWE, E.ON, and Vattenfall.

item.title: U.K. Crown Estate Plans More Than 20,000 Megawatts of Windfarms Under Round 3 Licenses, an Industrial Info News Alert
item.description: The Crown Estate, an independent body that owns the seabed within 12 nautical miles of the United Kingdom's coastline, is expected to announce the award of contracts under Round 3 of the Offshore Wind Development Program at the end of December. The projects under Round 3 include a 5,000-megawatt (MW) windfarm off the coast of Norfolk and an even larger 10,000-MW project in the North Sea.

item.title: Exhibition to show how wind farm electric cable will cross Norfolk
item.description: Plans for a giant electricity cable which will snake its way from an offshore windfarm across Norfolk are tp go on show at three public exhibitions the first of which takes place tomorrow. The cable will link the proposed Dudgeon Wind Farm, which will lie 32km to the north of Cromer, with an onshore substation.

item.title: Expansion written in the wind
item.description: China WindPower Group (0182) plans to build between eight and 10 wind farms annually in the coming years as the nation expands the use of the cleaner form of power. Each project will cost about 45 million yuan (HK$51.07 million) and the company will likely fund the expansion without the need to sell shares or bonds, executive director Samantha Ko said.

item.title: Governor signs modified Block Island Wind farm law
item.description: Gov. Don Carcieri this week signed modified legislation that would allow Deepwater Wind to install up to eight wind turbines in state waters south of Block Island capable of generating 12 megawatts of electricity operating at 40 percent efficiency.

item.title: US: Boost for offshore research
item.description: The US Department of Energy awarded US$ 8 million to the University of Maine for offshore, deepwater wind energy research. A consortium of companies and university experts is going to develop, deploy and test three wind turbines – two 10 kW and one 100 kW prototypes – that will float on composite platforms off the coast of Maine and New Hampshire.

item.title: Radical engineering paves way for thousands of lower cost offshore wind turbines
item.description: Carbon Trust reveals new foundation designs to transform offshore wind industry. Radical new designs shortlisted in a global competition run by the UK’s Carbon Trust are set to accelerate the installation of thousands of wind turbines around Britain’s coast by slashing the costs of construction and opening up deeper waters for development.

item.title: Two giant offshore wind turbines inaugurated in Avedøre
item.description: Avedøre: Two large wind turbines, which in future will be the capital's green landmarks, was last week inaugurated at Avedøre Holme in Hvidovre. The turbines each weigh 540 tons, and measure 151 meters in height and are as high as Avedøreværket.

item.title: Wind power industry sees need for research
item.description: Offshore wind power has a key role in the search for the cheapest renewable energy. Joachim Nick-Leptin from the Federal Environment Ministry, said, at a conference in Oldenburg.The Ministry had approved more than 40 million euros for wind energy research projects in 2008.

item.title: North East companies invited to meet Clipper Windpower
item.description: A special ‘Meet the Buyer’ event has been organised so that companies in North East England can meet wind turbine manufacturer Clipper Windpower Marine, owner of the Britannia Project, which is currently under development and will result in a 10 MW offshore wind turbine design.

item.title: Increasing interest in Vestas' offshore wind power turbines
item.description: The Danish wind turbine giant is once again getting a foothold in the growing broadband markets for offshore wind turbines.

item.title: Clean wind energy for Wallonia
item.description: Currently, a modern 15 MW wind farm is being installed in Saint-Ode, Wallonia in Belgium. Wallonia is one of the three regions in Belgium and has approximately 3.5 million inhabitants. With an increasing number of onshore and offshore wind-projects, Belgium has set the course for a future-proof and clean power supply.

item.title: Seeking Wind Energy, Some Consider the Sea
item.description: LAST June in a fjord in southwestern Norway, a 213-foot-tall wind turbine did something large wind turbines normally don’t do: it headed out to sea. Towed by tugboats, the newly built turbine, with three 139-foot rotor blades and a 2.3-megawatt generator atop the tower, which itself was bolted to a ballasted steel cylinder extending more than 300 feet below the waterline, made its way to a spot six miles off the coast. Once in position it was moored with cables to the seafloor, about 700 feet below.

item.title: Carbon Trust reveals innovative offshore wind designs
item.description: Radical new designs for offshore wind turbine foundations could be the key to reducing construction costs and opening up deep water areas for development, according to the UK’s Carbon Trust, and in support of that idea it has revealed seven new designs that have been shortlisted in a global competition designed to help accelerate the construction of offshore wind farms by reducing construction costs and overcoming key engineering challenges. The shortlisted designs include floating turbines anchored to the seabed and spider-like tripod structures.

item.title: Seven designs for offshore wind turbine foundations are short-listed
item.description: Seven new designs for offshore wind turbine foundations have been short-listed for funding by the Carbon Trust in Britain. The offshore wind turbine foundation designs are aimed at reducing the high costs associated with installing offshore wind turbines, where deepwater foundations comprise at least 20% of total project costs, says the Carbon Trust. Offshore wind currently costs £3 million a megawatt as many of the sites which are being tendered for development are farther from shore in deep water and in treacherous conditions.

item.title: Offshore wind farm developers visit Brewer: Norwegian energy experts invited to tour Cianbro plant
item.description: When planning to build a large-scale floating wind farm in the Gulf of Maine, it's good to draw on experience. And there is only one company in the world that has experience with deep-water wind turbines, Cianbro Chairman and CEO Peter Vigue said Tuesday.

item.title: EDP Renewables to put $4 bln into U.S. wind market
item.description: EPD Renewables will invest $4 billion into the U.S. wind market over the next three years, the company said on Thursday, citing the government's commitment to a clean energy economy. EPDR, the wind energy unit of Portuguese Energias de Portugal, ranks as the third-largest wind energy producer in the United States with 2.5 gigawatts of capacity.

item.title: Enel on Short List for EU400 Million Suez Wind Park, MF Says
item.description: Enel Green Power SpA is on a short list of companies to build a 400 million-euro ($596 million) wind-power park in the Gulf of Suez, daily MF reported, without saying where it got the information.

item.title: uropeans tackle wind turbine development
