item.description: Researchers at Risø DTU (the National Laboratory for Sustainable Energy at the Technical University of Denmark) and their European colleagues have discovered a way to develop a more reliable wind turbine design. By taking detailed measurements of the load distribution on a 10-metre-long wind turbine blade under natural wind conditions, the team can offer precise information concerning the wind flow over the wind turbine blade surface.

item.title: UNH gets stimulus funds to test floating wind turbine
item.description: The University of New Hampshire’s Center for Ocean Renewable Energy will receive $700,000 in federal stimulus money to test the nation’s first floating deepwater wind turbine off the Isle of Shoals.

item.title: German Transformer Maker To Open First U.S. Plant
item.description: A company that makes transformers that convert electricity from renewable energy sources to the grid plans to open its first U.S. plant in Wheat Ridge in January. SGB USA Inc. is a subsidiary of Starkstrom-Geratebau, based in Regensburg, Germany.

item.title: First marine work begins on Sheringham Shoal with horizontal directional drilling
item.description: The first marine work on the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm will begin on the weekend when contractor Visser & Smith Marine Contracting utilises a horizontal directional drilling technique to install ducts at Weybourne in preparation for the “pull-in” of the wind farm’s two export cables.

item.title: Cold economic winds blow projects into utilities' arms
item.description: Major utilities are increasingly dominating investment in wind power infrastructure as difficult credit markets and rising development costs drive independent developers to sell nascent projects to larger companies.

item.title: Siemens Turns Sights On Latin America For Wind Turbines
item.description: Siemens AG (SI) is moving into the Latin American market for wind-energy turbines - beginning in Mexico - as it seeks a place among the world's top suppliers for wind-driven renewable energy. "We have a defined target of becoming one of the top-three wind turbine producers," said Jan Kjaersgaard, vice president and general manager for Siemens Wind Power Americas, part of U.S. subsidiary Siemens Energy Inc.

item.title: Conference aims to address engineering challenges of delivering offshore renewable energy
item.description: The annual conference of the Society of Maritime Industries takes a look at the emerging offshore renewable energy market which will see a huge investment with an expected capital spend of £70 billion for offshore wind farms alone. Entitled “Investing in UK Maritime Renewable Energy - Engineering Challenges & Business Opportunities”, it will be held in the historic Assembly Rooms, Bath on Wednesday 10 & Thursday 11 February 2010.

item.title: Sheringham Shoal construction kicks off
item.description: Construction work has commenced for the UK's Sheringham Shoal offshore wind farm being developed by Norway's Statoil and Statkraft with drilling of two ducts to carry power cabling from the project ashore.

item.title: Still wind farm costing energy company millions
item.description: Faulty terminal strips in the cables from Horns Rev 2 have shut down the massive wind farm. After just two months of operation technical problems have forced the blades of the world’s largest offshore wind farm to stop turning.

item.title: Military wary of offshore wind energy development
item.description: The O'Malley administration's desire to build offshore wind turbines as part of its renewable energy program is running into an unlikely source of resistance: the military.

item.title: Research and Markets: Analyzing the Potential of Offshore Wind Energy - Now Available
item.description: Research and Markets (www.researchandmarkets.com/research/f68f67/analy ..) has announced the addition of the "Analyzing the Potential of Offshore Wind Energy" report to their offering. In many parts of the world, wind energy has already grown to be a mainstream energy source. This growth has long been driven by concerns about global climate change, mainly in the developed world and especially in Europe.

item.title: Keeping Weight Down Key to Boosting Turbine Performance
item.description: The V90-3.0 MW turbine from Vestas Americas improves on previous designs thanks to lightweight carbon fiber in blades and stronger steel for a lighter tower. What’s more, a microprocessor controlled pitch regulator and redesigned nacelle further improve the turbine’s performance. The company says minimizing weight was a matter of high priority.

item.title: Dong Chief Expects Deeper Cost Cuts, May Sell U.K. Wind Stakes
item.description: Dong Energy A/S, Denmark’s largest oil and gas company, will make deeper cost cuts in 2010 after fuel and power prices fell and may also seek to sell parts of its U.K. wind farms.

item.title: Energy Leaders Look Ahead to Changing Subsea Future
item.description: Over 300 energy leaders today debated the challenges of a sustainable future for the North Sea and explored the potential development of the subsea market over the next 10 years at Subsea UK’s annual London event - Subsea Europe.

item.title: Energy Companies In Competition for Right to Build Wind Farms off the UK Coast
item.description: It now seems that many utility companies are competing for the right to build wind farms off the coast of Britain. These plants would be about 50 times the size of even the biggest present plants. It seems like one prize would be to win the Norfolk field, and this is likely to go to Scottish Power and Vattenfall.

item.title: Copenhagen's new cleantech icons swing into action for COP15
item.description: Two Siemens 3.6 MW wind turbines are taken into use in the Avedøre Holme district of Copenhagen, and will supply electricity to approx. 5,000 households. The winds of change are blowing through the Avedøre Holme district of Copenhagen. The 12 old wind turbines that used to stand there have been taken down, and in their place now stand two of the biggest wind turbines in serial production today – the Siemens 3.6 MW model – each of which has the same capacity as the previous 12. Between them they can supply enough electricity to meet the demands of around 5,000 households.

item.title: Simulations Key to More Efficient Wind Farms
item.description: How can a wind-turbine OEM as well as their countless suppliers squeeze more power from the wind using already well developed equipment? Even a small efficiency increase would be welcome. The viability of the business depends on it. The wind business is also counting on such gains to improve returns on investment, especially in times of economic uncertainly and the heighten demand for green energy.

item.title: LM Glasfiber scales down production in Europe
item.description: Wind turbine blade maker LM Glasfiber has announced plans to phase out large scale manufacturing at two factories in Denmark and one in Spain, while continuing to build its presence in high growth markets such as China. Around 900 of the company's employees in Europe could lose their jobs.

item.title: National Grid Rejects Deepwater Wind Proposal
item.description: New England utility National Grid has rejected another proposal to buy electricity from a $200 million wind farm to be built off the coast of Rhode Island by Deepwater Wind, according to The Providence Journal.

item.title: Siemens Rides the Offshore Winds
item.description: It lags in the global wind power race—except in the fast-growing nautical niche. German engineering giant Siemens (SI) looks like an also-ran in wind turbines. It's in sixth place globally, with 7% of the market, well behind leaders Vestas and General Electric (GE). Yet the headquarters of Siemens Wind Power has plenty of bustle. Under the overcast skies of Denmark's Jutland peninsula, workers are putting the final touches on a vast parts warehouse.

item.title: Wind farm suffers gearbox faults
item.description: A wind farm off the coast of Kent has suffered persistent mechanical failure in the four years since it began operating, BBC South East has revealed. Gearboxes in all 30 turbines on the Kentish Flats have been replaced with newer, improved parts.

item.title: Nordex increases gross profit 12 per cent
item.description: In the first nine months of 2009, wind turbine developer the Nordex Group generated a four per cent increase in sales to €814m from €781.1m the previous year. Its US subsidiary Nordex USA contributed 17 per cent and thus almost one fifth to consolidated sales. However, Europe continued to account for the bulk of the group’s business, contributing a total of 76 per cent to consolidated sales compared to 89 per cent the previous year.

item.title: Research and Markets: This Essential Report Comprehensively Analyzes Offshore Wind Energy in the United States
item.description: Research and Markets (http://www.researchandmarkets.com/research/ba5bcd/analyzing_offshore) has announced the addition of the "Analyzing Offshore Wind Energy in the United States" report to their offering. In many parts of the world, wind energy has already grown to be a mainstream energy source. This growth has long been driven by concerns about global climate change, mainly in the developed world and especially in Europe.

item.title: Germany's Nordex bets big on US turbine market in 2010
item.description: Shares in Germany’s Nordex inched higher after the turbine maker announced it is betting large on a sharp rebound in the wind industry next year, driven largely by growth in the US market.

item.title: Utilities withdraw from UK offshore tender -sources
item.description: Four energy firms have withdrawn from a 1.15 billion pounds ($1.9 billion) auction of UK offshore electricity grids that aims to attract private capital in connecting offshore wind farms, sources said.

item.title: Time to stand up and say no
item.description: The recent announcement by Centrica concerning its massive expansion to its offshore wind farms off our coast should not hide the fact that there are massive plans to industrialise the entire landscape eastwards from the Lincolnshire Wolds.

item.title: Makes considerable progress towards commercialization of laser wind sensing technology
item.description: Catch the Wind Ltd. (TSX-V: CTW.S), developer and manufacturer of the Vindicator(R) laser wind sensor (LWS) and other sensor products, announced today its financial results for the three- and nine-month periods ended September 30, 2009. All figures are in U.S. dollars unless otherwise stated. "We achieved a number of significant milestones in the third quarter as part of our ongoing efforts to bring our laser wind sensing technology to market," said Phil Rogers, President and CEO of Catch the Wind Ltd.

item.title: Utility energy storage no longer just giant batteries
item.description: If you need more evidence that energy storage is much more than lithium ion batteries, take a look at the latest smart-grid utility storage projects. The U.S. Department of Energy on Tuesday announced that US$620 million in stimulus funding is going to 32 smart-grid programs, which will be coupled with another US$1 billion in private money. A total of US$770 million from government and industry sources in the next few years will go to energy storage, giving a number of storage technologies a dose of real-world experience.

item.title: Duke Energy gets $22 Million federal grant for wind power storage
item.description: Duke Energy intends to match a $22 million grant from the U.S. Department of Energy to design, build and install large-scale batteries to store wind energy at one of its wind farms in Texas. The batteries at Duke Energy's Notrees Windpower Project in Ector and Winkler counties, Texas, will store excess wind energy and discharge it whenever demand for electricity is highest - not just when wind turbine blades are turning.

item.title: Direct Current Brings Remote Offshore Wind Farm to Germany
item.description: ABB has joined forces with German utility company Transpower to link the world's most remote offshore wind farm to the German power grid. Essentially, it's a 120 mile-long connection--the longest cable-route built for a grid connection to a wind farm in the world. It connects the park using 400 megawatt high-voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission technology.

item.title: Ex-Im Bank Approves Debt Financing For Clipper's Liberty Wind Turbines
item.description: Clipper Windpower today announced that the first Clipper Liberty wind turbines to be installed internationally have been backed by an $80.66 million project financing loan by the Export-Import Bank of the United States (Ex-Im Bank). The transaction also marks Ex-Im Bank’s first project financing for wind power. The project owner is Electrica del Valle de Mexico, a subsidiary of EDF Energies Nouvelles (“EDF EN”).

item.title: At least £30bn needed for offshore wind
item.description: THE pace of development of offshore windfarms in Scottish waters in years to come will require tens of billions of pounds of investment, a conference at the Marriott Hotel, in Aberdeen, will hear today.

item.title: Aggressive Vestas chasing golden opportunity
item.description: Brazil could become a bonanza for windmill companies like Vestas, assesses recognized research company. Manufacturers of windmills showing increasing interest in the Brazilian market, and it is not without reason. The Wind Power Market in Brazil expected the coming years to grow explosively.

item.title: Longest cable run for offshore wind farm is completed
item.description: The network connection of the second German offshore wind farm, BorWin 1, has now been completed after 26 months of construction.

item.title: JCB dealer adapts digger for £1bn wind farm project
item.description: A JCB dealership has adapted a digger so it can help in the construction of a £1 billion offshore wind farm. Watling JCB, of Whetstone, has supplied a long reach excavator to contractors working on the Sheringham Shoal wind farm in Wells-next-the-Sea, Norfolk.

item.title: East Midlands businesses urged to take advantage of new composite opportunities
item.description: New initiatives to support the development of composite materials have been announced today and East Midlands Development Agency (emda) is urging companies to take advantage of the increasing range of opportunities in this growing sector.

item.title: Lightweight HTS turbine generators to transform wind energy sector
item.description: Two firms will test a new technology that could revolutionize the wind energy sector by reducing the weight of turbine generators. Trials of the first High Temperature Superconductor (HTS) generators will start in 2010 when the technology will be installed at a hydro-electric power plant in Germany.

item.title: UK power market needs radical reform: utilities
item.description: Britain's power market must be radically redesigned to spur hundreds of billions of pounds of investment in low-carbon technologies needed to fight climate change and keep the lights on, the heads of two UK utilities said on Wednesday.

item.title: Wind-power project fuels divisive debate among Haida
item.description: Band governing body's role in $2-billion windmill farm stirs controversy over potential environmental risks to ancestral landmark. A spit of land that native legend says is the birthplace of human life on earth is at the heart of a debate that has divided the Haida Nation.

item.title: Obama asked to delay wind farm decision
item.description: With a decision possibly looming in the weeks ahead, the proposal to build the country's first offshore wind farm in Nantucket Sound could face another delay. Earlier this month, U.S. Sen. Paul Kirk, temporarily filling the seat held by the late Edward M. Kennedy, sent a letter to President Obama urging that any decision on the proposed 130 turbine wind farm in Nantucket Sound be delayed until a national policy on ocean management and planning is in place.

item.title: Framework Deal for Repower Wind Turbines Signed
item.description: It was announced this week that German wind turbine manufacturer Repower signed a deal with French utility EDF for the supply of wind turbines for five wind farms in Canada. The framework agreement is for the supply of turbines totalling a capacity of 954 Megawatts for wind farms in Quebec, developed by Saint-Laurent Energies, a company part owned by EDF.

item.title: Mechanical glitches plague offshore wind farm
item.description: A multi-million pound wind farm built off the Kent coast to provide energy for 100,000 homes has suffered repeated mechanical problems in the four years since it was built. The Kentish Flats Offshore Wind Farm, which provides power to houses in Whitstable, Herne Bay and Canterbury, has undergone numerous upgrades to try and deal with setbacks that have caused a reduction in the amount of energy produced.

item.title: Siemens snags euro600m worth of wind turbine orders from US and Canada deals
item.description: Siemens Energy has been awarded six wind turbine orders in North America, which represent more than 5 65 MW and a value of more than euro600m ($900m), according to a company statement. Of the approximately 250 turbines, every fourth unit is destined for Ontario, Canada, with the remainder to be installed in the US - in the western states of California and Washington, and the states of Oklahoma and Wyoming.

item.title: Patrick, Kirk at odds over wind farm
item.description: The administration of Governor Deval Patrick, in a sharp disagreement with Patrick’s handpicked Senate appointee, said yesterday that it would be a mistake for President Obama to grant US Senator Paul G. Kirk Jr.’s request to delay federal approval of the Cape Wind project.

item.title: Synthetics Get More Work Out of Wind Turbines
item.description: Wind turbine nacelles are challenging environments for drivetrains. Input forces (wind captured by blades) can vary ±20% in the span of just three seconds. Unstable drivetrain foundations generate misalignments and additional stress. And the moisture levels and temperatures extremes outdoors are generally worse than in factories.

item.title: Daewoo Shipbuilding considers China wind power plant
item.description: South Korea's Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, the world's second-biggest shipbuilder, said on Friday that it was considering building a wind power equipment plant in China.

item.title: RI gov to speak about offshore wind power plans
item.description: Gov. Don Carcieri will offer industry leaders an update Thursday on his plans to build a massive wind farm off Rhode Island's coast capable of providing 15 percent of the state's electricity needs.

item.title: CanWEA Attracts Top OEMs
item.description: Officials for the Canadian Wind Energy Association (CanWEA) Annual Conference and Exhibition in Toronto say they sold out all 350-booth spaces to 235 exhibitors at the September event. The attendee count topped 2,000. What’s more, the conference drew ten utility and commercial wind turbine OEMs, a list that includes Acciona, Enercon, GE, Mitsubishi, Northern Power, and Siemens.

item.title: Günther Oettinger named as new Energy Commissioner
item.description: José Manuel Barroso, President of the European Commission, today unveiled his team of Commissioners for his second term at the helm of the European Commission. The new Energy Commissioner will be Günther Oettinger, current Minister-President of Baden-Württemberg in Germany.

item.title: Windfarm contract for Ruthin company
item.description: A RUTHIN firm has begun work on a controversial offshore wind farm project. RWE npower renewables has signed a deal with civil engineers Jones Bros Ltd to carry out key preparatory works related to Gwynt y Mor Offshore wind farm, based near Llandudno.

item.title: Tax dollars blow away in wind projects
item.description: When Gov. Ted Kulongoski vetoed a bill this summer that would have slashed Oregon's tax subsidies for large wind farms, he insisted the reduction went too far and would jeopardize the growth of Oregon's green economy. But during the past eight years, while the state has taken applications for $300 million in tax breaks to subsidize the development of the windiest, most transmission-accessible sites, it has yet to do any substantive analysis of how big a subsidy is necessary -- if any -- to continue attracting investments.

item.title: New pricing models will save millions in offshore wind
item.description: New measurements and Danish engineering stubbornness led to significant reductions of loads on wind turbine towers and foundations. When a new IEC standard for the calculation of steel foundations for wind turbines is due this spring, a bunch of engineers at Dong Energy can be proud.

item.title: ServusNet brings intelligence into wind farm management
item.description: Capability built with Nokia Siemens Networks software suite. Irish software company, ServusNet, is using Nokia Siemens Networks to help provide its management solution for wind farms. The operations and maintenance system aims to help wind farm operators boost productivity while simplifying the delivery of energy onto power grids. ServusNet is currently trialing the solution with a customer.

item.title: Wind sector welcomes Oettinger as EU energy chief
item.description: The European Wind Energy Asssociation (EWEA) cautiously welcomed the nomination of Günther Oettinger as the EU’s new energy commissioner. Commission president José Manuel Barroso unveiled his team for his second term on 27 November.

item.title: Public Service Commission adds new wind farm study to list
item.description: Developers of the proposed Galloo Island, Horse Creek and Cape Vincent wind farms have one more study to add to their lists after an order from the Public Service Commission. Under the PSC's order, dated Oct. 20, all renewable energy projects built at 80 megawatts or more in capacity must conduct the "energy deliverability" study.

item.title: New York solicits offshore wind proposals in Great Lakes
item.description: In what it’s calling a first, the New York Power Authority (NYPA) is seeking proposals for an offshore wind project of 120 megawatts (MW) to 500MW to be developed in state waters of Lake Erie or Lake Ontario.

item.title: Large wind blade test facility breaks ground
item.description: The Department of Energy (DOE) and the state of Massachusetts broke ground on a $40 million facility to test large wind turbine blades. The project is also supported by $25 million in funding from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act and $13 million from the state of Massachusetts.

item.title: Günther Oettinger named as new European Energy Commissioner
item.description: José Manuel Barroso, President of the European Commission, has unveiled his team of Commissioners for his second term at the helm of the European Commission. The new Energy Commissioner will be Günther Oettinger, current Minister-President of Baden-Württemberg in Germany.

item.title: EWEA President to become CEO of Greece’s biggest power company
item.description: Professor Arthouros Zervos, President of the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA), is to be appointed President and CEO of Greece’s Public Power Corp (PPC), the country’s biggest power company.

item.title: Korea Electric Power to develop core HVDC technologies
item.description: Korea Electric Power Corp. (KEPCO), South Korea's state power company, said Monday it will join forces with three local companies to develop core technologies for a high-end electric power transmission system.

item.title: Denmark launches new research platform for intelligent electricity systems
item.description: A consortium has started the first phase of PowerLabDK, an experimental platform for electric power and energy with a budget of DKK 131m

item.title: Landmark as offshore wind farm is officially opened
item.description: Wales' largest wind farm - the Rhyl Flats off the coast of north Wales - is to be opened officially by Welsh Secretary Peter Hain in Llandudno later. The off shore wind farm is expected to be fully operational by the end of the month. BBC Wales' environment correspondent Iolo ap Dafydd visits the site as it prepares to generate power.

item.title: RWE Innogy opens biggest offshore wind farm in Wales
item.description: The Right Honourable Peter Hain, the UK’s Secretary of State for Wales, together with Dr. Juergen Grossmann, Chief Executive Officer of RWE AG, officially opened Rhyl Flats Offshore Wind Farm in North Wales today.

item.title: SPT Offshore / Wood Group Gains Carbon Trust Contract
item.description: Carbon Trust has awarded a contract to SPT Offshore / Wood Group for performing a concept study on the basis of SPT's self installing wind turbine (SIWT) concept. The Carbon Trust is a UK initiative to develop innovative foundations for the UK’s third round of offshore wind farms in water depths varying from 30m to 60m. The Carbon Trust is supported by major utility companies, such as RWE, Dong, Scottish Power, StatoilHydro and Airtricity.

item.title: Dutch wind farm developments: Joint venture
item.description: Scottish and Southern Energy plc ("SSE") has entered into an agreement with DONG Energy to form a 50:50 joint venture to take forward the development of three offshore wind farms, with a total capacity of just over 1,000MW (megawatts), which SSE has the right to develop in the Dutch sector of the North Sea. The consented projects are: Den Helder I, Breeveertien II and West Rijn wind farms.

item.title: Wind industry urges more speed on recovery plan funding
item.description: Today, as European Energy Commissioner Andris Piebalgs speaks to the European Parliament’s Industry, Research & Energy (ITRE) Committee on the European Economic Recovery Plan, EWEA warned that the EU needs to speed up its stimulus package. The €5 billion plan, approved by the European Parliament last May, includes €565 million for offshore wind projects and additional funds for upgrading and building new electricity grids, but the EU’s slow legislative procedures have prevented a timely release of the funds.

item.title: STATEMENT BY THE AMERICAN WIND ENERGY ASSOCIATION ON NYPA FRESH WATER OFFSHORE RFP
item.description: Today the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) issued the following statement by Peter Mandelstam, Chairman of AWEA’s Offshore Wind Power Working Group, welcoming the announcement by the New York Power Authority (NYPA) of the world’s first fresh water wind power request for proposals (RFP) for up to 500 MW in Lake Erie and Lake Ontario:

item.title: National Grid in talks to buy power from Cape Wind
item.description: National Grid Plc (NG.L) and Cape Wind agreed to enter into negotiations for a long-term contract to buy power generated by the proposed Cape Wind offshore wind farm in Massachusetts, the state's governor, Deval Patrick, said in a release Wednesday.

item.title: Two more windfarm platform topsides for Heerema Hartlepool
item.description: Heerema Hartlepool, one of the fabrication locations of Heerema Fabrication Group (HFG), has been awarded a contract to fabricate and load out two substation platform topsides for the Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm by AREVA T&D UK Ltd on behalf of owners Statoil (formerly StatoilHydro) and Statkraft.

item.title: Offshore Wind Energy Newscatalyst now exceeds 100 windfarms worldwide
item.description: Aalund NetSearch A/S, the Copenhagen based market intelligence pioneer, today announced that the Offshore Wind Energy Newscatalyst now includes more than 100 windfarm projects worldwide.

item.title: Longyuan Said to Raise $2.3 Billion in Wind Power IPO
item.description: China Longyuan Power Group Corp., the nation’s largest wind-power producer, raised HK$17.5 billion ($2.26 billion) in the world’s third-biggest initial public offering by an alternative energy company.

item.title: Daewoo wins $300m order
item.description: DAEWOO has won an order worth $300m for two support vessels for the construction of offshore power generation capacity, according to reports from South Korea.

item.title: Conference opens on future of offshore wind turbines
item.description: The challenges facing the creation of an offshore wind industry in the United States are daunting, speakers at a national conference said Wednesday. Those logistical challenges include an absence of shipping ports ready to be used as staging facilities, a lack of a supply chain for offshore wind turbines that are only manufactured in Europe and the need to train workers in the installation, operation and maintenance of the turbines.

item.title: Offshore wind farm plan scrapped
item.description: Plans for a wind farm in the Bristol Channel have been scrapped, say the developers. Work on 30 turbines, each 400ft (121.9m) tall, at Scarweather Sands off Porthcawl, had been expected to start this year.

item.title: Competition moves offshore wind into deeper waters
item.description: Seven new design ideas for offshore wind turbine foundations have been shortlisted by the UK’s Carbon Trust in a competition aimed at transforming the offshore wind industry. It comes at a time when the industry faces the challenge of controlling the costs of wind farms as they move into deeper waters in meeting the EU target of supplying 20% of its energy from renewable sources by 2020, a figure that will see an estimated 6,000 wind turbines in operation.

item.title: Technocean signs co-operation agreement with Troll WindPower
item.description: Fearnley Offshore Supply reports that Technocean and Troll WindPower have signed a co-operation agreement which strengthens their combined ability to compete in the growing market for offshore wind farm development.

item.title: Innovative Mechanism Improves Off-Shore Wind Turbines’ Safety
item.description: Markus Mueller and Alasdair McDonald of the University of Edinburgh solved one of the fundamental engineering issues faced by builders of offshore wind turbines. They developed a new electric generator that is much cheaper, lighter and reliable than anything seen up to now in the industry.

item.title: £84M WINDFALL FROM TURBINES
item.description: EFFORTS to increase the financial trickle down of Welsh wind power have culminated in the founding of Vestri, a new not-for-profit company that aims to distribute a multi-million pound bonanza in rural Wales.

item.title: £500 each for tide and wind power
item.description: Households will be paying £500 a year to subsidise wind turbines and tidal power stations by 2025, the energy regulator warned yesterday. Almost a third of the average domestic fuel bill will be siphoned off to fund the construction of renewable energy sources and other Government green initiatives, according to Ofgem chief executive Alistair Buchanan.

item.title: A giant wind farm is planned off the North Wales coast
item.description: THE largest offshore renewable energy power station in Wales was officially opened at a ceremony in Llandudno yesterday, as it emerged a much bigger wind farm could be sited further out into the Irish Sea. The Rhyl Flats offshore wind farm, which has cost £220m to build five miles off the North Wales coast, will generate 90MW (megawatts) from its 25 turbines – equal to the electricity needs of more than 60,000 households.

item.title: Invenergy Chooses SmartSignal to Protect Wind Turbines Fleetwide
item.description: SmartSignal® Corporation today announced that it has been selected by Invenergy to install SmartSignal EPI*Center® predictive diagnostic software to protect Invenergy’s GE wind turbines across its entire U.S. fleet. SmartSignal will be monitoring all 975 GE 1.5 MW turbines at 14 Invenergy wind generation projects. The agreement calls for SmartSignal to deploy, maintain, and provide support services for EPI*Center, which will be hosted by Invenergy.

item.title: Trimming the Costs of Wind Power
item.description: As governments, businesses and environmentalists from around the world gather for the United Nations climate change summit meeting that begins today in Copenhagen, one of the featured attractions will be the array of windmills just off Denmark’s coast.

item.title: Global Offshore Wind Market Investment and Opportunities
item.description: Bharatbook.com added a new report on "Global Offshore Wind Market Analysis and Forecasts to 2015" which gives Detailed analysis of the offshore market globally.

item.title: Siemens, 64 MW Wind Farm in New Zealand
item.description: Siemens and Meridian Energy have signed an order for the supply of 28 SWT-2.3-101 wind turbines for the Te Uku wind power project. The Te Uku project will see the first installation of the new Siemens SWT-2.3-101 wind turbines in the Asia-Pacific region. With a diameter of 101 meters, the rotor of the new SWT-2.3-101 has a swept area of 8000 square meters. The new turbine is based on the design of the widely deployed 2.3 MW family.

item.title: enXco Signs Turbine Order with REpower
item.description: enXco, an EDF Energies Nouvelles Company (PARIS: EEN), has signed a delivery agreement with condition precedent with German turbine manufacturer REpower for up to 143.5 megawatts. The 70 REpower MM92 turbines, each with a rated capacity of 2.05 MW, are slated for delivery in 2011.

item.title: DSME wins order for offshore wind farm planter
item.description: RWE Innogy, a unit of German power utility RWE AG, has awarded Korean shipyard Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co., Ltd, (DSME) a contract to build a specialist ship for the construction of offshore wind farms. The contract also includes the option for two further identical construction ships. The value of the contract for each ship is around Euro 100 million. The first ship should be completed in 2011.

item.title: Seize the breeze: Carcieri urges speed in development of offshore wind projects
item.description: Governor Carcieri is urging an acceleration in the development of the nation’s offshore wind resources. In a speech Thursday at a national wind-industry conference, he said that for too long the focus in the United States has been on land-based wind power in the Midwest and not on the potentially vast wind resources off the East Coast.

item.title: No Norwegian offshore wind before 2012
item.description: Britian is in their third round of building offshore windfarms. But Norway's first building permit is first coming in 2012. Meanwhile investment are leaking into the UK continental shelf.

item.title: UK in commitment to offshore grid
item.description: The UK has signed up with eight other European countries to develop an offshore wind electricity grid spanning the North and Irish seas. The Government also announced three companies would receive a share of £5 million in grants for offshore wind technology research, including £1.75 million to turbine manufacturer Vestas.

item.title: NIB finances wind turbines in Denmark
item.description: NIB and Danish Ringkjøbing Landbobank are launching a new DKK 75 million (EUR 10 million) environmental loan programme for financing wind turbine projects in Denmark.

item.title: Copenhagen Failure Defied by $200 Billion in Green Investments
item.description: Renewable-energy investment may climb to a record $200 billion worldwide next year as companies from Hong Kong’s CLP Holdings Ltd. to American Electric Power Co. start projects that don’t depend on a new climate-change treaty.

item.title: Repower Expects Wind Turbine Orders to Rise in 2010, CEO Says
item.description: Repower Systems AG, the German unit of India’s Suzlon Energy Ltd., expects wind-turbine orders to rise next year as climate-change talks in Copenhagen may increase demand for renewable energy.

item.title: New York launches call for offshore wind power on Great Lakes
item.description: The New York Power Authority (NYPA) has launched a call for proposals for offshore wind power projects in the state-owned waters of Lakes Erie and Ontario. By March 20, 2010, the NYPA wants to receive proposals for offshore wind farms from 120 MW up to 500 MW. The organisation expects to announce the winning project or projects by December next year.

item.title: Canada Reaches Milestone, As Wind Energy Is Now Produced In Every Province
item.description: Canada has achieved a new milestone, as wind-generated electricity is now being produced in every province with the recent opening of Bear Mountain Wind Park, located near Dawson Creek, British Columbia. This new wind development has also increased Canada's total wind energy capacity to more than 3,100 MW.

item.title: USA remains most attractive country for renewable energy
item.description: The United States remains the most attractive country overall for renewable energy, but China has moved ahead of Germany to take second spot in the rankings released by Ernst & Young.

item.title: Vestas to Temporarily Halt Output at Colorado Plant
item.description: Vestas Wind Systems A/S, the world’s biggest maker of wind turbines, said it will halt production at its Windsor, Colorado, blade manufacturing plant until at least the second quarter of 2010.

item.title: Chinese wind power firms target foreign markets
item.description: China's Goldwind Science&Technology Ltd. is one of the world's biggest makers of wind turbines – a cornerstone of the booming clean power business – but is virtually unknown outside its home country. Goldwind aims to change that. In a Minnesota farmer's cornfield, the company is erecting three 20-storey-tall windmills in its first American project and hopes it will help to woo other buyers.

item.title: Clipper Awarded £2.5 Million DECC Funding For Mega-Sized Offshore Wind Gearboxes
item.description: Clipper Windpower Plc (“Clipper”) today announced that its subsidiary, Clipper Windpower Marine Limited, has received a grant of GBP 2.5 million from the Department of Energy and Climate Change (“DECC”) for the manufacture of gearboxes for Project Britannia, a 10 MW offshore wind turbine currently under development by Clipper. Under the terms of the grant, David Brown Gear Systems (“David Brown”) is named as supplier of the prototype gearboxes.

item.title: The Gearbox Standard for Windturbines gets an Upgrade
item.description: The recently drafted ISO/IEC standard for wind-turbine gearboxes is significant for many reasons. First, several organizations collaborated to produce ANSI/AGMA/AWEA 6006-A03, which was adopted without change in 2005 as ISO 81400-4, an international standard. The new draft (IEC project 61400-4), expands on preceding standards so it is more encompassing. It provides a conduit through which manufacturers and users can specify and evaluate products. The new IEC standard is a bit overdue, but may have been worthy of the wait.

item.title: National Grid negotiating PPA with offshore Cape Wind
item.description: The frontrunner to become America’s first offshore wind project, Cape Wind, is in negotiations to sell its output to utility National Grid, according to Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick.

item.title: Test license in place for Vestavind power
item.description: NVE (Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate) has given Vestavind Kraft AS permission for a test facility for floating wind farm off the Selje and Vågsøy in Sogn og Fjordane.

item.title: Doosan Heavy Sees Wind-Power Operating Profit in 2011
item.description:
Doosan Heavy Industries & Construction Co. expects its wind-power equipment division to make an operating profit in 2011, the first full year of sales, as climate concerns spur alternative-energy demand.
South Korea’s biggest power-equipment maker intends to build as many as 70 wind-power units a year, Senior Vice President Choe Seung Joo said in an interview yesterday at the company’s research center in Daejeon, south of Seoul. He didn’t give a precise profit forecast.

item.title: Siemens looks to offshore, Asia to gain top three spot
item.description: Siemens says it is on course to become one of the top three wind turbine suppliers by 2012, with much of its growth coming from the offshore market and the Asia-Pacific region

item.title: National Grid in offshore Rhode Island power purchase deal
item.description: National Grid has reached a 20 year agreement with developer Deepwater Wind to purchase power from a proposed eight-turbine demonstration wind farm offshore Rhode Island in the Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: New £15m Wind Turbine Test Facility Planned for Blyth, UK
item.description:
A new wind turbine blade test facility is planned for Blyth in the north east of England it was announced by R& D company Nirec today.
The £15 million ($24m) facility will test new turbine blade designs before they are used in offshore wind farms. The wind turbine blades to be tested will be up to 100 metres in length.
Narec are providers of R&D, consultancy, test and demonstration facilities for the renewable energy sector. The blade test centre will be the biggest of its type in the world, expanding the existing testing capability developed over the last five years at Blyth.

item.title: Green energy projects win £100m
item.description:
Two Scottish offshore renewable energy projects have had more than £100m of EU funding confirmed.
The EU energy commissioner confirmed a grant of 40 million euros (£36m) for Aberdeen's proposed offshore wind farm.
While a further 74 million euros (£67m) has also been approved for an offshore platform between Shetland and the Scottish mainland.
The platform will form part of the North Sea Grid, which will connect wind farms in eight European countries.

item.title: Excellent performance Prinses
item.description: In the month November the Princess Amalia wind farm, off the coast of IJmuiden, achieved a record performance. The largest Dutch offshore wind farm produced more power in this month than in all previous months since its existence.

item.title: New technology reduces wear and raises output from wind turbines
item.description: Danish industrial concern NKT's subsidiary NKT Photonics has successfully tested a laser-based technology that can significantly reduce wear on wind turbines and also improve output by at least 5%

item.title: Trumbull firm looks for offshore wind
item.description: Trumbull-based Ocean and Coastal Consultants Inc. will be managing a South Carolina project to investigate whether winds off the Atlantic Ocean can support a wind farm there.

item.title: Brussels grants 1.5 billion euros to clean energy projects
item.description: The European Union's executive on Wednesday granted over 1.5 billion euros (2.2 billion dollars) in aid to 15 experimental clean energy projects. The decision is part of a package of measures designed to fight the European recession and combat global warming by boosting investment into clean coal-fired power stations, offshore wind generators and international energy links.

item.title: United Technologies Corp. To Invest in Clipper Windpower
item.description:
United Technologies Corp. (NYSE: UTX) today announced it has agreed to acquire a 49.5 percent stake in Clipper Windpower Plc (CWP.L), a California-based wind turbine manufacturer that trades on the AIM London Stock Exchange.
UTC's total investment will be 166 million pounds sterling (approximately $270 million) to purchase a combination of 84.3 million newly issued shares and 21.8 million shares from existing shareowners. The investment has been approved by the boards of directors of both UTC and Clipper Windpower, and closing is pending Clipper Windpower shareholder and regulatory approval.

item.title: List of 15 energy projects for European economic recovery
item.description: The Commission approved today 15 energy projects which will significantly contribute to the economic recovery of the EU. This decision grants €1 billion to six CO2 capture and storage projects and €565 million to nine offshore wind energy projects.

item.title: Deepwater Wind to build first U.S. ocean wind farm
item.description: The tiniest state in the nation may build the first U.S. offshore wind farm, after privately held Deepwater Wind on Thursday landed a deal to sell power from the first phase of a Rhode Island project that eventually could supply 15 percent of the state's electricity.

item.title: Danes, South Africans team up to develop Eastern Cape wind farm
item.description: A memorandum of understanding has been signed at Wittekleibosch, in the Eastern Cape, between partners hoping to develop the Tsitsikamma Community Wind Farm (TCWF) project, which aims at generating 40 MW of wind power by 2013, and will be worth about R1-billion.

item.title: Increasing sums going into green technology
item.description: Since the environmental protection industry offers attractive returns, private investors are also putting more and more money into green technology. Georg Meck, of Deutschland Online, says: “Environmental technology will be the leading industry of the twenty-first century.” He adds that consultants have analysed the industry prospects and surveyed 1 300 companies and 200 research institutions on the subject

item.title: Offshore Northeast green energy projects win £100 million
item.description: Two Scottish offshore renewable energy projects have had more than £100m of EU funding confirmed. The EU energy commissioner confirmed a grant of 40 million euros (£36m) for Aberdeen's proposed offshore wind farm. While a further 74 million euros (£67m) has also been approved for an offshore platform between Shetland and the Scottish mainland.

item.title: Chinese Windmills and the Little Mermaid in Copenhagen
item.description: Copenhagen, besides being the home to COP15, is also famous for its association with the fairytale author Hans Christian Andersen, who famously wrote "The Little Mermaid." As with the story of ‘The Little Mermaid,’ it had previously been assumed that renewable energy projects were popular. The issue at stake is tariffs. The EB suspects, but admits it has no evidence either way, that wind tariffs may have been set at a level that relied on the CDM to make them profitable.

item.title: Copenhagen climate summit: Businesses 'squeezed out' of treaty discussions
item.description: World leaders have harmed the credibility of the Copenhagen climate treaty amongst the financial community by squeezing business groups out of the summit, according to the Business Council for Sustainable Energy.

item.title: Lawrence R. Kunkel: Offshore wind offers new hope for R.I. economy
item.description: Thomas E. Gebhard argues in his Nov. 28 column, “Rhode Island’s renewable-energy suicide,” that Rhode Island leaders are committing “renewable-energy suicide” by supporting Deepwater Wind’s plans for two offshore wind farms. In fact, the opposite is true. [Deepwater struck a deal with National Grid last week in which the latter agreed to buy electricity from Deepwater, whose initial plans involve putting eight turbines off Rhode Island.]

item.title: Centrica Powers Up for Copenhagen
item.description: Power companies don't usually argue for aggressive cuts in the world's carbon emissions. Centrica PLC, the U.K.'s biggest energy supplier, is a rare exception. Sam Laidlaw, Centrica's chief executive officer, says at Copenhagen the European Union should pledge to cut heat-trapping CO2 emissions by 30% by 2020, not the planned 20%.

item.title: Nexans wins cable deal for wind farm
item.description: Nexans (NEXS.PA) has won a contract worth 100 million euros (90 million pounds) to supply subsea power cables for the world's largest offshore wind-farm project that is being developed in the UK, the cable group said.

item.title: Vattenfall targets further five wind farms in Scotland by 2012
item.description: VATTENFALL, Europe's fifth largest energy group, wants to have a further five onshore wind farms operating in Scotland within the next three years as part of its plans to become "climate-neutral" by 2050. The Swedish company's strategy includes using a mixture of renewable energy – from wind and wave sources – alongside nuclear power and "clean" coal and gas-fired power stations, fitted with carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, to reach its target.

item.title: Deepwater Wind to build first U.S. ocean wind farm
item.description: The tiniest state in the nation may build the first U.S. offshore wind farm, after privately held Deepwater Wind on Thursday landed a deal to sell power from the first phase of a Rhode Island project that eventually could supply 15 percent of the state's electricity.

item.title: Siemens attacks Enercon's monopoly
item.description: Enercon will soon cease to be the only large manufacturer able to supply gearbox-less wind turbines. Siemens has recently erected the prototype of its SWT-3.0-101 DD in the Danish town of Brande. The somewhat complicated type designation of the prototype specifies its most important characteristics: a capacity of 3 MW, a rotor diameter of 101 m and the most important feature, the gearless direct drive (DD).

item.title: £122m wind plan ready to blow in to revitalise beleaguered Nigg Yard
item.description: 2,000 jobs may be created in Easter Ross as US site owner considers renewables proposal The US owner of the Nigg Yard in Easter Ross will this week consider $200 million (£122m) proposals for a major move into offshore wind manufacturing that would restore its glory days by creating at least 2,000 jobs.

item.title: Offshore wind as Europe's largest untapped energy source
item.description: The €565 million investment in nine offshore wind energy projects and infrastructure – approved by the European Commission as part of its European Economic Recovery Plan - shows that the European Union sees the offshore wind industry as a strategic sector for Europe's future, said the European Wind Energy Association (EWEA).

item.title: Narec builds offshore wind turbine blade test facility
item.description: The UK New and Renewable Energy Centre (Narec) will build a £15 million facility for testing offshore wind turbine blades of up to 100 m in length. The offshore wind turbine blade testing facility will provide “an independent and confidential environment to accelerate the development of new blade designs before they are taken offshore,” according to Narec.

item.title: Robin Rigg windfarm work delayed by weather
item.description: Completion of the Robin Rigg windfarm off the coast of Maryport was delayed by at least a month by the devastating weather in recent weeks. Workers could not reach their headquarters at the Port of Workington for three weeks because of bridges down and the amount of debris in the harbour.

item.title: Offshore Wind Energy NewsCatalyst Exclusively Covers Offshore Wind Issues from COP15 UN Climate Change Conference 2009 in Copenhagen
item.description: Aalund NetSearch A/S, the Copenhagen based market intelligence pioneer, welcomes the COP15 United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009 and includes unique focus on conference related issues.

item.title: Goldman Sachs selling German Nordex stake -sources
item.description: Goldman Sachs (GS.N: Quote, Profile, Research) is selling its stake in German wind turbine maker Nordex (NDXGk.DE: Quote, Profile, Research), two people familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday. Goldman will sell almost all of its 14 percent stake except for a few shares, the sources said on Monday, adding that the package was likely to be sold to an investor.

item.title: E.ON, DONG, Masdar sign London Array wind deal
item.description: Germany's E.ON (EONGn.DE) Denmark's state-owned group DONG Energy [DONG.UL] and Masdar said on Monday they had signed contracts worth nearly 2 billion euros for work on London Array offshore wind project. Masdar is an Abu Dhabi green energy investment firm.

item.title: First turbine erected at Thanet offshore wind farm
item.description: European energy company Vattenfall has erected the first of 100 Vestas V90 turbines at the 300MW Thanet offshore wind farm off the Kent coast. Vattenfall finished the erection of the turbine last Wednesday (December 9) at dawn.

item.title: Siemens open wind power research centre at University
item.description: Siemens Energy opened a unique centre at the University of Sheffield today, which has been developed to look at wind power generation (14 December 2009). The pioneering Sheffield-Siemens Wind Power Research Centre (S²WP), located at the Kroto Innovation Centre, Broad Lane, Sheffield, is expected to employ an estimated 20 people and will focus on developing the most reliable, innovative and efficient wind turbine generators that will be at the forefront of future onshore and offshore wind power systems.

item.title: Tanti Says Suzlon to Seal $2.8 Billion in Refinancing
item.description: Suzlon Energy Ltd, India’s biggest maker of wind-turbine generators, plans to complete $2.8 billion of refinancing by the end of January, Chairman Tulsi Tanti said. Suzlon is consolidating its short and long-term loans, working capital and other borrowings into a single loan that’s already been agreed by State Bank of India and IDBI Bank Ltd., the lead banks in the deal, the billionaire said in an interview.

item.title: REpower wins 30 MW contract with E.ON
item.description: REpower UK has won its second major contract with E.ON Climate and Renewables in the UK. The sites located at Butterwick Moor and Haswell Moor will consist of 15 turbines, specification MM82 with a rated power of 2,050 kW each. Together, they will produce 30.75 MW of clean power, enough energy for 17,000 homes.

item.title: London Array: Siemens to provide grid access for world’s largest offshore wind farm
item.description: Siemens Energy received the order to connect the London Array offshore wind farm to the power supply network. The order volume is EUR128 million. Purchasers are Dong Energy, E.ON and Masdar, the wind farm’s owners. Siemens Energy was already appointed to supply the 175 wind turbines for the wind farm as well. With a total capacity of 630 megawatts (MW) the London Array offshore wind farm will follow completion in 2012 and be the largest of its kind in the world.

item.title: JDR Cable Systems to provide subsea cables for London Array offshore wind farm
item.description: JDR Cable Systems, a global provider of subsea power cables, offshore umbilical systems and specialised marine cables, has been awarded the contract for the supply of subsea power array cables for the first phase of London Array Offshore Wind Farm by the project consortium of DONG Energy, E.ON and Masdar.

item.title: SPI wind farm looks years away at the earliest
item.description: So far, talk of wind farms off South Padre Island has been just that: wind. However, giant turbines offshore may be closer to reality now that the state has awarded leases to two companies studying their feasibility along the Texas coast. One is Baryonyx Corporation, which in July signed a contract with the Texas General Land Office to lease 8,000 onshore acres in Dallam County in the Texas panhandle and 38,000 acres off South Padre Island and Mustang Island.

item.title: Wind turbines everywhere at the summit
item.description: There are wind turbines everywhere at the climate summit - real ones and images that have become a symbol of how to combat climate change. The Presidents and Prime Ministers coming to the talks later in the week will enter next to a working turbine, 75 metres tall, plugged into the Danish electricity grid. At the main entrance to the negotiations there's a wind turbine blade - a huge 61 metre blade of the kind installed in offshore wind farms.

item.title: Denmark - AWEA heads to Copenhagen to share wind power message
item.description: Delegation sent to the United Nations Climate Change Conference of the Parties (COP15). AWEA is sending a delegation to the United Nations Climate Change Conference of the Parties (COP15), currently underway in Copenhagen, Denmark. Led by AWEA CEO Denise Bode, the group also includes COO Britt Theismann, Senior Vice President of Public Policy Rob Gramlich, and Vice President of Public Affairs Sarah Howell, among others.

item.title: NaiKun Wind Receives Environmental Approval
item.description: NaiKun Wind Energy Group Inc. has been granted a provincial Environmental Assessment Certificate from the British Columbia Environmental Assessment Office (EAO) for its 396-megawatt (MW) offshore wind energy project in northwest British Columbia. This paves the way for construction of the project, which would be Canada's first offshore wind energy installation.

item.title: US Interior Secretary visits offshore wind farm during COP15 participation
item.description: The Global Wind Energy Council was pleased to host US Secretary of the Interior Mr. Ken Salazar on a tour of the Middelgrunden offshore wind energy farm just outside of Copenhagen this afternoon, along with representatives of the Danish Wind Industry Association, Vestas, DONG and Siemens. Secretary Salazar has been a strong proponent of exploiting the vast potential for offshore wind generation off the US East Coast, in pursuit of President Obama’s “25% by 2025” initiative.

item.title: US reveals funds for green tech in poor nations, $350 million international effort
item.description: The White House on Monday announced a new program drawing funds from international partners to spend $350 million over five years to supply developing nations with clean energy technology to curb greenhouse gas emissions and reduce global warming.

item.title: Wind industry gears up for high level participation in Copenhagen climate talks
item.description: As international climate negotiations kick off in the Danish capital today, the Global Wind Energy Council (GWEC) has called on governments to agree a legally binding framework for emissions reductions out to 2020. More than 350 wind industry participants have confirmed their participation, including the CEOs of some of the world’s leading wind turbine manufacturers, wind farm operators and developers.

item.title: Offshore Wind Makes Sense for China
item.description: One of the thorniest issues that should be addressed at the COP 15 conference in Copenhagen is how large developing nations such as China can continue to grow their economies without producing catastrophic levels of carbon emissions.

item.title: Siemens installs prototype of three-megawatt direct drive wind turbine
item.description: The new SWT-3.0-101 DD is a gearless machine with a power rating of three megawatts (MW). It has a rotor diameter of 101 meters. The prototype was installed close to the Danish town of Brande, where Siemens Wind Power headquarters is located. Direct drive wind turbines offer a smart, straightforward design that makes the use of gearboxes dispensable.

item.title: New wind in the sails of UK and US
item.description: New wind farms are moving ahead on both sides of the Atlantic. ScottishPower Renewables has been given consent to expand the Whitelee Windfarm near Glasgow in Scotland, which is already Europe’s largest onshore wind farm.

item.title: What Do Wind Power Chiefs Want In Copenhagen?
item.description: A UN climate summit this week in Copenhagen needs to agree a deal that offers clarity for the prospects of wind energy if it is to mobilise investment in the industry, the heads of four leading wind energy companies said.

item.title: Siemens Seek to Become Leading Provider of Wind Turbines
item.description: Siemens has confirmed its objective to become one of the world’s top providers of wind turbines. Siemens entered the wind power market five years ago with its acquisition of Denmark’s Bonus Energy. Since then, wind power operations at Siemens have undergone rapid development.

item.title: Vattenfall divests minority share in Borkum Riffgrund 1
item.description: Vattenfall has decided to divest its minority share in the Borkum Riffgrund 1 Offshore Wind Project to Dong Energy. The offshore wind project has up until now been jointly owned by Plambeck Neue Energien, Dong and Vattenfall.

item.title: Copenhagen: Emphasis should be on action plan
item.description: According to the recent World Population report, 2009, in the last century the world population increased from 1.65b to 6b and is expected to surpass 9b by 2050. Since the invention of steam engine, humans have replaced muscle, wind, and water power with the profligate use of fossil fuel. The use of fossil fuels to meet ever increasing demand, coupled with the culture of conspicuous consumerism has exponentially increased greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. This has resulted in the depletion of natural resources, and transformation of the environment.

item.title: Mayor Bloomberg Covets Denmark's Huge Offshore Wind Farm, Dreams of a New York Version
item.description: As hundreds of delegates and reporters faced a crush at Copenhagen's Bella Center, which was packed to capacity at the start of the final week of climate talks, New York's Mayor Mike Bloomberg took off in a helicopter to survey the world's largest offshore wind farm, the 209 megawatt Horns Rev 2.

item.title: PRESENTATION OF ØRESUND'S WIND PROJECT AT COP15
item.description: The research project Wind in Øresund - collaboration between the Technical University of Denmark and the Faculty of Engineering at Lund's University – is presently presented to climate enthusiasts from all over the world at the COP15 meeting in Copenhagen.

item.title: Wind: AREVA Commissions First Offshore Project in Germany
item.description: AREVA (Paris:CEI), via its German subsidiary Multibrid, has successfully installed and commissioned the first six M5000 turbines for the Alpha Ventus project, the first German offshore wind park located in the North Sea, 45 kilometers off the island of Borkum. The group is creating a reference in the offshore wind industry with its 5 MW turbines specially designed for offshore conditions.

item.title: UK companies lose out on £1.8bn wind farm contracts
item.description: European suppliers are main winners at London Array. The £1.8bn major supply and installation contracts for the London Array wind farm have been signed - but less than 10% went to UK companies.

item.title: Deepwater Wind Signs PPA for First Offshore Wind Farm
item.description: Deepwater Wind and National Grid have signed a 20-year, power-purchase agreement for the electricity to be produced by the Block Island Wind Farm off the coast of Rhode Island.

item.title: COP15: New super efficient wind turbines to provide U.S. leadership
item.description: U.S. Energy Minister Stephen Chu unites aerospace, technology companies and energy sector in joint efforts to create new generation of ultra-compact and highly efficient wind turbines.

item.title: What "green" CEOs want from Copenhagen
item.description: Business leaders are watching Copenhagen climate talks, which might launch new, bigger carbon markets and help drive investment in green technologies. Following are views of chief executives of green and clean companies attending the conference.

item.title: IEA: Energy Revolution Required to Combat Climate Change
item.description: The International Energy Agency has analyzed exactly what it would take to limit greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Revolutionizing the energy industry to achieve a target concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere of no more than 450 parts per million (ppm) would require building 17 nuclear power plants a year between now and 2030; 17,000 wind turbines a year; or two hydropower dams on the scale of Three Gorges Dam in China, according to the International Energy Agency.

item.title: DONG acquires offshore wind turbine projects Borkum Riffgrund 1 and 2
item.description: DONG Energy and PNE Wind AG have agreed that DONG Energy will acquire PNE's 50% ownership interest in each of the two German offshore wind turbine projects Borkum Riffgrund 1 and 2. DONG Energy previously acquired Vattenfall AB's 49% ownership interest in Borkum Riffgrund 1 Holding, which owns 50% of Borkum Riffgrund 1.

item.title: French Wind Farm Tax Increase Would Be ‘Harmful,’ Union Says
item.description: A proposed increase in France’s tax on wind turbine installations is unfair and may slow planned expansion of the alternative energy, a trade organization said. The measure being considered by parliament is “discriminatory and harmful,” said the Union Francaise de l’Electricite, a group that represents power suppliers including Electricite de France SA, which controls renewable-energy company EDF Energies Nouvelles SA.
